Seen in right heart failure an d portal venous obstruction i n cirrhosis
Solution to Question 6:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of septic shock as a result of gram-negative sepsis originating from a urinary tract infection.
Gram-negative organisms contain lipopolysaccharide in the outer membrane, which triggers the release of cytokines, such as tumor necrosis factor (TNF). These cytokines cause a cascade of events culminating in increased capillary permeability and redistribution of circulatory volume into the interstitium. It is also known as warm shock, due to fever and increased perfusion.
Other types of shock are:
Anaphylactic shock - sudden circulatory collapse due to type I hypersensitivity reaction
Cardiogenic shock - ventricular failure, often following myocardial infarction; is a form of cold hock
Hypovolemic shock - due to blood or fluid lo
Solution to Question 7:
The first step of hemostasis is arteriolar vasoconstriction. The normal process of hemostasis is as follows:
Arteriolar vasoconstriction - After vascular injury, local neurohumoral factors induce transient vasoconstriction.
Primary hemostasis - The various steps involved in this process are:
Platelets bind via glycoprotein Ib (GpIb) receptors to von Willebrand factor (vWF) on exposed extracellular matrix (ECM)
Activation of platelets which undergo a change in shape and release their granule
Released adenosine diphosphate (ADP) and thromboxane A2 (TxA2) induce additional platelet aggregation through platelet GpIIb-IIIa receptor binding to fibrinogen
Formation of the primary platelet plug
Secondary hemostasis - Local activation of the coagulation cascade involving tissue factor and platelet phospholipids results in fibrin polymerization, cementing the platelets into a definitive econdary hemostatic plug.
Clot stabilization and resorption - Counter-regulatory mechanisms, mediated by tissue plasminogen activator (tPA, a fibrinolytic product) and thrombomodulin, confine the hemostatic process to the site of injury.
Solution to Question 8:
The tissue factor binds and activates factor VII.
Tissue factor is produced by the subendothelial cells in the vessel wall such as vascular smooth muscle cells and fibroblasts. It is a membrane-bound procoagulant glycoprotein.
Secondary hemostasis involves a sequence of events, which results in the polymerization of fibrin. This is achieved by cross-linking fibrin monomers into insoluble strands that serve to stabilize the loose platelet clot formed in primary hemostasis.


Solution to Question 9:
Serotonin is present in the dense or delta() granules of the platelets, not alpha() granules.
Platelets are disc-shaped, anucleate cell fragments that are released from the megakaryocytes in the bone marrow into the bloodstream. The functions of these platelets depend on
their glycoprotein receptors, contractile cytoskeleton, and cytoplasmic granules. There are two types of cytoplasmic granules present in platelets:
Alpha granule
Dense or delta granule
-granules contain:
Adhesion molecule P-selectin on their membrane
Proteins involved in coagulation like -
Fibrinogen
Coagulation factor V
vWF
Protein factors involved in wound healing like -
Fibronectin
Platelet factor 4 (a heparin-binding chemokine)
Platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF)
Transforming growth factor  (TGF  )
-granules contain:
Adenosine diphosphate (ADP) and adenosine triphosphate (ATP)
Ionized calcium
Serotonin
Epinephrine
Solution to Question 10:
A deficiency of vitamin K does not alter the function of factor V.
Vitamin K is required as a cofactor for the -carboxylation of factors II, VII, IX, and X. Calcium binds to -carboxylated glutamic acid residues that are present in these factors during clotting.
This action of vitamin K is antagonized by drugs such as warfarin, which is widely used as an anticoagulant.
Solution to Question 11:
The partial thromboplastin time (PTT) assay screens the function of the proteins in the intrinsic pathway. As factor VII is only a part of the extrinsic pathway, it cannot be assessed by this test.
The factors assessed by the PTT assay are XII, XI, IX, VIII, X, V, and II and fibrinogen.
In this assay, clotting of plasma is initiated by the addition of negatively charged particles (e.g., ground glass) that activate factor XII (Hageman factor) together with phospholipids and calcium, and the time to fibrin clot formation is recorded.
Solution to Question 12:
Thrombomodulin is an anticoagulant.
It is produced by all endothelial cells except those in cerebral microcirculation. It binds to thrombin on the endothelial cell surface. When bound in this complex, thrombin loses its ability to activate coagulation factors and platelets, and instead cleaves and activates protein C. Activated protein C/protein S complex is a potent inhibitor of coagulation factors Va and VIIIa. This action results in an anticoagulant effect.
The effect of recombinant thrombomodulin administration in sepsis-induced coagulopathy and DIC is being studied currently.
Other important anticoagulant substances are:
Antithrombin III - It inhibits the activity of thrombin and other factors like XIIa, XIa, Xa, and IXa. It is activated by binding to heparin-like molecules.
Proteins C and S - These proteins are vitamin K–dependent proteins that inactivate factors Va and VIIIa.
Endothelial prostacyclin (PGI2) and nitric oxide (NO) - These are potent vasodilators and inhibitors of platelet aggregation.
Tissue factor pathway inhibitor - This is derived from the endothelium and inhibits tissue factor VIIa and Xa molecules.
Solution to Question 13:
Leiden mutation is a single nucleotide mutation that occurs in factor V. This is named after the city in The Netherlands where it was discovered.
Of the inherited causes of hypercoagulability, point mutations in the factor V gene and prothrombin gene are the most common.
Solution to Question 14:
Hyperviscosity is not part of Virchow’s triad. However, hyperviscosity states as in polycythemia vera may, in turn, cause small vessel stasis that may cause thrombosis.
Virchow's triad in thrombosis:
Injury to endothelial cells can alter local blood flow and affect coagulability.
Abnormal blood flow (stasis or turbulence), in turn, can cause endothelial injury.
Hypercoagulability of blood
These factors may promote thrombosis independently or in combination.
Solution to Question 15:
Thrombi often have grossly and microscopically apparent laminations called lines of Zahn. These are formed by pale platelet and fibrin deposits alternating with darker red cell-rich layers.
They signify that a thrombus has formed in flowing blood. Their presence can therefore distinguish antemortem clots from the nonlaminated postmortem clots.
The below histopathological image of a thrombus shows these alternating bands called lines of Zahn.

Solution to Question 16:
Chicken fat clots refer to post-mortem clots i.e., clots that are formed after death.
Postmortem clots are gelatinous and have a dark red (currant jelly) dependent portion where red cells have settled by gravity and a yellow (chicken fat) upper portion due to coagulation of plasma.
Antemortem clots can be differentiated from postmortem clots by:
Presence of lines of Zahn
Attachment to the underlying vessel wall
Solution to Question 17:
An embolus in the bifurcation of the main pulmonary artery is referred to as a saddle embolus.
Pulmonary emboli (PE) originate from deep venous thromboses and are the most common form of thromboembolic disease. In more than 95% of cases, PE originates from leg deep vein thrombi (DVTs).
Fragmented thrombi from DVTs are carried through progressively larger veins and the right side of the heart, before slamming into the pulmonary arterial vasculature. Depending on the size of the embolus, it can have 3 fates:
It can occlude the main pulmonary artery
It can straddle the pulmonary artery bifurcation (saddle embolus)
It can pass out into the smaller, branching arterie
The CT image given below shows a saddle embolus lodged in the main pulmonary artery extending into both its limbs as indicated by the red arrows.

Solution to Question 18:
The given image shows the presence of laminated swirls of squamous cells in the pulmonary arteriole which is characteristically seen in amniotic fluid embolism(AFE).

AFE is a life-threatening obstetric emergency characterized by sudden cardiorespiratory collapse and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). The underlying cause is the infusion of amniotic fluid or fetal tissue into the maternal circulation via a tear in the placental membranes or rupture of uterine veins.
Findings at autopsy include:
Presence in the maternal pulmonary micro-vasculature of-
Squamous cells shed from fetal skin
Lanugo hair
Fat from vernix caseosa
Mucin derived from the fetal respiratory or gastrointestinal tract
Marked pulmonary edema
Diffuse alveolar damage
Presence of fibrin thrombi in many vascular beds due to DIC
Solution to Question 19:
Increased prothrombin time (PT) is a feature of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is an acute, subacute, or chronic thrombohemorrhagic disorder occurring as a secondary complication in a variety of diseases.
It is characterized by the activation of the coagulation sequence, which leads to the formation of microthrombi throughout the microcirculation of the body. As a consequence of the thrombotic diathesis, there is a consumption of platelets, fibrin, and coagulation factors and, secondarily, activation of fibrinolytic mechanisms.
Laboratory investigations in DIC reveal the following:
Thrombocytopenia
Prolonged prothrombin time (PT)/thrombin time (TT)
Decreased fibrinogen level
Elevated levels of fibrin-split products (D-dimers)
Solution to Question 20:
White infarcts occur in the spleen, not red infarcts. Red infarcts occur in the following conditions:
Venous occlusions (e.g., testicular torsion)
Loose, spongy tissues (e.g., lung), where blood can collect in the infarcted zone
Tissues with dual circulations (e.g., lung and small intestine), which allows blood to flow from an unobstructed parallel supply into a necrotic zone
Tissues previously congested by sluggish venous outflow
When flow is re-established at a site of previous arterial occlusion and necrosis (e.g., following angioplasty of an arterial obstruction)
The below image shows a hemorrhagic, roughly wedge-shaped pulmonary red infarct.

White infarcts occur with arterial occlusions in solid organs with end-arterial circulation (e.g., heart, spleen, and kidney), and where tissue density limits the seepage of blood from adjoining capillary beds into the necrotic area.
The below image shows a sharply demarcated white infarct in the spleen.

Septic infarctions occur when infected cardiac valve vegetations embolize or when microbes seed necrotic tissue. In these cases, the infarct is converted into an abscess, with a correspondingly greater inflammatory response.
Solution to Question 21:
Caisson disease is a chronic form of decompression sickness which occurs when individuals experience a sudden decrease in atmospheric pressure.
It is named after the pressurized vessels that are used in bridge construction as workers in these vessels are known to suffer from both acute and chronic forms of decompression sickness.
When air is breathed at high pressure, increased amounts of gas, particularly nitrogen, are dissolved in the blood and tissues. If there is a sudden fall in pressure, the nitrogen comes out of the solution in the tissues and the blood and forms gas emboli. In Caisson disease, the persistence of gas emboli in the skeletal system leads to the development of multiple foci of ischemic necrosis. The more common sites are the femoral heads, tibia, and humeri.
Solution to Question 22:
High plasma protein content in the pleural fluid would rule out a transudative cause. In a transudative effusion, the fluid has low protein content, little or no cellular material, and low specific gravity.
It is essentially an ultrafiltrate of the blood plasma. It is produced as a result of osmotic or hydrostatic imbalance across the vessel wall. There is no increase in vascular permeability.

Solution to Question 1:
Mendelian disorders are caused by single-gene mutations.
A mutation is defined as a permanent change in the genetic material that can result in altered protein function and phenotypic changes.
Mutations that affect germ cells are transmitted to the progeny and can give rise to inherited diseases.
Human genetic disorders can be broadly classified into three categories:
Single-gene mutations - these diseases usually follow the classic Mendelian pattern of inheritance.
Chromosomal disorders - These arise from the structural or numerical alteration in the autosomes and sex chromosomes. Like a monogenic disease, they are uncommon but associated with high penetrance.
Complex multigenic disorders - They are more common and are caused by interactions between multiple variant forms of genes and environmental factors. Such variations in genes are common within the population and are also called polymorphisms.
Solution to Question 2:
A non-sense mutation is seen in  0 thalassemia.
A point mutation is a change in which a single base is substituted with a different base. The point mutations within the coding sequences of the DNA are of two types:
Missense mutations: These involve alteration of a single base in a triplet of bases. It leads to the replacement of one amino acid by another in the gene product. These mutations alter the meaning of the sequence of the encoded protein. Based on the substituted amino acid coded, the missense mutations are again of two types:
Conservative missense mutation: The substituted amino acid is biochemically similar to the original. It typically causes little change in the function of the protein.
Non-conservative missense mutation: This type of mutation replaces the normal amino acid with a biochemically different one.
Nonsense mutations: It is a point mutation in a sequence of DNA that results in a premature stop codon.
For example, a point mutation affecting the codon for glutamine (CAG) creates a stop codon (UAG) if U is substituted for C. This change leads to premature termination of  -globin gene translation, and the short peptide that is produced is rapidly degraded. The resulting deficiency of
 -globin chains can give rise to a severe form of anemia called  0 thalassemia.
Option B: -thalassemias are caused by inherited deletions that result in the reduced or absent synthesis of -globin chains.
Option C: Sickle-cell anemia is an example of non-conservative missense mutation. It occurs due to the replacement of the 6th glutamic acid by valine in the beta-globin gene on chromosome 11.
Option D: Hereditary spherocytosis (HS) is an inherited disorder caused by intrinsic defects in the red cell membrane skeleton that render red cells spheroid less deformable and vulnerable to splenic sequestration and destruction.
Solution to Question 3:
ABO blood group and HLA are both examples of codominant inheritance.
In a codominant phenotype, alleles of a gene pair in a heterozygote are fully expressed. Thereby resulting in an offspring with a phenotype that is neither dominant nor recessive and both the alleles of a gene pair contributes to the phenotype.
Mendelian traits are usually described as dominant or recessive:
A dominant allele produces a dominant phenotype in individuals who have one copy of the allele, which can come from just one parent.
A recessive allele produces a recessive phenotype, in individuals who have two copies of the allele, one from each parent.
The illustration below shows the codominant inheritance pattern of the blood group.

Hair colour, height, and skin color are polygenic traits.
Solution to Question 4:
Pleiotropism is characterized by a single mutant gene, which may lead to many end effects.
For example, in sickle-cell anemia, the point mutation in the gene not only predisposes the red blood cells to hemolysis but can also block the vessels. This leads to splenic fibrosis, organ infarcts, and bone changes. The numerous differing end-organ derangements are all related to the primary defect in hemoglobin synthesis.
Option B: In variable expressivity, a trait is seen in all individuals carrying the mutant gene but is expressed differently among them.
Option C: Polymorphisms are caused by interactions between multiple variant forms of genes and environmental factors.
Option D: Genetic heterogeneity refers to mutations at several genetic loci that may produce the same trait. An example of this is profound childhood deafness - an apparently homogeneous clinical entity that results from many different types of autosomal recessive mutations.
Solution to Question 5:
Achondroplasia is an autosomal dominant disorder.
It is caused by a mutation of the fibroblast growth factor receptor-3 (FGFR-3) gene.
The primary defect is abnormal chondrocyte proliferation at the growth plate that causes development of short and thick bones.
Clinical features:
Short limbs
Normal trunk
Large head
Saddle nose
Exaggerated lumbar lordosis
Severe spinal deformity may lead to cord compression

Solution to Question 6:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Huntington's disease. It is an autosomal-dominant inherited disorder.
Huntington disease (HD) also known as Huntington chorea is associated with CAG repeats and anticipation. It has an adult-onset and cell loss within a specific subset of neurons in the basal ganglia and cortex is seen. The characteristic features of HD include involuntary movements, dementia, and behavioral changes.
Solution to Question 7:
The given scenario and image showing the characteristic hatchet facies are suggestive of myotonic dystrophy (dystonia myotrophica). It is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder affecting muscle function.
There are mainly two types:
DM1 - In this type, the affected gene is DMPK, which codes for myotonic dystrophy protein kinase, a protein expressed predominantly in skeletal muscle. The gene is located on the long arm of chromosome 19.
DM2 - It is caused by a defect of the CNBP gene on chromosome 3.
Solution to Question 8:
Tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC)/ Bourneville disease is an autosomal-dominant genetic disorder.
TSC affects the differentiation, proliferation, and migration of cells early in development. This results in a variety of hamartomatous lesions that may affect virtually every organ system of the body. Two distinct genetic loci have been identified which are on chromosome 9 (TSC1) and on chromosome 16 (TSC2).
The most common cutaneous manifestation of TSC is hypomelanotic macules (ash-leaf macules) and is observed in most children with tuberous sclerosis. It presents at birth or appears within the first few years of life and may fade or disappear in adulthood.
The following image shows an ash-leaf macule.

Solution to Question 9:
Albinism is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.
Solution to Question 10:
The given scenario is suggestive of hereditary hemochromatosis. It is an autosomal recessive genetic disorder that involves the HFE gene.
Hemochromatosis is characterized by excessive iron accumulation that results in tissue damage. It consists of a triad of:
Micronodular cirrhosis
Bronzing of the skin
Diabetes mellitus
Diagnosis is by elevated levels of serum ferritin, serum iron, transferrin saturation, and confirmation by a gene assay.
Note: Autosomal recessive disorders include almost all inborn errors of metabolism.
Solution to Question 11:
The given pedigree chart is pointing towards an autosomal recessive mode of inheritance. A boy with cardiomegaly, scoliosis, and pes cavus is suggestive of Friedreich’s ataxia. This is an autosomal recessive inherited disease, resulting from a mutation of a gene locus on chromosome 9.
The condition causes nervous system damage and movement problems. It usually begins in childhood and leads to impaired muscle coordination (ataxia) that worsens over time. Scoliosis, cardiomegaly, and foot problems may also develop.
Option A: Hundreds of adenomatous polyps throughout the colon are suggestive of familial adenomatous polyposis(FAP) which is an autosomal-dominant inherited disorder.
Option C: Vitamin D–resistant rickets is an X-linked dominant inherited disorder.
Option D: A child with a triad of micro-thrombocytopenia, eczema, and recurrent infections points towards Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome. It is an X-linked recessive inherited disorder.
Solution to Question 12:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of congenital adrenal hyperplasia. It includes a group of autosomal recessive disorders, each of which involves a deficiency of an enzyme involved in the synthesis of cortisol, aldosterone, or both.
The most common form is known to occur due to the deficiency of 21-hydroxylase, resulting from mutations or deletion of CYP21A.
Solution to Question 13:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of phenylketonuria (PKU). It is caused by mutations in the PAH gene which encodes for phenylalanine hydroxylase.
Phenylketonuria is the most common inborn error of amino acid metabolism. It is less commonly known as phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH) deficiency. The mode of inheritance is autosomal recessive.
Solution to Question 14:
The given scenario is suggestive of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. It is the most common enzyme deficiency in humans, inherited as an X-linked recessive disorder. The gene that codes for G6PD is located in the distal long arm of the X chromosome at the Xq28 locus.
The inheritance pattern is similar to that of hemophilia and color blindness, where males usually manifest the abnormality and females are carriers. Females may be symptomatic if they are homozygous or if inactivation of their normal X chromosome occurs.
Solution to Question 15:
The given scenario is suggestive of Lesch–Nyhan syndrome. It is an X-linked recessive inherited disorder characterized by the deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase (HGPRT).
Lesch–Nyhan syndrome and its variants are caused by mutations in the HPRT gene on the X chromosome.
The disorder is associated with 3 major clinical elements:
Overproduction of uric acid (hyperuricemia)
Neurologic disability - intellectual disability and delayed milestones
Behavioral problems - self-mutilation (excessive biting of lips and nails)
Solution to Question 16:
The patient's height and the presence of early diastolic murmur in the given clinical scenario are suggestive of Marfan syndrome. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant disorder. The family pedigree confirms the mode of inheritance.
The following flow chart helps in making out the pattern of inheritance from a given pedigree chart.

Patients with Marfan syndrome have pleiotropic manifestations:
Skeletal systems - Tall and decreased upper to lower segment ratio with long arms, hands, and fingers
Deformities of the chest wall, vertebral column, and foot arches
Cardiovascular abnormalities - mitral valve prolapse leading to mitra
regurgitation and dilatation of aortic root leading to aortic regurgitation, aortic dissection, and rupture.
Ocular - superio-temporal lens dislocation
Solution to Question 17:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Marfan's syndrome. It is due to the inherited defect of the protein fibrillin 1.
Fibrillin is a major building block of microfibrils. This constitutes the structural components of the suspensory ligament of the ocular lens and serves as substrates for elastin in the aorta and other connective tissues.
It occurs in two homologous forms:
Fibrillin-1: encoded by FBN1, mapped on chromosomes 15q21.1. Mutations cause Marfan's syndrome.
Fibrillin-2: encoded by FBN2, mapped on chromosomes 5q23.31. Mutations cause congenita contractural arachnodactyly.
Solution to Question 18:
Skeletal abnormalities are the most striking feature of Marfan syndrome. Skeletal abnormalities include:
Unusually tall, with exceptionally long extremities and long, tapering fingers and toes
The joint ligaments in the hands and feet are lax, suggesting that the patient is double-jointed. Typically, the thumb can be hyper-extended back to the wrist
The head is commonly dolichocephalic (long-headed) with bossing of the frontal eminences and prominent supraorbital ridges
Spinal deformities include:
Kyphosis
Scoliosis
Rotation/slipping of the dorsal or lumbar vertebrae
Pectus excavatum (deeply depressed sternum)
Pigeon-breast deformity
Ocular changes include bilateral subluxation or dislocation (outward and upward) of the lens, referred to as ectopia lentis.
Cardiovascular lesions are the most life-threatening features of this disorder. The two most common lesions are:
Mitral valve prolapse
Dilation of the ascending aorta due to cystic medionecrosis
The images given below show features seen in patients with Marfan's syndrome.



Solution to Question 19:
Cardiovascular lesions, like rupture of aortic dissections, are the most life-threatening features of the Marfan syndrome.
The weakening of the media predisposes the aorta to an intimal tear. It may initiate an intramural hematoma that cleaves the layers of the media to produce aortic dissection.
After causing the cleavage of the aortic layers for a considerable length, sometimes extending to the root of the aorta or down to the iliac arteries, the hemorrhage often ruptures through the aortic wall.
Although mitral valve lesions are more frequent, they are clinically less important than aortic lesions. Loss of connective tissue support in the mitral valve leaflets makes them soft and billowy, creating a so-called floppy valve.
Valvular lesions, along with the lengthening of the chordae tendineae, frequently give rise to mitral regurgitation. Similar changes may affect the tricuspid and, rarely, the aortic valves.
Solution to Question 20:
The mode of inheritance of Ehler–Danlos syndrome (EDS) encompasses two Mendelian patterns, namely:
Autosomal dominant
Autosomal recessive
The biosynthesis of collagen can be disturbed by genetic errors that may affect any one of the numerous structural collagen genes or enzymes necessary for posttranscriptional modifications of collagen. Such molecular heterogeneity results in the expression of EDS as a clinically variable disorder, with varied patterns of inheritance.
Solution to Question 21:
The given scenario is suggestive of the kyphoscoliotic form of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS).
This was previously known as Type VI EDS.
The kyphoscoliotic form of EDS is caused by the deficient activity of the enzyme procollagen-lysine, 2-oxoglutarate 5-dioxygenase 1 (PLOD1, or lysyl hydroxylase 1).
It is a generalized connective tissue disorder characterized by:
Friable hyperextensible skin
Thin scars
Easy bruising
Generalized joint laxity
Severe muscular hypotonia at birth
Progressive scoliosis may be present at birth or may develop within the first year of life
Solution to Question 22:
Classic Ehlers-Danlos syndromes (EDS) type involves type V collagen (defects in genes COL5A1 and COL5A2).
Types I and II of EDS are termed as classic forms. Type I is severe, while type II is milder.
It has an autosomal-dominant type of inheritance. Clinically, this type is characterized by skin and joint hypermobility, atrophic scars, and easy bruising.
Solution to Question 23:
Dermatosparaxis type of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS) is type VIIc.
Solution to Question 24:
Spinal muscular atrophy has an autosomal recessive inheritance, not autosomal dominant.
Solution to Question 25:
The given scenario is suggestive of Wolman disease. It is due to a deficiency of the lysosomal acid lipase enzyme. It is an autosomal recessive disease.
It leads to the accumulation of cholesterol esters and triglycerides. It presents in the first few weeks of life with:
Failure to thrive
Vomiting
Abdominal distention
Steatorrhea
Hepatosplenomegaly
Hyperlipidemia
Extensive bilateral calcifications of the adrenal glands
No specific therapy is available and death usually occurs within 6 months of life.

Solution to Question 1:
Hurler disease is a mucopolysaccharidosis.
Sphingolipidoses are a group of lysosomal storage disorders characterized by the accumulation of sphingolipids. It includes:
Niemann–Pick disease
Fabry disease
Krabbe disease
Gaucher disease
Tay–Sachs disease
Metachromatic leukodystrophy
Solution to Question 2:
Gaucher disease is the most common lysosomal storage disorder.
It is an autosomal recessive disorder resulting from mutations in the gene encoding glucocerebrosidase.
Solution to Question 3:
The given scenario and hexosaminidase -subunit deficiency are seen in Tay–Sachs disease. Sphingolipidoses with their deficient enzyme:
GM1 Gangliosidoses - GM1 Ganglioside  - galactosidase deficiency
Type 1- infantile, generalizsed
Type 2- juvenile
GM2 Gangliosidosis:
Tay–Sachs disease - Hexosaminidase -subunit
Sandhoff disease - Hexosaminidase  -subunit
GM2 Gangliosidosis variant AB - Ganglioside activator protein
Note: Tay–Sachs disease is the most common form of GM2 gangliosidosis.
Solution to Question 4:
In Tay–Sachs disease, an electron microscope shows whorled configurations within lysosomes composed of onion-skin layers of membranes.
Affected infants appear normal at birth but begin to manifest signs and symptoms at about 6 months of age. The involvement of neurons in the central and autonomic nervous systems and retina dominates the clinical picture.
There is a severe motor and mental deterioration, beginning with motor incoordination and mental obtundation. This leads to muscular flaccidity, blindness, and increasing dementia. Over the span of 1 or 2 years, a completely vegetative state is reached, followed by death at age 2 to 3 years
On histologic examination, the neurons are ballooned with cytoplasmic vacuoles, each representing a markedly distended lysosome filled with gangliosides.
A cherry-red spot appears in the macula, representing the accentuation of the normal color of the macular choroid. This is in contrast with the pallor produced by the swollen ganglion cells in the remainder of the retina. This finding is characteristic of Tay-Sachs disease and other storage disorders affecting the neurons.
The image given below shows a cherry-red spot on retina.

Solution to Question 5:
Metachromatic leukodystrophy is an autosomal recessive condition caused by the deficiency of arylsulfatase A.
The deficiency of this enzyme leads to the accumulation of cerebroside sulfate. These sulfatides can contribute to white matter injury, demyelination, and gliosis.
Macrophages with vacuolated cytoplasm are scattered throughout the white matter. They contain metachromatic material, which can be detected in the urine and peripheral nerves when stained with toluidine blue.
Solution to Question 6:
Krabbe disease is due to the deficiency of galactosylceramidase.
The onset of symptoms is between 3 and 6 months of age, dominated by motor signs such as stiffness and weakness. They often don't survive beyond the age of 2 years. The brain shows loss of myelin and oligodendrocytes with a similar process affecting the peripheral nerves.
The aggregation of engorged macrophages called globoid cells in the brain parenchyma and around blood vessels is the characteristic and diagnostic feature of Krabbe disease.
Solution to Question 7:
Ceramide trihexoside (also known as globotriaosylceramide) is accumulated in Fabry disease. The enzyme defect seen in this disease is -galactosidase A.
Clinical features:
Painful acroparaesthesia
Hypohidrosi
Abdominal cramping
Diarrhea
Small petechiae around the umbilicu
Lenticular opacitie
Corneal dystrophy
Solution to Question 8:
Niemann–Pick disease types A and B are two related disorders that are characterized by lysosomal accumulation of sphingomyelin due to an inherited deficiency of sphingomyelinase.
The disease is typically inherited as an autosomal recessive condition on chromosome 11.
Type A is a severe infantile form with extensive neurologic involvement, marked visceral accumulations of sphingomyelin, progressive wasting, and early death within the first 3 years of life.
Type B disease patients have organomegaly, but generally no central nervous system involvement. They usually survive into adulthood.
Solution to Question 9:
Electron microscopy showing zebra bodies is suggestive of Niemann–Pick disease.
Zebra bodies are engorged secondary lysosomes that contain membranous cytoplasmic bodies resembling concentric lamellated myelin figures. Similar zebra bodies can also be seen in mucopolysaccharidoses.
Solution to Question 10:
Inclusion-cell (I-cell) disease, also referred to as mucolipidosis II, is a part of the lysosomal storage disease family.
It is characterized by the deficiency of phosphorylating enzymes essential for the formation of the mannose-6-phosphate recognition marker.
Acid hydrolases lacking the recognition marker cannot be targeted to the lysosomes but are secreted extracellularly.
It is characterized by:
Coarse facial feature
Gingival hyperplasia
Clouded cornea
Restricted joint movement
Claw hand deformitie
Kyphoscoliosi
High plasma levels of lysosomal enzyme

Solution to Question 11:
All the mucopolysaccharidoses are inherited as autosomal-recessive traits except Hunter syndrome. It is inherited as an X-linked recessive disease.
The mucopolysaccharidoses (MPSs) are a group of closely related syndromes that result from genetically determined deficiencies of enzymes involved in the degradation of mucopolysaccharides (glycosaminoglycans).
Mucopolysaccharides are abundant in the ground substance of connective tissues. In the absence of enzymes involved in their degradation, they accumulate within lysosomes in various tissues and organs of the body. Two among these are:
Hurler syndrome - deficiency of -L-iduronidase
Hunter syndrome - deficiency of iduronate 2-sulphatase
Solution to Question 12:
Glycogen storage disorder type II, also called Pompe disease, is the only glycogen storage disease with a defect in lysosomal metabolism.
It is an autosomal-recessive metabolic disorder. It is caused by the accumulation of glycogen in the lysosome due to deficiency of the lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase enzyme.
Solution to Question 13:
The given scenario and bone marrow aspiration images showing necrotic bone with lack of osteocytes in the lacunae (Image A) and Gaucher cells (Image B)are suggestive of Gaucher's disease. This condition has a deficiency of glucocerebrosidase.
Gaucher cells are plump macrophages that characteristically have a crumpled tissue paper appearance (Image B) of the cytoplasm. It is due to the accumulation of glucocerebrosides.
They can be seen in Virchow–Robin spaces (perivascular fluid-filled cavities that surround perforating arteries and veins in the brain parenchyma) in patients with cerebral involvement.
Solution to Question 14:
In type 1, enzyme activity is reduced but detectable. Gaucher disease is of two types:

Type 2:Acute neuronopathic f orm

Solution to Question 15:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of von Gierke disease. It is due to the deficiency of glucose 6 phosphatase enzyme.
The condition usually manifests as:
Failure to thrive
Stunted growth
Hepatomegaly
Renomegaly
Hypoglycemia is due to the failure of glucose mobilization which often leads to convulsions. Lactic acidosis, hyperlipidemia, and hyperuricemia result from deranged glucose metabolism. Many patients also develop gout, skin xanthomas, and bleeding tendency (due to platelet dysfunction).
With treatment, most patients survive and develop late complications (e.g., hepatic adenomas).
Solution to Question 16:
McArdle’s syndrome is caused due to the deficiency of muscle phosphorylase.
In the skeletal muscles, as opposed to the liver, glycogen is used predominantly as a source of energy during physical activity. If enzymes hydrolyzing glucose are deficient, there will be an accumulation of glycogen in the muscles. This will cause muscle weakness due to impaired energy production.
Enzyme deficiencies leading to muscle glycogen storage include:
McArdle disease/type V glycogenosis - deficiency of muscle phosphorylase
Type VII glycogen storage disease - deficiency of muscle phosphofructokinase
Typically, individuals with myopathic forms present with muscle cramps after exercise. This is because lactate levels in the blood fail to rise after exercise due to a block in glycolysis.

It may be associated with horseshoe kidney

Solution to Question 1:
Standard karyotyping refers to an arrangement of chromosomes from a cell that is undergoing mitosis at metaphase.
At other mitotic stages, the chromosomes are not sufficiently condensed or are too dispersed to allow for the counting and comparison of pairs under the microscope. In a metaphase spread, the individual chromosomes take the form of two chromatids connected to the centromere.
A variety of staining methods are available to identify the individual chromosomes on the basis of a distinctive and reliable pattern of alternating light and dark bands. The most common method used involves a Giemsa stain and is hence called G-banding. Standard G-banding can detect approximately 400 to 800 bands per haploid set.
The image below shows G-banding (karyogram of human male using Giemsa staining):

Solution to Question 2:
The short arm of a chromosome (marked as 1) is designated p (for petite), and the long arm
(marked as 2) is referred to as q (the next alphabet).

In a banded karyotype, each arm of the chromosome is divided into two or more regions bordered by prominent bands. The regions are numbered (e.g., 1, 2, 3) from the centromere outward. Each region is further subdivided into bands and sub-bands, and these are ordered numerically as well.

Solution to Question 3:
A ring chromosome is an aberrant chromosome whose broken ends fuse together to form a ring.
Ring chromosomes behave abnormally in meiosis or mitosis and usually result in serious consequences. In rare cases, the telomeres at the ends of a chromosome fuse without any loss of
genetic material, which results in a normal phenotype. A ring chromosome is denoted by the symbol r in human genetics.

The following image shows a representative karyotype from a well-differentiated transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder. The chromosome indicated by 'r' represents a ring chromosome. Also evident are monosomy 9, 18, and X and trisomy 7.

Option A: In a translocation, a segment of one chromosome is transferred to another.
Option C: Inversion refers to a rearrangement that involves two breaks within a single chromosome, with reincorporation of the inverted, intervening segment.
Option D: Isochromosome formation results when one arm of a chromosome is lost and the remaining arm is duplicated. It results in a chromosome consisting of two short arms only or of two long arms.
Solution to Question 4:
Inversion involves only a rearrangement of the genetic material. There is no change in the genetic material.
It occurs as a result of two breaks within a single chromosome. The intervening segment between the breaks gets inverted and reincorporated. It is of two types:
Paracentric - inversion involving only one arm of the chromosome
Pericentric - inversion involving opposite sides of the centromere Inversions are often fully compatible with normal development.
Transversions are mutations where a purine base pair is replaced by a pyrimidine or vice versa.

Solution to Question 5:
In Down's syndrome, the major cause of death in infancy and early childhood is cardiac disease, not leukemia.
Down's syndrome is the most common chromosomal disorder and is a major cause of mental retardation. Maternal age is a strong risk factor. This condition can occur by the following mechanisms:
Majority of cases - meiotic nondisjunction of chromosome 21 in the ovum
Rarely - Robertsonian translocation of the long arm of chromosome 21 to another acrocentric chromosome (e.g., 22 or 14)
The clinical features of Down's syndrome include:
Mental retardation
Facial dysmorphism - flat facial profile, oblique palpebral fissures, and epicanthic folds
Congenital heart disease - endocardial cushion defects (ASD, VSD, AV valve malformations)
Atresias of the esophagus and small bowel
Neuropathologic changes characteristic of Alzheimer's disease - in patients > 40 years
Increased risk of developing acute megakaryoblastic leukemia (AML-M7)
Predisposition to autoimmune diseases and serious lung infections

Solution to Question 6:
This clinical scenario and image showing a single palmar crease (simian crease) are suggestive of Down's syndrome. It is associated with an increased risk of acute megakaryoblastic
leukemia (AML-M7) in affected children < 2 years old.
Children with trisomy 21 have a 10 to 20-fold increased risk of developing acute leukemia.
In children < 2 years of age - acute megakaryoblastic leukemia(AML-M7) is the most common
In children > 3 years of age - acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is the most predominant
Solution to Question 7:
The images show the index finger overlapping other fingers and rocker bottom feet. This along with the clinical features is suggestive of Edward's syndrome. Leukemia is not a feature of this condition.
It is due to the inheritance of a complete extra copy of chromosome 18 as a result of meiotic nondisjunction (47, XY+18). The incidence is 1 in 8000 births.
The clinical features of Edward's syndrome include:
Low-set ears
Short neck
Overlapping fingers
Congenital heart defects
Renal malformations
Limited hip abduction
Rocker-bottom feet
Prominent occiput
Mental retardation
Micrognathia
Note: Although, rocker bottom feet are seen in both Edward's syndrome and Patau's syndrome, overlapping of fingers is characteristic of Edward's syndrome.
Solution to Question 8:
Low set ears are a feature of Patau syndrome, not high set ears. Patau syndrome occurs due to trisomy 13 and is characterized by:
Microphthalmia
Polydactyly
Microcephaly and mental retardation
Cleft lip and palate
Cardiac defects
Umbilical hernia
Renal defects
Rocker-bottom feet (commonly seen in Edwards syndrome also)

Solution to Question 9:
Lyon's hypothesis states the idea of the inactivation of the X chromosome. It states the following:
Only one of the X chromosomes is genetically active
The other X undergoes heteropyknosis and is rendered inactive (known as Barr body)
Inactivation of either the maternal or paternal X occurs at random among all the cells of the blastocyst on or about day 5.5 of embryonic life
Inactivation of the same X chromosome persists in all the cells derived from each precursor cell. The molecular basis of X inactivation involves the XIST gene.
Solution to Question 10:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Klinefelter's syndrome. In this condition, the follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) levels are elevated.
The clinical features include:
Eunuchoid body habitus - elongated body and long legs (increased length between the soles and the pubic bone)
Absence of secondary sexual characteristics - lack of body and facial hair, deep voice
Small atrophic testes
Micropenis
Gynecomastia
Lower IQ, but no mental retardation
The following hormonal variations are seen in these patients:
Elevated FSH
Elevated estradiol
Low testosterone
Insulin resistance - increased incidence of type 2 diabetes Patients with Klinefelter syndrome are at a higher risk for:
Male breast cancer (20x more common than in normal males)
Extragonadal germ cell tumors
Autoimmune diseases - systemic lupus erythematosus
Solution to Question 11:
The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of Turner's syndrome. In this condition, the most common karyotypic abnormality seen is a missing entire X chromosome, seen in more than half the cases.
Less commonly, structural abnormalities of the X chromosome and mosaicism can also occur. The common feature of the structural abnormalities is to produce partial monosomy of the X chromosome.
In order of frequency, the structural abnormalities of the X chromosome include the following:
An isochromosome of the long arm, 46,X,i(X)(q10), resulting in the loss of the short arm
Deletion of portions of both long and short arms, resulting in the formation of a ring chromosome - 46, X,r(X)
Deletion of portions of the short or long arm - 46X,del(Xq) or 46X,del(Xp).
The mosaic patients have a 45,XO cell population along with one or more karyotypically normal or abnormal cell types.
Few patients with this condition also have Y-chromosome sequences, either as a complete Y chromosome or as fragments of Y chromosomes translocated on other chromosomes. These patients are at a higher risk for the development of a gonadal tumor (gonadoblastoma).
Solution to Question 12:
Huntington's disease is due to CAG (trinucleotide) repeat mutation in the coding region of the gene, not the non-coding region.
Expansion of trinucleotide repeats is an important genetic cause of human disease, particularly neurodegenerative disorders. The causative mutations are associated with the expansion of a stretch of trinucleotides that usually share the nucleotides G and C. In all cases, the DNA is unstable, and an expansion of the repeats above a certain threshold impairs gene function.
Expansions affecting noncoding regions will cause a loss of function mutation. They include:
Fragile X syndrome
Myotonic dystrophy
Friedreich ataxia
Expansions affecting coding regions cause a gain of function mutation. They include:
Spinobulbar muscular atrophy (Kennedy disease)
Huntington disease
Dentatorubral-pallidoluysian atrophy (Haw–River syndrome)
Spinocerebellar ataxia types 1, 2, 3, 6, 7
Solution to Question 13:
Macro-orchidism (large testicles) are seen in fragile X syndrome, not micro-orchidism.
Fragile X syndrome is the second most common genetic cause of mental retardation (Down syndrome being the most common). It is caused by a trinucleotide mutation, characterised by multiple tandem repeats of the CGG sequence in the familial mental retardation-1 (FMR1) gene. It is associated with the phenomenon of anticipation, where the disease phenotype worsens over generations within a family.
The affected males are mentally retarded, with an IQ in the range of 20 to 60. The characteristic phenotypic features include the following:
Long face with a large mandible
Large everted ears
Macro-orchidism
Hyperextensible joints
High arched palate
Mitral valve prolapse
The given image shows a child suffering from fragile X syndrome.

Solution to Question 14:
CGG premutations in the FMR1 gene are characteristic of fragile X ataxia. It is also known as fragile X tremor and fragile X-associated primary ovarian failure.
Normally, the FMR1 gene is methylated and silenced, and the number of CGG repeats remains
< 55.
However, abnormalities in this gene lead to the accumulation of CGG-containing FMR1 mRNAs, which are toxic to the cell. Depending on the type of mutation, there are 2 distinct syndromes:
Fragile X ataxia syndrome (FXTAS): 55-200 repeats (premutation) which causes gain of function
Fragile X syndrome (FXs): 200- 4000 repeats (full mutation) leading to loss of function
More than half the individuals with FXTAS develop a progressive neurodegenerative syndrome starting in their 6th decade. It is characterized by intention tremors and cerebellar ataxia and may progress to Parkinsonism.
Option B: Prader-Willi syndrome is associated with deletion of paternal chromosome 15q12 and the silencing of the maternal allele.
Option D: Friedreich ataxia is due to GAA repeat sequences in the noncoding regions.
Solution to Question 15:
Leber hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON) is an example of mitochondrial inheritance. It is inherited along the maternal line, as shown in image 4.

In diseases following the mitochondrial pattern of inheritance, all children of an affected mother and normal father develop the disease. However, children born to an affected father and a normal mother do not inherit the disease. Hence, only the daughters of the affected mother will transmit the disease.
This is because this condition is due to a mutation in the mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA), which is derived from the maternal mitochondria. The ovum contains several mitochondria, while the spermatozoa have very few mitochondria if present. Hence, the mitochondrial DNA of the zygote is entirely derived from the ovum.
LHON is a neurodegenerative disease that manifests as progressive bilateral loss of central vision. Visual impairment starts between ages 15 and 35, leading eventually to blindness. Other features include cardiac conduction defects and minor neurologic manifestations.
Solution to Question 16:
Chromosome 19 is involved in myotonic dystrophy.
Solution to Question 17:
Maltese cross crystals in the urine are seen in Fabry's disease.
Urine analysis in Fabry’s disease may reveal oval fat bodies and birefringent glycolipid globules under polarized light showing a Maltese cross appearance. It can also be seen in nephrotic syndrome.
The following image shows Maltese cross casts:

Note: Maltese cross appearance is also seen in short-range shotgun wounds and babesiosis.
Solution to Question 18:
The given clinical picture most likely suggests Klinefelter's syndrome. The most common cardiac lesion in this condition is mitral valve prolapse which is seen in nearly half the adults.
Systemic manifestations associated with Klinefelter's syndrome:
Gynecomastia
Type 2 diabetes and metabolic syndrome
Mitral valve prolapse
Osteoporosis and fractures
Male infertility
Higher risk for breast cancer, extragonadal germ-cell tumors
Systemic lupus erythematosus
Solution to Question 19:
Huntington's chorea is a trinucleotide repeat disorder.
It is an autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disorder. It is caused by CAG
trinucleotide repeats (>40). It occurs due to a gain-of-function (expansion) mutation in the huntingtin gene on chromosome 4p.
The disease shows genetic anticipation and has an early-onset (2-3 decades) if inherited from the father.
Cognitive impairment is an early feature. Pathologically, atrophy of caudate and putamen with ex vacuo ventriculomegaly is seen. Decreased acetylcholine leads to dementia and decreased GABA and increased dopamine lead to chorea.
Treatment consists of haloperidol and tetrabenazine. Trinucleotide repeat disorders:

Solution to Question 20:
In Turner's syndrome, webbing of the neck is associated with a higher risk of cardiac anomalies. The image below summarises the clinical features of Turner's syndrome.

The image given below shows the webbing of neck.

Noonan syndrome is characterised by mutations in the RAS-MAPK pathway. The most common of these is the PTPN11 which encodes a protein tyrosine phosphatase on chromosome 12.
Clinical features include:
Short stature
Short webbed neck
Cystic hygroma
Tall forehead
Low posterior hairline
Dental malocclusion
Although it shares many clinical features with Turner’s syndrome, Noonan syndrome
affects both sexes. It follows an autosomal dominant pattern and it also has a different pattern of congenital heart disease, typically involving right-sided lesions.
Solution to Question 21:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Angelman syndrome. It can occur due to one of the following genetic abnormalities:
Deletion (most common) - band q12 on the long arm of maternal chromosome 15
Paternal uniparental disomy - inheritance of both chromosomes of a pair from the paternal pair f chromosomes
Defective imprinting - defect in the resetting/maintaining of imprints during gametogenesis or after fertilization
Chromosome 15 diseases (mnemonic - MAP):
M: Marfan syndrome
A: Angelman syndrome
P: Prader Willi syndrome
The following images show children suffering from Prader-Willi syndrome.

Solution to Question 1:
Cancer cells are insensitive to growth-inhibitory signals.
All cancer cells are known to show around 8 fundamental physiological changes in the cell, which are considered as the hallmarks of cancer. These changes include the following:
Self-sufficiency in growth signals - once activated, tumors can proliferate without externa stimuli
Insensitivity to growth-inhibitory signals - tumors do not respond to inhibitors of cell growth. This is attributed to the inactivation of the tumor-suppressor genes in cancer cells
Altered cellular metabolism - tumor cells switch to aerobic glycolysis, called the Warburg effect
Evasion of apoptosis
Limitless replicative potentia
Sustained angiogenesis
Ability to invade and metastasis
Ability to evade the host immune response
Solution to Question 2:
Increased conversion of glucose to lactic acid is done via the glycolytic pathway (not HMP).
Even in the presence of ample oxygen, cancer cells demonstrate a distinctive form of cellular metabolism. This is characterized by high levels of glucose uptake and increased conversion of glucose to lactic acid via the glycolytic pathway. This phenomenon is called the Warburg effect.
Aerobic glycolysis provides rapidly dividing tumor cells with metabolic intermediates that are required for the synthesis of cellular components, whereas mitochondrial oxidative phosphor- ylation□ does not.
Solution to Question 3:
P eomorphic adenoma is an example of a mixed tumor consisting of epithelial and myoepithelia cells with or without stromal components.
Adenomas are benign epithelial tumors. They can arise from:
Glandular cells and form glandular structures - for example, follicular adenomas of the thyroid, which arise from the thyroid gland and forms glandular structures
Glandular cells but form non-glandular structures - for example, heterogeneous mass of adrena cortical cells growing as a solid sheet
Non-glandular cells and form glandular structures - for example, benign epithelial neoplasm that arises from renal tubular cells growing in the form of numerous tightly clustered small glands
Solution to Question 4:
Hemangioblastoma is not a small round blue cell tumor.
Hemangioblastomas are tumors of central nervous system that originate from vascular tissues. They demonstrate the proliferation of capillaries with variable sized, closely packed, and thin walled vessels as seen in the image below.

Small round blue cell tumors consist of small round cells that stain blue on routine H&E staining sections. They include:
Neuroblastoma
Retinoblastoma
Ewing's sarcoma
Wilms tumor
Rhabdomyosarcomas
Acute leukemia
The following is the image of neuroblastoma showing Homer-Wright pseudorosettes.

Solution to Question 5:
Hamartomas are disorganized but benign, masses composed of cells indigenous to the involved site.
Examples of hamartoma include:
Mammary hamartoma
Pulmonary chondromatous hamartoma
Splenic hamartoma
Neurocristic hamartoma
Fibrous hamartoma of infancy
Option A: Choristomas are heterotopic rests of cells.
Option D: Teratomas arise from totipotent germ cells. They contain recognizable mature or immature cells or tissues belonging to more than one germ cell layer, and sometimes all three germ layers.
Option C: Papillomas are benign epithelial neoplasms. They are characterized by microscopically or macroscopically visible finger-like or warty projections from epithelial surfaces.
Solution to Question 6:
Anaplasia or lack of differentiation is a characteristic feature of malignant neoplasm like sarcoma.
Differentiation refers to the extent to which neoplastic parenchymal cells resemble the corresponding normal parenchymal cells, both morphologically and functionally.
The image below shows a hepatocellular carcinoma characterized by large anaplastic carcinoma cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm, large hyperchromatic nuclei, and prominent nucleoli. The normal trabecular structure of the liver is distorted.

Solution to Question 7:
The normal nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio is 1:4 to 1:6.
Normal nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio implies that the volume occupied by the cytoplasm is 4 to 6 times greater than the volume occupied by the nucleus.
Abnormal nuclear morphologies that are seen in malignant cells:
Nuclei disproportionately large for the ce
Nuclear shape is variable and often irregular
Chromatin
Coarsely clumped
Hyperchromatic
Nucleoli are abnormally large
Solution to Question 8:
Loss of polarity is a microscopic finding in malignant neoplasm, like metastatic breast cancer.
In malignancy, the orientation of cells is markedly disturbed, and polarity is lost. Sheets or large masses of tumor cells grow in an anarchic, disorganized fashion.
Morphological changes in cancer cells:
Anaplasia
Pleomorphism
Nuclear changes
Nuclei disproportionately large for the ce
Nuclear shape is variable and often irregular
Chromatin - coarsely clumped and hyperchromatic
Nucleoli are abnormally large
Atypical mitosis
Loss of polarity
Solution to Question 9:
Once the tumor cells breach the basement membrane, the tumor is said to be invasive.
Progression of cancer occurs in the following stages: dysplasiacarcinoma in situinvasive carcinoma
In situ carcinoma is when dysplastic changes are marked and involve the full thickness of the epithelium, but the lesion does not penetrate the basement membrane. It is a pre-invasive neoplasm.
The tumor is said to be invasive when the basement membrane is breached by the tumor cells.
Solution to Question 10:
All tumors with invasive property (malignant tumors) may not necessarily metastasize. Examples of tumors with invasive properties but do not metastasize are:
Gliomas
Basal cell carcinomas of the skin
Both of these cancers invade early in their course, but rarely metastasize. Thus, it is evident then that the properties of invasion and metastasis are separable.
Solution to Question 11:
The sentinel lymph node, which is the first node in a regional lymphatic basin that receives lymph flow from the primary tumor, is often used to assess the presence or absence of metastatic lesions in the lymph nodes microscopically.
Sentinel node mapping can be done by the injection of radiolabeled tracers or colored dyes. Examination of frozen sections of the sentinel lymph node is often performed during surgery. It can guide the surgeon to the appropriate therapy.
Sentinel node examination has also been used for detecting the spread of:
Melanomas
Colon cancers

Solution to Question 12:
Thrombospondin is an anti-angiogenic factor.
Angiogenic and antiangiogenic factors are produced by tumor and stromal cells and are essential for the vascularization of tumors.
Angiogenic activators include:
Angiogenin
Interleukin-8
Growth factors:
Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF)
Basic fibroblast growth factor (bFGF)
Transforming growth factor (TGF)- and 
Tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-
Platelet-derived endothelial growth factor
Granulocyte colony-stimulating factor
Placental growth factor
Hepatocyte growth factor
Epidermal growth factor
Anti-angiogenic factors include:
Angiostatin
Endostatin
Interferon
Platelet factor 4
Thrombospondin
Prolactin 16 KD fragment
Tissue inhibitor of metalloproteinase-1, 2, and 3
Solution to Question 13:
Alcohol abuse alone increases the risk of carcinomas of the oropharynx (excluding lip), larynx, and esophagus.
Alcohol and tobacco together synergistically increase the risk of cancers in the upper airway and digestive tract.
Solution to Question 14:
Repeated exposure to benzene is associated with increased risk of acute myeloid leukemia (AML)
Malignancies associated with repeated exposure to benzene:
Acute myeloid leukemia (AML)
Acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL).
Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL).
Multiple myeloma.
Note: While studies have shown that benzene has a propensity to cause bladder carcinoma , it is most commonly associated with AMLs.
Solution to Question 15:
The given clinical history and findings of the gross specimen are suggestive of angiosarcoma of the liver and beryllium is not a risk factor for the development of this tumor.
Angiosarcoma of the liver is associated with exposure to:
Vinyl chloride
Androgenic steroids
Arsenic
Thorotrast
Histological specimen of angiosarcoma of the liver is given below.

Solution to Question 16:
Radon is implicated in the causation of lung carcinoma. Carcinogens implicated in lung carcinoma are:
Asbestos
Arsenic
Beryllium
Chromium
Nicke
Radon.

Opisthorchis viverrini (liver fluke) is implicated in the pathogenesis of cholangiocarcinoma.

Solution to Question 1:
Gliomas show overexpression of PDGF- and TGF-.
Isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH) wild-type glioblastomas are associated with epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) amplification and homozygous CDKN2A deletion.
Solution to Question 2:
Loss of function mutation in RET proto-oncogene is associated with Hirschsprung's disease.
Hirschsprung's disease is caused by mutations in other genes encoding proteins involved in enteric neurodevelopment. These include:
RET ligand glial-derived neurotrophic factor
Endothelin
Endothelin receptor
Note: Medullary thyroid carcinoma and multiple endocrine neoplasias, types 2A and 2B are usually due to gain of function mutations in RET proto-oncogene.
Solution to Question 3:
Anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) is a membrane-bound receptor tyrosine kinase. When aberrantly expressed, it is associated with neuroblastoma pathogenesis. It serves as a therapeutic target.
Neuroblastoma is one of the most common solid cancers among children.
Solution to Question 4:
The given scenario and fundus examination are suggestive of uveal melanoma which is associated with a point mutation of GNAQ protein or GNA11 genes.
Uveal melanomas (UM) originate from melanocytes in the interior wall of the eye. This includes the iris, ciliary body, and the choroid with marked differences in light exposure (from dark anterior to illuminated posterior).
GNAS mutation causes pituitary adenoma and other endocrine tumors.
The 3 RAS genes in humans (H-RAS, K-RAS, and N-RAS) are the most common oncogenes in human cancer. They code for a family of proteins called GTP-binding (G) proteins, which are involved in transmitting signals within cells (cellular signal transduction). When RAS is 'switched on' by incoming signals, it subsequently switches on other proteins, which ultimately results in cell growth, differentiation, and survival.
Mutations in RAS genes can lead to the production of permanently activated RAS proteins. As a result, this can cause unintended and overactive signaling inside the cell, even in the absence of incoming signals. Because these signals result in cell growth and division, overactive RAS signaling can ultimately lead to cancer.
Solution to Question 5:
MYC oncogene codes for nuclear regulatory proteins. It is the most commonly involved transcription factor in tumors.
The MYC proto-oncogene MYC activates the expression of many genes that are involved in cell growth. It upregulates the expression of telomerase and reprograms somatic cells into pluripotent stem cells.
Solution to Question 6:
Translocation of cyclin D1 is seen in mantle cell lymphoma.
Mantle cell lymphoma is an uncommon lymphoid neoplasm that is characterized
by overexpression of cyclin D1. It is a type of non Hodgkins lymphoma that involves (11;14) translocation i.e. between IgH locus on chromosome 14 and the cyclin D1 locus on chromosome 11.
Solution to Question 7:
Retinoblastoma is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait.
Knudson's hypothesis, also known as the two-hit hypothesis or multiple-hit hypothesis states that cancer is the result of accumulated mutations in a cell's DNA. Two mutations (hits), involving both alleles of RB at chromosome locus 13q14, are required to produce retinoblastoma.
In familial cases, children inherit one defective copy of the RB gene in the germline (the first hit), and the other copy is normal. Retinoblastoma develops when the normal RB allele is mutated in retinoblasts as a result of a spontaneous somatic mutation (the second hit). Most individuals inheriting a germline defect in one RB allele develop unilateral or bilateral retinoblastoma as it is an autosomal dominant disease.
Sporadic cases are comparitively rare. In sporadic cases, both normal RB alleles must undergo somatic mutation in the same retinoblast (two hits).
The image given below shows the Knudson's two-hit hypothesis.

Solution to Question 8:
If the retinoblastoma (RB) gene is hypophosphorylated, it is active and the cell cycle will stop at G1.
RB is a cell-cycle regulator because it binds to and inactivates a transcription factor (E2F). This is necessary for the transcription of certain genes necessary for the progression from the G1 to S phase. The phosphorylation of RB results in the release of E2F. This activates gene transcription and cell-cycle progression occurs.
The image given below shows the cell cycle regulation by RB gene.

Solution to Question 9:
P53 is the tumor suppressor gene and activation (not inactivation) causes cell cycle arrest at the G1-S and G2-M phase of the cell cycle.
P53 regulates:
Cell cycle progression
DNA repair
Cellular senescence
Apoptosis
It is activated by:
Anoxia
Inappropriate signaling by mutated oncoproteins
DNA damage
It is the most frequently mutated gene in cancers. It upregulates the expression of proteins such as the cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor p21, thereby causing cell-cycle arrest at the G1-S. It also transactivates and transrepresses target gene to induce G2/M arrest. Mutation in the p53 gene causes resistance in tumors to radiation and chemotherapy.
The E6 protein of human papillomavirus (HPV) binds to and helps in the degradation of p53 and stimulates the expression of telomerase reverse transcriptase (TERT), which is the catalytic subunit of telomerase, thereby helping in the longevity of the cells. E6 from high-risk HPV types has a higher affinity for p53 than E6 from low-risk types.
Li-Fraumeni syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder due to a defect in the tumor suppressor gene P53 located on chromosome 17.
Solution to Question 10:
p63 is essential for the differentiation of stratified squamous epithelia.
p53 is ubiquitously expressed, while p63 and p73 show more tissue specificity.
p73 has strong pro-apoptotic effects after DNA damage induced by chemotherapeutic agents.
Solution to Question 11:
The given scenario is suggestive of Cowden syndrome. This condition is caused due to germline loss of function mutation in PTEN (phosphatase and tensin homolog) gene.
PTEN is a membrane-associated phosphatase encoded by a gene on chromosome 10q23 that is mutated.
Cowden syndrome is characterized by skin appendage tumors and an increased incidence of epithelial cancers, particularly of the breast, endometrium, and thyroid.
Solution to Question 12:
The given scenario and MRI findings are suggestive of neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF-2). Merlin protein is mutated in NF-2, sporadic schwannomas, and meningiomas.
Cells lacking Merlin do not establish stable cell-to-cell junctions. They are insensitive to normal growth arrest signals generated by cell-to-cell contact.
Solution to Question 13:
Germline loss-of-function mutations of the PTCH1 gene cause Gorlin syndrome. Gorlin syndrome is an autosomal-dominant disorder. Clinical features include:
Multiple basal cell carcinomas
Highly characteristic facies - large forehead
Bifid or misshapen ribs
Vertebral and other skeletal anomalies
Pits of the skin of the palms and soles
Dysgenesis of the corpus callosum
Calcification of the falx cerebri - at an earlier age than is seen in non■affected individuals
Macrocephaly
Acquired biallelic loss-of-function mutations of PTCH1 cause sporadic basal cell carcinomas and medulloblastoma.
Solution to Question 14:
The given scenario is suggestive of Peutz–Jeghers syndrome.
Loss-of-function mutations of STK11 cause the Peutz–Jeghers syndrome. The STK22 gene, also known as LKB1, encodes a serine/threonine kinase that is an important regulator of cellular metabolism.
Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal-dominant disorder. It is associated with arborizing polyps of the gastrointestinal tract (small intestine > colon > stomach). It increases the risk of multiple epithelial cancers, particularly of colon, breast, lung, pancreas, and thyroid.
Solution to Question 15:
The given scenario is suggestive of lobular carcinoma of the breast which involves mutated E-cadherin protein. In this condition, the histopathological examination shows infiltrating small monomorphic discohesive tumor cells arranged in
an Indian-file or single-file pattern.
The image below shows the single file pattern seen in lobular carcinoma of the breast.

Reduced cell surface expression of E-cadherin is seen in carcinomas of:
Breast
Esophagus
Colon
Ovary
Prostate
E-cadherin is a cell-surface protein that maintains intercellular adhesiveness. Loss of E-cadherin causes disaggregation of cells, which can then invade locally or metastasize.
Germline loss-of-function mutations of the E-cadherin gene lead to familial gastric
carcinoma. Sporadic gastric carcinomas are also associated with the loss of E-cadherin expression.
Solution to Question 16:
BRCA2 (not BRCA 1) mutation causes well-differentiated cancer.
Solution to Question 17:
The intrinsic apoptotic pathway is most frequently disabled in cancer cells to evade cell death.
p53 is an important pro-apoptotic protein that induces apoptosis in cells that are unable to repair DNA damage.
Chemotherapy and radiation therapy kills cancer cells mainly by inducing apoptosis via the intrinsic pathway.
In greater than 85% of follicular B-cell lymphomas, the anti-apoptotic gene BCL2 is overexpressed due to a (14;18) translocation.
Solution to Question 18:
SNAIL and TWIST, which encode transcription factors, promote epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT).
In EMT, carcinoma cells downregulate certain epithelial markers (e.g., E-cadherin) and upregulate certain mesenchymal markers (e.g. vimentin and smooth muscle actin). This favors the development of a promigratory phenotype that is essential for metastasis. EMT has been documented mainly in breast carcinoma.
Solution to Question 19:
ABL is a non-receptor tyrosine kinase.
Tyrosine kinases may be receptors and non-receptors.
Nonreceptor tyrosine kinases normally localize to the cytoplasm or the nucleus. These are:
ABL - translocation causes CML and point mutation causes ALL
JAK mutation - seen in polycythemia vera, essential thrombocythemia, and myelofibrosis as we as other myeloproliferative disorders
Receptor tyrosine kinases:
VEGFR
PDGFR
EGFR
In chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) and some acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), the ABL gene is translocated from its normal abode on chromosome 9 to chromosome 22 where it fuses with the BCR gene forming the Philadelphia chromosome. The resultant chimeric gene encodes a constitutively active, oncogenic BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase.
Solution to Question 20:
Enhancer deletion does not convert a proto-oncogene to an oncogene. Mechanisms of activating oncogenes:
Mechanism
Activation of oncogenes
Mutation
Mutation activates the gene. A classic example is the point mutation of the RAS oncoge ne.
Promoter insertion
Insertion of a viral promoter region near a gene activates i t.
Enhancer insertion
Insertion of a viral enhancer region near a gene activates i t.
Chromosomal translocati on
One chromosome is split off and joined to another. An ex ample is the Philadelphia chr omosome.
Gene amplification
Abnormal multiplication of a gene resulting in many copie
s. This can occur with oncoge nes and genes involved in tu mor drug resistance.
Solution to Question 21:
RAS is an oncogene that undergoes mutation and serves as a tumor antigen.
Tumor cells express antigenic molecules on their surface that elicit an immune response. These are called tumor antigens. Some tumor cells evade immune response which results in growth of the tumor.
Solution to Question 22:
Inhibition of PD-1 receptor (programmed death -1 receptor) on T cells causes activation of immunity against the tumor cells, not evasion.
PD-1 receptors present on T cells inhibit T-cell activation. This allows tumors to evade the host immunity by the upregulation of the expression of factors like PD-L1 and PD-L2, which act on PD-1 receptors.
Solution to Question 23:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of xeroderma pigmentosum. It is caused by a defect in the DNA nucleotide excision repair pathway resulting in inability to repair pyrimidine dimers.
Clinical features of xeroderma pigmentosum:
Actinic keratosis
Hyperkeratotic lesions
Multiple lentigos
ùerosis
Corneal scarring
The image of a child with xeroderma pigmentosum is given below.

Solution to Question 24:
Fanconi syndrome is not associated with defective homologous recombination DNA repair mechanism. It is a rare disorder of kidney tubule function.
Diseases with defects in DNA repair by homologous recombination:
Bloom syndrome and ataxia–telangiectasia triggered by DNA-damaging agents such as ionizing radiation
Fanconi anemia is an autosomal recessive disease caused by mutations in multiple genes responsible for coding for proteins that participate in DNA repair pathways and are triggered by DNA-crosslinking agents like chemotherapeutic drugs.
Familial breast cancer is due to inherited gene defects in BRCA1 and BRCA 2 genes
Solution to Question 25:
The given clinical history and biopsy findings are suggestive of Burkitt lymphoma and the translocation involved is t(8;14).
Burkitt lymphoma, also known as small non-cleaved-cell lymphoma, is a highly aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma. It is characterized by the translocation and deregulation of the c-myc gene on chromosome 8.
The classic t(8;14)(q24;q32) reciprocal translocation results in the transposition of the c-myc proto-oncogene on chromosome 8 with one of the immunoglobulin heavy chain (IGH) genes on chromosome 14. This results in activation of the c-myc gene and is considered responsible for tumor proliferation.

Solution to Question 26:
MLL2 is an epigenomic regulatory gene that is mutated in most follicular lymphomas. It results in histone methylation.
Epigenetics refers to factors other than the sequence of DNA that regulate gene expression. These factors involved in epigenetics are:
Histone modifications
DNA methylation
Nucleosome positioning/ chromatin remodeling
Solution to Question 27:
The loss of miR-15 leads to upregulation of the anti-apoptotic protein BCL-2.
miR-15 and miR-16 are tumor-suppressive miRNAs involved in chronic lymphocytic leukemia
(CLL).
Onco-miRNAs include:
miR200 - promotes epithelial-mesenchymal transitions that promote tumor invasion and metastasis
miR155 - involved in human B-cell lymphomas
Solution to Question 28:
Anti-CTLA-4 antibody ipilimumab was the first drug to achieve a significant improvement in survival of advanced-stage melanoma. Cytotoxic T lymphocyte antigen 4 (CTLA-4) plays an important inhibitory role in the control of T-cell activation.
Ipilimumab is a fully-humanized IgG1 monoclonal antibody that inhibits cytotoxic T lymphocyte antigen-4 (CTLA-4).
It has been postulated that anti-CTLA-4 antibodies act by blocking inhibitory signals from effector T-cells, allowing costimulatory signaling and generation of antitumor T-cell responses. In vitro studies demonstrated also that the antitumor activity of CTLA-4 blockade is mediated by Fc gamma receptor-expressing macrophage and hypothesized a possible role of regulatory T-cell depletion in the tumor microenvironment.
Option B - Mutation of tumor supressor genes is associated with increased risk of cancer. Antigen toxicity is when the immune response to an antigen is excessive or misdirected, causing damage to tissues or organs.
Option C - PD1/PDL1 is an immune checkpoint whose activation inhibits T-cell function and helps with immune tolerance. Blocking PD-1/PD-L1 interaction using immune checkpoint inhibitors reactivates T cells and enhances immune responses against tumors.
Option D - CD28 is primarily involved in providing the second signal required for T ce activation. The first signal comes from the interaction between the T cell receptor (TCR) and the antigen presented by the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) on antigen-presenting cells (APCs). Without CD28-mediated costimulation, T cells that only receive the TCR signal (without the second signal) can become anergic.

Direct-acting carcinogens require no metabolic conversion to become carcinogenic. Most are weak carcinogens, but some are important because they are cancer chemotherapeutic drugs (e.g.,
alkylating agents). The direct-acting carcinogens include:

Solution to Question 4:
UVB (ultraviolet B) causes cutaneous cancers due to the formation of pyrimidine dimers in DNA.
When DNA absorbs energy from UVB, there is a covalent crosslinking of pyrimidine bases and distortion of the DNA helix. This prevents proper pairing of the dimer with bases in the opposite DNA strand.
Normally, these defects are repaired by nucleotide excision repair pathway. Defects in nucleotide excision repair pathway result in xeroderma pigmentosum.

Note: UVC is the most potent mutagen but is not considered significant as it is filtered out by the ozone layer.
