Individuals with repeated exposure to ionizing radiation are at increased risk of myeloid leukemia. Carcinogenic radiations include:
Electromagnetic radiation -
›-rays
 rays
Particulate radiation -
 particles
 particles
Protons
Neutrons
Cancers due to ionizing radiation:
Most frequent - myeloid leukemia and thyroid cancer
Intermediate frequency - cancers of breast, lungs, and salivary glands
Relatively resistant cancers - cancers of skin, bone, and gastrointestinal tract
Solution to Question 6:
Adenocarcinoma carcinoma of the lung is not associated with microbial etiopathogenesis. It is associated with smoking and genetic predispositions.
Solution to Question 7:
Human T-cell leukemia-lymphoma virus (HTLV-1) causes adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma
(ATLL).
HTLV-1 encodes the viral protein Tax, which leads to polyclonal expansion of T cells. It exhibits tropism for CD4+ T cells.
Human infection requires transmission of infected T cells through sexual intercourse, blood products or breast feeding. Leukemia develops only in 3-5% of infected individuals, typically after a long latent period of 40-60 years.
Solution to Question 8:
The target genes for viral oncoproteins of human papilloma virus (HPV) are as follows:
E6 - p53
E7 - RB
The image given below shows the functions of the E6 and E7 oncoproteins of HPV.

Solution to Question 9:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of infectious mononucleosis caused by Epstein-Barr virus. This virus is not implicated in follicular lymphoma.
Epstein–Barr virus (EBV), a member of the herpesvirus family, has been implicated in:
African form of Burkitt lymphoma
B-cell lymphomas in immunosuppressed
A subset of Hodgkin lymphoma
Nasopharyngeal carcinoma
Gastric carcinoma - most common EBV associated malignancy
T-cell lymphoma and natural killer (NK) cell lymphoma
Solution to Question 10:
Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection does not always result in Burkitt lymphoma.
EBV infection is highly prevalent even in areas where Burkitt lymphoma is not found. It commonly causes infectious mononucleosis.
EBV uses the complement receptor CD21 to attach to and infect B cells. EBV genome triggers B-cell signaling pathways inducing B-cell growth and transformation.
The infection of B cells is latent as there is no viral replication and the cells are not
killed. However, B cells latently infected with EBV express viral proteins that result in the ability to propagate indefinitely in vitro. In the absence of T-cell immunity, EBV-infected B cells can rapidly grow out as aggressive B-cell tumors.
Solution to Question 11:
Human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8) is a gamma-herpesvirus associated with Kaposi sarcoma, multicentric Castleman disease, and primary effusion lymphoma.
They are lymphoproliferative diseases that are most commonly observed in immunocompromised individuals. The viral genome expresses genes responsible for inhibition of apoptosis, cell cycle entry, and angiogenesis.
Solution to Question 12:
The given clinical scenario and histopathological image showing follicular hyperplasia of lymph nodes are suggestive of Castleman disease.
Castleman disease (angiofollicular lymph node hyperplasia) is a lymphoproliferative disorder that can be associated with HHV-8 (multicentric Castleman disease or MCD) or idiopathic (unicentric Castleman disease or UCD)
There are 3 major histological subtypes:
Hypervascular (UCD) -
Lollipop appearance - atrophic germinal centers with radially penetrating blood vessels
Onion skin appearance of mantle zone around germinal centers
Plasma cell subtype (UCD or MCD) - hypertrophic germinal centers, increased vascularity
Mixed variant (MCD) - mix of hypervascular and plasma cell subtype features in the same lymph node
The clinical features include:
Multiple enlarged lymph nodes
Night sweats
Weight loss
Weakness and fatigue
Hepatosplenomegaly
As this condition is associated with elevated levels of IL-6, the treatment involves IL-6 inhibitors like siltuximab and tocilizumab.
Note: Hodgkin's lymphoma has characteristic Reed-Sternberg cells in the histopathological section of lymph nodes.
Solution to Question 13:
LMP-1 is an EBV oncogene that behaves like a constitutively active CD40 receptor.
The CD40 receptor-like activity stimulates B-cell growth. LMP-1 activates the NF-B and JAK / STAT signaling pathways and promotes B-cell survival. It also prevents apoptosis by activating BCL2.
Solution to Question 14:
Helicobacter pylori is implicated in the following conditions:
Peptic ulcer
Gastric adenocarcinoma - preceded by chronic gastritis, gastric atrophy, intestinal metaplasia, and dysplasia
MALT lymphoma of the stomach - through polyclonal B cell proliferation Helicobacter pylori is protective for:
Barrett's esophagus
Adenocarcinoma of esophagus
Solution to Question 15:
Cushing syndrome is the most common endocrinopathy caused by tumors.
Endocrinopathy refers to ectopic hormone production by non-endocrine tumors. Approximately, 50% of the individuals with Cushing syndrome as endocrinopathy have carcinoma of the lung, chiefly the small-cell type.
Hypercalcemia is the most common paraneoplastic syndrome. Cancer-associated hypercalcemia occurs due to:
Osteolysis induced by cancer - due to primary or secondary involvement of the skeleton by tumor
Production of calcemic humoral substances by extraosseous neoplasms - for example, parathyroid hormone-related protein. Only this mechanism is considered to be paraneoplastic.
Solution to Question 16:
Thymoma often presents with pure red cell aplasia as a paraneoplastic manifestation.
Thymomas are unusual neoplasms of thymic epithelial tissue, ranging from small indolent tumors to aggressive thymic carcinomas.
Pure red cell aplasia is a rare cause of anemia, caused by the absence of RBC precursors in the bone marrow. Causes of pure red cell aplasia include:
Neoplasms - thymomas and large granular lymphocytic leukemia
Drug exposure - phenytoin, azathioprine, and isoniazid
Auto-immune disorders - neutralizing antibodies against erythropoietin
Parvovirus infection
Hereditary - Diamond Blackfan syndrome
Solution to Question 17:
Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) as a paraneoplastic syndrome is most commonly associated with acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) and prostatic adenocarcinoma.
Major determinants of coagulopathy in APL are endogenous factors of the malignant leukemic cells and their interaction with host defense mechanisms.
Factors that cause coagulopathy include:
Increased expression of procoagulant activity (PCA)
Expression of fibrinolytic and proteolytic properties
Secretion of pro-inflammatory cytokines - interleukin-1b (IL-1b) and tumor necrosis factor (TNF)
Solution to Question 18:
The given clinical history is suggestive of hypertrophic osteoarthropathy. It is commonly associated with bronchiogenic carcinoma.
Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy is characterised by the following:
Periosteal new bone formation, primarily at the distal ends of long bones, metatarsals, metacarpals, and proximal phalanges
Arthritis of the adjacent joints
Clubbing of the digits
Solution to Question 19:
The given clinical history and laboratory investigations are suggestive of hypercalcemia. It is associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the lung.
Tumors associated with paraneoplastic hypercalcemia:
Breast carcinoma
Lung carcinoma
Renal cell carcinoma
Ovarian carcinoma
Solution to Question 20:
Phosphaturic mesenchymal tumor presents with osteomalacia as a paraneoplastic manifestation. Phosphaturic mesenchymal tumor is caused due to mutation of the FGF-23 gene.
Solution to Question 21:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of acanthosis nigricans. It is not associated with thymoma.
Acanthosis nigricans is a disorder characterized by gray-black patches of thickened, hyperkeratotic skin with a velvety appearance. The causal mechanism is immunologic due to secretion of epidermal growth factor.
Acanthosis nigricans is commonly associated with:
Gastric carcinoma
Lung carcinoma
Gynecological cancers
Breast carcinoma
Bladder carcinoma
Gallbladder and bile-duct carcinoma
Acromegaly and gigantism
Dermatomyositis
Diabetes
Hashimoto thyroiditis
Lupus erythematosus
Phenylketonuria
Polycystic ovary syndrome
Systemic sclerosis
Wilson syndrome
Solution to Question 22:
The given clinical history and laboratory investigations are suggestive of polycythemia which is not seen in melanoma as a paraneoplastic manifestation.
Polycythemia, as a paraneoplastic syndrome, is mediated by erythropoietin (EPO). EPO is a glycoprotein that induces differentiation of erythrocyte colony-forming units in the bone marrow
to promote red blood cell production.
Under normal physiological conditions, EPO is produced by peritubular renal interstitial cells in response to local tissue hypoxia. However, in tumors, EPO production occurs in the neoplastic cells themselves.
Solution to Question 23:
Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) is associated with small cell carcinoma of lung.
Solution to Question 24:
The given clinical presentation is suggestive of migratory thrombophlebitis (Trousseau syndrome) and it is not associated with bladder carcinoma.
Trousseau syndrome may be encountered in association with deep-seated cancers, most often carcinomas of the pancreas or lung. It is caused by hypercoagulability leading to multiple repeated venous thromboembolism.
Malignant brain tumors, hematological malignancies, and adenocarcinomas of the pancreas, stomach, ovary, uterus, lungs, and kidneys are at the highest risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE) development.
Advanced, metastatic cancer has been shown to be associated with an increased risk of VTE compared with localized tumors.
Solution to Question 25:
The serum levels of catecholamines are elevated in malignant pheochromocytoma. Extra-adrenal location is the only criteria for malignancy in pheochromocytoma.
Pheochromocytoma is a rare catecholamine-secreting tumor that may precipitate life-threatening hypertension. It is classically associated with three syndromes:
von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome
Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN 2)
Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1)
Catecholamines produced by pheochromocytomas are metabolized within chromaffin cells. Norepinephrine is metabolized to normetanephrine, and epinephrine is metabolized to metanephrine. Because this process occurs within the tumor, independent of catecholamine release, pheochromocytomas are best diagnosed by the measurement of these metabolites, rather than by measurement of the parent catecholamines.
Solution to Question 26:
A pha-fetoprotein (AFP) and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) are oncofetal antigens.
A pha-fetoprotein is a valuable clinical aid in diagnosis, prognosis, and monitoring of the following tumors:
Primary hepatocellular carcinoma
Hepatoblastoma
Non-seminomatous testicular germ cell tumors
Embryonal carcinoma
Teratomas
Choriocarcinoma
Yolk sac carcinoma
Germ cell tumors of the ovary and extragonadal germ cell tumors
Regenerated hepatic tissue following liver damage due to viral hepatitis, chemically induced necrosis, and liver surgery are associated with moderately raised serum AFP levels.
Carcinoembryonic antigen is normally detected in glycocalyx of fetal epithelial cells. It is useful in detection, assessing recurrence, and prognosis of the following tumors:
Adenocarcinoma of lung
Colorectal carcinoma
CEA levels >5 ng/dL are noted in ascites fluid associated with malignancy. Canalicular pattern for polyclonal CEA more sensitive for hepatocellular carcinoma, metastases in pancreatic adenocarcinoma and not sensitive for metastasis in bile duct adenoma.
Elevated levels are also present in the following non-neoplastic conditions:
Cirrhosis
Biliary obstruction
Hepatitis
Inflammatory bowel disease
Smokers
Post-surgical bowel sequestration
Mucocele
Benign cysts may be positive for carcinoembryonic antigen
Solution to Question 27:
The level of cancer antigen 15-3 (CA 15-3) is elevated in patients with breast cancer.
The reference range of serum CA 15-3 is less than 30 U/mL. It is used to monitor response to breast cancer treatment and disease recurrence.
Solution to Question 28:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of small cell carcinoma of the lung (SCLC) in which levels of neuron-specific enolase (NSE) are elevated.
NSE is also called gamma enolase or enolase 2 (ENO2) and is encoded by ENO2 gene. It is a phosphopyruvate hydratase that is produced by small-cell lung carcinomas, which are neuroendocrine in origin. Their levels have been implicated as a prognostic factor for patients with small-cell lung cancer.
Solution to Question 29:
NRG-1 (Neuregulin-1) is not a marker for gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs).
GIST are the most common mesenchymal tumor of the abdomen, the stomach being the most common site. They arise from the interstitial cells of Cajal, the pacemaker cells of the GIT. GIST is seen in the 5th to 6th decade of life and has an equal preponderance among males and females.
Most patients present with haematemesis, melena, or vague abdominal pain. The most common indications for surgery include bleeding and obstruction.
The GIST may occur in a sporadic form or as part of familial syndromes. In sporadic GIST, the most common mutations seen are gain-of-function mutation in KIT (75-80%) and PDGFRA mutation (8%). Microscopically, GIST has elongated spindle cells or plumper epithelioid cells, or a mixed pattern.
The below image shows the microscopy of GIST composed of bundles, or fascicles, of spindle-shaped tumor cells.

Succinate dehydrogenase (SDH)-deficient GIST is a subset of wild-type GIST seen with Carney triad or Carney-Stratakis syndrome.
Imatinib can be used to treat GIST with mutations in KIT or PDGFRA. Succinate dehydrogenase (SDH) - deficient GIST is imatinib-resistant, so sunitinib, sorafenib, or regorafenib can be used instead.
During surgical resection of GIST, care must be taken to prevent capsule rupture, which causes seeding of nearby tissues leading to relapse in 100% of the cases. If capsule rupture occurs, adjuvant therapy with imatinib is indicated regardless of tumor extent.
Other options:
Option A: KIT (CD117): This is the most well-known marker for GISTs. About 85% of GISTs show mutations in the KIT gene, leading to the expression of the KIT protein on the cell surface. KIT is a receptor tyrosine kinase, and its activation is a key driver in the pathogenesis of GISTs.
Option B: SDH (Succinate Dehydrogenase): SDH mutations are associated with a subset of GISTs, particularly those that are KIT and PDGFRA wild-type. Loss of SDH function is characteristic of this subgroup, and SDH deficiency can be demonstrated through immunohistochemistry.
Option C: PDGFRA (Platelet-Derived Growth Factor Receptor Alpha): Mutations in the PDGFRA gene account for approximately 5-10% of GISTs. Similar to KIT, PDGFRA is a receptor tyrosine kinase, and mutations in this gene can lead to the development of GISTs.

Solution to Question 1:
B cell is not a component of innate immunity. It is a component of adaptive immunity.
Innate immunity refers to the body’s natural immunity. It is a built-in defence system that is present since birth. It differs from adaptive immunity in that it does not require any prior sensitization to an antigen.
The major components of innate immunity are as follows:
Epithelial barriers that block the entry of microbes
Phagocytic cells (neutrophils and macrophages)
Natural killer (NK) cells
Dendritic ce
Cells that can sense and react to microbes - mast cells, epithelial and endothelial cells
Plasma proteins - complement system factors, mannose-binding lectin, and C-reactive protein
Innate lymphoid cells
Lung surfactant

Interferon regulatory factors - stimulate the production of the antiviral cytokines like type I interferons
The image given below shows a toll-like receptor.

Solution to Question 3:
Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC) is mediated by NK cells, neutrophils and eosinophils (killing certain parasitic worms like helminths via IgE antibodies).
In ADCC, cells/ antigens are coated with IgG antibodies. These are killed by effector cells like NK cells and macrophages. These effector cells bind to the target by their receptors for the Fc fragment of IgG and cell lysis proceeds without phagocytosis.
Solution to Question 4:
The gain of function mutations in NOD-Like receptors (NLRs) result in periodic fever syndromes called autoinflammatory syndromes.
They are a group of clinical conditions characterised by recurrent inflammatory episodes. This disorder is marked by abnormally increased inflammation, mediated predominantly by cells and molecules of the innate immune system, with a significant host predisposition.
NOD-like receptors are cytosolic receptors that signal via a cytosolic multiprotein complex called the inflammasome. This activates caspase-1 that generates biologically active form of interleukin-1 (IL-1). IL-1 is a mediator of inflammation that recruits leukocytes and induces fever. The autoinflammatory syndromes respond very well to treatment with IL-1 antagonists.
Note: Autoimmune diseases result from T and B-lymphocyte reactions against self-antigens.
Solution to Question 5:
Normal CD4+: CD8+ T lymphocyte ratio is 2:1. Approximately 60% of mature T cells are CD4+ and about 30% are CD8+.
T-lymphocytes (thymus-derived cells) constitute 60–70% of peripheral blood lymphocytes. T-cell progenitors are derived from the bone marrow, but travel to the thymus, where they mature. T cells can be divided into three main subtypes:
They are located in the paracortical areas of lymph nodes and the periarteriolar sheaths of the spleen. They have an antigen-specific T-cell receptors (TCR) which have alpha/beta
polypeptide chains components. Demonstration of TCR gene rearrangement by southern blot is a molecular marker of T-cell lineage.
The CD molecules present on T cells are CD1, CD2, CD3, CD4, CD5, CD7, CD8 and CD28. CD3 is involved in signal transduction and is also called a pan T-cell marker. CD40 ligand on the surface is required for B-cell activation and induction of immunoglobulin.

Solution to Question 6:
CD86 is a protein expressed on antigen-presenting cells, and not B-cell receptor complex. This protein provides costimulatory signals necessary for T-cell activation and survival.
B-cell receptor complex expresses the following:
CD79a and CD79b - essential for signal transduction through the antigen receptor
CD21 or CR2 - complement receptor (recognize complement products during innate immune response) and Epstein–Barr virus (EBV) receptor
CD40 - receives signals from helper T cells
Other B cell-associated markers are CD10 (CALLA), CD19, CD20, CD22, CD23.
Solution to Question 7:
Dendritic cells or interdigitating dendritic cells are the most important antigen-presenting cells. They initiate T-cell responses against protein antigens.
They are located in the epithelium and interstitium. They express many receptors for capturing and responding to microbes (and other antigens), including toll-like receptors (TLRs) and lectins. They also express high levels of major histocompatibility complex (MHC) for presenting antigens to and activating T cells.
In response to microbes, dendritic cells are recruited to the T-cell zones of lymphoid organs. Here, they present antigens to T cells with help of MHC.
Similar cells with dendritic morphology in the germinal centers of lymphoid follicles in the spleen and lymph nodes are follicular dendritic cells. They bear Fc receptors for IgG and receptors for C3b. Immature dendritic cells within the epidermis are called Langerhans cells.
Note:
Aggretope - part of the antigen associated with the MHC molecule on the antigen-presenting ce
Epitope - antigenic part of contact with the T-cell receptor
Solution to Question 8:
Macrophages are components of both innate and acquired immunity.
They phagocytose microbes and protein antigens. They process the antigens and present the peptide fragments to T cells. Thus, macrophages function as antigen-presenting cells in T-cell activation.
They also participate in the effector phase of humoral immunity. Macrophages efficiently phagocytose and destroy microbes that are opsonized (coated) with IgG or C3b.
They are key effector cells in certain forms of cell-mediated immunity to eliminate intracellular microbes. In this type of response, T cells activate macrophages and enhance their ability to kill ingested microbes.
Solution to Question 9:
IL-2 and IL-15 stimulate the proliferation of NK cells. On the other hand, IL-12 activates the killing of target cells and secretion of IFN-.
NK cells are large granular lymphocytes, which constitutes 5% to 10% of peripheral blood lymphocytes. CD16 and CD56 are the surface molecules.
Functions of NK cells:
Killing of a variety of virus-infected cells and tumor cells, without prior exposure to or activation by these microbes or tumors
Secretion of interferon- (IFN-), which activates macrophages to destroy ingested microbes
Antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity (ADCC) - NK cells express CD16 which is a receptor for IgG Fc tails. Hence, these cells have the ability to lyse IgG-coated target cells.
ADCC is also seen in immune responses involving neutrophils, eosinophils, macrophages, etc. The image given below shows activating and inhibitory receptors of natural killer (NK) cells.

Note: A new group of T cells has been discovered called NK-T cells. These are T cells that contain markers of NK cells. These are important defence mechanisms against microorganisms like Listeria monocytogenes and Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
Solution to Question 10:
Both cytotoxic T-cells and NK cells are effective against virus-infected cells. The NK cells have different mechanisms of action while killing target cells.
NK cells can lyse IgG-coated target cells by binding to the Fc tail of IgG, through the CD16 receptor expressed on NK cells. This phenomenon is known as antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC).
NK cells secrete various cytokines such as interferon- (IFN-), which activate macrophages to destroy ingested microbes.
Target cell destruction by NK cells is also mediated through two others receptors - activating receptors and inhibitory receptors.
The activating receptors enable NK cells to recognize infected and stressed cells. The inhibitory receptors recognize self class-I MHC molecules, that are expressed on all healthy cells thereby preventing NK cells from killing normal cells. Virus infection / neoplastic transformation overexpresses the activating receptors and simultaneously reduces the expression of class-I MHC molecules. As a result, NK cells are activated and the infected cells are killed.

Solution to Question 11:
CD80 (B7-1) and CD86 (B7-2) are the costimulatory molecules present on antigen-presenting cells
(APCs). They bind to CD28 protein present on T cells. This promotes the expansion of antigen-stimulated T cells and their differentiation into effector and memory cells.
T-cell activation requires two signals that are delivered by APCs. They include:
Antigens displayed by APCs in the form of peptides bound to MHC molecules, that are recognised by T-cell receptors
Costimulatory signal (as it stimulates T cells in conjunction with antigen) provided by molecules on APCs that engage particular costimulatory receptors on T cells
In the absence of costimulation, T cells that recognize antigen either fail to respond and die or enter a state of unresponsiveness known as anergy. Thus, costimulation is a key determinant of the outcome of a T-cell encounter with an antigen.

Solution to Question 12:
IL-4 induces T helper 2 cells. Mechanism of cell-mediated immunity:
Antigen-presenting cells  recognized by naive CD4+ T cells  IL-2 secretion  T-ce proliferation and differentiation  activated CD4+ T helper cells
Activated CD4+ T cells further differentiate into effector cells that secrete different sets of cytokines and perform different functions
Solution to Question 13:
IL-4 stimulates B-cells to differentiate into IgE secreting plasma cells.
Solution to Question 14:
Polysaccharides and lipids stimulate the secretion of mainly IgM antibodies.
B lymphocytes use their antigen receptors to recognize various types of antigens:
Proteins (through CD40L and cytokine-mediated helper T-cell actions) - induce production of IgG, IgA, IgE
Polysaccharides and lipids - induce production of IgM mainly Helper T cells also help in antibodies by the mechanisms:
Stimulate formation of germinal centers which consist of proliferating B cells
Induce isotype switching through cytokines IFN- and IL-4
Affinity maturation - stimulate the production of antigen-specific antibodies Isotype switching and affinity maturation occur mainly in germinal centers.
Solution to Question 15:
When papain acts on a molecule of immunoglobulin, the end products are 1 Fc and 2 Fab fragments.
If an antibody molecule is digested with papain, cleavage occurs above the disulfide bonds that hold the heavy chains together. This generates 3 separate fragments, two of which are called Fab (fragment antigen binding), and one of which is called Fc (fragment crystallizable).
The image given below shows the cleavage of immunoglobulin by papain.

Cleavage of the antibody molecule with pepsin generates one large fragment called F(ab´)2 and a digested Fc fragment.
The image given below shows the cleavage of immunoglobulin by pepsin.

Solution to Question 16:
Lymphocyte recirculation is seen in T lymphocytes.
Migration of the lymphocytes between blood and lymphoid organs is called recirculation. Naive lymphocytes traverse the peripheral lymphoid organs, where immune responses are
initiated. When antigen-presenting cells activate them, the effector lymphocytes migrate to sites of infection and inflammation.
In contrast, plasma cells remain in lymphoid organs and the bone marrow. They do not need to migrate to sites of infection because they secrete antibodies that are carried to distant tissues.
Solution to Question 17:
■ T-cells do not need antigen processing and presentation for its recognition. There are two types of T cells: ■ T-cells and  T-cells.
The functions of ■ T-cells:
Provide protection against mycobacteria by direct killing of infected macrophages
Kills extracellular bacteria by granulysin and perforin
Plays a role in maintaining self-tolerance
Capable of recognising and lysing diverse cancers in an MHC-unrestricted manner
 T-cells have MHC restricted action.
Solution to Question 18:
Basophils are activated by IL-5 and IL-3. Note: IL-5 primarily activates eosinophils.
Solution to Question 19:
Class II major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules are mainly expressed
on macrophages, B lymphocytes, and dendritic cells. These cells present ingested antigens to T-cells.
The function of MHC molecules is to display peptide fragments of protein antigens for recognition by antigen-specific T cells. In humans, the MHC molecules are called human leukocyte antigens (HLA) because they were initially detected on leukocytes by the binding of antibodies. The combination of HLA alleles in each individual is called the HLA haplotype.
The genes encoding HLA molecules are clustered on the short arm of chromosome 6. Uses of MHC/ HLA typing include:
Anthropology
Transfusion
Paternity testing
Forensic science
Transplantation
Disease correlation
Solution to Question 20:
 2 microglobulin associated cell surface molecules are encoded by MHC class I and not class III. Class III MHC molecules include:
Complement proteins (such as C2, C4, and B factor)
Cytokines (such as TNF-, LTA, and LTB)
Properdin factor BQ of alternate pathway
Enzyme tyrosine hydroxylase
Heat-shock proteins
Class III molecules are encoded by genes located between those that encode class I and class II molecules.
Hypersensitivity and Autoimmunity

question_text:
d
Solution to Question 1:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of anaphylaxis following a bee sting. This is an example of IgE-mediated reaction or type 1 hypersensitivity.
Injurious immune reactions are called hypersensitivity reactions. There are four types of hypersensitivity reactions.
Immediate (Type 1) hypersensitivity is also called allergic reactions. They are induced by environmental antigens (allergens) that stimulate strong TH2 responses and IgE production in genetically susceptible individuals.
IgE coats mast cells by binding to Fcg receptors. Reexposure to the allergen leads to cross-linking of the IgE and FcRI, activation of mast cells, and release of mediators. The principal mediators are histamine, proteases, and other granule contents like prostaglandins and leukotrienes
and cytokines.
It occurs in two phases: immediate phase and late phase. The mediators are responsible for the immediate vascular and smooth muscle reactions and the late-phase reaction (inflammation). The clinical manifestations may be local or systemic and range from mildly annoying rhinitis to fatal anaphylaxis.
The image given below shows the sequence of events in immediate hypersensitivity.

Solution to Question 2:
Arthus reaction is characterized by a localized area of tissue necrosis due to immune-complex-mediated (type III hypersensitivity reaction) vasculitis in the skin.
This reaction can be produced experimentally by intracutaneous injection of antigen in a previously immunised animal that contains circulating antibodies against the antigen. As the antigen diffuses into the vessel wall, it binds with the preformed antibody, and immune complexes are formed locally. These complexes precipitate in the vessel walls and cause fibrinoid necrosis.
Solution to Question 3:
The given clinical condition is highly suggestive of myasthenia gravis. It is an example of a type II hypersensitivity reaction.
Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disease that is usually associated with autoantibodies directed against acetylcholine receptors. In Type II hypersensitivity, antibodies react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause. These
antibodies destroy cells, trigger inflammation, or interfering with normal functions.
Solution to Question 4:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nephritic syndrome due to post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. This is an example of a type III hypersensitivity reaction.
In type III hypersensitivity, immune complexes may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement. The pathogenesis of systemic immune
complex disease can be divided into three phases:
Formation of immune complexes
Deposition of immune complexes
Inflammation and tissue injury
This results in various manifestations like vasculitis, glomerulonephritis and arthritis. Examples of type III hypersensitivity reactions:
Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis
Systemic lupus erythematosus
Reactive arthritis
Polyarteritis nodosa
Serum sickness
Arthus reaction
Farmer’s lung
Hypersensitivity pneumonitis
Type II lepra reaction
Henoch–Schonlein purpura
The image given below shows the mechanism of type III hypersensitivity reactions.

Solution to Question 5:
The given clinical scenario shows a positive tuberculin test. It is a classical example of type IV or delayed or cell-mediated hypersensitivity reaction.
Tuberculin test involves intradermal injection of purified protein derivative (PPD, also called tuberculin), a protein-containing antigen of the tubercle bacillus. In a previously sensitized individual, reddening and induration of the site appear in 8 to 12 hours, reach a peak in 24 to 72 hours, and thereafter slowly subside.
Morphologically, delayed-type hypersensitivity is characterized by the accumulation of mononuclear cells, mainly CD4+ T cells and macrophages, around venules. The cell-mediated type of hypersensitivity is caused by inflammation resulting from cytokines produced by CD4+ T cells and cell killing by CD8+ T cells.
Solution to Question 6:
Anaphylactoid reactions are those reactions that are similar to the anaphylactic reactions but are not IgE mediated. These reactions are caused by direct degranulation of the mast cells or basophils, which causes the release of mediators.
Unlike the classic anaphylaxis which occurs on re-exposure to the allergen, the anaphylactoid reaction can occur even on the first exposure. The most common agents that can cause an anaphylactoid reaction include NSAIDs and radiocontrast media.
In 2014, World Allergy Organisation has introduced two new terms:
Immunologic anaphylaxis - It includes anaphylactic reactions mediated by IgE, IgG (in animals), and immune complex/ complement-mediated reactions.
Non-immunologic anaphylaxis (previously called anaphylactoid reaction) - It includes reactions caused by agents which cause massive degranulation of mast cells or basophils in the absence of immunoglobulin.
The image given below shows the sequence of events in type 1 hypersensitivity reaction.

Solution to Question 7:
Rheumatoid arthritis is mediated by T cells, not antibodies. Antibody-mediated diseases:
Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
Pemphigus vulgaris
Vasculitis caused by ANCA
Goodpasture syndrome
Myasthenia gravis
Acute rheumatic fever
Graves disease
Pernicious anemia
Insulin resistant diabetes T cell-mediated diseases:
Rheumatoid arthritis
Multiple sclerosis
Psoriasis
Type 1 diabetes mellitus
Inflammatory bowel disease
Contact sensitivity
Note: In T cell mediated diseases, although the role of T cells have been demonstrated, antibodies may also be involved in tissue injury.
Solution to Question 8:
PTPN22 gene is most frequently implicated in autoimmunity.
PTPN22, which encodes the protein tyrosine phosphatase, is associated with the following conditions:
Rheumatoid arthritis
Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD)
Type 1 diabetes
Because these disorders have a fairly high prevalence, PTPN22 is said to be the gene that is most frequently implicated in autoimmunity.
Option A: Mutations in FOXP3 cause a systemic autoimmune disease called IPEX (immune dysregulation, polyendocrinopathy, enteropathy, X-linked).
Option C: Polymorphisms in the gene encoding for NOD2 are associated with Crohn's disease.
Option D: AIRE mutation is associated with the autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 1 (APS-1).
Solution to Question 9:
The above process is called central tolerance and the AIRE (AutoImmune REgulator) protein is necessary for this process.
Immature self-reactive T and B lymphocyte clones recognize self-antigens during their maturation in the central lymphoid organs (thymus for T cells, bone marrow for B cells). They are killed or rendered harmless.
The removal of self reacting T lymphocytes in the thymus is called negative selection/ deletion. For this process, AIRE protein is needed. Mutations in the AIRE gene results in autoimmune disorders (autoimmune polyendocrinopathy).
B cells undergo a process called receptor editing. When developing B cells encounter an antigen, it formulates a change in the receptor that makes the antigen unrecognizable. Self-reacting B cells can also undergo apoptosis.
Solution to Question 10:
Autoimmunity in Epstein–Barr virus (EBV) infection is the result of polyclonal B cell activation.
Microbes may induce other abnormalities that promote autoimmune reactions. Some viruses, such as EBV and HIV, cause polyclonal B-cell activation, which may result in the production of autoantibodies.
The role of infections in autoimmunity is exemplified by the following:
Molecular mimicry of antigenic cross-reactivity: The structural similarity of the microbial antigens and self-antigens. Rheumatic heart disease is an example in which streptococcal proteins cross-react with myocardial proteins causing myocarditis.
Upregulation of co-stimulatory molecules by infectious organisms.
Polyclonal B cell activation: Caused by EBV and HIV, resulting in the production of autoantibodies.
Alteration of tissue antigens: Infections may alter tissue self-antigens so that they activate T cells and lose the property of self-tolerance.
Solution to Question 11:
Homogeneous or diffuse nuclear staining does not reflect antibodies to RNA. The nucleolar pattern of staining represents antibodies to RNA.
Antinuclear antibodies (ANAs) are directed against antibodies to:
DNA
Histones
Nonhistone proteins bound to RNA
Nucleolar antigens
The most widely used method for detecting ANAs is indirect immunofluorescence. The pattern of nuclear fluorescence suggests the type of antibody present in the patient’s serum.
Solution to Question 12:
The lupus erythematosus (LE) cell is a phagocytic neutrophil or macrophage.
Nuclei of damaged cells react with ANAs, lose their chromatin pattern, and become homogeneous to produce LE bodies or hematoxylin bodies. Phagocytic neutrophils or macrophages engulf the denatured nucleus of an injured cell. Demonstration of LE cells in vitro was used in the past for the diagnosis of SLE.
The image below shows a lupus erythematosus (LE) cell.

Solution to Question 13:
The given clinical picture is highly suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). In this condition, lymphocytic infiltration in the salivary gland is not seen. However, this finding is seen in Sjogren's syndrome.
If cell nuclei are exposed to anti-nuclear antibodies (ANAs), they can bind to them. The nuclei of damaged cells react with ANAs, lose their chromatin pattern, and become homogeneous. They are called lupus erythematosus (LE) bodies or hematoxylin bodies.
An acute necrotizing vasculitis involving capillaries, small arteries, and arterioles with fibrinoid necrosis is seen in SLE. Central penicilliary arteries in the spleen may show concentric intimal and smooth muscle cell hyperplasia, producing so-called onion-skin lesions.
Solution to Question 14:
Celiac disease is not an IgG4-Related disease.
IgG4-related disease (IgG4-RD) is a newly recognized constellation of disorders characterized by tissue infiltrates dominated by IgG4 antibody-producing plasma cells and lymphocytes, particularly T cells, storiform fibrosis, obliterative phlebitis, and usually increased serum IgG4.
IgG4-RD spectrum includes:
Mikulicz syndrome - enlargement and fibrosis of salivary and lacrimal glands
Riedel thyroiditis
Idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis
Autoimmune pancreatitis
Inflammatory pseudotumors of the orbit, lungs, and kidney

Solution to Question 1:
Leukocyte-adhesion deficiency (LAD) type 2 is due to the absence of Sialyl-Lewis X. Physiologically Sialyl-Lewis X has the necessary ligand for the selectins which bind to leukocytes. Inherited defects in leukocyte adhesion:
Type 1 - defect in the biosynthesis of the  2 chain shared by the LFA-1 and Mac-1 integrins
Type 2 - absence of sialyl-Lewis X, the fucose containing ligand for E- and P-selectins. It is due to defect in the fucosyltransferase, the enzyme that attaches fucose moieties to protein backbones.
The major clinical problem in both conditions is recurrent bacterial infections due to inadequate granulocyte function.

Solution to Question 2:
Leukocytes contain giant granules in Chédiak–Higashi syndrome as seen in peripheral blood smears. They are due to aberrant phagolysosome fusion.
The image shows giant granules in a neutrophil in Chédiak–Higashi syndrome.


Chédiak–Higashi syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition. The defective fusion of phagosomes and lysosomes results in defective phagocytes function and susceptibility to infections.
The abnormalities are neutropenia, defective degranulation, and delayed microbial killing, causing:
Albinism - melanocytes
Nerve defects - nervous system cells
Bleeding disorders - platelets
The gene associated with this disorder encodes a large cytosolic protein called LYST, which is believed to regulate lysosomal trafficking.
Solution to Question 3:
The given clinical scenario suggests chronic granulomatous disease. It is due to a macrophage-rich chronic inflammatory reaction, not lymphocytic.
Chronic granulomatous disease is a defect in bacterial killing and renders patients susceptible to recurrent bacterial infections. The name of this disease comes from the macrophage-rich chronic inflammatory reaction that tries to control the infection when the initial neutrophil defense is inadequate. This often leads to collections of activated macrophages that wall off the microbes, forming granulomas.

The disorders caused due to complement deficiency are:
The deficiency of C2 is the most common complement protein deficiency.
Complement
Disease/syndrome
C1 esterase inhibitor
Hereditary angioneurotic ede ma
C1, C2, C4
Pyogenic infections, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)

Pyogenic infections, SLE

Pyogenic infections,Glomerul onephritis, SLE
Factor H
Hemolytic uremic syndrome( HUS), Pyogenic infections, Gl omerulonephritis, SLE
C5 to C8
Recurrent infections withNei sseriaspp.
Properdin

Factor D
Meningitis, sepsis -Neisseria
Factors H and I
Recurrent pyogenic infection s
DAFF and CD59
P roxysmal nocturnal hemog lobinuria (PNH)
Mannan-binding lect in
Respiratory tract infections
MASP-2
Respiratory tract infections
Solution to Question 5:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hereditary angioneurotic edema. It is due to the deficiency of C1 inhibitors.
Hereditary angioneurotic edema is an autosomal dominant disorder, which is more common than complement deficiency states.
Targets of C1 inhibitors are proteases, specifically C1r and C1s of the complement cascade, factor XII of the coagulation pathway, and the kallikrein system. Deficiency of C1 inhibitor leads to unregulated activation of kallikrein. This increases the production of vasoactive peptides such as bradykinin.
It causes episodes of edema affecting the skin and mucosal surfaces such as the larynx and the gastrointestinal tract. This may result in life-threatening asphyxia or nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea after minor trauma or emotional stress.
Solution to Question 6:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). The biopsy of the thymus showing remnants of Hassall's corpuscles indicates it is due to adenosine deaminase (ADA) deficiency. SCID is a defect in both humoral and cell-mediated immune responses. Usually the defect lies in the T-cell compartment with secondary impairment in humoral immunity.
Affected infants present with prominent thrush (oral candidiasis), extensive diaper rash, and failure to thrive. Some patients develop a morbilliform rash shortly after birth because maternal T cells are transferred across the placenta and attack the fetus, causing graft-versus-host disease (GVHD).
Persons with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range of pathogens, including:
Candida albicans
Pneumocystis jiroveci
Pseudomonas
Cytomegalovirus
Varicell
There are 2 types of SCID based on inheritance:
X-linked SCID is the most common form and hence it is more common in boys than in girls. The genetic defect is the mutation in the common -chain (c) subunit of cytokine receptors. T-cell numbers are greatly reduced, and although B cells may be normal in number, antibody synthesis is impaired because of the lack of T-cell help. The thymus contains lobules of undifferentiated epithelial cells resembling fetal thymus.
Autosomal recessive is most commonly caused due to deficiency of the enzyme adenosine deaminase (ADA). The deficiency of ADA leads to the accumulation of deoxyadenosine and its derivatives (e.g., deoxy-ATP). They are toxic to rapidly dividing immature lymphocytes, especially those of the T-cell lineage. Hence, there may be a greater reduction in the number of T lymphocytes.
In the two most common forms (c mutation and ADA deficiency), the thymus is small and devoid of lymphoid cells. In SCID caused by ADA deficiency, remnants of Hassall’s corpuscles can be found.
Note: X-linked SCID is the first human disease in which gene therapy has been successful.
Solution to Question 7:
BTK mutation causes X-linked agammaglobulinemia and not SCID (severe combined immunodeficiency).
Severe combined immunodeficiency is a defect in both humoral and cell-mediated immune responses. In this condition, the following genes are involved:
JAK3
RAG1
IL-7R
Persons with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range of pathogens, including:
Candida albicans
Pneumocystis jiroveci
Pseudomonas
Cytomegalovirus
Varicell
Solution to Question 8:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Bruton agammaglobulinemia/ X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA). Even though it is an immunodeficiency disease, it is
paradoxically associated with autoimmune diseases such as arthritis and dermatomyositis in 35% of individuals.
The classic form of this disease has the following characteristics:
B cells are absent or markedly decreased and the serum levels of all classes of immunoglobulins re decreased
T-cell mediated reactions are normal
Germinal centers of lymph nodes, Peyer’s patches, the appendix, and tonsils are underdeveloped
Plasma cells are absent throughout the body
XLA is characterized by the failure of B-cell precursors (pro-B cells and pre-B cells) to develop into m ture B cells. It is associated with mutations in a cytoplasmic tyrosine kinase called Bruton tyrosine kinase (Btk).
The related gene is located on the long arm of the X chromosome. This X-linked disease is seen almost entirely in males. The disease usually does not become apparent until about 6 months of age, when maternal immunoglobulins are depleted.
Affected individuals are susceptible to infections with:
Bacteria that are normally opsonized by antibodies and cleared by phagocytosis
Haemophilus influenzae
Streptococcus pneumoni
Staphylococcus aureus
Giardia lamblia - intestinal protozoan that is normally resisted by secreted IgA, causes persistent infections
Enteroviruses
Echovirus
Poliovirus
Coxsackievirus
Solution to Question 9:
The given clinical scenario with the image suggests DiGeorge syndrome. It results from the failure of the development of the 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouches. They give rise to the thymus, the parathyroids, some of the C cells of the thyroid, and the ultimobranchial body.
The absence of cell-mediated immunity causes poor defense against certain fungal and viral infections. The T-cell zones of lymphoid organs, i.e. paracortical areas of the lymph nodes and the periarteriolar sheaths of the spleen, are depleted. Ig levels may be normal or reduced, depending on the severity of the T-cell deficiency.
Solution to Question 10:
The serum of patients with Hyper-IgM syndrome contains extremely low levels of IgG.
In Hyper-IgM syndrome production of IgM antibodies is normal but the ability to produce IgG, IgA, and IgE antibodies is deficient. There are normal or elevated levels of IgM, no IgA or IgE, and extremely low levels of IgG. It affects the ability of helper T cells to deliver activating signals to B cells and macrophages. However, B cells and T cells counts are normal.
It is mostly an X-linked disease, that has mutations in the gene encoding CD40L located on Xq26. If the disease is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, then there are loss-of-function
mutations involving either CD40 or the enzyme called activation-induced cytidine deaminase
(AID).
Those with CD40L mutations are also susceptible to pneumonia caused by the intracellular organism Pneumocystis jiroveci. This is due to CD40L-mediated macrophage activation, a key reaction of cell-mediated immunity being defective. Recurrent pyogenic infection occurs because the level of opsonizing IgG antibodies is low.
Occasionally, the IgM antibodies react with blood cells, giving rise to autoimmune hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and neutropenia. In older patients, the proliferation of IgM-producing plasma cells that infiltrate the mucosa of the gastrointestinal tract is seen.
Solution to Question 11:
The deficiency of the CD40 and its absence in B cells interferes with class switching and the production of memory cells. The B-cell response to antigens, is unaffected, accounting for the presence of increased IgM antibodies. Hence, the condition is known as Hyper IgM syndrome.
The given clinical scenario and the flow cytometry is suggestive of Hyper IgM syndrome. The flow cytometry shows the following findings:
In comparison of image 3 to 1, where side scatter is plotted against CD 19: B-cell gating is present.
Gating of B cells means selecting a cell during a flow cytometry experiment for further analysis or data presentation.CD 19 is widely expressed on B cells. Hence the graph shows B cell gating. Side scatter measurement provides information about the granularity of a cell.
In comparison of image 4 to 2, where CD 40 is plotted against CD 19: B cells are present only in quadrant 4, which means that there is CD 40 deficiency.
The deficiency of the CD40 and its absence in B cells interferes with class switching and the production of memory cells. The B-cell response to antigens is unaffected, accounting for the presence of increased IgM antibodies. Hence, the condition is known as Hyper IgM syndrome.
Given below is the explanation of how to interpret flow cytometry results:

Interpretation of results:
Quadrant 1- Cells marked in green: -VE for A antigen, +VE for B antigen Quadrant 2- Cells marked in purple: -VE for both the antigens.
Quadrant 3- Cells marked in yellow: +VE for both the antigens Quadrant 4- Cells marked in red: +VE for A antigen, -VE for B antigen
Solution to Question 12:
Isolated IgA deficiency is associated with deficiency of IgG subtypes IgG2 and IgG4.
IgA deficiency-affected individuals have extremely low levels of both serum and secretory IgA. It m y be familial or acquired in association with toxoplasmosis, measles, or some other viral infection.
Because IgA is the major antibody in external secretions, mucosal defenses are weakened, and infections occur in the respiratory, gastrointestinal, and urogenital tracts. Symptomatic patients commonly have recurrent sinopulmonary infections and diarrhea.
IgA-deficient patients have a high frequency of respiratory tract allergy and a variety of autoimmune diseases, particularly systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and rheumatoid arthritis.
Solution to Question 13:
The X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome is due to mutations in the gene encoding an adaptor molecule called SLAM-associated protein (SAP).
It is characterized by an inability to eliminate Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), eventually leading to fulminant infectious mononucleosis and the development of B-cell tumors.
In about 80% of cases, the disease is due to mutations in the gene encoding the adaptor molecule SAP. Defects in SAP contribute to attenuated NK cell and T-cell activation, resulting in increased susceptibility to viral infections.
Option B: LYST gene is associated with Chediak-Higashi syndrome.
Option C: BTK gene is associated with Isolated growth hormone deficiency type III. Option D: TBX1 gene is associated with 22q11.2 deletion syndrome.
Solution to Question 14:
Normal B-cell count is most commonly seen in lymphoid tissues of individuals with the common variable hypogammaglobulinemia.
It is a heterogeneous group of disorders in which the common feature is hypogammaglobulinemia, generally affecting all the antibody classes, but sometimes only IgG.
In contrast to X-linked agammaglobulinemia, most individuals with common variable immunodeficiency have normal or near-normal numbers of B-cells in the blood and lymphoid tissues. These B cells, however, are not able to differentiate into plasma cells.
FDA approved XEMBIFY in 2019, 20% immunoglobulin solution for subcutaneous injection. It is indicated for the use of primary humoral immunodeficiency disorders in patients 2years of age and older.
Solution to Question 15:
The given history with eczema, recurrent infections, and thrombocytopenia points towards Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome. In this condition, IgM levels in the serum are low.
Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome is caused by mutations in the gene encoding the Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP), which is located on Xp11.23. The X-linked disease is characterized by thrombocytopenia, eczema, and a marked vulnerability to recurrent infection, resulting in early death.
Platelets are small in size. The thymus is morphologically normal, at least early in the course of the disease, but there is the progressive loss of T lymphocytes in the peripheral blood and in the T-cell zones (paracortical areas) of the lymph nodes, with variable defects in cellular immunity.
P tients do not make antibodies to polysaccharide antigens, and the response to protein antigens is poor. IgM levels are low, IgG is usually normal, while the levels of IgA and IgE are often elevated. Patients are prone to developing B-cell lymphomas.
Solution to Question 16:
The above clinical scenario and image showing telangiectasia are diagnostic of ataxia-telangiectasia. It is an autosomal-recessive disorder, not autosomal dominant.
The most prominent humoral immune abnormalities are defective production of IgA and IgG2. The gene responsible for this disorder is located on chromosome 11 and encodes a protein called ATM. The ATM protein is a sensor of DNA damage (double-strand breaks), and it activates p53 by phosphorylation.
Ataxia-telangiectasia is characterized by abnormal gait (ataxia), vascular malformations (telangiectases), neurologic deficits, increased incidence of tumors, and immunodeficiency. It may affect both B and T cells.
There is a high incidence of lymphomas and leukemias.
Solution to Question 17:
The CD4 cells are affected by HIV due to their interaction with gp120.
HIV-1 virion is spherical and contains an electron-dense, cone-shaped core surrounded by a lipid envelope derived from the host cell membrane. Target cells of HIV include CD4+ helper T cells (worst affected), monocyte-macrophages, and dendritic cells.
The virus core contains:
Major capsid protein p24
Nucleocapsid protein p7/p9
Two copies of viral genomic RNA
The three viral enzymes (protease, reverse transcriptase, and integrase)
The viral core is surrounded by a matrix protein called p17, which lies underneath the virion envelope. The viral envelope is studded by two viral glycoproteins, gp120 and gp41, which are critical for HIV infection of cells.
Viral glycoprotein gp120 binds to CD4+ cells in the host. CXCR4 and CCR5 function as coreceptors for HIV-1 entry into CD4+ cells. This binding leads to a conformational change in gp41 causing exposure of a hydrophobic region called the fusion peptide at the tip of gp41. This peptide inserts into the cell membrane of the target cells (e.g., T cells or macrophages), leading to the fusion of the virus with the host cell.
The image below shows the pathogenesis of HIV infection.

Solution to Question 18:
The neutrophil is not a target for the initiation and maintenance of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection.
HIV enters the body and affects T cells, dendritic cells, and macrophages. Particularly, memory and activated T cells are infected, but it is inefficient at productively infecting naive (unactivated) T cells.
Completion of the viral life cycle in latently infected cells occurs only after cell activation, and in the case of most CD4+ T cells, virus activation results in cell lysis.
The image below shows the pathogenesis of HIV infection.

Solution to Question 19:
The most common central nervous system (CNS) neoplasm in patients with HIV infection is primary CNS lymphoma.
Lymphomas are the most common CNS neoplasm in immunosuppressed individuals, including those with acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) and immunosuppression after transplantation. They are associated with latent infection with Epstein–Barr virus (EBV). The vast m jority of primary brain lymphomas are of B-cell origin.
At least two mechanisms appear to underlie the increased risk of B-cell tumors in HIV-infected individuals. They are:
The unchecked proliferation of B cells infected with oncogenic herpes viruses in the setting of profound T-cell depletion (AIDS).
Germinal center B-cell hyperplasia in the setting of early HIV infection.
The most common site for lymphoma in patients with acquired immunodeficiency syndrome
(AIDS) is the central nervous system (CNS).
Solution to Question 20:
Hematoxylin bodies are seen in lymph nodes in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
Features of AIDS-related lymphadenopathy:
Early stages of HIV infection:
Florid hyperplasia of B cell follicles
Follicle lysis
Monocytoid B cells in sinuses
Neutrophils and dermatopathic lymphadenopathy
The interfollicular zone shows vascular proliferation, which may progress to Kaposi sarcom Late stages of HIV infection:
Severe lymphoid involution
Possible hyalinization of the germinal centers
Burnt-out lymph nodes, which become atrophic and may harbor numerous opportunistic pathogens, often within macrophages
Solution to Question 21:
The most likely diagnosis is Kaposi sarcoma, caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8).
Kaposi sarcoma is a vascular neoplasm, that is highly associated with acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). It is the most common cancer seen in patients having AIDS. Though the
incidence of Kaposi carcinoma reduced, it still occurs in 2-3% of HIV-infected individuals. The pathogenesis of Kaposi sarcoma that is caused by HHV8 includes:
A virally encoded G protein that induces VEGF production, stimulating endothelial growth
The lytic infection caused by HHV8 increases the pro-inflammatory cytokines
HHV8 encoded proteins inhibit the p53 induced apoptosis
The given images show coalescent red-purple macules and plaques of the skin and the histologic appearance of Kaposi sarcoma, demonstrating sheets of proliferating spindle cells:


Solution to Question 22:
The smears stained with methenamine silver show black-colored stained cysts resembling the crushed ping pong balls of Pneumocystis jirovecii.
Approximately 15% to 30% of untreated HIV-infected people develop pneumonia during the course of the disease. It is mainly caused by the fungus P. jirovecii (reactivation of prior latent infection).

Solution to Question 1:
Amyloid can be best described as a proteoglycan.
Amyloidosis refers to the extracellular deposition of fibrillar proteins.
Abnormal fibrils are produced by the aggregation of misfolded proteins. The fibrillar deposits bind a wide variety of proteoglycans and glycosaminoglycans (heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate), and plasma proteins (serum amyloid P component).
The abundant charged sugar groups in these adsorbed proteins give the deposits staining characteristics that resemble starch (amylose). Therefore, these deposits are called amyloid.
Amyloid appears as an amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline, extracellular substance.
Solution to Question 2:
There is the deposition of AA proteins in reactive systemic amyloidosis (secondary amyloidosis).
In inflammatory states, there is a release of IL-1 and IL-6, which act on the liver cells. The liver increases the production of SAA (serum amyloid-associated) proteins which circulate bound to high-density lipoproteins. This gives rise to AA proteins, which get deposited in tissues causing reactive systemic amyloidosis or secondary amyloidosis.
The most common sites are the kidney and heart. It is usually seen secondary to:
Rheumatoid arthritis (most common)
Tuberculosis
Bronchiectasis
Chronic osteomyelitis
Inflammatory bowel disease
Ankylosing spondylitis
Malignancies - renal cell cancer, Hodgkin’s lymphoma
Solution to Question 3:
The most common cause of reactive amyloidosis worldwide is rheumatoid arthritis.
Amyloidosis is reported to occur in 3% of patients with rheumatoid arthritis and is clinically significant in one-half of those affected.
Conditions associated with reactive systemic (secondary) amyloidosis:
Rheumatoid arthritis (most common)
Ankylosing spondylitis
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis)
Tuberculosis
Bronchiectasis
Chronic osteomyelitis
Malignancies - renal cell cancer, Hodgkin’s lymphoma
Solution to Question 4:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Alzheimer's disease. A amyloid deposition is seen in this condition.
A constitutes the core of cerebral plaques found in Alzheimer's disease. It also gets deposited in the walls of cerebral blood vessels. The A protein is derived by proteolysis from a much larger transmembrane glycoprotein, called amyloid precursor protein (APP).
Solution to Question 5:
Patients on long-term hemodialysis for renal failure can develop amyloidosis as a result of the deposition of  2-microglobulin.
This protein is present in high concentrations in the serum of persons with renal disease. The protein is retained in the circulation because it cannot be filtered through the dialysis membranes.
It gets deposited in the synovium, joints, and tendon sheaths. When this deposition takes place in the carpal ligament of the wrist, it leads to the development of carpal tunnel syndrome.
With new dialysis filters, the incidence of this complication has decreased substantially.
Solution to Question 6:
Familial amyloidotic polyneuropathy (FAP) is associated with the deposition of mutant transthyretin protein (TTR).
FAP is an autosomal dominant condition. The deposition occurs as amyloid fibrils in peripheral and autonomic nerves. Mutated TTR is prone to misfolding and aggregation, and shows resistance to proteolysis.
Systemic senile amyloidosis (amyloid of aging) refers to the systemic deposition of normal
TTR amyloid in elderly patients. Symptomatic patients present with restrictive cardiomyopathy and arrhythmias. Another rare form affecting predominantly the heart results from the deposition of a mutant form of TTR.
Familial Mediterranean fever (FMF) is an autosomal-recessive condition seen in individuals of Mediterranean descent (Armenian, Sephardic Jewish, and Arabic). The affected gene encodes a protein called pyrin, which is involved in cytokine production. The amyloid fibril proteins in this condition are made up of AA proteins. It presents with attacks of fever and serositis.
Isolated atrial amyloidosis is associated with AANP (atrial natriuretic peptide) amyloid deposition
Solution to Question 7:
Older individuals with insulin resistance are likely to have type 2 diabetes mellitus. These patients are at increased risk of developing amyloidosis.
Microscopic deposits of localized amyloid may be found in certain conditions such as:
Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid gland
Islet tumors of the pancreas
Pheochromocytomas
Undifferentiated carcinomas of the stomach
Islets of Langerhans in individuals with type 2 diabetes mellitus
Solution to Question 8:
The slide is showing the presence of amyloid-rich stroma (pinkish material) and nests of polygonal cells, suggestive of medullary carcinoma thyroid. The major fibril protein that gets deposited is A Cal, which is derived from calcitonin.


Microscopic deposits of localized amyloid may be found in certain conditions such as:
Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid gland

Pheochromocytomas
Undifferentiated carcinomas of the stomach
Islets of Langerhans in individuals with type 2 diabetes mellitus
Solution to Question 9:
The most common organ involved in AL amyloidosis is renal tissue (Kidneys). They are affected in 70–80% of patients with amyloidosis.
Heart is the second most commonly affected organ (50–60%), and cardiac involvement is the leading cause of death from AL amyloidosis.
Renal amyloidosis usually manifests as proteinuria, often in the nephrotic range, and is associated with hypoalbuminemia, secondary hypercholesterolemia, hypertriglyceridemia, and edema or anasarca.

Solution to Question 10:
Bone marrow examination in AL amyloidosis shows plasmacytosis.
The AL type of amyloid or primary amyloidosis is associated with immunocyte dyscrasias like multiple myeloma or other B cell neoplasms. The tumor cells in multiple myeloma secrete light chains of the immunoglobulins of either the lambda or kappa type, which get deposited in the tissues as amyloid.
The chemical nature of the amyloid is AL (A for amyloid and L for light chain).
Solution to Question 11:
Lardaceous spleen is due to the deposition of amyloid in sinusoids of the red pulp. Sago spleen is due to the deposition of amyloid in splenic follicles (white pulp).

Solution to Question 13:
In suspected systemic amyloidosis, the initial investigation of choice is abdominal fat aspirate staining.
Diagnosis of amyloidosis involves the following:
Localized amyloidosis - biopsy the organ involved. e.g., kidney
Systemic amyloidosis - deposits can be found in any tissue of the body
Initial test - non-invasive test on easily accessible tissue (eg: abdominal fat) which is positive in
>80% of cases
If this is negative - more invasive biopsies of the kidney, heart, lung or GI tract (rectal biopsy)
Suspected AL amyloidosis - serum and urine electrophoresis and immunoelectrophoresis
The histological examination of the biopsy material is the commonest confirmatory method for the diagnosis in a suspected case of amyloidosis. The next best step is to determine the type of precursor protein by immunohistochemistry, immunoelectron microscopy, or extraction and biochemical analysis employing mass spectrometry.
Scintigraphy with radiolabeled serum amyloid P component is a rapid and specific test, which gives the extent of the disease. It can be used to follow up on patients undergoing treatment.
Solution to Question 14:
Sudan Black is used for staining lipids, not amyloid. Staining for amyloid:
Congo red - most widely used and specific
Iodine staining -
Used for unfixed specimens or histological sections
Amyloid stains mahogany brown and turns violet on adding sulfuric acid
Thioflavin T and S -
Secondary immunofluorescence with ultraviolet light
Thioflavin T is useful for demonstrating the juxtaglomerular apparatus of the kidney
Metachromatic stains (crystal violet and methyl violet) - rose-pink appearance.
Periodic-acid Schiff (PAS) positive
The image given below shows the amyloid appearance on congo red under plain microscopy.

Solution to Question 15:
Amyloid shows apple-green birefringence under polarised microscopy, after staining with Congo red.
The appearance of amyloid:
Light microscopy - amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline, extracellular substance
Congo red stain - the characteristic appearance using this stain is due to the cross- -pleated sheet conformation
Under ordinary light, it appears pink or red color (as shown below)

- Under the polarizing microscope - imparts apple-green birefringence to amyloid deposits (as shown in the image below)

Electron microscopy - continuous, nonbranching fibrils with a diameter of approximately 7.5 to 10 nm
X-ray crystallography and infrared spectroscopy - Characteristic cross- -pleated sheet conformation.
It appears mahogany brown on iodine staining and rose-pink on staining with crystal violet.
Solution to Question 16:
Macrophages present foreign graft antigens to the T-cells but are not directly involved in graft rejection.
Graft rejection is both humoral and cell-mediated in nature. It is a process in which T-cells and antibodies produced against graft antigens react against tissue grafts and destroy it.
The major antigenic differences that result in the rejection of transplants are differences in HLA alleles. The recipient T-cells are involved in the recognition of the donor MHC molecules and mount an immune response. Depending on the antigen-presenting cells (APCs) that are involved in T-cell activation, there are 2 pathways:
Direct pathway of allorecognition - MHC antigens are presented by the APCs in the graft
Indirect pathway of allorecognition - MHC antigens are presented by the recipient’s own APCs
(e.g., macrophages)
The early activation of NK cells kill allogeneic target cells directly or via antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and release various chemokines and immunomodulatory cytokines.
Solution to Question 17:
The given clinical scenario within minutes of transplant is suggestive of hyperacute rejection and is due to preformed antibodies from the recipient.
Solution to Question 18:
The given clinical history and the biopsy findings of endotheliitis suggest a diagnosis of acute cell-mediated graft rejection.
In acute cell-mediated graft rejection, CD8+ CTLs directly destroy graft cells or CD4+ cells secrete cytokines that damage the graft.
On histopathology, it produces two different patterns of injury in the graft:
Tubulointerstitial pattern (type I): extensive interstitial and tubular inflammation associated with focal tubular injury
Vascular pattern - Inflammation (type II) and necrosis (type III), endotheliitis (swollen endothelial cells with lymphocytes between endothelium and vessel wall)
Immunosuppressive therapy aims to prevent and reduce acute rejection by blocking the activation of alloreactive T cells. In the absence of humoral rejection, patients respond well to immunosuppressive therapy.
Solution to Question 19:
The lung is least likely to get affected in acute graft-versus-host disease (GVHD).
GVHD occurs when immunologically competent cells or their precursors are transplanted into immunologically crippled recipients. The transferred cells recognize alloantigens in the host and attack host tissues.
It is seen most commonly in the setting of hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) transplantation. Rarely, it may occur following transplantation of solid organs rich in lymphoid cells (e.g., the liver) or transfusion of unirradiated blood.
It is of two types, acute and chronic.
Acute GVHD develops within days to weeks. There is the involvement of the immune system and epithelium of the skin, liver, and intestines. It presents with:
Generalized rash
Jaundice
Bloody diarrhea due to mucosal ulceration
Non-infectious pulmonary infiltrates (rarely), the outcome is generally poor Chronic GVHD may follow the acute syndrome or occur insidiously. It presents with:
Skin - extensive cutaneous injury, with the destruction of skin appendages and dermal fibrosis
(may resemble systemic sclerosis)
Liver - chronic liver disease, manifested as cholestatic jaundice
GIT - esophageal strictures
Immune system involvement - involution of the thymus and depletion of lymphocytes GVHD is mediated by T lymphocytes contained in the transplanted donor
cells. Therefore, depletion of donor T cells before transfusion virtually eliminates the disease.
Solution to Question 20:
A graft from an identical twin is called an isograft.
Isograft is defined as an organ or tissue that is taken from a donor and is transplanted to a recipient who has the same genetic constitution as the donor. For example, graft between identical twins.

Solution to Question 2:
Anaemia is the most common hematologic abnormality associated with HIV infection. It affects 60–80% of patients during the late stage.
In most cases, the cause of anaemia in HIV-infected patients is multifactorial. It is often associated with infection, inflammation, malignancy, malnutrition, and polypharmacy.
Note: Prior to the use of potent antiretroviral therapy (ART), thrombocytopenia was a common finding in individuals infected with HIV. With use of potent ART, the incidence of thrombocytopenia is far lower.
Solution to Question 3:
Hereditary spherocytosis is not due to diminished erythropoiesis. It is a type of hemolytic anemia. Classification of anemia according to underlying mechanism:
Anemias of diminished erythropoiesis - decreased red cell production
Hemolytic anemias - increased red cell destruction
Anemia due to blood loss
Anemias due to diminished erythropoiesis:
Iron deficiency anemia
Megaloblastic anemia
Anemia of chronic diseases
Aplastic anemia
Myelophthisic anemia
Fanconi's anemia
Solution to Question 4:
MCV >100 fl indicates macrocytic anaemia which is not seen in anaemia of chronic disease. RBCs in anemia of chronic disease are initially normocytic and normochromic, becoming microcytic and hypochromic over time.
Vitamin B12 deficiency, thiamine deficiency, and orotic aciduria cause macrocytic anaemia.
Solution to Question 5:
Absorption of iron is increased by ascorbic acid. It is decreased by phosphates, oxalates, and carbonates.
Solution to Question 6:
Most of the functional iron (80%) in the body is found in hemoglobin.
The storage pool represented by hemosiderin, and ferritin contains about 15% to 20% of total body iron. Myoglobin and iron-containing enzymes such as catalase and the cytochromes contain the rest.
Solution to Question 7:
DMT1 (divalent metal transporter 1) is required for the transport of iron into the enterocyte.
Dietary iron is mostly in Fe3+ (ferric state) and must be reduced to Fe2+ (ferrous state) by ferrireductases. Fe2+ iron destined for circulation is transported from the cytoplasm across the basolateral enterocyte membrane by ferroportin 1.
Hephaestin is an iron oxidase that converts Fe2+ to Fe3+

Solution to Question 8:
Ceruloplasmin is involved in iron metabolism.
Ferritin is the storage form of iron in the body. Ceruloplasmin and hephaestin help in oxidation of Fe2+ to Fe3+ at the basolateral border of enterocytes. This is coupled with transport through ferroportin. In plasma, iron is transported by transferrin.
Haptocorrin and cubulin are involved in vitamin B12 absorption. Selenoprotein is involved in selenium metabolism.

Solution to Question 9:
Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocytes into the plasma by binding to ferroportin, which is an iron efflux channel in the enterocyte.
Iron metabolism is regulated by hepcidin, a protein and acute phase reactant produced by the liver. It binds to ferroportin and degrades it. This inhibits the transfer of iron from the enterocyte to the plasma via ferroportin. As a result, iron becomes trapped within the duodenal cells (enterocytes) in the form of mucosal ferritin and is lost in feces when these cells are shed off.
Transcription of hepcidin is increased by the following factors:
Increased levels of iron
Inflammatory cytokines
Transcription of hepcidin is decreased by the following factors:
Iron deficiency
Hypoxia
Ineffective erythropoiesis
Hepcidin is encoded by the HAMP gene and its mutations are associated with hereditary hemochromatosis.

Solution to Question 10:
Absorption of iron mainly occurs in the proximal duodenum.
Solution to Question 11:
In iron deficiency anaemia, there is an increase in transferrin receptor mRNA concentration and synthesis.
Iron absorbed through diet or which is released from circulation is bound to transferrin (iron transfer protein). When erythropoiesis is stimulated, iron-transferrin complexes act as transferrin receptors on the surface of bone marrow erythroid cells. Through receptor-mediated endocytosis, this complex is internalised.
This iron is then made available for heme synthesis while the transferrin-receptor complex is recycled to the surface of the cell, from where the transferrin is released back into circulation and the transferrin receptor re-anchors into the cell membrane. The excess iron after hemoglobin synthesis binds to apoferritin (storage protein), forming ferritin.
Senescent RBCs undergo phagocytosis in the cells of the reticuloendothelial system. The hemoglobin is broken down, the globin and other proteins are returned to the amino acid pool, and the iron is shuttled back to the surface of the reticuloendothelial cell, where it is taken up by transferrin via ferroportin (iron export channel).
There is no regulated excretory pathway for iron, and the only mechanisms by which iron is lost are blood loss (via gastrointestinal bleeding, menstruation, or other forms of bleeding) and the loss of epithelial cells from the skin, gut, and genitourinary tract. The normal daily iron loss from the body is 1-2 mg.

Solution to Question 12:

Koilonychia is a symptom of iron deficiency anaemia. It may or may not be present in Plummer Vinson syndrome. Hence, it is not a part of the triad.

Solution to Question 1:

History of OCP use

Solution to Question 2:
Ileal resection for Crohn's disease can cause megaloblastic anaemia due to the decrease in cubilin receptors. They are the vitamin B12 receptors on the ileum.
Absorption of vitamin B12 involves the following steps:
Pepsin in the stomach releases vitamin B12 from the binding proteins in the food
Released B12 binds to haptocorrin, which is a salivary protein
In the duodenum, pancreatic proteases release B12 from haptocorrin
B12 binds to intrinsic factor to form IF-B12 complex
In the ileum, ileal enterocytes that contain cubulin receptors (IF receptor) endocytose the complex
In the ileal cells, B12 is associated with transcobalamin II, which is a carrier protein
B12 is delivered to the liver, bone marrow and GIT

Solution to Question 3:
Phenytoin therapy causes folate deficiency leading to megaloblastic anaemia. It does not cause vitamin B12 deficiency.
Dietary folate is in polyglutamate form, which is then converted into monoglutamates by the intestinal conjugase. Phenytoin acts by inhibiting this enzyme, thereby causing folate deficiency, and thus megaloblastic anaemia.
Options A, B and C: They cause megaloblastic anemia due to vitamin B12 deficiciency.
Solution to Question 4:
Skin hyperpigmentation especially on the dorsum of hands involving the knuckles is seen in cyanocobalamin or vitamin B12 deficiency which is a causative factor of megaloblastic anaemia.
In megaloblastic anaemia, there is impairment of DNA synthesis that leads to ineffective hematopoiesis. It also causes distinctive morphologic changes, including abnormally large erythroid precursors and red cells.
Clinical features of megaloblastic anaemia (cyanocobalamin and folate deficiency) include: Peripheral smear findings:
Macro-ovalocytes
Most macrocytes lack the central pallor of normal red cells and even appear hyperchromic, but the MCHC is not elevated.
Reticulocyte count is low
Nucleated red cell progenitors occasionally appear in the circulating blood when anaemia is severe
Neutrophils are also larger than normal (macro polymorphonuclear) and show nuclear hypersegmentation, having five or more nuclear lobules
The image given below shows hypersegmented neutrophils seen in megaloblastic anaemia.

Solution to Question 5:

Solution to Question 6:
The reticulocyte count is decreased in megaloblastic anaemia.
The reticulocyte count is indicative of bone marrow function and its ability to produce healthy erythrocytes. In megaloblastic anemia, there is intramedullary hemolysis leading to raised indirect bilirubin and impaired erythroid maturation leading to a low reticulocyte count.
Solution to Question 7:
Increased serum homocysteine levels are common to both vitamin B12 deficiency and folate deficiency. Hence, it cannot be used to differentiate between them.
Solution to Question 8:
The marked structure in this peripheral smear showing figure of 8 appearance is a Cabot ring. They are RBC inclusion bodies seen in conditions due to ineffective erythropoiesis. It is considered a remnant of microtubules during cell division.
Cabot rings can be seen in the following conditions:
Megaloblastic anaemia
Post-splenectomy patients
Lead poisoning
Hemolytic anemias
Option A: Heinz bodies are due to oxidative damage, seen in G6PD deficiency.
Option B: Basophilic stippling is due to ribosomal precipitation, seen in heavy metal poisoning, thalassemia and sickle cell disease.
Option D: Howell Jolly bodies are due to ineffective RBC enucleation, characteristic of asplenia.
