Schilling test cannot identify the extent of megaloblastic anaemia.
Solution to Question 10:
Type III antibodies are not against haptocorrin. They recognize the  and  subunits of the gastric proton pumps.
Pernicious anaemia is a specific form of megaloblastic anaemia caused by autoimmune gastritis. It impairs the production of intrinsic factor, which is required for vitamin B12 uptake from the gut.
Types of antibodies in pernicious anaemia are:
Type I antibodies - block the binding of vitamin B12 to intrinsic factor. They are found in both plasma and gastric juice
Type II antibodies - prevent binding of the intrinsic factor-vitamin B12 (IF-B12) complex to its ileal receptor
Type III antibodies - recognize the  and  subunits of the gastric proton pump of parietal cells
Solution to Question 11:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of anaemia of chronic diseases (ACD). In this condition, the anaemia initially can be normocytic normochromic.
ACD occurs in the setting of persistent systemic inflammation. It is associated with
Low serum iron
Reduced total iron-binding capacity
Abundant stored iron in tissue macrophages
Inflammatory mediators like IL-6 stimulate an increase in the production of hepcidin.
This inhibits ferroportin function in the macrophages and reduces the transfer of iron from the storage pool to developing erythroid precursors in the marrow. As a result, erythroid precursors are starved for iron despite the availability of plenty of iron in tissue macrophages.

Solution to Question 12:
Acanthocyte or spur cells are seen in anaemia of liver disease. These cells are characterized by only a few spicules of varying sizes that project from the cell surface at irregular intervals.
Conditions where acanthocytes can be seen include:
Severe liver disease
Abetalipoproteinemia
Post splenectomy
Hyposplenism
The image given below shows a peripheral smear with acanthoctye.

Echinocytes or burr cells are seen in anaemia of renal disease. These cells are characterized by smaller, regularly spaced projections, smoothly rounded crenulations which are uniform in shape and distribution compared to acanthocytes.
Conditions where echinocytes can be seen include:
Anaemia of renal disease (uremia)
In premature infants, after exchange transfusion
Storage artefact
The image given below shows a peripheral smear with echinocytes.

The given hemogram is suggestive of pancytopenia. Cause of pancytopenia can be aplastic anaemia (hypocellular bone marrow) or myeloid neoplasms (hypercellular bone marrow). Hence, the best investigation is bone marrow biopsy to differentiate between them.
Findings in bone marrow biopsy in aplastic anaemia:

Abundant fat cells
Fibrous stroma, scattered lymphocytes, and plasma cells
Bone marrow aspiration often yields a dry tap, so biopsy is preferred.

Solution to Question 18:
The most common cause of myelophthisic anaemia is metastatic cancer from the breast, lung, and prostate.
Myelophthisic anaemia describes a form of marrow failure in which space-occupying lesions replace normal marrow elements. Causes include:
Metastatic cancer
Granulomatous diseases
Myeloproliferative neoplasms.
This leads to the release of nucleated erythroid precursors and immature granulocytic forms into peripheral blood (leukoerythroblastosis) and tear-drop shaped red cells.
The image given below shows a peripheral smear with teardrop cells.

Solution to Question 19:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of myelophthisic anaemia. Prostatic mass with elevated PSA and age suggestive of prostatic carcinoma, which could be the likely cause in this case.
It is a form of marrow failure in which space-occupying lesions replace normal marrow elements. The most common cause is metastatic cancer from the breast, lung, and prostate.
Lab findings of myelophthisic anaemia include:
Myelocytes + nucleated RBCs = leukoerythroblastic image
Presence of tear-drop cells
Solution to Question 20:
The given findings are suggestive of pernicious anemia, which is associated with atrophic gastritis and vitamin B12 deficiency.
Anemic patient with a peripheral smear showing macrocytic RBCs and hypersegmented neutrophils are important characteristic features of megaloblastic anemia. Vitamin B12 and folic acid deficiency are the main causes of megaloblastic anemia.
Pernicious anemia is an autoimmune disease characterized by the presence of autoantibodies which impairs the production or activity of the intrinsic factor (IF). This is required for the uptake of vitamin B12. There are three types of autoantibodies namely, type I, II, and III. The action of each of these include:
Autoantibody type I prevents the binding of vitamin B12 to the intinsic factor (IF).
Autoantibody type II prevents the binding of vitamin B12-IF complex to the ileal receptors.
Autoantibody type III acts against the  and  subunits of the gastric proton pump, which impairs the production of intrinsic factor.
These patients also develop chronic atrophic gastritis, characterized by loss of parietal cells, infiltration of lymphocytes and plasma cells and megaloblastic changes in mucosal cells.

Solution to Question 4:
Reticulocytes are red cell precursors, which are non-nucleated.
They have blue-red polychromatophilic cytoplasm due to the presence of a reticular (mesh-like) network of ribosomal RNA. They can be visualized using supravital stains like methylene blue and brilliant cresyl blue, which stain the ribosomal RNA.
Reticulocytosis (increased reticulocytes) indicates effective erythropoiesis i.e. good bone marrow response to anaemia. It is seen in:
Hemolytic anaemia
Acute blood lo
Reticulocytopenia (decreased reticulocytes) indicates ineffective erythropoiesis i.e. poor bone marrow response to anaemia. It is seen in:
Chemotherapy
Aplastic anaemia
Bone marrow malignancy
Anaemia of chronic disease
Iron-deficiency anaemia
Vitamin B12 and folate deficiency
The peripheral smear shows reticulocytosis and spherocytosis seen in non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

Solution to Question 5:
In the given scenario, the corrected reticulocyte count is 3. It is given by the following formula:
Corrected reticulocyte count = Reticulocyte count × (patient's hemoglobin or hematocrit  standard hemoglobin or hematocrit)
So, in this case, the corrected reticulocyte count = 9×5/15 = 9/3 = 3
This formula corrects for hemoglobin. It will show you if the patient is making enough reticulocytes for the degree of anemia present. As the hemoglobin drops, reticulocytes increase from the normal range of 0.5–2.0%.
The standard reference range of hemoglobin concentration in females is 12-15 g/dl. Accordingly, in this scenario, corrected reticulocyte count would range between 3-3.75%. So, the best answer to this question remains option C.
Absolute reticulocyte count is the percentage of red cells that are reticulocytes (normal is about 0.5 – 2.0%). However, it does not reflect the fact that as the hemoglobin drops, there should be more reticulocytes, percentage-wise (for example, at a hemoglobin of 5, you should have a much higher percentage of reticulocytes than you should at a hemoglobin of 10). To take this into account, we use corrected reticulocyte count.
Reticulocyte Index = Corrected reticulocyte count / maturation factor
This corrects for the longer life span of prematurely released reticulocytes in the blood which is a phenomenon of increased red blood cell production.

Red cell distribution width (RDW) deals with anisocytosis of RBCs. It refers to the unequal size of the RBCs.
Normal values are:
RDW-SD (Standard deviation) - 39-46 fL
RDW-CV (Coefficient of variation) - 11.6-14.6%
RDW is of great use in two clinical situations. They are:
To differentiate between thalassemia and iron deficiency anaemia (IDA)
Thalassemia - the RBCs are small (low MCV) and of uniform size (normal RDW)
IDA - the RBCs are small (low MCV) but vary greatly in size (high RDW).
To diagnose dimorphic anaemia (anaemia due to both iron and vitamin B12 deficiency)
High RDW

Solution to Question 9:
Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is a disease that results from acquired mutations in the phosphatidylinositol glycan complementation group A gene (PIGA).
This gene codes for an enzyme that is essential for the synthesis of certain membrane-associated complement regulatory proteins. It is the only hemolytic anaemia caused by an acquired genetic defect.
PNH blood cells are deficient in 3 GPI-linked proteins that regulate complement activity:
Decay Accelerating Factor or CD55
Membrane Inhibitor of Reactive Lysis or CD59
C˜-binding protein
CD59, a potent inhibitor of C3 convertase, prevents the spontaneous activation of the alternative complement pathway. Red cells deficient in these GPI-linked factors are abnormally susceptible to lysis or injury by C5b-C9 membrane attack complex of the complement system.

Solution to Question 10:
All three cell lines, RBCs, WBCs, and platelets are affected in paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH).
PNH occurs from acquired mutations in the gene PIGA which affect GPI-linked proteins.
These causative mutations occur in a hematopoietic stem cell. Hence, all of its clonal progeny, i.e., red cells, white cells, and platelets, are deficient in GPI-linked proteins.
Clinical features of PNH include:
Intravascular hemoglobinuria - cola-colored urine
Pancytopenia + hypercellular bone marrow
Thrombosis (if hepatic vein involved  Budd–Chiari syndrome)
Solution to Question 11:
In PNH, the leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score is decreased.
Alkaline phosphatase activity is found predominantly in mature segmented neutrophils. LAP score is obtained by assessing the staining intensity in 100 consecutive neutrophils, with each neutrophil scored on a scale of 1–4. Conditions that result in an increase in leukocytes in all stages of maturity will reflect a corresponding increase in LAP.
Increased LAP

Solution to Question 12:
Among the following, Budd-Chiari Syndrome is the most likely the cause of death in a patient with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH).
Thrombosis (particularly venous thrombosis) is the leading cause of disease-related death in patients with PNH. 40% of PNH patients suffer from venous thrombosis, which commonly affects the hepatic, portal, or cerebral veins.
The pathophysiology of thrombosis in PNH is not completely understood, but two main mechanisms may be responsible:
Nitric oxide (NO) is absorbed by free hemoglobin (which is released during hemolysis).
Endothelial damage caused by the C5-9 membrane attack complex (due to deficiency of CD59).
Solution to Question 13:
The deficiency of GPI linked proteins on blood cells is seen in paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH). Cryoglobulinemia is not a complication of this condition.
Thrombosis is the leading cause of disease-related death in individuals with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH). About 5% to 10% of patients eventually develop acute myeloid
leukemia (AML) or myelodysplastic syndrome.
Solution to Question 14:
The gold standard for the diagnosis of PNH is flow cytometry. It provides a sensitive means for detecting red cells that are deficient in GPI-linked proteins such as CD59.
Investigations in PNH include:
Flow cytometry (gold standard) - deficiency of CD59 and CD55
Ham test (acidified serum lysis) - lysis of RBCs in a mildly acidic pH due to complement fixation
Bone marrow biopsy -
Hypercellularity with erythroid hyperplasia is seen in classical presentation
Patients who develop pancytopenia will have hypocellular bone marrow
Imaging - to evaluate venous thrombosi
Solution to Question 15:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of PNH (paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria). The curative therapy for this condition is a hematopoietic stem cell transplant.
Pancytopenia is seen in this condition. Flow cytometry shows 2 populations of red cells:
Marked red in the left lower quadrant - deficient in both CD55 and CD59, characteristic of PNH.
Marked black in the right upper quadrant - CD55+ and CD59+ cells from the residual normal hematopoietic cell
Eculizumab is a monoclonal antibody that can be used in PNH. It prevents the conversion of C5 to C5a and reduces hemolysis.
Immunosuppressive drugs are sometimes beneficial for those with evidence of marrow aplasia. Note: FDA has approved the following drugs for treatment of adults with PNH:
Ravulizumab injection, a long-acting C-5 complement inhibitor
Pegcetacoplan, which acts by binding to complement protein C3 and increasing hemoglobin concentration
Extravascular Hemolysis

Solution to Question 1:
The given peripheral smear shows Howell–Jolly bodies. They are not seen in paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria.
They are small nuclear remnants seen as inclusions in red cells and are characteristic of asplenia. They are seen in the following conditions:
Sickle cell anaemia - due to auto splenectomy
Hereditary spherocytosi
Thalassemia post-splenectomy

The most common types of mutations causing thalassemia are:
The different splicing mutations are:
Mutations that destroy the normal RNA splice junctions - completely prevent the production of normal  -globin mRNA resulting in  0-thalassemia
Mutations that create an ectopic splice site within an intron with normal splice regions - some normal  -globin mRNA is made resulting in  + thalassemia
There are two subtypes of chain terminator mutations:
New stop codon within an exon
Small insertions or deletions that shift the mRNA reading frame

Solution to Question 3:
Chromosome 16 contains an identical pair of -globin genes which is affected in alpha-thalassemia. This condition is due to decreased synthesis of alpha chains.
The two  chains are encoded by a single  -globin gene on chromosome 11.
Solution to Question 4:
 chains are coded by 4 genes i.e. two pairs of genes located on chromosome 16.
Free  and  chains are more soluble than free  chains. They also form more stable homotetramers. Hence, hemolysis and dyserythropoiesis in  thalassemia are less severe when compared to  thalassemia.
In HbH disease, excess  -globin chains form  4 tetramers. They are seen in older children with -thalassemia.
Hydrops fetalis is the most severe form of -thalassemia. It is caused by the deletion of all four
-globin genes. This leads to excess -globin chains forming -globin tetramers (hemoglobin Barts).
Solution to Question 5:
Hb Barts is a tetramer of -globin chains (4). This type of hemoglobin is seen in newborns with the most severe form of -thalassemia and results in hemoglobin Barts hydrops fetalis. There is no production of  chains.
Hb Barts has a higher affinity for oxygen. This leads to intrauterine hypoxia, eventually leading to stillbirth.
The image given below shows (a) immature red cell precursors in peripheral smear and (b)
stillborn hydropic infant in Hb Barts hydrops syndrome.

In HbH disease, excess  -globin chains form  4 tetramers. They are seen in older children with -thalassemia.
Solution to Question 6:
The given clinical scenario of extravascular hemolysis (jaundice and splenomegaly) and peripheral smear showing golf ball cells is suggestive of HBH disease. It is a type of  thalassemia where the HbH is composed of tetramers of  chains ( 4).
Hb-H disease is one type of alpha-thalassaemia with inactivation of 3 of the 4 alleles. It is more common in the Asian population. It usually manifests in the 1st year of life. It causes acute episodes of hemolysis when triggered by infections or oxidant drugs.
The decreased  chain production leads to a relative excess of  chains. This leads to the formation of HbH which has a high affinity for oxygen. Such RBCs are more prone to oxidation which causes precipitation of HbH to form golf ball inclusion bodies. This leads to increased sequestration and phagocytosis in the spleen.

The presence of HbA2 3% and HbF 97% indicates that it is a case of thalassemia major. In thalassemia major, hematological findings in image 1 showing poikilocytes and image 3 showing target cells are seen. Image 2 showing Howell Jolly bodies are seen in post-splenectomy thalassemia patients and not in this case.
Hematological findings in thalassemia major include the following:
Anisopoikilocytosi
Target cells (codocytes)
Nucleated RBC’
Dacrocyte
Basophilic stippling
Polychromatophilic cell

Solution to Question 9:
The given image shows NESTROFT i.e. Naked Eye Single Tube Red cell Osmotic Fragility test. It is a very useful screening tool for thalassemia, particularly in poor resource settings.
The principle is based on the decreased osmotic fragility of red cells in thalassemia. It is performed as follows:
Mix EDTA blood and 0.36% buffered saline solution.
Shake the tube and leave it at room temperature for 30 minutes.
Shake the tube again and immediately hold the tube in front of a piece of paper with text or lines.
The image given below shows the NESTROFT.

Solution to Question 10:
In the given clinical scenario, the risk of their offspring having thalassemia major is 0%.
From the given HPLC reports, the husband is normal (normal value of HbA2 is 2.5%±0.3%) and the wife has  thalassemia minor (HbA2 level 4.9%). This disease is transmitted with an autosomal recessive inheritance. Hence, the chance of their offspring having full blown thalassemia is zero.
In  thalassemia minor, the Hb A2 levels are increased to 4–8%. This is due to an elevated ratio of
 chain to  chain synthesis. Hb F levels are generally normal or slightly increased.
Note: Increased HbF (diagnostic) and normal HbA2 levels are features of thalassemia major.
Solution to Question 11:
The given peripheral smear showing spherocytes, along with the history, is suggestive
of hereditary spherocytosis. Inheritance of this condition is mainly autosomal dominant.
Hereditary spherocytosis is a structural RBC disorder making the RBCs more spheroid. The RBCs are less deformable and more vulnerable to splenic sequestration and destruction. This decreases the lifespan of RBCs.
Solution to Question 12:
Ankyrin is the most common protein deficiency associated with hereditary spherocytosis (HS).
The chief protein component of the RBC membrane skeleton is spectrin. It consists of two polypeptide chains, alpha and beta. These dimers associate with actin oligomers. The spectrin–actin skeleton is then connected to the cell membrane by two distinct interactions.
Ankyrin and band 4.2 binds spectrin to the transmembrane ion transporter, band 3
Protein 4.1 binds the tail of spectrin to the transmembrane protein glycophorin A
Defect in any of the components of the red cell membrane skeleton results in hereditary spherocytosis. The image given below shows the pathogenesis of this condition.

Note: Few one-liners on membrane skeleton -
Most abundant integral proteins - glycophorin, band 3
Responsible for biconcave shape of RBC - spectrin
Most severe deficiency - spectrin
Hereditary elliptocytosis is due to deficiency of alpha spectrin
Mushroom cells appearance due to deficiency of band 3
Never involved in HS - glycophorin
Solution to Question 13:
Pincer cell or mushroom cell is seen in hereditary spherocytosis associated with deficiency of cytoskeletal protein band 3.

Solution to Question 14:
Hemoglobinuria is not seen in hereditary spherocytosis where extravascular hemolysis occurs. It is a feature of intravascular hemolysis. Pigment gallstones, pallor and splenomegaly can be seen in this condition.
Cinical features of extravascular hemolysis include:
Anaemia
Jaundice
Splenomegaly
Causes of extravascular hemolysis:
Hereditary spherocytosi
Thalassemia
Sickle cell anaemia
Note: G6PD deficiency and autoimmune hemolytic anaemia can cause both intravascular and extravascular hemolysis.
Solution to Question 15:
The life span of affected red cells in hereditary spherocytosis is 10 to 20 days. The normal life span of RBC is 120 days.
Solution to Question 16:
Increased MCHC in hereditary spherocytosis is due to dehydration caused by the loss of K+ and H2O.
MCHC (mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration) is given by the formula hemoglobin / PCV
(g/dL). It indicates the amount of hemoglobin per unit volume. Note:
MCV (mean corpuscular volume) is given by the formula PCV / RBC (fL). It denotes the size of the RBCs.
MCH (mean corpuscular hemoglobin) is given by the formula hemoglobin / RBC (pg). It quantifies the hemoglobin in the RBCs.
Solution to Question 17:
Osmotic fragility curve shifts to the right in hereditary spherocytosis.
In hereditary spherocytosis, the cells are spherocytic in normal plasma (0.9% NaCl)
and hemolyse readily at higher concentrations than normal discoid red cells do, hence shifting the curve to the right.
Osmotic fragility is the susceptibility of the RBC to rupture under osmotic stress.
In hypotonic solutions, RBCs swell to become spherical and eventually hemolyse. In the graph, the x-axis represents the saline concentration while the y-axis represents the percentage of red cells that have undergone hemolysis. When osmotic fragility is normal, red cells begin to hemolyse at 0.5% saline, with 50% of hemolysis occuring at 0.40-0.42% saline and complete hemolysis occuring at 0.35% saline as represented in the curve.
In thalassemia and sickle cell anemia on the other hand, the cells are resistant to hemolysis and don’t hemolyse unless the concentration of saline is very low, shifting the graph to the left.

Solution to Question 18:
The given hemogram showing pancytopenia and spherocytes in peripheral smear is suggestive of aplastic crisis in hereditary spherocytosis. It is usually triggered by parvovirus infection.
Parvovirus infects and kills the red cell precursors. This creates a transient arrest of erythropoiesis
i.e. aplastic crisis as the life span of RBCs are shortened. The immune response clears the virus in 1-2 weeks.
Blood transfusions may be necessary during acute phases of the infection. This crisis can also occur in other hemolytic anaemias.
Solution to Question 19:
Glutamate lies at the 6th position of the beta chain of hemoglobin.
Sickle-cell disease is caused by a point mutation in the sixth codon of  -globin. This leads to the replacement of a glutamate residue with a valine residue.
Solution to Question 20:
Solubility can be used to differentiate as HbS is less soluble than HbA. The function, stability and affinity of HbS are similar to that of HbA.
In HbS, glutamic acid, which is a polar amino acid, is replaced by a non-polar amino acid valine at the 6th position. HbS molecules have the tendency to stack into polymers when
deoxygenated. This process converts the red cell cytosol from a free-flowing liquid into a viscous gel. This causes a change in the solubility of the hemoglobin.
The major pathologic manifestations of decreased solubility and polymerisation of HbS are chronic hemolysis, microvascular occlusions, and tissue damage.
Solution to Question 21:
In heterozygotes with sickle-cell trait, about 40% of the hemoglobin is HbS. The rest of hemoglobin (60%) is HbA.
Sickle cell trait is a largely asymptomatic condition characterised by heterozygosity seen for HbS (sickle hemoglobin). As only a fraction of the Hb are HbS, polymerization leading to sickling only occurs in severe and prolonged hypoxia. Offsprings of 2 heterozygotes have a 1 in 4 chance of having sickle cell disease.
In HbSC heterozygotes, HbS is 50% and HbC is 50%.
Solution to Question 22:
Among the given options, the heterozygous combination of HbS and HbC causes a more severe form of the disease. Overall severity is more in homozygous HbS.
Severity sequence is HbSS > HbSC > HbSA > HbSF.
In HbC, lysine is substituted for glutamate in the sixth amino acid residue of  -globin. The percentage of HbS is 50% in HbSC red cells and 40% in HbAS cells. Moreover, HbSC cells tend to lose salt and water and become dehydrated, which increases the intracellular concentration of HbS. Both of these factors increase the tendency for HbS to polymerize. As a result, individuals who are compound heterozygotes for HbS and HbC, have symptomatic sickling disorder (termed HbSC disease). However, it is milder than sickle cell disease (HbSS).
HbF inhibits the polymerization of HbS even more than HbA. Hence, infants do not become symptomatic until they reach 5 or 6 months of age when the level of HbF normally falls.
Solution to Question 23:
HbC promotes the sickling of RBC, whereas HbF opposes it. Factors that promote sickling are:
Increased MCHC
Hb C
Acidic pH
Hypoxia
HbF has a high affinity for oxygen than other hemoglobins. Hence, high oxygen content prevents sickling. HbF inhibits the polymerization of HbS. So the infants do not become symptomatic until they reach 5 or 6 months of age when the level of HbF normally falls.
Solution to Question 24:
The reagent used for the sickling test is sodium metabisulfite. It is an oxygen-consuming reagent, which induces the sickling of red cells in the presence of HbS.
Sickling test with sodium metabisulfite is used as a screening test for sickle cell anaemia.
Solution to Question 25:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of sickle cell anaemia. HbS gives protection against Plasmodium falciparum malaria.
Hand-foot syndrome or dactylitis of bones of hands and feet is a severe acute inflammatory response seen in sickle cell anaemia. It is caused by vaso-occlusive episodes leading to ischemia and finally infarction of the distal portions of the extremities.
Sickle cells impair the formation of membrane knobs containing a protein made by P. falciparum called PfEMP-1. This decreases the adherence of infected red cells to the endothelium.
Individuals with sickle cell trait are significantly less likely to have severe disease or to die from malaria. It is because of the increased phagocytosis of sickled cells in the spleen, which keeps the parasite load down.
The image given below shows sickle cells seen on peripheral smear in sickle cell anemia.

Solution to Question 26:
The concurrence of sickle cell anaemia and -thalassemia results in less severe hemolytic anaemia.
Sickle cell anaemia is caused by point mutations in  globin synthesis leading to defective HbS synthesis. When these RBCs release oxygen, the HbS polymerises leading to membrane distortion
Thalassemia is due to germline mutations causing decreased globin chain synthesis ( or  ). Since these diseases have a different pathogenesis, they can occur concurrently.
In alpha-thalassemia, the concentration of hemoglobin is decreased. Therefore the concentration of HbS in sickle cell anaemia is also decreased. Since HbS molecules should be close to each other for polymerization to occur. Since there is a decreased concentration of HbS in alpha-thalassemia, the HbS molecules are far apart. So there is a decreased polymerization of HbS and therefore less severity of the disease.
Solution to Question 27:
Aplastic crisis in sickle cell anaemia is caused by parvovirus B19. It is a transient arrest of erythropoiesis, usually triggered by an acute parvovirus infection. Parvovirus infects and kills red cell precursors. It occurs in sickle cell disease and other hemolytic anaemias.
Vaso-occlusive crises (pain crises) are episodes of hypoxic injury and infarction that cause severe pain in the affected region. The most commonly involved sites are the bones, lungs, liver, brain, pleen, and penis. Acute chest syndrome is a type of vaso-occlusive crisis involving the lungs. It typically presents with fever, cough, chest pain, and pulmonary infiltrates. Pulmonary inflammation may cause blood flow to become sluggish and “spleenlike,” leading to sickling and vaso-occlusion.
Sequestration crises occur in children with intact spleens. Massive entrapment of sickle red cells leads to rapid splenic enlargement, hypovolemia, and sometimes shock. Both sequestration crises and acute chest syndrome may be fatal and sometimes require prompt treatment with exchange transfusions.
Solution to Question 28:
Non-visualisation of the spleen on routine USG is suggestive of autosplenectomy, which is seen in sickle cell anemia. Splenomegaly is seen in thalassemia and hereditary spherocytosis.
In children with sickle cell anaemia, there is moderate splenomegaly. This is due to red pulp congestion caused by the entrapment of sickled red cells. As age advances, chronic erythrostasis produces hypoxic damage and infarcts. By adulthood, the spleen is reduced to a band of fibrous tissue. This process is called autosplenectomy.
G6PD deficiency and Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemias

Solution to Question 1:
The given clinical history suggestive of hemolysis after the antimalarial (primaquine) and Heinz bodies on PBF, points to a diagnosis of G6PD deficiency (Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency). It is inherited as an X-linked recessive trait.
G6PD is an enzyme belonging to the hexose monophosphate shunt (HMP) pathway. Deficiency of enzymes of this pathway causes hemolysis as the protective ability of RBCs from oxidative stress is impaired.
The image given below shows the Heinz bodies seen on peripheral smear.

Solution to Question 2:
The most common trigger for hemolysis in G6PD deficiency is infection. Viral hepatitis, pneumonia, and typhoid are the common infections that trigger hemolysis.
Episodic hemolysis (both intravascular and extravascular) is seen in G6PD deficiency. It is due to exposures that cause oxidative stress. The triggers include:
Infections - oxygen-derived free radicals produced by activated leukocytes
Drugs
Antimalarials - primaquine and chloroquine
Sulfonamides
Nitrofurantoin
Diet - fava bean
Solution to Question 3:
The given peripheral smear shows Heinz bodies which are dark stained inclusion bodies in red cells. They can cause intravascular as well as extravascular hemolysis.
In G6PD-deficiency, the RBCs are exposed to high levels of oxidants. This causes cross-linking of reactive sulfhydryl groups on globin chains. The globin chains become denatured and form membrane-bound precipitates known as Heinz bodies. These can be detected by supravital staining.
Heinz bodies can damage the membrane sufficiently to cause intravascular hemolysis.
As RBCs with Heinz bodies pass through the spleen, the macrophages pluck out the Heinz bodies. As a result, some of these partially devoured cells retain an abnormal shape i.e. as if a bite was taken out of them. Such cells are called bite cells. Bite cells are trapped in splenic cords and removed by phagocytes leading to extravascular hemolysis.
The images given below show Heinz bodies and bite cells seen in G6PD deficiency.




Solution to Question 4:
Acute hemolysis in G6PD deficiency is intravascular. This is marked by anaemia, hemoglobinemia, and hemoglobinuria.
These episodes are self-limited and intermittent. Reticulocytosis occurs during the recovery phase. Hence, features related to chronic hemolysis (e.g., splenomegaly, cholelithiasis) are absent.
Solution to Question 5:
The peripheral smear shows RBCs with anisopoikilocytosis with polychromasia and many bite cells (arrows) suggestive of G6PD deficiency. This condition is protective against Plasmodium
falciparum malaria.
Malarial parasites preferentially invade RBCs which are rich in G6PD. G6PD deficiency causes oxidative stress and hemolysis, preferably in the older RBCs. Reticulocytes and young erythrocytes have much higher G6PD activities and are less susceptible to oxidant damage.
P. falciparum can invade erythrocytes of all ages. P. vivax, and P. ovale invade reticulocytes
(immature erythrocytes) preferentially. Hence, a low G6PD level in older RBC is protective against
P. falciparum malaria.
Episodic hemolysis in this condition can be triggered by fava beans which is a staple in Egyptian cuisine.
The images given below show Heinz bodies and bite cells seen in G6PD deficiency.


Solution to Question 6:
Hemolysis in G6PD-deficiency anemia does not continue for the entire period that the patient takes the offending drug. It stops after a few days.
Two variants of G6PD, designated as G6PD– and G6PD Mediterranean, cause most of the clinically significant hemolytic anemias. The half-life of G6PD- is moderately reduced, whereas that of G6PD Mediterranean is markedly reduced; hence, the severity of deficiency is greater with the Mediterranean variant. The most common normal variant is G6PD B.
The hemolysis in G6PD deficiency is both extravascular and intravascular hemolysis. The damaged red cells are sequestered in the spleen and killed
by macrophages, causing extravascular hemolysis. The oxidative stresses can denature hemoglobin, resulting in intravascular hemolysis.
In individuals with G6PD deficiency, acute intravascular hemolysis begins 2 to 3 days after exposure to oxidants. Only older RBCs are at risk for lysis. The hemolytic episode is
self-limited because hemolysis stops when only younger G6PD-replete red cells remain, even if the patient continues to take the offending drug.
Solution to Question 7:
Warm antibody type is the most common form of immunohemolytic anaemia. Most of the causative antibodies in this condition belong to the IgG class.
Immunohemolytic anaemia is caused by antibodies that cause premature destruction of the red cells. Based on the temperature at which the different types of antibodies bind to the RBCs stably, they are classified as:
Warm antibody type - most common
Cold agglutinin type
Cold hemolysin type
Solution to Question 8:
The type of hemolysis seen in the different immunohemolytic anemia are:
Autoimmune hemolytic anemias (AIHA) cause both extravascular and intravascular hemolysis.
In warm antibody type, hemolysis is extravascular. IgG-coated red cells are phagocytosed and destroyed in the spleen.
In cold agglutinin type, hemolysis is extravascular and intravascular. In the peripheral vascular bed (low temperature), IgM binds to the red cells. This causes agglutination and
complement-fixing. They are unbound when they reach the general circulation. However, the IgM interaction causes deposition of sublytic quantities of C3b. It is an excellent opsonin, which leads to the removal of RBCs by phagocytes in the spleen, liver, and bone marrow.
Cold hemolysin type is a rare subtype of AIHA. Hemolysis is intravascular. IgG binds to the P blood group antigen on the red cells, which leads to complement-mediated lysis.

Solution to Question 9:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of drug-induced warm antibody type of immunohemolytic anemia. In this condition, primarily extravascular hemolysis is present. LDH may be increased when there is hemolysis.
Two different mechanisms for drug-induced immune hemolytic anemias are: Antigenic drugs:
Anemia occurs 1-2 weeks after initiation of large IV dose of the offending drug
These drugs bind to red cell membrane and are recognised by anti-drug antibodies
They can cause both extravascular and intravascular hemolysis
E.g. penicillin, cephalosporins, quinidine Tolerance-breaking drugs:
Antibodies are produced against red cell antigens, particularly Rh antigens
E.g. alpha-methyl dopa
Solution to Question 10:
In paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria (PCH), antibodies are directed against the P blood group antigen.
PCH is a cold hemolysin type of hemolysis caused by IgG autoantibodies classically. They are also called Donath Landsteiner antibodies and are produced often in response to a viral infection. This antibody is a biphasic hemolysin. i.e., the antibody binds to RBC at colder temperature but hemolysis occurs at core temperature 37°C.
This can cause substantial, sometimes fatal, intravascular hemolysis, and hemoglobinuria. Most cases are seen in children following viral infections and usually recover within 1 month.

Solution to Question 11:
Microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia is most commonly seen with disseminated intravascular coagulation.
It occurs in the following conditions:
Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP)
Hemolytic-uremic syndrome (HUS)
Malignant hypertension
Systemic lupus erythematosus
Disseminated cancer
A common pathogenic feature in these disorders is a microvascular lesion. Deposition of fibrin and platelets result in luminal narrowing. These vascular changes produce shear stresses. These changes mechanically injure the passing red cells producing schistocytes or helmet cells on the peripheral smear.

Solution to Question 3:
Rees and Ecker's solution is used as a diluting fluid in the RBC pipette for performing platelet counts. Its composition is:
The steps involved in platelet count are:
I - Filling the pipette
Diluting fluid is drawn to mark 1 of the RBC pipette and expelled
Blood is aspirated to 0.5 mark of the RBCs diluting pipette
Diluting fluid is aspirated to 101 mark
Blood and diluting fluid are mixed mechanically for 5 min II - Filling the counting chamber
Allow the counting chamber to stand for 20-30 minutes to allow the platelets to settle.
To prevent drying out of the preparation, it should be kept in a moist atmosphere, this is most easily arranged by placing the filled counting chamber in the bottom of a clean Petri dish, alongside which arrange a small piece of cotton wool which has been soaked in water and squeezed out. Petri dish lid is additionally put over the dish.
After 20-30minutes, the counting chamber can be removed and carefully transferred to the microscope stage.
III - Counting the number of platelets
Focus on the surface of the hemocytometer chamber with a high power dry objective. Dim the ight to make the thrombocytes visible, and count all of the thrombocytes in the entire center 1 mm² (erythrocyte counting area) of both sides of the hemocytometer. This gives the number of thrombocytes in 0.2 l of 1: 200 dilution of blood.
The number of thrombocytes counted X 1000 = number of thrombocytes/l of undiluted blood.

Solution to Question 4:
Spontaneous bleeding (non-traumatic) is associated with platelet values below 20,000 platelets/µL.
It most often involves small vessels. The common sites for such hemorrhages are:
Skin
Mucosa of gastrointestinal and genitourinary tracts
Intracranial bleeding - most feared site of bleeding
The production of the platelets is regulated by the hormone thrombopoietin produced in the liver. The platelet synthesis is also specifically increased by interleukin 6. The average lifespan of the platelets is 7–10 days. The normal platelet count is 1,50,000 - 4,00,000 /µL.
Solution to Question 5:
Functional platelet disorders have normal platelet count and increased bleeding time. Classification of platelet functional disorders:

Von Willebrand disease - deficiency or defect in plasma vWF
Bernard–Soulier syndrome - deficiency or defect in GP Ib IX
Defects in platelet-platelet interaction (disorders of aggregation)
Congenital afibrinogenemia - deficiency of plasma fibrinogen
Glanzmann thrombasthenia - deficiency or defect in GPIIb-IIIa
Disorders of platelet secretion and signal transduction
Storage pool deficiency - -Granule deficiency and gamma-Granule deficiency
Quebec platelet disorder
Chediak–Higashi syndrome
Gray platelet syndrome
Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome
Disorders of platelet coagulation-protein interaction
Scott syndrome - defect in factor Va-Xa interaction on platelets
Solution to Question 6:
Von Willebrand factor (vWF) is not synthesized by hepatocytes. They are produced by endothelial cells of liver and megakaryocytes. It is also found in:
Platelet granules - lesser compared to endothelial cells
Endothelial cells within cytoplasmic vesicles called Weibel-Palade bodies
Subendothelium - binds to collagen
It mediates the adhesion of platelets to sites of vascular injury (subendothelium). It links the exposed collagen to platelets. It facilitates platelet to platelet interaction and also stabilizes the hemostatic plug against shear forces.
It is a carrier protein for factor VIII and also protects it from proteolytic degradation
and stabilizes it. The half-life of factor VIII is about 2.4 hours when free and 12 hours when bound to vWF in the circulation.
Since vWF stabilizes factor VIII, a deficiency of vWF gives rise to a secondary decrease in factor VIII levels. This may be reflected by a prolongation of the partial thromboplastin time (PTT) in von Willebrand disease types 1 and 3.

Solution to Question 7:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of von Willebrand disease (vWD). Type 3 vWD is inherited as an autosomal recessive disease.
The characteristics of different subtypes of vWD are:
Type 1 is the most common subtype of vWD. In Type 2, vWF is expressed in normal amounts, but missense mutations are present that lead to defective multimer assembly. This type has several subtypes, of which type 2A is the most common.
Laboratory findings in vWD:
Prolonged bleeding time
Normal platelet count
Hess test - positive tourniquet test due to defective platelet adhesion
Ristocetin-induced aggregation - defective and diagnostic of this disease
Platelet aggregation with ADP, collagen, and thrombin - norma
Increased aPTT
Though the synthesis of factor VIII remains normal, the half-life of VIII in plasma decreases due to reduced vWF (carrier) levels. This leads to secondary VIIIC deficiency in plasma. So, the intrinsic pathway of coagulation is affected. Hence, aPTT is increased in these patients.

Solution to Question 10:
In Bernard–Soulier syndrome, platelet aggregation by ristocetin is abnormal.
The receptor for vWF i.e. Ib-IX is essential for normal platelet adhesion to the subendothelial extracellular matrix. In this condition, there is deficiency of Gp Ib/ IX. Clinical manifestations include epistaxis, ecchymoses, menorrhagia, gingival bleeding, and gastrointestinal bleeding.
Laboratory findings seen in Bernard-Soulier syndrome:
Prolonged bleeding time
Moderate thrombocytopenia
Platelet aggregation by ristocetin is deficient (but ADP, arachidonic acid, epinephrine, collagen -
normal).
Clot retraction - norma
Abnormally large platelets

Solution to Question 11:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Glanzmann thrombasthenia.
It is an abnormality of platelet GPIIb-IIIa (fibrinogen receptor). Platelets are unable to adhere to each other and to the underlying tissue of the damaged blood vessels. It is inherited in
an autosomal recessive manner. The symptoms include mucocutaneous bleeding in the neonatal period, menorrhagia, ecchymoses, epistaxis, and gingival hemorrhage.
Types of Glanzmann thrombasthenia include:
Type 1: Absence of GPIIb-IIIa
Type 2: Reduced surface expression of GPIIb-IIIa/ Essentialis athrombia - clot retraction is norma
Type 3: Dysfunction of GPIIb-IIIa
Laboratory features of Glanzmann thrombasthenia:
Normal platelet count and morphology
Platelet aggregation occurs in response to ristocetin, but not to other agonists (such as ADP, thrombin, collagen or epinephrine)
Clot retraction is absent

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP). Autoantibodies seen in ITP are most often directed against platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb-IIIa or Ib-IX. It is a diagnosis of exclusion due to the following findings:
Bleeding tendency - petechiae
Low platelet count, elevated bleeding time
Presence of megathrombocytes in the peripheral smear - a sign of accelerated thrombopoiesis
Female preponderance
Absence of splenomegaly
Note: Prothrombin time (PT) is normal in ITP.
Solution to Question 14:
Antiplatelet antibodies in chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) are mainly IgG class.
Autoantibodies most often directed against platelet membrane glycoproteins are IIb-IIIa or Ib-IX. It can be demonstrated in the plasma and bound to the platelet surface in about 80% of patients.
Solution to Question 15:
Lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly are uncommon in idiopathic (primary) ITP. They are seen in secondary ITP.
Chronic ITP occurs most commonly in adult women younger than 40 years of age. The female-to-male ratio is 3: 1. It is a type II hypersensitivity reaction. It is of 2 types:
Primary or idiopathic - without any risk factors
Secondary - presence of predisposing conditions like SLE, HIV, CLL Signs of accelerated thrombopoiesis that are seen in this condition are:
Megakaryocytes in bone marrow
Megathrombocytes (abnormally large platelets) in peripheral blood
The image given below shows 2 megakaryocytes seen in bone marrow aspirate (Wrights stain).

Acute ITP is mainly a disease of childhood. It occurs with equal frequency in both sexes, mostly after a viral illness. It is self-limited condition, resolves within 6 months.

Solution to Question 18:
Terlipressin does not cause drug-induced thrombocytopenia. Drug-induced thrombocytopenia can be caused by:

Quinine

They cause thrombocytopenia through direct effects on platelets or secondary to immunologically mediated platelet destructions. Quinine, quinidine, and vancomycin bind to platelet glycoprotein and create antigenic determinants that are recognized by antibodies.
Solution to Question 19:
The risk of severe heparin-induced thrombocytopenia is lowered with LMWH but not eliminated. Hence, once severe HIT develops even LMWH exacerbates the thrombotic tendency and must be avoided.
Management of HIT includes the immediate withdrawal of heparin therapy and instituting an alternative non-heparin anticoagulant.
Solution to Question 20:
ADAMTS13 deficiency is associated with thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP).
ADAMTS13 is also called vWF metalloprotease which degrades very high-molecular-weight multimers of von Willebrand factor (vWF). Its deficiency causes accumulation of these multimers in the plasma and promotes platelet activation and aggregation.
TTP is a part of a spectrum of clinical syndromes called thrombotic microangiopathy. They are caused by insults that lead to excessive activation of platelets, which deposit as thrombi in small blood vessels.
Features of TTP include:
Fever
Thrombocytopenia
Microangiopathic hemolytic anaemia
Transient neurologic deficits
Renal failure
Solution to Question 21:
The given clinical scenario and peripheral smear showing helmet cells or schistocytes are suggestive of hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS). This condition is most commonly associated with enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli strain O157: H7 worldwide.
This strain releases Shiga-like toxin. This toxin is absorbed from the inflamed gastrointestinal mucosa into the circulation and causes endothelial dysfunction. It leads to platelet activation and aggregation. Children and older adults are at the highest risk.
The image given below shows schistocytes or helmet cells seen in HUS.

Solution to Question 22:
Atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome is not associated with deficiency of CD59. It is associated with deficiency of the following components:
Complement factor H
Membrane cofactor protein (CD46)
Complement factor I
These three proteins prevent excessive activation of the alternative complement pathway.
Deficiencies of these proteins can be caused by inherited defects or acquired inhibitory autoantibodies. The disease may be associated with a remitting, relapsing course.
Solution to Question 23:
Coombs test is positive in immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) as it is an immunogenic cause of thrombocytopenia.
Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) are nonimmunogenic causes. Hence, Coombs test is negative in these conditions.

Solution to Question 24:
Weber–Osler–Rendu syndrome is a disorder of the blood vessels.
It is an autosomal-dominant disorder caused by mutations that modulate TGF- signalling. It is also known as hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia.
This condition is characterized by dilated, tortuous blood vessels with thin walls that bleed readily. Bleeding is most common in the mucous membranes of the nose (epistaxis), tongue, mouth, and eyes, and throughout the gastrointestinal tract.
Platelet count, prothrombin time (PT), and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) are normal.
Clinical conditions in which abnormalities of vessel wall cause bleeding include:
Infections - meningococcemia, infective endocarditis, rickettsioses
Collagen defects - Ehlers–Danlos syndrome, scurvy, and Cushing's syndrome
Perivascular amyloidosis - most common with amyloid light-chain (AL) amyloidosis
Henoch–Schönlein purpura
Drug reactions

Solution to Question 1:
The most common hereditary disease associated with life-threatening bleeding is hemophilia
options: It is caused by mutations in factor VIII, an essential cofactor for factor IX in the coagulation cascade. N te: von Willebrand disease is the most common inherited bleeding disorder. Solution to Question 2: The given clinical scenario showing hemarthrosis and elevated aPTT is suggestive of hemophilia. Specific tests for measuring levels of factor VIII and factor IX can determine whether it is hemophilia A or hemophilia B respectively. Clinical features of hemophilia: Hemarthroses - joint hemorrhages, later causing progressive deformities Recurrent bleeding Pseudotumour syndrome - fascial hemorrhages that occur as blood-filled cysts with calcification and proliferation of fibroblasts, giving the appearance of the tumor It is associated with elevated aPTT and normal platelet count, bleeding time, and PT. Option A: In ITP, the platelet count is low and bleeding time is prolonged. Option B: In functional platelet disorders, like Bernard Soulier syndrome, the platelet count is normal and bleeding time is prolonged. Option D: In vitamin K deficiency, both PT and aPTT are prolonged. PT is relatively more prolonged than is the aPTT. Solution to Question 3: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Hemophilia A (factor VIII deficiency). It is inherited as an X-linked recessive trait. Hence, it affects mainly males and homozygous females. Hemophilia B is also inherited as X-linked recessive trait. Hemophilia C is inherited as an autosomal-recessive trait. Solution to Question 4: Hemophilia A and B mostly affect males, but rarely can affect females also. Hemophilia A is an X-linked recessive disorder, affecting mainly males and homozygous females. Rarely, excessive bleeding occurs in heterozygous females. It is due to the inactivation of the X chromosome bearing the normal factor VIII allele by chance in most cells (unfavourable lyonization). About 30% of patients have no family history and the disorder is caused due to new mutations. Hemophilia B is inherited as X-linked recessive trait. There is a deficiency of factor IX. Hemophilia C is an autosomal-recessive condition and hence can occur in females. There is a deficiency of factor XI. Solution to Question 5: Patients with moderate hemophilia A have 2% - 5% of normal levels of factor VIII. The clinical manifestations of Hemophilia A vary in severity, corresponding to the level of factor VIII present. They can be classified as: Severi ty Levels of factor VIII Mild

Laboratory findings in this condition are:
Normal levels of bleeding time (BT), platelet count, prothrombin time (PT), activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), and thrombin time (TT)

Solution to Question 8:
Reptilase is a thrombin agonist which is used to differentiate heparin-induced thrombocytopenia
(HIT) and afibrinogenemia. It is resistant to the action of heparin.
The differential diagnosis for normal platelet count with elevated PT, aPTT and TT are HIT and afibrinogenemia. After adding reptilase, if the TT is corrected, it points to HIT.
In afibrinogenemia, since there is an absence of fibrin, there is no change in the TT.
Solution to Question 9:
Kasabach–Merritt syndrome is associated with DIC (disseminated intravascular coagulation). This syndrome is characterised by the following features:
Rapidly growing vascular tumour
Thrombocytopenia
Microangiopathic haemolytic anaemia
Consumptive coagulopathy
An unusual form of DIC occurs in association with giant hemangiomas. In this type, stasis and recurrent trauma to the fragile blood vessels cause thrombi to form within the neoplasm.
The image given below shows a reddish-blue lesion covering the lower part of the abdomen. It is a caverno-capillary haemangioma seen in Kasabach–Merritt syndrome.

Solution to Question 10:
Factor XII deficiency will not affect the clotting in vivo.
Unlike the clotting cascade in the lab (in vitro), the cascade in the body (in vivo) differs slightly - as tissue factor (TF) is the major initiator of the cascade. The TF/VIIa complex is the most important activator of factor IX and factor IXa/factor VIIIa complex is the most important activator of factor X. Factor V is involved in both the pathways as shown in the image below.
The coagulation cascade in the laboratory:
Extrinsic pathway sequence (in a test tube): Tissue factor  Factor VII  Factor X.
Intrinsic pathway sequence (in a test tube): Factor XII  Factor XI  Factor IX  Factor X Laboratory methods to initiate clotting include:
Intrinsic pathway - adding phospholipids, calcium, and either a negatively charged substance such as glass beads
Extrinsic pathway - a source of tissue factor

Solution to Question 11:
Prothrombin time (PT) evaluates the extrinsic pathway of coagulation.
PT measures the clotting time of plasma in the presence of an optimal concentration of tissue extract (thromboplastin). This indicates the overall efficiency of the extrinsic clotting system.
Causes of prolonged PT:
Administration of oral anticoagulant drugs - vitamin K antagonists
Liver disease - obstructive jaundice
Vitamin K deficiency
Disseminated intravascular coagulation
Previously undiagnosed factor VII, X, V or prothrombin deficiency or defect (rare)
Activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT) measures the clotting time of plasma after the activation of contact factors and the addition of phospholipid and CaCl2, but without added tissue thromboplastin. It indicates the overall efficiency of the intrinsic pathway.
Causes of prolonged APTT:
Disseminated intravascular coagulation
Liver disease
Massive transfusion with plasma-depleted red blood cells
Administration of or contamination with heparin or other anticoagulants
A circulating anticoagulant (inhibitor)
Deficiency of a coagulation factor other than factor VII
Intake of oral anticoagulant drugs
Vitamin K deficiency

Solution to Question 14:
The most commonly used vacutainer for coagulation studies is a blue vacutainer containing trisodium citrate.
The benefits of trisodium citrate are that the calcium ion is neutralized more rapidly in citrate.
Other anticoagulants are unacceptable for coagulation studies. The labile factors (factors V and VIII) are unstable in oxalate (grey), whereas heparin (green) and EDTA (lavender) directly inhibit the coagulation process and interfere with end-point determinations. Also, activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) tests are more sensitive to the presence of heparin (green).
The image given below shows colour coding of vacutainers with the anticoagulant used and their practical uses.

Solution to Question 16:
Thromboelastography (TEG) tests the entire coagulation pathway. It measures coagulation cascade, platelet function, and fibrinolysis.
It is a test that quantitatively measures the ability of whole blood to form a clot. The advantages are:
Global assessment of blood coagulability, including coagulation cascade, platelet function, and fibrinolysis
Rapid real-time bedside test with a simple methodology (point-of-care testing)
Diagnosis of coagulopathic bleeding
Guide transfusion therapy and decrease the use of blood products
Detect dynamic changes in blood coagulation during resuscitation
Predict the clinical efficacy of therapeutic agents affecting blood coagulability

Solution to Question 2:
Citrate dextrose phosphate adenine-1 (CDPA-1) can be used to store blood for up to 35 days. It helps in improving ATP synthesis during storage. Hence, it increases the shelf life.
The disadvantage of using CDPA-1 is that it increases uric acid stone formation. The shelf life of storage with other components are:
Acid Citrate dextrose – 21 days
Citrate-phosphate dextrose – 21 days
Solution to Question 3:
Blood received from blood bank should be completely transfused within 4 hours of receiving. Principles of blood administration:
All blood products should be given through an appropriate blood administration set containing a filter.
A careful aseptic technique should be practised at all times.
Vital signs should be documented before and after transfusion and as clinically required. For the first 15 minutes after the infusion has begun, the patient should be kept under close observation to detect any signs of a serious transfusion reaction. If none is observed, the infusion rate may be increased.
One unit of red cells is often given in 1 to 4 hours, depending on the amount to be transfused and on the patient’s cardiovascular status. Infusion of a unit for longer than 4 hours is not recommended, as there is a risk of bacterial proliferation because the opened unit is at room temperature.
No other solution and no medication should be added to or infused through the same tubing as a blood product.
Ringer’s lactate or other solutions containing calcium must never be added to a blood product because the calcium present leads to coagulation.
After the transfusion has been completed, the transfusion tag or record should become part of the patient’s chart.
Solution to Question 4:
Patients with thrombocytopenia receiving blood transfusions (platelets) are more prone to develop bacterial sepsis.
Sepsis is mostly due to significant bacterial contamination of the blood products. Platelets have the maximum risk of causing this condition when compared to red cell preparations. Since patients with thrombocytopenia receive platelet transfusion, they are at an increased risk of infections.
Platelets (unlike red cells) must be stored at room temperature. This is a condition that
is favourable for bacterial proliferation. Broad-spectrum antibiotics must be started while waiting for the culture reports.
The blood components that are preferred for the other conditions are:
Anaemia - RBCs
Hemophilia - FFP
vonWillebrand disease - cryoprecipitate
Solution to Question 5:
Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP) from AB blood group can be given to this patient as it is the universal plasma donor. AB plasma does not contain antibodies against antigens on RBCs of AB blood group.
O Rh-negative blood is the universal blood donor. It is used during emergency packed cell blood transfusion with an unknown blood group. It is preferred because it lacks the A and B and Rh antigens. Hence, it cannot be hemolyzed by anti-A, anti-B or anti-D antibodies in the recipient’s blood.
Solution to Question 6:
The most common blood transfusion reaction is the febrile nonhemolytic reaction.
Solution to Question 7:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of severe, potentially fatal, allergic reactions. These are most likely to occur in patients with IgA deficiency.
Such reactions may occur when blood products containing certain antigens are given to previously sensitized recipients. It is triggered by recipient IgG antibodies that recognize IgA in the infused blood product.
Solution to Question 8:
The given image, showing a raised and erythematous lesion, is suggestive of urticaria. Such reactions may be triggered by the presence of an allergen in the donated blood product that is recognized by IgE antibodies in the recipient.
These are mild reactions occurring more commonly in 1% to 3% of transfusions.
Solution to Question 9:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of delayed hemolytic reaction following blood transfusion. It is IgG mediated and gives a positive result in direct Coombs test.
These antibodies recognize foreign protein red cell antigens in a previously sensitized recipient (through a prior blood transfusion). They present with laboratory features of hemolysis like low haptoglobin level and elevated LDH.
Acute hemolytic reactions are usually caused by preformed IgM antibodies against donor red cells that fix complement. The direct Coombs test is usually positive.

Solution to Question 10:
Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) is sudden-onset respiratory failure that occurs during or soon after the transfusion. It occurs within 6 hours, and not after 2 days following transfusion.
TRALI is a severe fatal complication of blood transfusion. The incidence of TRALI is low (1 per 10,000 transfusions). However, it may occur more frequently in patients with preexisting lung disease.
The pathogenesis involves a two-hit hypothesis:
Priming event - increased sequestration and sensitization of neutrophils in the microvasculature of the lung
Second hit - the factor (most commonly MHC class I antigens) present in the transfused blood roduct activates the primed neutrophils
TRALI can occur in transfusions with all plasma-containing blood products. However, it is more likely to occur following the transfusion of fresh frozen plasma and platelets. This is because these products contain high levels of donor antibodies.
Note: TRALI is important to recognize because donor products that induce complications in one patient are much more likely to do so in a second. Indeed, recent measures to exclude multiparous women from plasma donation have resulted in reduced incidence of TRALI.
Solution to Question 11:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of TRALI (transfusion-related acute lung injury). It is mediated by neutrophils entrapped in the lung vasculature.
Features of TRALI are:
Fever
Hypotension
Hypoxemia
Bilateral pulmonary infiltrates - not responsive to diuretics
Treatment is mainly supportive and blood transfusions are discontinued. The mortality rate in this condition is 5-10%.
Solution to Question 12:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO).
TACO is caused by rapid or excess transfusion of red cell preparations or plasma products. This condition is characterized by:
Dyspnea with O2% <90 at room air
Bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray
Systolic hypertension
Elevation of brain natriuretic peptide, 1.5 times that of pre-transfusion levels
It can be prevented by administering the transfusion slowly, at the rate of 1 to 2 ml of blood/kg of body weight per hour. Diuretics are also used if necessary.
Solution to Question 13:
The given scenario is suggestive of febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHTR). Such reactions can be prevented by using leukoreduced RBCs.
Removal of leukocytes from the blood is called leukoreduction. It is done before storage to prevent cytokine formation.
FNHTR may occur due to the following:
Sensitization to the WBC antigens by previous blood transfusions or pregnancy
Cytokines produced by the donor leukocytes during storage
Bacterial contamination
Note: Luspatercept is an erythroid maturation agent, a receptor fusion protein consisting of a modified extracellular domain of human activin receptor type-2B linked to the human Ig-G1 Fc domain. The drug was recently approved by the FDA for the treatment of transfusion-dependent
thalassemia.

Solution to Question 1:
Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria is not a preleukemic condition.
It is an autoimmune hemolytic anemia due to IgG autoantibodies that bind to the P blood group antigen and cause intravascular hemolysis and hemoglobinuria. Most cases are seen in children and show recovery within a month.
Option A: Few patients with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) develop acute non-lymphocytic leukemia. This is thought to arise from the injured marrow as a secondary hematopoietic disorder.
Option B: Bone marrow aplasia preceding acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is a rare condition that usually affects children. It generally follows the recovery of normal blood counts and most commonly occurs within 6 months of the onset of aplasia.
Option C: Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) occurs in 10% to 40% of individuals with myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS). It is usually accompanied by the appearance of additional cytogenetic abnormalities.
Solution to Question 2:
In acute leukemia, there is an arrest in differentiation and decreased apoptosis.
Genomic aberrations create oncoproteins. They arrest normal maturation, turn on pro-growth signaling pathways, or protect cells from apoptotic death.
Solution to Question 3:
As per WHO classification, 20% of blast cells must be present in the bone marrow and /
peripheral smear for the diagnosis of acute leukemia. In FAB criteria, the cut-off is more than 30%.
Solution to Question 4:
Polycythemia vera increases the risk of developing AML, not ALL.
Inherited diseases that are associated with a higher risk of developing leukemias are:
Bloom syndrome
Fanconi anemia
Ataxia–telangiectasia
Down syndrome
Type-1 neurofibromatosi
Other germline risk factors for the development of ALL:
Li-Fraumeni syndrome
Familial ALL syndrome
Note: AML has a higher incidence during the neonatal period than ALL among children with Fanconi anemia, Bloom syndrome, and Down syndrome.
Solution to Question 5:
Precursor B-cell or pre B cell (previously classified as L1) type is the most common subtype of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).
Solution to Question 6:
CD10 is not a primary marker of T cells. It is a marker of pre-B cells and germinal-center B cells.
Note: Although CD10/ Common ALL antigen (CALLA) can be found in B-ALL and T-ALL, it is primarily expressed by pre-B cells and germinal centre B cells. Lymphoblasts of both B and T cell lineages, express CD10 that is lost upon progression to a mature phenotype. It is variably expressed by a few mature B cell tumours. However, the expression of CD10 by mature T cells has not been well established.
Solution to Question 7:
Lymphoblasts in acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL) show block-like or dot-like PAS positivity. Erythroblasts in acute myeloid leukemia-M6 (AML-M6) show diffuse periodic acid-Schiff (PAS)
positivity.
The image given below shows dot-like positivity for periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) in lymphoblasts.

Solution to Question 8:
Lymphocytes do not stain positively with Sudan black dye. Although some positivity may be seen in azurophilic granules of lymphoblasts.
Sudan Black B (SBB) is a lipophilic dye that binds irreversibly to an undefined granule component in granulocytes, eosinophils, and some monocytes.
Solution to Question 9:
The most commonly affected gene in T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (T-ALL) is NOTCH1.
B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia is associated with mutations of genes such as PAX5, E2A, and EBF. It may be associated with balanced t(12;21) involving the genes ETV6 and RUNX1.
Solution to Question 10:
The size of BCR-ABL protein in t(9;22) associated with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is 190 kDa.
BCR-ABL fusion transcript protein with t(9;22):
Major BCR (M-BCR) 210 kDa size in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) with weaker tyrosine kinase activity
Minor BCR (m-BCR) 190 kDa size in acute lymphoblastic leukemia ( ALL) with stronger tyrosine kinase activity
Micro BCR (-BCR) 230 kDa size in myeloproliferative neoplasm (MPN) with exuberant neutrophilia
Solution to Question 11:
Cytoplasmic immunoglobulins and CD10 are negative in early pre-B acute leukemia but become positive in pre-B ALL.
Solution to Question 12:
Cytokeratin is not a marker of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). It is an epithelial cell marker for thymoma.
Tdt, CD1a, and CD3 are markers of ALL.
Solution to Question 13:
The given scenario with bone marrow histology showing lymphoblasts (condensed nuclear chromatin, small nucleoli, scanty agranular cytoplasm) is suggestive of acute lymphoblastic leukemia.
ALL is more common in childhood. Clinical features of ALL include:
Bone marrow failure - anemia, fever, infections, bleeding
Mass effects due to neoplastic infiltration - bone pain, generalized lymphadenopathy, plenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and testicular enlargement
CNS manifestations - headache, vomiting, and nerve palsie
B-ALL - Pancytopenia due to marrow involvement
T-ALL - Mediastinal mass, compression of large vessels and airways in the mediastinum, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly
Solution to Question 14:
The given clinical scenario and bone marrow aspirate are suggestive of T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Thus, immunophenotyping of the blasts would demonstrate an immature T-cell phenotype (Tdt/CD34/CD7 positive).
The bone marrow aspirate shows lymphoblast with condensed nuclear chromatin, small inconspicuous nucleoli, and scanty cytoplasm lacking granules.
ALL is usually seen in adolescent boys with thymic involvement in 50% to 70%. It has an abrupt stormy onset, within days to a few weeks of the first symptoms.
Clinical features of ALL include:
Bone marrow failure - anemia, fever, infections, bleeding
Mass effects due to neoplastic infiltration - bone pain, generalized lymphadenopathy, plenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and testicular enlargement
CNS manifestations - headache, vomiting, and nerve palsie
B-ALL - Pancytopenia due to marrow involvement
T-ALL - Mediastinal mass, compression of large vessels and airways in the mediastinum, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly
Solution to Question 15:
The given clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) based on immunophenotyping.
CD10 and CD19 are markers for B-cell lineage and this patient most probably have B-ALL. Although CD13 and CD33 are myeloid antigens, their expression does not exclude the diagnosis of B- ALL.
Option B: The diagnosis of mixed phenotypic acute leukemia (MPAL)/ acute leukemia of ambiguous lineage (ALAL) (previously known as biphenotypic leukemia) requires a demonstration of multiple lineages in blast cells. According to WHO's latest update (2022), the requirements for assigning more than one lineage to blast cells are :
In the absence of MPO or evidence of monocytic differentiation, expression of CD13 and CD33 is not sufficient for a diagnosis of MPAL. Hence, biphenotypic leukemia is not the answer here.
B cell lineage
CD19 strong:1 expressed CD 10, CD22, CD79aCD 19 weak:
 2 or more strongly expresse d CD10, CD22, CD79a
T cell lineage
CD3 positive
Myeloid linea ge
Myeloperoxidase (MPO)ORM onocyte differentiation (non- specific esterase, CD11c, CD1 4, CD64, lysozyme)
Solution to Question 16:
The presence of t (12;21) indicates a good prognosis in acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). It involves genes ETV6 and RUNX1.
Conversely, a translocation involving the MLL gene, t(9;22), and hypodiploidy are associated with a bad prognosis.
Solution to Question 17:
The given bone marrow biopsy report is suggestive of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). The good prognostic markers of ALL include trisomy 7, hyperdiploidy, and age of 5 years.
