d
Solution to Question 1:
CD3 is not a myeloid marker. It is a T-cell lymphoid marker. Cell markers:
B-cell: CD10, CD19, CD20, CD22, CD23, CD24, CD79b, CD103, Pax-5, kappa, lambda, CD200,
cytoplasmic kappa, cytoplasmic lambda
T- cell: CD1, CD2, CD3, CD4, CD5, CD6,CD7, CD8, TCR apha-beta, TCR gamma-delta, cytoplasmic CD3
Myeloid: CD11b, CD13, CD14, CD15, CD33, CD64, CD 117, myeloperoxidase
Solution to Question 2:
The most common type of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is AML - M2 or AML with maturation. The least common type of AML is AML M7 or megakaryocytic.
Solution to Question 3:
The most common subtype of AML seen in Down's syndrome is acute myeloid leukemia-M7 (AML
- M7) or acute megakaryocytic leukemia.
Myeloid proliferations of Down's syndrome are usually megakaryoblastic. It includes:
Transient abnormal myelopoiesis (TAM) - occurs at birth or within days of birth and resolves in 1 to 2 months
Myeloid leukemia associated with Down syndrome - occurs later, but usually in the first 3 years of life.
Both are characterized by GATA1 mutations and mutations of the JAK-STAT pathway.
Solution to Question 4:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
AML is a tumor of hematopoietic progenitors caused by acquired oncogenic mutations that impede differentiation, leading to the accumulation of immature myeloid blasts in the marrow. It occurs at all ages, but the incidence rises throughout life, peaking after 60 years of age.
The peripheral smear shows blasts with abundant cytoplasm, fine azurophilic granules, Auer rods, and delicate nuclear chromatin with 1-4 prominent nucleoli. The blasts are positive for
CD33. Occasionally, blasts are entirely absent from the blood (aleukemic leukemia). Bone marrow examination is essential to exclude acute leukemia in pancytopenic patients.
Solution to Question 5:
The image shows Auer rods in myeloblasts. These are needle-shaped azurophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies formed by the fusion of lysosomes.
Auer rods contain peroxidase and lysosomal enzymes. Myeloblasts with bundles of Auer rods are called faggot cells and are seen in acute promyelocytic leukemia.
Solution to Question 6:
Auer rods are seen in:
Acute promyelocytic leukemia
Myelodysplastic syndromes
Chronic myelomonocytic leukemia
These are not seen in acute monocytic leukemia and acute lymphoblastic leukemia.
Solution to Question 7:
The given cell shows multiple Auer rods clustered together within a single cell resembling a bundle of sticks. Such cells have been termed as faggot cells (faggot in French means bundle of sticks).
Since the question specifically asks about the cell, the best answer is faggot cell (not Auer rods).
Option A: Auer rods are distinctive needle-like azurophilic granules present in many cases but particularly numerous in AML with the t(15;17) aberration (acute promyelocytic leukemia).
Option B: The term flaming promyelocyte refers to cells that appear to be breaking apart, taking on a vibrant reddish-purple hue with the apparent liberation of granules into the surrounding cellular matrix.
Option C: Promyelocytes containing fine granules appear dusky or hazy and are referred to as dusky promyelocytes.
Solution to Question 8:
Serum muramidase or lysozyme levels are seen to be increased in patients with acute myelomonocytic leukemia (AML - M4).
It is also increased in chronic myelomonocytic leukemia and chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).
Solution to Question 9:
Acute myeloid leukemia-M6 (AML-M6) or acute erythroid leukemia is known as Di Guglielmo disease.
AML-M6 accounts for 1% of AML cases. It has two subtypes:
Erythroid/myeloid leukemia (M6a, more common) - Dyserythropoiesis is prominent
Pure erythroid leukemia/ erythemic myelosis/ Di Guglielmo disease (M6b, rare) - >80% erythroid precursors. Clinical findings include anemia, thrombocytopenia, and variable neutropenia.
Positive stains for erythroid cells are glycophorin A, hemoglobin A, CD36, CD71, CD117, and PAS.
Solution to Question 10:
Acute megakaryocytic leukemia (AML M7) may yield a dry tap on marrow aspiration.
It may be associated with extensive bone marrow fibrosis as a result of the stimulation of the normal fibroblasts by the local secretion of platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) by the leukemic cells.
Solution to Question 11:
The presence of faggot cells is highly suggestive of acute myeloid leukemia - M3 (AML - M3) or acute promyelocytic leukemia.
A cluster of Auer rods is known as a faggot cell. It is characteristic of acute myeloid leukemia
(AML) M3.
The image given below shows AML M3 with a cluster of Auer rods (faggot cell).

Solution to Question 12:
The patient shows features of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). It is most likely to be associated with acute myeloid leukemia - M3 or acute promyelocytic leukemia. The pathogenesis behind this is t(15,17) or PML-RARA fusion gene.
Option A: Inversion 16 is seen in acute myelomonocytic leukemia or AML - M4. Option B: t(8;21) is seen in AML with differentiation or AML - M2.
Option C: Inversion 3 is seen in AML - M7 (megakaryoblastic) which shows normal or increased platelet count. It has a poor prognosis.
Solution to Question 13:
AML M0 is negative for myeloperoxidase (MPO). AML-M5 (monocytic), AML-M6 (erythroid), and AML-M7 (megakaryocytic) are also negative for MPO.
Myeloperoxidase (MPO) is located in the primary granules of neutrophils and their precursors, in eosinophil granules, and in the azurophilic granules of monocytes.
The most primitive myeloblasts are negative, with granular positivity appearing progressively as they mature toward the promyelocyte stage. Promyelocytes and myelocytes are the most strongly staining cells in the granulocyte series. Monoblasts and monocytes may be negative or positive.
AML-M4 shows both myelocytic and monocytic differentiation. Hence, it shows both MPO and non-specific esterase (marker for monocytes) positivity.
Solution to Question 14:
The given clinical scenario with myeloblasts that stain positive for CD61 is suggestive of acute megakaryocytic leukemia (AML-M7).
AML M7 is the least common type of AML. Blasts of megakaryocytic lineage predominate and are associated with marrow fibrosis. There is also frequent budding of cytoplasmic margins.
They are CD41+ and CD61+. They stain negatively with Sudan black B (SBB) and myeloperoxidase
(MPO). Blasts are reactive with PAS and acid phosphatase. The prognosis for this type of acute leukemia is poor.
Solution to Question 15:
The given image shows leukemia cutis. It is seen in acute myeloid leukemia - M4 and acute myeloid leukemia - M5. It refers to leukemic cells infiltrating the skin.
Signs and symptoms related to the involvement of tissues other than the marrow are usually less striking in AML than in acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL). But tumors with monocytic differentiation (AML M4, M5) often infiltrate the skin (leukemia cutis) and the gingiva. This probably reflects the normal tendency of monocytes to extravasate into tissues.
Solution to Question 16:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute myeloid leukemia-M5 (AML-M5) or acute monocytic leukemia.
The patients with AML - M5 develop organomegaly, lymphadenopathy, gingival hyperplasia, C•S involvement, and other tissue infiltration. The bone marrow aspirate shows 20% or more
blasts. Monoblasts have folded or lobulated nuclei, lack Auer rods, and are nonspecific esterase positive.
Myeloperoxidase is present in the azurophilic granules of neutrophils and their precursors. It is positive in AML M1, M2, M3, M4 and negative in AML M0. Monoblasts and monocytes may be negative or positive. When positive, the granules are smaller than in neutrophils and diffusely scattered throughout the cytoplasm.
The image given below shows bone marrow aspirate in AML - M5.

Solution to Question 17:
CD61 is a marker of acute megakaryoblastic leukemia, not chloroma. Lysozyme, CD43, CD45, CD117, and MPO are positive markers of chloroma.
Chloroma, also called myeloid sarcoma, granulocytic sarcoma, or myeloblastoma is an extramedullary tumor that occurs in 2% to 14% of patients with AML. Frequent sites of involvement are:
Skin
Lymph nodes
Gastrointestinal tract
Bone
Soft tissue, testis
Peritoneum
Orbital involvement of myeloid sarcoma is rare without any evidence of systemic involvement. Proptosis is the most common presentation. Other symptoms include lacrimal
swelling, conjunctival mass lesion, retinal hemorrhages, ptosis, dystopia. Decreased visual acuity and ocular movement restriction have also been reported.
Solution to Question 18:
Arbiskov cells are monocytes seen in myeloblastoma or chloroma.
Chloroma, also known as granulocytic sarcoma, is a hematopoietic stem cell tumor,
where myeloblasts are located at extramedullary sites. Orbit is one of the most common sites of occurrences in pediatric population. It is seen in AML - M2 most commonly. Other conditions associated are myelodysplastic and myeloproliferative syndromes.
The image given below shows Arbiskov cells in chloroma.

Solution to Question 19:
All-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) is used in the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML),
which is associated with PML-RARA fusion gene.
Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML) is associated with a reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 15 and 17 producing a PML-RARA fusion gene. This fusion gene encodes for a chimeric protein, which consists of a part of the PML protein and a part of the retinoic acid receptor- (RAR).
The normal RAR binds to the D•A and activates the transcription in the presence of retinoids. However, the chimeric protein produced by PML-RARA has reduced affinity for retinoids. This causes inhibition of transcription, thereby preventing gene expression for cellular differentiation. This leads to the accumulation of myeloid progenitor cells.
The condition is treated with all-trans retinoic acid. It binds to the PML-RARA chimeric protein. This causes conformational change such that the protein regains its normal function and activates D•A transcription.
Solution to Question 20:
•ormal karyotyping with mutated •PM indicates a favorable prognosis in acute myeloid leukemia
(AML).
Solution to Question 21:
Inversion 16 is associated with a good prognosis in acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

Solution to Question 1:
Nodular sclerosis is the most common type of Hodgkin's lymphoma, while mixed cellularity is most common in India.
The incidence of nodular sclerosis is equal in men and women. It commonly involves the lower cervical, supraclavicular, and mediastinal lymph nodes. It commonly affects adolescents and young adults. It has an excellent prognosis.
Mixed-cellularity Hodgkin lymphoma is seen in patients older than 50 years of age. There is a male predominance.
The image given below shows the histology of nodular sclerosis showing a lacunar variant of Reed–Sternberg cells

Solution to Question 2:
An owl-eyed appearance of giant cells in lymph nodes is characteristic of Hodgkin's lymphoma
(HL). Mesenteric lymph nodes are infrequently involved in HL.
Hodgkin’s lymphoma is a group of lymphoid neoplasms arising in a single group of lymph nodes. Extranodal involvement is uncommon. However, if it spreads from the nodes, the first organ to be involved is the spleen, then the liver, and finally the bone marrow. This pattern of spread is known as the contiguous spread.
This predictable route of spread is important clinically as it aids in staging and prognosis as well as treatment of HL.
Solution to Question 3:
Activation of the transcription factor NF-B is a common event in classical Hodgkin's lymphoma
(HL).
NF-B may be activated by Epstein–Barr virus (EBV) infection. EBV+ tumor cells express latent membrane protein-1 (LMP-1) which upregulates NF-B. Activation of NF-B may occur in
EBV tumors as a result of the acquired loss-of-function mutations in TNF alpha-induced protein 3
(TNFAIP3).
Activation of NF-B by EBV rescues crippled germinal center B cells that cannot express Igs from apoptosis, eventually leading to the formation of Reed–Sternberg cells.
Solution to Question 4:
Copy-number gains in the REL proto-oncogene on chromosome 2p are particularly common in Hodgkin's lymphoma. It may also contribute to increased NF- activity.
Reed-Sternberg cells are aneuploid and possess diverse clonal chromosomal aberrations.
Note: the MYC gene, commonly associated with Burkitt lymphoma is present on chromosome 8.
Solution to Question 5:
Reed–Sternberg-like cells (RSLC) can be seen in the following:
Infectious mononucleosis
Large-cell non-Hodgkin lymphomas (most common in immunoblastic NHL)
Solid tissue cancers
While Reed-Sternberg cells (RS cells) are seen in Hodgkin’s lymphoma, there can be presence of Reed-Sternberg like cells which that may have morphologic features resembling RS cells.
Diagnostic Reed–Sternberg cells are large cells with multiple nuclei or a single nucleus with multiple nuclear lobes, each with a large inclusion-like nucleolus, about the size of a small lymphocyte with abundant cytoplasm (owl-eye appearance).
The image given below shows the classic Reed Sternberg cells.

Solution to Question 6:
Monomorphic is not a variant of RS cell.
Reed–Sternberg cell (RS cell) is the characteristic tumor giant cell of Hodgkin Lymphoma. It is derived from the germinal center B cell. It has a classic owl-eyed appearance due to the presence of a symmetric or mirror-image bilobed nucleus, with prominent nucleoli surrounded by a clear
space. It has the following variants:
Lacunar
Classic
L&H Popcorn cells
Pleomorphic
Mononuclear
RS cells should be present in a background of non-neoplastic inflammatory cells like lymphocytes, plasma cells, and eosinophils, to make a diagnosis of Hodgkin’s lymphoma.
The image given below shows the diagnostic Reed-Sternberg cell, with two nuclear lobes, large inclusion-like nucleoli, and abundant cytoplasm, surrounded by lymphocytes, macrophages, and an eosinophil.

The image below shows Reed-Sternberg cell, mononuclear variant.

The image below shows Reed-Sternberg cell, lacunar variant. This variant has a folded or multilobated nucleus and lies within an open space, which is an artefact created by disruption of the cytoplasm during tissue sectioning.

The image below shows the Reed-Sternberg cell, lymphohistiocytic variant. Several such variants with multiple infolded nuclear membranes, small nucleoli, fine chromatin, and abundant pale cytoplasm are present.

Solution to Question 7:
In the case of Hodgkin's Lymphoma, the pain in the lymph nodes aggravates following the intake of alcohol.
Clinical features of HL:
Painless enlargement of lymph nodes is the most common presenting symptom.
Cyclical fever (Pel–Ebstein fever) - cyclical increase, which then decreases over an average period f one or two weeks and night sweats in disseminated disease. This cyclical fever may be due t
the release of cytokines.
A unique paraneoplastic syndrome associated with Hodgkin's lymphoma is the occurrence of pain in the affected lymph nodes during alcohol consumption. This has been attributed to the enlargement of the affected lymph nodes following alcohol consumption, which stretches the capsule of the lymph node and produces pain.
Solution to Question 8:
The given clinical scenario with biopsy findings of CD15 and CD30 negative Reed–Sternberg cell is suggestive of nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma.
The Reed–Sternberg cells are positive for CD15 and CD30 for most subtypes, except in lymphocyte-predominant HL, in which the neoplastic cells stains for CD20 and BCL-6.
Solution to Question 9:
The given graph shows a disease with a biphasic incidence which is characteristically seen in mixed cellularity type of Hodgkin lymphoma.
It has a male predominance, biphasic incidence, peaking in young adults and again in adults older than 55 years. It has more systemic symptoms like night sweats and weight loss. There is diffuse involvement of the entire lymph node. It consists of a mixture of cells composed of T cells, eosinophils, plasma cells, and benign macrophages mixed with Reed–Sternberg cells. The mononuclear variant and diagnostic Reed–Sternberg cells are seen in this type.
Reed–Sternberg cell is infected with Epstein–Barr virus in 70% of cases. It has very good prognosis.
Image given below shows mononuclear variant of RS cell.

Solution to Question 10:
Mixed-cellularity Hodgkin's lymphoma is associated with older age, systemic symptoms like night sweats and weight loss, and advanced tumor stage.
It has a biphasic incidence peaking in young adults and again in adults more than 55 years of age. It also has a strong association with HIV. It is more common in males than females.
Nonetheless, the overall prognosis is very good.
Solution to Question 11:
The given image shows a lacunar variant of Reed–Sternberg cell. These are common in the nodular sclerosis subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma.

Solution to Question 12:
Reed–Sternberg cells in nodular sclerosis variant of Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) are negative for CD45. It is the most common variant.
These are characterized by the presence of lacunar variant Reed–Sternberg cells and the deposition of collagen bands. These bands divide involved lymph nodes into circumscribed nodules.
The Reed-Sternberg cells are found in a polymorphous background of T cells, eosinophils, plasma cells, and macrophages. Diagnostic Reed-Sternberg cells are often uncommon.
The Reed–Sternberg cells are positive for PAX5 (a B-cell transcription factor), CD15, and CD30, and negative for other B-cell markers, T-cell markers, and CD45 (leukocyte common
antigen). This subtype is uncommonly associated with Epstein–Barr virus (EBV).
Involvement of the spleen, liver, bone marrow and other organs and tissues can occur later in the disease.
The prognosis is excellent.
Solution to Question 13:
The lymphocyte-depleted subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma is associated with maximum necrosis of the lymph nodes.
Lymphocyte-depleted is the least common type (<5%). It is seen in older and HIV-infected individuals and can present with systemic symptoms. There is a paucity of lymphocytes and a
relative abundance of Reed–Sternberg (RS) cells or their pleomorphic variants. RS cells are CD15+ and CD30+ RS cells are infected with Epstein–Barr virus (EBV) in 90% of the cases. It has a poor prognosis.
Solution to Question 14:
The Mixed cellularity subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL) is most commonly associated with HIV.
Note: Although both mixed cellularity and lymphocyte depletion are seen in patients with HIV, mixed cellularity is more commonly associated with HIV.
Solution to Question 15:
The given image shows the lymphohistiocytic variant (L&H) of Reed–Sternberg (RS) cell. It is seen frequently in lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma.
The cell has the following features:
Polypoid nuclei
Inconspicuous nucleoli
Moderately abundant cytoplasm
As it resembles popcorn in its morphology it is also termed popcorn cell.
Note: A unique paraneoplastic syndrome associated with Hodgkin's lymphoma is the occurrence of pain in the affected lymph nodes during alcohol consumption. This has been attributed to the enlargement of the affected lymph nodes following alcohol consumption, which stretches the capsule of the lymph node and produces pain.
Solution to Question 16:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma (NLPHL).
Axial group (cervical) lymphadenopathy and along with the L&H variant of Reed-Sternberg cells is characteristic.
RS cells are neoplastic giant cells. In NLPHL, the cells have vague nodular formation. Immunophenotyping is positive for CD20 (B cell-associated), LCA (CD45), EMA (epithelial marker), and negative for CD15 (monocyte or macrophage-associated) and CD30 (activation marker).
The image given below shows the L&H variant of RS cells seen in NLPHL.

Solution to Question 17:
Nodular-lymphocyte predominant Hodgkin Lymphomas have Reed Sternberg cells(aka L&H CELL) that are BCL-6 positive & CD 20 positive and CD 15 & CD 30 negative.
Note:
CD30 is the most sensitive marker of Reed–Sternberg cell.
PAX5 is the most specific marker of Reed–Sternberg cell.
Solution to Question 18:
Lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL) is not associated with Epstein–Barr virus
(EBV) infection.
In 3% to 5% of cases, this type transforms into a tumor resembling diffuse large B-cell lymphoma.
A majority of patients are males, usually younger than 35 years of age, who typically present with cervical or axillary lymphadenopathy. Mediastinal and bone marrow involvement is rare.
This form of HL is more likely to recur than the classical subtypes, but the prognosis is excellent.
Solution to Question 19:
Clinical staging of both Hodgkin and Non-Hodgkin lymphoma is done by Ann-Arbor classification.
Option B: Masaoka staging is used for thymoma.
Option C: Modified Durie–Salmon staging is used for multiple myeloma.

The prognosis of the nodular sclerosis ( a subtype of classical Hodgkin lymphoma) is
excellent compared to the other subtypes mentioned in the options. Lacunar Reed-Sternberg cells are seen in this condition.
The nodular sclerosis type occurs with equal frequency in males and females. It has a propensity to involve the lower cervical, supraclavicular, and mediastinal lymph nodes of adolescents or young adults.

Solution to Question 21:
With current treatment protocols, the tumor stage is the most important prognostic variable, not histologic type.
Hodgkin's Lymphoma most commonly presents as painless lymphadenopathy. The cure rate of patients with stages I and IIA are close to 90%.
Long-term survivors treated with radiotherapy had a much higher incidence of certain malignancies, such as lung cancer, melanoma, and breast cancer.
Solution to Question 22:
Absolute lymphocyte count <600 cells/cumm is a poor prognostic factor for Hodgkin lymphoma.
Poor prognostic factors for Hodgkin's lymphoma:
Age >45 years
Male gender
Haemoglobin <10.5 g/dl
Total WBC count >15000 cells/mm3
Lymphocytopenia: absolute count <600/mm3 or lymphocytes <8% of leukocytes
Serum albumin level: <4g/dl
Stage IV

Solution to Question 1:
The mantle zone of the lymph nodes shows small, unchallenged B cells surrounding pale-staining germinal centres.
Structures in a follicle:
Germinal centre - round/oval zone containing pale-staining cells surrounded by darker cells.
Mantle zone - small, unchallenged B cells surrounding pale-staining germinal centres.

(NHL) in adults and children over the age of 15 years, worldwide and in India. Burkitt's lymphoma is the most common NHL in children under the age of 15 years.

Anaplastic large cell lymphoma is a T-cell lymphoma.
Solution to Question 6:
The most common site for primary extranodal lymphoma is the stomach.
The term primary extranodal non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma (PE-NHL) refers to lymphomas that present with the disease at any organ or tissue other than lymph nodes or spleen.
Gastrointestinal lymphoma is the most common form of primary extranodal lymphoma, accounting for 30%–40% of cases. The most common site involved is the stomach (60%–75% of cases), followed by the small bowel, ileum, cecum, colon, and rectum.
Note: The most common site for extranodal non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) in AIDS is Primary CNS lymphoma.
Solution to Question 7:
Primary effusion lymphoma is associated with human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8).
It is a rare type of diffuse large B cell lymphoma with lymphomatous effusions in pleural, pericardial, and abdominal cavities, but no tumor mass.
Only one body cavity is typically involved. It is strongly associated with HHV8 and advanced HIV and usually EBV. It can also occurs in non-immunosuppressed patients, often the elderly.

Solution to Question 1:
The peripheral smear finding shows Downey cells or ballerina skirt cells. These are typically seen in infectious mononucleosis caused by Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) and cytomegalovirus (CMV).
They are atypical lymphocytes with abundant basophilic cytoplasm containing clear vacuolations and prominent nucleoli. They become large as a result of antigen stimulation.

Solution to Question 2:
Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK) is associated with B-cell chronic lymphocytic lymphoma/ small lymphocytic lymphoma (CLL/SLL).
Tumour cells in CLL rely on signals generated by the B-cell receptor for growth and survival. These signals are transduced by a cascade of kinases that include BTK.
Note: BTK is also defective in patients with congenital X-linked agammaglobulinemia.
Solution to Question 3:
The clinical presentation and peripheral smear findings point toward a diagnosis of chronic lymphocytic leukemia.
The peripheral smear shows smudge cells and increased lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm, round to slightly irregular nuclei containing clumped chromatin. This large number of monotonous, uniform-looking, mature lymphocytes is often described as a "convent-girl" appearance.

Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) / Small lymphocytic lymphoma(SLL) is the most common leukemia among adults in the western world.
The differentiating point between CLL and SLL is that in CLL the absolute lymphocyte count is >5000 per mm³ and in SLL:<5000 per mm³.
It is usually asymptomatic at diagnosis but can present with easy fatigability, weight loss, and anorexia. Generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly are usually seen.
Total blood count:
Total leukocyte count is highly variable; leukopenia is seen when the marrow is involved.
Hypogammaglobulinemia is common and contributes to increased susceptibility to infections.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
% to 15% of patients develop hemolytic anemia or thrombocytopenia due to autoantibodies made by nonneoplastic B cells.
Peripheral smear:
Predominantly shows small lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm
Smudge cells or basket cells or parachute cells - artifacts of the lymphocytes which are disrupted during the process of making smears.
Contains a large number of monotonous, uniform-looking, mature lymphocytes, which is often described as a convent-girl appearance.
Spherocytes (due to coexisting autoimmune hemolytic anemia) and nucleated RBCs (due to premature release of progenitors in face of severe anemia, marrow infiltration by the tumor, or both)
Lymph node biopsy:
Diffuse effacement composed of small lymphocytes admixed with variable numbers of larger activated lymphocytes that often gather in loose aggregate
Referred to as proliferation centers, which contain mitotically active cells. Proliferation center are pathognomonic for CLL / SLL.
The chromosomal defects:
Deletion of 13q (commonest and has a good prognosis)
Deletion of 11q
Trisomy 12q
Deletion of 17p (poor prognosis).
Solution to Question 4:
The cell of origin for chronic lymphocytic leukemia/small lymphocytic lymphoma (CLL/SLL) is either a post-germinal center memory B cell or a naive B cell.
The cells of CLL show both unmutated Ig segments (those of naive B-cell origin) and somatic hypermutated Ig segments (those of post-germinal center memory B cell).
Tumours with unmutated Ig segments (those of naive B-cell origin) pursue a more aggressive course.
Solution to Question 5:
Deletion of 17p is a genetic anomaly seen in chronic lymphocytic lymphoma (CLL)/ small lymphocytic lymphoma (SLL), not trisomy 17p.
The genetic anomalies seen in CLL/SLL are:
Trisomy 12q
Deletion of 13q
Deletion of 17p (bad prognosis)
Deletion of 11q (bad prognosis)
Solution to Question 6:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukemia/small lymphocytic lymphoma (CLL/SLL).
Lymph node biopsy in CLL/SLL shows effacement of normal nodal architecture by sheets
of predominantly small lymphocytes. They have round to slightly irregular nuclei, condensed chromatin, and scant cytoplasm.
Admixed are a variable number of larger activated lymphocytes that often gather in loose aggregates referred to as proliferation centers. These contain mitotically active cells. When present, proliferation centers are pathognomic for CLL/SLL (also known as a pseudofollicular pattern).
The image given below shows a lymph node biopsy of CLL in a low-power view. It shows loss of normal architecture and a large, pale-staining area in the center of the node (a proliferation center)




Solution to Question 7:
The diagnostic requirement for chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is absolute lymphocyte count
>5000 per cubic millimetre.
Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) and small lymphocytic lymphoma (SLL) differ only in the degree of peripheral blood lymphocytosis:
CLL - 5000/mm3
SLL - <5000 cells/mm3
Note: CLL is the most common leukemia of adults in the western world.
Solution to Question 8:
Small lymphocytes of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)/ small lymphocytic leukemia (SLL) are CD23 and CD5 positive. Hence, the flow cytometry of patient 1 (CD23 and CD5 positive) correctly represents the phenotype of CLL.
The tumour cells also express the pan B-cell markers CD19 and CD20
Low-level expression of surface Ig (usually IgM or IgM and IgD) is also typical. Given below is the explanation of how to interpret flow cytometry results:

Interpretation of results:
œuadrant 1- Cells marked in green: -VE for A antigen, +VE for B antigen œuadrant 2- Cells marked in purple: -VE for both the antigens. œuadrant 3- Cells marked in yellow: +VE for both the antigens œuadrant 4- Cells marked in red: +VE for A antigen, -VE for B antigen
Solution to Question 9:
The given scenario and histopathological findings are suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukemia
(CLL). The presence of NOTCH1 mutation is associated with a poor prognosis in chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL).
The histopathological image shows small, darker staining lymphocytes with prominent nucleoli which are typically seen in chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL).

Variables that correlate with a worse outcome include:
The presence of deletions of 11q and 17p
Lack of somatic hypermutation
Expression of ZAP-70
Presence of NOTCH 1 mutation
Solution to Question 10:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of follicular lymphoma. This condition is associated with overexpression of BCL2.
It usually presents in middle age as painless generalized lymphadenopathy. The involvement of extranodal sites is relatively uncommon. It has an indolent waxing and waning course.
In almost 50% of patients, this cancer gets transformed to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. The median survival rate is for 7-9 years.
The cell of origin for follicular lymphoma is germinal centre B cells. It shows (14;18) translocation.
Lymph node biopsy shows closely packed follicles. Centrocytes (small cells with the cleaved nucleus and scant cytoplasm) and centroblasts (large cells with open nuclear chromatin and multiple nucleoli) are seen.
Bone marrow is involved in 85% of the cases and shows para-trabecular lymphoid aggregates.


Solution to Question 11:
Follicular lymphoma shows t(14;18).
Its hallmark is a translocation that juxtaposes the IgH locus on chromosome 14 and the BCL2 locus on chromosome 18. It is seen in up to 90% of follicular lymphomas and leads to overexpression of BCL2.
BCL2 inhibits apoptosis and promotes the survival of follicular lymphoma cells.
Solution to Question 12:
The lymph biopsy shows closely packed back-to-back follicles of variable areas and very less inter-follicular area. It is suggestive of follicular lymphoma.

Follicular lymphoma usually follows an indolent waxing and waning course, not an aggressive course.
Lymph node (LN) biopsy shows a nodular pattern with centrocytes and centroblasts as shown below.


Immunophenotyping:
The cell of origin is germinal-center B cell, so it is positive for CD19, CD20, CD10, BCL6, and urface Ig.
BCL2 expression is positive in over 90% of cases.
Histologic transformation to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) occurs in 30 to 50% of cases.
Note: In contrast to follicular lymphoma, DLBCL has an aggressive course, shows a diffuse pattern of growth in lymph node biopsy and shows BCL-6 positivity.
Solution to Question 13:
Mantle-cell lymphoma arises from the mantle-zone B cells which are naive B cells as they lack somatic hypermutation IgH gene.
Mantle-cell lymphomas have an (11;14) translocation involving the IgH locus on chromosome 14 and overexpression of cyclin D1.
It is CD5 positive and CD23 negative.

Solution to Question 14:
The neoplastic cells in mantle cell lymphoma are CD5 positive and CD23 negative.
Mantle cell lymphoma usually presents as painless lymphadenopathy. Centroblasts and proliferation centers are absent, differentiating it from chronic lymphocytic lymphoma.
Immunophenotyping reveals the cells expressing cyclin D1, CD5, CD19, CD20, surface Ig. CD23 is negative in these cells.
Solution to Question 15:
The given clinical picture and pathological findings point toward the diagnosis of mantle cell lymphoma.
The lymph node biopsy typically shows proliferation consisting of a homogenous population of small lymphocytes. The nuclei of these cells have irregular or deeply cleaved contours.
Mantle cell lymphoma has(11;14) translocation involving the IgH locus on chromosome 14 and the cyclin D1 locus on chromosome 11 that leads to overexpression of cyclin D1.
Option A: Follicular lymphoma has t(14:18), not t(18:14). Hence, it is not the answer.
Solution to Question 16:
Translocation (11;14) is characteristic of mantle cell lymphoma. The markers to be done to confirm the diagnosis, are Sox11 and Cyclin D1.
Mantle cell lymphoma is seen in the fifth and sixth decades of life and has a male predominance. It is characterised by painless lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly.
In some cases, there is multifocal mucosal involvement of the small bowel and colon known as lymphomatoid polyposis.
It has (11;14) translocation.
Lymph node biopsy shows nodal tumour cells may surround reactive germinal centres.
A homogeneous population of small lymphocytes with irregular to occasionally deeply cleft
(cleaved) nuclear contours is typically seen.
Large cells resembling centroblasts and proliferation centres are absent, distinguishing mantle cell lymphoma from follicular lymphoma and CLL/SLL, respectively.
Immunophenotyping is positive for cyclin D and SOX-11. SOX11 variant that often presents with circulating disease with splenomegaly but without significant lymphadenopathy and with a low Ki67 index (<10%).
Other markers include:
CD 5, CD19 and CD20 +ve
CD 23 -ve
Moderately high levels of surface Ig (usually IgM and IgD with  or  light chain) The IgH genes lack somatic hypermutation, supporting an origin from a naive B cell.
Solution to Question 17:
SOX11 is the marker used for cyclinD1 negative mantle cell lymphoma. Note: MYD88 is a marker for Waldenstorm macroglobulinemia.
Solution to Question 18:
Marginal zone lymphoma does not spread rapidly to other sites. It remains localised for prolonged periods and spread systematically in the later course of the disease.
They are B-cell tumours that arise within lymph nodes, spleen, or extranodal tissues. It is the most common primary extranodal lymphoma.
They arise within tissues involved by chronic inflammatory disorders of autoimmune or infectious aetiology:
Salivary gland in Sjögren disease
Thyroid gland in Hashimoto thyroiditi
Stomach in Helicobacter gastriti
They may regress if the inciting agent is eradicated. Antibiotic therapy directed against Helicobacter pylori leads to tumour regression.
Translocations are associated with MALToma are t(11;18),t(14;18) and t(1;14). These translocations then upregulate BCL-10/MALT1, a protein that activates NF-kB and promotes the growth and survival of B-cells.
They may invade epithelial structures to form lymphoepithelial lesions. Transformation to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma may occur.
Solution to Question 19:
Marginal zone lymphomas are considered to be of memory B cell origin. In most cases, they show evidence of somatic hypermutation.
The category of marginal zone lymphoma encompasses a heterogeneous group of B cell tumours that arise within lymph nodes, spleen, or extranodal tissues. They are often referred to as MALTomas.
Solution to Question 20:
Lymphomas arising in the setting of Sjögren syndrome in the salivary gland is marginal-zone lymphomas.
They often arise in tissues involved by chronic inflammatory disorders of autoimmune or infectious aetiology such as:
Salivary gland in Sjögren syndrome
Thyroid gland in Hashimoto thyroiditi
Stomach in Helicobacter gastritis.
Solution to Question 21:
The translocation seen in marginal-zone lymphoma is t(11;18). Other translocations include t(14;18), t(1;14).
Marginal-zone lymphoma begins as a polyclonal immune reaction. Signals from the
antigen-stimulated T helper cells, drive the growth and survival of the clonal B-cells. At this stage, it is reversible, as in gastric MALToma after antibiotics against Helicobacter pylori.
With time tumour cells may acquire mutations that render their growth and survival
antigen-independent. Translocations such as t(11;18), t(14;18), or t(1;14) up-regulate the expression and function of BCL10 or MALT1 and promote the growth and survival of B cells.
These translocations are relatively specific for extranodal marginal-zone lymphomas.
Solution to Question 22:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hairy cell leukemia. It is a B-cell neoplasm and not a T-cell lymphoma.
The peripheral smear shows leukemic cells with fine circumferential cytoplasmic hairy projections as shown below.

Patients present with massive splenomegaly and pancytopenia. There is an increased incidence of atypical mycobacterial infections, possibly related to frequent unexplained monocytopenia.
Activating point mutations in the serine/threonine kinase BRAF is seen in 90% of cases.
Peripheral smear shows fine circumferential cytoplasmic hairy projections which are best recognized under the phase-contrast microscope. The bone marrow aspirate produces a dry tap.
A trephine biopsy reveals infiltration by the cancer cells often in the pattern of a honeycomb appearance. Leukemic cells have nuclei surrounded by a cytoplasmic halo (fried egg appearance).
The neoplastic cells stain positive for tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP).
Markers for hairy cell leukemia include:
pan-B-cell markers- CD 19, CD2O
CD11c
CD25
CD103
annexin A1
Solution to Question 23:
The clinical features and peripheral smear showing fine circumferential cytoplasmic hairy projections point towards the diagnosis of hairy cell leukaemia.
It's a rare but distinctive neoplasm of the B cells where splenomegaly is often the only abnormal finding. Pancytopenia from marrow involvement and sequestration of cells in the enlarged spleen is seen in half the cases and infections are seen in one-third of the affected patients.
CD103 must be tested among the markers to confirm hairy cell leukaemia. Hairy-cell leukaemias typically express the following markers:
Pan B-cell markers CD19, CD20, surface Ig (usually IgG)
CD11c
CD25
CD103
Annexin A1.
Annexin A1 is the most specific and sensitive marker.
Solution to Question 24:
The area marked '1' in the image is the white pulp of the spleen. Hairy-cell leukemia does not arise from the white pulp, it involves only the red pulp of the spleen. The other condition involving the red pulp is hepato-splenic lymphoma.
All the other non-Hodgkin lymphomas (NHLs) involve white pulp.
Splenomegaly is the most common and often the only abnormal physical finding in hairy-cell leukemia. The spleen in this condition is described as a beefy red spleen.
The image given below shows the normal histology of the spleen.

Solution to Question 25:
The given pathological feature is characteristic of a Pautrier's microabscess. These are seen in mycosis fungoides.
It is a mature, cutaneous, CD4+ T-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Skin lesions include truncal scaling, red-brown patches, plaques, and fungating nodules. Lesions may evolve into a systemic lymphoma, with visceral and nodal spread.
Sezary syndrome is a variant of mycosis fungoides. It is the leukemic seeding of blood by malignant T cells from the skin (CD4+). It presents with diffuse erythroderma and scaling.
Histological hallmark includes:
Sézary-Lutzner cells - cells with cerebriform nuclei (infolded/hyper-convoluted nuclear membrane).
Pautrier's microabscesses - tumor cells invade the epidermis as single cells and small clusters.
Epidermotropism - invasion of the tumor cells into the epidermis.
The image shows sezary cells with cerebriform nuclei in the peripheral smear.

Solution to Question 26:
The image shows a classical Sezary cell with cerebriform nuclei which points towards a diagnosis of Sezary syndrome. These are neoplastic T cells.
Sezary syndrome and mycosis fungoides are different manifestations of tumors of CD4+ helper T cells that are home to the skin.
Sezary syndrome is a variant presenting as generalized exfoliative erythroderma. It rarely goe into tumefaction and there is associated leukemia of Sezary cells.
In Mycosis fungoides, only the epidermis and upper dermis are infiltrated by neoplastic T cells with the characteristic cerebriform appearance. In the later stages of the disease, progression occurs to lymph nodes and bone marrow. Tumour cells are not seen in blood. The disease progresses through the premycotic phase, plaque phase, and tumour phase.
Solution to Question 27:
A triad of rheumatoid arthritis, splenomegaly, and neutropenia is known as Felty's syndrome. Some patients with Felty's syndrome have large granular lymphocytic leukemia as an underlying cause.
Large granular lymphocytic leukemia is a T-cell (CD3+) and NK-cell (CD56+) variant leukemia. They are associated with mutations in the transcription factor, STAT3.
Patients usually presents with mild to moderate lymphocytosis and splenomegaly. Neutropenia and anemia are also present. Lymphadenopathy and hepatomegaly are usually absent.
There is an increased incidence of rheumatological disorders associated with this condition.
The peripheral smear picture shows large lymphocytes with abundant blue cytoplasm and few azurophilic granules.
Non Hodgkin Lymphomas: High Grade

Solution to Question 1:
The clinical presentation and biopsy findings point to a diagnosis of Burkitt's lymphoma. Neoplastic cells in Burkitt's lymphoma are usually BCL2 negative.
The biopsy image shows the classical finding of Burkitt's lymphoma called the starry sky appearance.
Tumour cells show multiple small nucleoli, minimal cytoplasm and a high mitotic index. They are closely apposed to each other forming a dark blue background (sky).
The macrophages get stuffed in between along with cellular debris. They are called tingible body macrophages. Upon fixation, the cytoplasm of these phagocytes washes away leaving behind white spaces filled with debris (the stars).

Burkitt lymphoma is the most common NHL in children <15 years. Three distinct clinical forms of Burkitt's lymphoma are:
Endemic- affects children in Africa, affects jaw, maxilla, and is EBV-associated.
Sporadic- in adults in western countries.
Immunodeficiency associated- is associated with HIV infection.
It is the most rapidly proliferating human tumor, Ki-67 stains for 100% of cells (DLBCL- 40% staining with Ki-67). Histology shows the characteristic starry sky pattern.
Immunophenotypic markers include:
Surface IgM type and immunoglobulin light chains (kappa > lambda)
B cell-associated antigens -CD19, CD20, CD22, CD79a
Germinal centre-associated markers- CD10 & BCL-6
HLA-DR and CD43
Expression of CD21 -the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)/C3d receptor, is dependent on the EBV status of the tumors
Endemic BL: EBV (+), express CD21
Non-endemic BL: EBV (--) and lack CD21 expression
Treatment must begin within 48h of diagnosis in both children and adults with an intensive combination of chemotherapy regimens with high doses of cyclophosphamide and CNS prophylaxis.
Solution to Question 2:
The translocation seen in Burkitt's lymphoma is t(8;14) causing translocation of the MYC gene. It is the most common translocation and is seen in 70% of the cases.
Other translocations that may be present include t(2;8) and t(8;22).
Solution to Question 3:
All forms of Burkitt lymphoma are highly associated with translocations of the MYC gene on chromosome 8 that lead to increased MYC protein levels.
In addition to the MYC translocations in Burkitt lymphoma and a subset of other B and T cell tumours, MYC is amplified in some breast, colon, lung, and many other carcinomas.
The functionally identical NMYC and LMYC genes are also amplified in neuroblastomas and small-cell cancers of the lung, respectively.
Solution to Question 4:
Sporadic Burkitt's lymphoma most often presents as a mass involving the ileocecum and peritoneum. About 15 to 20% of these are associated with Epstein–Barr virus (EBV).
Endemic Burkitt's lymphoma, in contrast, presents as a mass involving the mandible. It shows an unusual predilection for the involvement of abdominal viscera, particularly kidneys, ovaries and adrenal glands. Involvement of the bone marrow and peripheral blood is uncommon.
Immunodeficiency-associated Burkitt's lymphoma commonly involves the gastrointestinal tract
(GIT) and central nervous system (CNS).
Solution to Question 5:
Burkitt's lymphoma is a very aggressive tumour, having a very high mitotic index and a ki67 of about 100%.
ki67 is a proliferation marker used to assess the mitotic index of the tumour. It is high in high-grade tumours and low in low-grade tumours.
Both mantle-cell lymphoma and DLBCL also have a high ki67, but it is not as high as that seen in Burkitt's. Follicular lymphoma is a low-grade tumour, and hence, it has a low ki67 index.
The following are the images of Burkitt's lymphoma.
Image a - sheets of medium-sized cells with numerous tingible body macrophages showing the classic starry-sky pattern.
Image b - BCL 6 stain positivity in lymphoma cells.
Image c - the Ki-67 proliferation rate of virtually 100%.
Image d - EBER (Ebstein-Barr encoding region) in situ hybridization with numerous positive cells.




Solution to Question 6:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) positive diffuse large-cell lymphoma (DLBCL).
The histopathological findings show large cells with multilobed irregular nuclei. These cells are positive for CD20, CD79a, IRF4/MUM1, EBVLMP1. The smaller cells in the background are CD3+ which is a T-cell marker.
It is seen in the elderly (>50 years) and without immunodeficiency or prior lymphoma. 70% of the cases are extranodal and mainly affect skin, lung, tonsil, and stomach with or without LN involvement. 30% of the cases have LN disease alone.
Option A: This is not infectious mononucleosis as the monospot test is negative.
Option B: It is not Hodgkin lymphoma because it is positive for CD20 and CD79a and negative for CD15.
Option D: It is not EBV positive mucocutaneous ulcer as the patient is immunocompetent and it is strongly positive for CD20.
Note: EBV positive mucocutaneous ulcer occurs in immunocompromised patients and reverts to treating the immunocompromised state. It shows polymorphous infiltrate and atypical large B cells with RS cell-like morphology admixed abundant T cells.
There is a uniform expression of CD30, MUM1, PA›5, OCT2. There is variable expression of CD20,CD45, CD15, CD79a, BCL6.
Solution to Question 7:
The given history and histopathological examination point towards the diagnosis of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL).
It is molecularly heterogeneous and can show the given abnormalities:
BCL6 (transcription factor) overexpression is most common

Mutations in gene encoding histone acetyltransferases
DLBCL and follicular lymphoma, both are positive for CD19, CD20, CD10, and BCL6 (germinal-center B-cell origin). While BCL2 is positive in >90% of the cases of follicular lymphoma, it can also be positive in DLBCL.
To differentiate DLBCL from follicular lymphoma, the ki67 index is used. If ki67 >40% (high) it suggests DLBCL.
Solution to Question 8:
Hemoglobin levels are not a part of the International prognostic index (IPI) score. IPI is based on the presence or absence of five adverse prognostic factors:
Age >60 years
Raised serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)
Performance status >2 (ECOG) or <70 (Karnfosky)
>1 site of extranodal (extra lymphatic) involvement
Ann Arbor stage III or IV
Solution to Question 9:
The transformation of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)/ small lymphocytic leukemia (SLL) to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma is called Richter syndrome. It is seen in approximately 5% to 10% of the cases.
Option B: Chédiak–Higashi syndrome is an autosomal-recessive disorder that arises from a mutation of a lysosomal trafficking regulator protein. It leads to a decrease in phagocytosis, recurrent pyogenic infections, albinism, and peripheral neuropathy.
Sézary syndrome (SS) is a triad of erythroderma, generalized lymphadenopathy, and the presence of clonally related neoplastic T cells. These cells have cerebriform nuclei (Sézary cells) and are seen in the skin, lymph nodes, and peripheral blood.
Kostmann's syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by severe neutropenia. It is associated with mutations in G-CSF.
Solution to Question 10:
The given scenario and histopathological image point towards a diagnosis of anaplastic large cell lymphoma.
The biopsy shows characteristic large anaplastic cells, some containing horseshoe-shaped nuclei and voluminous cytoplasm called hallmark cells.

It is a type of T-cell lymphoma that consists of large lymphoid cells.
This occurs due to rearrangements in the ALK gene and usually affects children and young adults. It frequently involves soft tissue and carries a good prognosis. T-cell lymphomas with similar morphology without ALK positivity occur in older adults and have a bad prognosis.
CD markers: T cell markers (CD3, CD4, CD8 etc) +, CD30+.
Solution to Question 11:
Plasmablastic lymphoma is an aggressive lymphoid neoplasm that classically occurs in the oral cavity in immunosuppressed patients.
Plasmablastic lymphoma usually occurs in HIV+ patients (73%), immunosuppressed or elderly patients without known immunodeficiency, and EBV+ patients.
Lymphomas more specific to HIV+ patients:
Primary effusion lymphoma
Plasmablastic lymphoma
Primary CNS lymphoma
Solution to Question 12:
Extranodal NK/T-Cell Lymphoma is most likely to present as a destructive nasopharyngeal mass. Less common sites of presentation include the testis and the skin.
It accounts for 3% of all non-Hodgkin lymphomas (NHLs) in Asia. Extranodal NK/T-cell lymphoma is highly associated with EBV.
The tumor cells typically surround and invade the small vessels leading to extensive ischemic necrosis. In touch preparations, large azurophilic granules are seen in the cytoplasm of the tumor cells.
They express NK-cell markers (CD16, CD56) supporting an NK-cell origin.
Most extranodal NK/T-cell lymphomas are highly aggressive neoplasms that respond well to radiation therapy but are resistant to chemotherapy.
Solution to Question 13:
The given clinical scenario and peripheral smear findings showing cloverleaf cells, point towards a diagnosis of adult T-cell leukemia/ lymphoma.
Adult T-cell leukemia/ lymphoma occurs in adults infected by human T-cell leukemia retrovirus type 1 (HTLV-1). Common findings include skin lesions, generalized lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly and hypercalcemia.
Peripheral smear blood shows characteristic cloverleaf cells or flower cells which are tumour cells with multilobulated nuclei. Lymphocytosis is also observed.
It is a rapidly progressive disease that is fatal within months to 1 year.
The image given below shows peripheral blood smear findings in adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma.

Note: Apart from adult T-cell leukemia, HTLV-1 may also give rise to progressive demyelinating disease of the CNS and spinal cord.
Solution to Question 14:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient is enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma.
Individuals with celiac disease have a higher than normal rate of malignancy. The most common cancer associated with celiac disease is enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma. It is an aggressive lymphoma of intraepithelial T lymphocytes.
When the symptoms in a celiac disease patient deteriorate, even being on a strict gluten-free diet, cancer must be considered.
Note: Small intestinal adenocarcinoma is also more frequent in individuals with celiac disease.
Solution to Question 15:
The given scenario points towards the diagnosis of lymphomatoid polyposis. The most common among the non-Hodgkin's lymphoma to present like this is mantle cell lymphoma.
Lymphomatoid polyposis is characterized by multifocal mucosal involvement of the proliferating lymphocytes. It has aggressive behavior and a relatively poor prognosis. It must be treated accordingly as a high-grade lymphoma with systemic chemotherapy.
Solution to Question 16:
BRAF V600E (valine to glutamate substitution at residue 600) mutation is not seen in glioblastoma multiforme.
BRAF is a serine/threonine kinase positioned immediately downstream of RAS in the MAPK signalling cascade.
It is seen in the following conditions:
Hairy cell leukaemia
Malignant melanoma
Langerhans cell histiocytosis
Papillary carcinoma thyroi
Pilocytic astrocytoma
Erdheim–Chester disease

Solution to Question 1:
The normal ratio of kappa to lambda light chains is 60:40.
In multiple myeloma, usually this ratio is skewed, i.e., favorable secretion of one type of light chain occurs at the expense of the other. Serum-free light chain assay is a recommended part of the initial diagnostic workup for multiple myeloma.
Solution to Question 2:
Smoldering multiple myeloma refers to an uncommon variant defined by a lack of symptoms and a high plasma M component.
The difference between MGUS, smouldering multiple myeloma, and multiple myeloma is given below:
MGUS
Smouldering multiple Myelo ma
Multiple Myeloma
Asymptomatic
Asymptomatic
Symptomatic
M protein in serum <3g/dL
M-protein in serum:IgG 3 g/ dL,IgA >1 g/dL
M protein in serum and urin e

BM plasma cells 10-60%
BM plasma cells 60%

Solution to Question 3:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of multiple myeloma.
Plasma cell dyscrasias are B-cell proliferations that contain neoplastic plasma cells that secrete a monoclonal Ig or Ig fragment. Multiple myeloma is a malignant neoplasm of plasma cells characterized by the presence of monoclonal immunoglobulin or light chains in the serum and urine. It is a disease of older adults, with a peak age of incidence of 65 to 70 years.
Signs and symptoms include:
Hypercalcemia
Pathologic fractures/ lytic bone lesions
Renal failure
Anemia Investigations reveal:
Radiography - Punched-out lytic lesions on X-ray
Electrophoresis - Monoclonal elevation of one immunoglobulin
Urinalysis - Free kappa and lambda light chains (Bence Jones proteins)
Bone marrow biopsy - 10 to 20%plasma cells (normal is < 5%)
Peripheral smear - Rouleaux formation. A high level of M proteins in myeloma causes red cells in the peripheral blood smears to stick to one another in linear arrays, a finding referred to as rouleaux formation.
Plasma cell tumors are positive for CD138.
Solution to Question 4:
The most common cytogenetic abnormality in multiple myeloma is translocation 14q. Cytogenetic abnormalities in multiple myeloma include:
Translocations involving IGH on chromosome 14q - most frequent
Monosomy or partial deletion of chromosome 13 (13q14) - Found by FISH (nearly half the cases)
Translocation of the IgH occurs frequently with cyclin D1 on chromosome 11q and cyclin D3 on chromosome 6p
Deletions of chromosome 17p involving TP53 tumor-suppressor locus
Translocations with cyclin D1 are associated with a good outcome, whereas deletion of 17p and t(4;14) portend an aggressive course.
Solution to Question 5:
The proliferation and survival of plasma cells are dependent on several cytokines, most notably IL-6.
It is an important growth factor for plasma cells. It is produced by the tumor cells themselves and by resident marrow stromal cells. IL6, along with other cytokines, promotes osteoclastic activity and lytic bone lesions. High serum levels of IL-6 are seen in patients with active disease and are associated with a poor prognosis.
Solution to Question 6:
The most common monoclonal Ig (M protein) in myeloma is IgG (approximately 55% of patients), followed by IgA (approximately 25% of cases).
The immunosecretory disorders are a diverse group of diseases associated with the proliferation of an abnormal clone of immunoglobulin-synthesizing, terminally differentiated B cells. These disorders include:
Multiple myeloma (MM) and its variants
Plasmacytoma
Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia
Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance
Monoclonal Ig deposition diseases - Includes primary amyloidosis and nonamyloidotic types.
The immunoglobulin can be complete or can be composed of either heavy or light chains and is termed M-(monoclonal) protein. Most myelomas are associated with more than 3 gm/dL of serum
immunoglobulin. Myelomas expressing IgM, IgD, or IgE occur, but they are rare.
Solution to Question 7:
Lytic bony lesions in myeloma patients are most commonly seen in the vertebrae.
Multiple myeloma usually presents as destructive plasma cell tumors involving the axial skeleton. The bones most commonly affected (in descending order of frequency) are:
Vertebral column
Ribs
Skull
Pelvis
Femur
Clavicle
Scapula
Pathologic fractures are common in this condition. The bone lesions appear radiographically as punched-out defects, usually 1 to 4 cm in diameter.
The image given below shows osteoblastic lesions of vertebra in multiple myeloma.

Solution to Question 8:
MIP1 secreted by myeloma cells is responsible for the marked increase in bone resorption and hypercalcemia.
Factors produced by neoplastic plasma cells mediate bone destruction, the major pathologic feature of multiple myeloma. Of particular importance, myeloma-derived macrophage
inflammatory protein 1 (MIP1) upregulates the expression of the receptor activator of NF-B ligand (RANKL) by bone marrow stromal cells, which in turn activates osteoclasts.
Other factors released from tumor cells, such as modulators of the Wnt pathway, are potent inhibitors of osteoblast function.
The net effect is a marked increase in bone resorption, which leads to hypercalcemia and pathological fractures.
Serum alkaline phosphate levels are normal in multiple myeloma.
Solution to Question 9:
The given peripheral smear shows rouleaux formation. It is seen in patients with early HIV, SLE, and multiple myeloma.


Conditions that cause rouleaux formation are:
Multiple myeloma
Connective tissue disorders like SLE
Early HIV
Infections
Rouleaux formation is retarded by albumin.

Mooser bodies are seen in Typhus fever, not in multiple myeloma. Histopathological findings seen in multiple myeloma:
Dutcher bodies - pale-staining intranuclear inclusions within plasma cells containing Ig, which are more common in IgA myeloma (Image below).


Russell bodies - Hyaline intracytoplasmic inclusions containing Ig
Mott cells/ morula cells - Plasma cells containing multiple grape-like cytoplasmic inclusions comprised of Ig
Flame cells - Vermillion-staining, glycogen-rich IgA in cytoplasmic projections
Thesaurocytes - Dilated endoplasmic reticulum cisternae

The given image shows a Mott cell which is a plasma cell with globular cytoplasmic inclusions containing immunoglobulins called Russell bodies.
Inclusions containing Ig are frequently seen in the cytoplasm (Russell bodies) or the nucleus
(Dutcher bodies) of some of the plasma cells in myeloma.


Solution to Question 12:
The marked finding is perinuclear hof (perinuclear clearing) in plasma cells. It occurs due to a prominent Golgi apparatus.
Plasma cell characteristics include:
Eccentric nuclei
Moderate to abundant basophilic cytoplasm
Pale perinuclear hof, representing the Golgi zone
The image given below shows plasma cells with perinuclear hof.

Solution to Question 13:
The given clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of multiple myeloma.
The image shows Russell bodies which are eosinophilic, large, homogeneous immunoglobulin-containing inclusions usually found in a plasma cell undergoing excessive synthesis of immunoglobulins. Russell bodies are distended endoplasmic reticulum.
Globular inclusions are Russell bodies (if cytoplasmic) and Dutcher bodies (if nuclear). The below image shows Russell bodies:

Solution to Question 14:
Wire-loop lesions are seen in systemic lupus erythematosus and not in multiple myeloma.
Renal insufficiency occurs in half the patients with multiple myeloma and several factors are responsible for it. They develop acute kidney injury with ologuria and chronic kidney disease. Tubular casts, amyloidosis, and renal tubular necrosis are all described in the myeloma kidneys.
Features of myeloma kidney:
Bence–Jones proteinuria and cast nephropathy - The main cause of renal dysfunction is related to Bence–Jones (light-chain) proteinuria. Ig light chains are directly toxic to epithelial cells. Bence-Jones proteins form large, histologically distinct tubular casts that obstruct the tubular lumens and induce a characteristic inflammatory reaction (light-chain cast nephropathy).
Amyloidosis of AL type, formed from free light chains (usually of  type)
Light-chain deposition disease - light chains (usually of  type) deposit in the glomerular basement membrane and mesangium causing a glomerulopathy and in tubular basement membranes, which may cause tubulointerstitial nephritis.
Hypercalcemia - Nephrocalcinosis
Solution to Question 15:
Bence Jones proteins are immunoglobulin light chains (paraproteins) produced by neoplastic plasma cells.
They can be kappa (most of the time) or lambda. The light chains can be immunoglobulin fragments or single homogeneous immunoglobulins. In patients with plasma cell tumors, the level of free light chains is usually elevated. One of the light chains is elevated with a reduction in the other. Free light chains are excreted in the urine because they are small in size, where they are referred to as Bence Jones proteins. Tests for Bence Jones protein are:
Heat test
Urine protein electrophoresis
Immunofixation
Solution to Question 16:
Symptoms related to hyperviscosity in multiple myeloma occurs due to excessive production of M proteins, usually of IgG3 or IgA subtype.
Waldenstrom macroglobulinemia (IgM myeloma) is the most common cause for hyperviscosity syndrome due to excess IgM paraprotein. Less commonly, it also occurs in multiple myeloma (with myeloma proteins IgA and IgG3 types) and connective tissue diseases.
Normal relative serum viscosity ranges from 1.4 to 1.8 units. Symptoms are not seen at <4, and hyperviscosity syndrome typically requires a viscosity of >5 units.
Clinical features include:
Visual impairment
Neurologic problems
Bleeding
Cryoglobulinemia
Solution to Question 17:
IgD type of multiple myeloma has the highest risk of renal insufficiency.
IgG is most commonly involved in multiple myeloma. The higher the level of IgG, the more is the risk of renal failure in patients with multiple myeloma overall. But the rarer IgD predominant multiple myeloma has the highest risk of renal insufficiency when compared to other types.
IgD type multiple myeloma is a rare type of multiple myeloma. In this condition, there is monoclonal IgD in serum. On serum electrophoresis, there is no or absent M spike. There is a higher incidence of extramedullary involvement, amyloidosis, proteinuria, and renal insufficiency in comparison to IgG or IgA type multiple myeloma. It has a poor prognosis.
Solution to Question 18:
Plasma-cell tumors are least likely to show positivity for CD 21.
They are positive for CD138, an adhesion molecule also known as syndecan-1, CD 38, and often express CD56.
Solution to Question 19:
Biopsy-proven plasmacytoma is not considered as a myeloma-defining event (MDE).
Revised International Myeloma Working Group criteria for the diagnosis of multiple myeloma: Clonal bone marrow plasma cells 10% (or) Biopsy-proven bony or extramedullary plasmacytoma.
AND
Myeloma defining events (one or more): Evidence of end-organ damage attributable to the underlying plasma cell proliferative disorder, specifically-
HyperCalcemia: Serum calcium level >1 mg/dL higher than the upper limit of normal or >11 mg/dL
Renal insufficiency: Creatinine clearance <40 mL/min or serum creatinine >2 mg/dL
Anemia: Hemoglobin level of >20 g/L (2gm/dl) below the lowest limit of normal, or Hb <10 g/dL
Bone lesions: One or more osteolytic lesions on skeletal radiography, computed tomography
(CT), or positron emission tomography (PET)/CT.
Any one or more biomarkers of malignancy: Clonal bone marrow plasma cells 60%; Serum involved/uninvolved free light-chain ratio  100; >1 focal lesion on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) that is  5 mm in size.
Solution to Question 20:
The given clinical scenario and X-ray showing lytic lesions on the bone are suggestive of multiple myeloma. The best immunohistochemical (IHC) marker for this condition is cyclin D1.
Multiple myeloma is associated with diverse translocations involving the IgH locus; overexpression of D cyclins—cyclin D1 and D3. Plasma cell tumors are positive for CD138 and often express CD56.
Solution to Question 21:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of amyloidosis. The amyloid of the AL type is produced from free Ig light chains secreted by a monoclonal population of plasma cells and its deposition is associated with multiple myeloma.
Solution to Question 22:
Infections are the most common cause of death in patients with myeloma. Complications of multiple myeloma include:
Infections
Renal failure
Cardiac failure
Hypercalcemia
Anemia
Solution to Question 23:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of multiple myeloma. The most powerful prognostic indicator of this condition at the time of diagnosis is serum  2 microglobulin.
Beta-2 microglobulin is a low-molecular-weight protein found on the surface of all nucleated cells. It is the light chain of the HLA histocompatibility complex.
Solution to Question 24:
t(11;14) is associated with a good prognosis in patients with myeloma.
t(4;14), high serum beta-2 microglobulin, and low serum albumin are all poor prognostic factors in myeloma.

The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of multiple myeloma. Translocations involving cyclin D1 are associated with a good outcome in this condition.
t(14;16), deletions of 17p, and t(14;20) are associated with a more aggressive course.

Bence–Jones proteinuria is not diagnostic of monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) because it is seen in multiple myeloma also.
MGUS is the most common monoclonal gammopathy.
Diagnostic criteria of MGUS according to International Myeloma Working Group guidelines

The three distinct clinical types of MGUS are:
Non-IgM MGUS:
Most common subtype of MGUS
Approximately 1% of patients with MGUS develop a symptomatic plasma cell neoplasm, usually multiple myeloma, per year
IgM MGUS:
IgM MGUS accounts for approximately 15% of MGUS cases
It can progress to Waldenström macroglobulinemia, but progression to multiple myeloma is rare
Bence–Jones proteinuria has been reported in approximately 20% of these cases
Light chain MGUS (LC-MGUS):
LC-MGUS is a unique subtype of MGUS in which there is no immunoglobulin heavy-chain component
Urinary M protein <500 mg/24 hour
LC-MGUS may progress to light-chain smoldering multiple myeloma (idiopathic Bence–Jones proteinuria) and to light-chain multiple myeloma
Solution to Question 27:
High levels of IgM are seen in lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma.
In lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma, high levels of IgM lead to symptoms related to hyperviscosity of the blood. This is known as Waldenstrom’s macroglobulinemia. ‘M’ or monoclonal spike is seen in this condition. Here, it is caused by IgM; in multiple myeloma, it is caused by IgG. It is characterized by the absence of lytic lesions and normal serum calcium levels.
IgM greatly increases the viscosity of the blood, giving rise to a hyperviscosity syndrome characterized by the following:
Visual impairment
Neurologic problems
Bleeding
Cryoglobulinemia
The normal relative viscosity of the serum is 1.8. Hyperviscosity is seen in:
Multiple myeloma
Waldenstrom’s macroglobulinemia
Cryoglobulinemia
Myeloproliferative disorders
Solution to Question 28:
Virtually all cases of lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma are associated with acquired mutations in MYD88.
The most common cytogenetic abnormality associated with lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma is deletion of 6q.
Solution to Question 29:
Serum calcium levels remain normal in Waldenström macroglobulinemia. Waldenström macroglobulinemia is a syndrome characterised by the following:
Hyperviscosity syndrome due to high levels of IgM
Most commonly occurs in association with lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma
‘M’ or monoclonal spike
Absence of lytic lesions
Normal serum calcium levels
Diffuse marrow infiltration by plasma cells, plasmacytoid lymphocytes, and lymphocytes (all from the same clone)
Cells do not form tumor masses or produce lytic lesions
Lymphocytes commonly contain Dutcher bodies (intranuclear inclusions)
Bence–Jones proteins in 20–30%

Extramedullary plasmacytomas are seen in the upper respiratory tract. Most of them are seen in the nasopharynx, oropharynx, sinuses, and larynx.
Plasmacytoma is a tumor of plasma cells of bony or soft tissue. It can occur anywhere in the body without evidence of systemic disease.
Solution to Question 31:
- heavy chain disease (HCD) is known as Seligmann's disease. There are three heavy chain diseases:
- heavy chain disease - Seligmann's disease
- heavy chain disease - Franklin's disease
- heavy chain disease - Associated with light-chain secretion (Bence–Jones proteinuria) in a few cases
Solution to Question 32:
The given clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of plasma cell leukemia. In this case, the peripheral blood smear shows 22% of plasma cells and presents with organomegaly.
Plasma cell leukemia is defined by the observation in blood of more than 20% clonal plasma cells by differential count of the leucocytes or by counting more than 2 × 109 per liter circulating clonal plasma cells. Plasma cell leukemia (PCL) is a rare and aggressive form of leukemia and plasma cell dyscrasia. PCL can be divided into primary PCL (PCL) and secondary PCL (sPCL) following previously diagnosed multiple myeloma (MM); the latter typically occurring at a late and advanced stage of MM.
Patients with plasma cell leukemia are more likely to have extramedullary involvement of liver and spleen, causing organomegaly than in multiple myeloma. (Option A)

Solution to Question 1:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of therapy-related myelodysplastic syndrome (t-MDS).
The bone marrow biopsy stained with Perl's Prussian blue shows ringed sideroblasts. They are erythroblasts with iron-laden mitochondria visible as perinuclear granules as shown in the image below.

Myelodysplastic syndrome is a group of clonal stem cell disorders characterized by maturation defects, associated with ineffective hematopoiesis.
It is of two types:
Primary MDS - develops slowly, usually after 50 years of age.
Secondary or therapy-related MDS (t-MDS) - develops 2 to 8 years after toxic drug or radiation exposure with poor prognosis
Patients usually present with weakness, infections and hemorrhages due to pancytopenia. Both types of MDS have a high risk of transformation to acute myeloid leukemia (AML). However, most frequent and rapid transformation occurs in therapy-related MDS (t-MDS).
Solution to Question 2:
Monosomy 7 is the most common cytogenetic change seen in myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) in children.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
q deletion is the most common cytogenetic change seen in MDS in adults.
The del(5q) abnormality is the dominant clone in most cases of MDS. This involves the stem-cell compartment and hence occurs as an early or initiating event in disease pathogenesis.
Solution to Question 3:
Pseudo–Pelger–Huet cells are seen in myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) and not Pelger–Huet cells.
Pelger–Huet cells are seen in Pelger–Huet syndrome, which is due to mutations in the lamin B-receptor gene. It is a neutrophil differentiation disorder with leukocyte appearance as:
Dumbbell-shaped bilobed nuclei
Reduced number of nuclear segments
Coarse clumping of the nuclear chromatin
In MDS, pseudo-Pelger Huet cells are seen due to abnormal nuclear budding i.e. neutrophils with only 2 nuclear lobes.
Solution to Question 4:
Image 3 showing hypocellular bone marrow is not seen in myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS.) In this condition, bone marrow is hypercellular. However, pancytopenia results from ineffective hematopoiesis.
The image given below shows the histopathological findings seen in MDS.

Solution to Question 5:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML).
In this condition, the peripheral smear contains neutrophils and their precursors of various sizes and configurations like band cells, myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and blasts. Hence, the histological picture is described to have garden party or college girl appearance.
The image given below shows the peripheral smear in CML showing garden party or college girl appearance.

CML is a myeloproliferative disorder with peak incidence in the 5th to 6th decades of life. It occurs due to the chimeric BCR-ABL gene.
Clinical features of CML:
Hypermetabolism
Fatigability
Weakness
Weight loss and anorexia
Extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis causing -
Splenomegaly
Mild hepatomegaly
Lymphadenopathy Hematological findings include:
Mild-to-moderate anemia
Leukocytosis
Platelets - usually increased
DLC shows predominantly neutrophils, band forms, metamyelocytes, myelocytes, eosinophils, and basophils and blasts (>10%)
Note: Convent girl appearance is seen in CLL.
Solution to Question 6:
Philadelphia chromosome results from t(9;22)(q34;q11). It is most commonly seen in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).
CML is due to the formation of a chimeric BCR-ABL gene or Philadelphia chromosome. This gene is derived from a reciprocal translocation (9;22)(q34;q11).
The image given below shows the formation of the Philadelphia chromosome.

This translocation can be identified on fluorescence in situ hybridisation (FISH).
The image given below shows (9;22) translocation as seen on FISH.

Psuedo-Gaucher cells are characteristic of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). These cells are scattered macrophages with abundant wrinkled, green-blue cytoplasm. Their presence indicates a good prognosis.
Bone marrow findings in CML:
Markedly hypercellular marrow - increased maturing granulocytic precursors
Elevated eosinophils and basophils
Increased megakaryocytes - include small, dysplastic forms
Erythroid progenitors - normal or mildly decreased
Increased reticulin deposition
Overt marrow fibrosis - rare early in the course
Pseudo-Gaucher cells
Sea blue histiocytes
The image given below shows pseudo-Gaucher cells in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).

In a patient with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), progressive splenomegaly, not responsive to therapy is suggestive of an accelerated phase. In this phase, blasts are <20% in blood or marrow.
Diagnosis of an accelerated phase of CML requires one of the following criteria:
Persistent or increasing WBC (>10 × 109/L), unresponsive to therapy
Persistent or increasing splenomegaly, unresponsive to therapy
Persistent thrombocytosis (>1000 × 109/L), unresponsive to therapy
Persistent thrombocytopenia (<100 × 109/L) unrelated to therapy

Solution to Question 9:
In the blast phase of chronic myeloid leukemia, there are >20% blasts in the bone marrow. The 3 phases of CML are:
Chronic phase is the most common presentation. It is characterized by:
Leukocytosis - bimodal distribution with higher proportions of mature segmented neutrophils and myelocytes
Blast cells <10%
Increased basophils and eosinophils
Monocytosis <3%
Accelerated phase occurs in 50% of the patients who present with increasing anemia, thrombocytopenia and splenomegaly. It is characterized by:
Blast count 10-19%
Basophilia >20%
Blast phase in CML occurs in an average of 3 years after the diagnosis. It is characterized by:
Large foci or clusters of blasts on the bone marrow biopsy >20%.
Presence of extramedullary blastic infiltrates (e.g., myeloid sarcoma or chloroma)

Myelodysplastic/Myeloproliferative syndrome (MDS/MPN) with neutrophilia (previously named as atypical chronic myeloid leukemia) shows minimal absolute basophilia, i.e., <2% of total WBCs.
Myelodysplastic/Myeloproliferative syndrome (MDS/MPN) with neutrophilia is a leukemic disorder having features of both myelodysplastic and myeloproliferative features at the time of diagnosis. It is classified under the WHO 5th edition (2022) MDS/MPN category.
Characteristics of myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative syndrome (MDS/MPN) with neutrophilia:
Peripheral blood leukocytosis with an increased number of mature and immature neutrophils
Prominent dysgranulopoiesis
Philadelphia chromosome-negative
Neutrophil precursors (promyelocytes, myelocytes, metamyelocytes) >10% of WBCs
Minimal absolute basophilia <2% of WBCs
Absolute monocytosis <10% of WBCs
Hypercellular bone marrow
<20% blasts in blood and bone marrow
Thrombocytopenia
