Solution to Question 11:
Leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score is decreased in chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) i.e. garden party appearance on peripheral smear.
Solution to Question 12:
High altitude produces absolute polycythemia and not relative polycythemia.
Polycythemia denotes an abnormally high red cell count, usually with a corresponding increase in the hemoglobin level (> 16 ±2 g/dL). It is 2 types:
Relative - hemoconcentration due to decreased plasma volume
Absolute - increase in the total red cell mass Causes of relative polycythemia include:
Dehydration - deprivation of water, prolonged vomiting or diarrhea, excessive use of diuretics
Gaisböck syndrome - stress polycythemia where affected individuals are usually hypertensive, obese, and anxious
Causes of absolute polycythemia include:
Primary - intrinsic abnormality of hematopoietic precursors
Polycythemia vera
Inherited erythropoietin receptor mutations
Secondary - red cell progenitors responding to increased levels of erythropoietin
Compensatory due to cyanotic heart and lung disease, high altitude
Paraneoplastic erythropoietin secreting tumours
Note: In dengue hemorrhagic fever, increased vascular permeability causes plasma leakage and volume loss. Hence, relative polycythemia is seen.
Solution to Question 13:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of polycythemia (Hb>16 g/dL). Hence, erythropoietin levels (EPO) are estimated next, to differentiate between primary or secondary polycythemia.
Based on EPO levels:
Primary polycythemia - normal/ decreased
Secondary polycythemia - increased
Options A and B: JAK 2 mutation and Philadelphia chromosome analysis is only done as a last resort.
Option D: Bone marrow estimation with reticulin is done for myelofibrosis which can be seen in the spent/ late stage of the disease. However, peripheral smear findings are not suggestive of primary myelofibrosis. Leukoerythroblastic reaction with dacrocytes is seen in myelofibrosis.
Solution to Question 14:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of polycythemia vera. Hepatic failure is not seen in this condition.
Polycythemia vera is strongly associated with activating point mutations in the tyrosine kinase JAK2. In this condition, clonal erythrocytosis occurs autonomously i.e. independent of erythropoietin.
Clinical features of polycythemia vera:
Headache
Hypertension
Dizziness
Intense pruritis, aquagenic pruritis
Peptic ulcer
Venous thrombosis - Budd-Chiari syndrome (hepatic vein thrombosis), bowel infarction, stroke, myocardial infarction
Minor hemorrhages - epistaxis, gum bleeding Laboratory findings in polycythemia vera:
Panmyelosis - increased marrow production of red cells, granulocytes, and platelets
Low erythropoietin
Elevated hematocrit
Hyperuricemia
Complications of polycythemia vera:
Myelofibrosis and extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis - spent /late phase
Acute myeloid leukemia
Solution to Question 15:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of essential thrombocythemia (ET). The image showing erythematous hands is suggestive of erythromelalgia.
Essential thrombocythemia (essential thrombocytosis) is a myeloproliferative neoplasm. It is associated with mutations that increase JAK-STAT signaling.
WHO criteria for diagnosis of essential thrombocythemia:
Major criteria -
Platelet count 450 × 109/L
Bone marrow biopsy showing proliferation mainly of the megakaryocyte lineage with increased numbers of enlarged, mature megakaryocytes with hyperlobulated nuclei
Not meeting WHO criteria for BCR-ABL1 chronic myeloid leukemia, PV, PMF, myelodysplastic syndromes, or other myeloid neoplasms
Presence of JAK2, CALR, or MPL mutation
Minor criteria - the presence of a clonal marker or absence of evidence for reactive thrombocytosis
Diagnosis of ET requires meeting all 4 major criteria or the first 3 major criteria and the minor criterion
Option A: Polycythemia vera can also present with erythromelalgia. However, it also presents with increased Hb levels.
Option C: Fibrosis (not reticulin fibrils) is seen in bone marrow biopsy of primary myelofibrosis. Option D: WBC counts are increased in leukemoid reactions.
Solution to Question 16:
Leukoerythroblastic picture is not seen in patients with thalassemia as it is a hemoglobinopathy and does not involve myeloid precursors.
Abnormal presence of immature precursors of blood in the peripheral blood smear is called leukoerythroblastosis. Findings include:
Nucleated red cells
Dacryocytes (or teardrop RBC) - formed due to damage to red cell membrane caused by fibrous tissue in the marrow
Immature cells of granulocytic series
It occurs due to conditions causing marrow replacement like:
Primary myelofibrosis - fibrosis of bone marrow
Myelophthisic anemia - space occupying lesions of bone marrow
Gauchers disease
Spent phase of polycythemia vera
The image given below shows a leukoerythroblastic blood picture with nucleated RBCs, tear-drop cells, and immature myeloid cells.

Solution to Question 17:
Myelodysplastic syndrome/ myeloproliferative neoplasm (MDS/MPN) overlap syndromes are a group of chronic clonal myeloid malignancies in which there are features of both MDS and MPN at the time of presentation. According to the 5th edition WHO classification (2022), it includes:
Chronic myelomonocytic leukemia
MDS/MPN with neutrophilia (previously atypical chronic myeloid leukemia)
MDS/MPN with SF31B mutation and thrombocytosis
MDS/MPN not otherwise specified
Solution to Question 18:
More than 20% of blasts in the blood or bone marrow are not compatible with a diagnosis of chronic myelomonocytic leukemia (CMML). In this condition, blasts are less than 20%.
WHO 5th edition diagnostic criteria (2022_for chronic myelomonocytic leukemia (CMML)
include:
Prerequisite criteria:
subject: Pathology

question_text: Persistent absolute (0.5 × 109/ L) and relative (10%) peripheral blood monocytosis.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Blasts constitute <20% of the cells in the peripheral blood and bone marrow.
subject: Pathology

question_text: Not meeting diagnostic criteria of chronic myeloid leukemia or other myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPN).b
subject: Pathology

question_text: Not meeting diagnostic criteria of myeloid/lymphoid neoplasms with tyrosine kinase fusions.c Supporting criteria:
subject: Pathology

question_text: Acquired clonal cytogenetic or molecular abnormality.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
Abnormal partitioning of peripheral blood monocyte subsets.e Pre-requisite criteria must be present in all cases:
If monocytosis is  1 × 109/ L: one or more supporting criteria must be met.
If monocytosis is 0.5 and <1 × 109/ L: supporting criteria 1 and 2 must be met. Subtype criteria:
Myelodysplastic CMML (MD-CMML): WBC < 13 × 109/L
Myeloproliferative CMML (MP-CMML): WBC  13 × 109/L
Blasts and blast equivalents include myeloblasts, monoblasts, and promonocytes.
MPN with monocytosis can mimic CMML. In these instances, a documented history of MPN excludes CMML. The presence of MPN features in the bone marrow and/or a high burden of
MPN-associated mutations (JAK2, CALR, or MPL) tends to support MPN with monocytosis rather than CMML.
Criteria for myeloid/lymphoid neoplasms with tyrosine kinase fusions should be specifically excluded in cases with eosinophilia.
Morphologic dysplasia should be present in 10% of cells of a hematopoietic lineage in the bone marrow.
Based on the detection of increased classical monocytes (>94%) in the absence of known active autoimmune diseases and/or systemic inflammatory syndromes.
Solution to Question 19:
HbF levels are increased in juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia (JMML), not Hb A2.
JMML is a hematopoietic stem cell-derived myeloproliferative neoplasm of early childhood. It is one of the myeloproliferative neoplasms. It is associated with mutations in the RAS pathway.
Neurofibromatosis 1, Noonan syndrome, and trisomy 8 mosaicism can predispose to this condition. Aggressive types include PTPN11 mutation and neurofibromatosis type 1.
WHO diagnostic guidelines of JMML:
*Germline mutation (indicating Noonan syndrome) needs to be excluded.
It is associated with a poor prognosis and only a few patients undergo spontaneous regression.

Solution to Question 20:
Polycythemia vera is strongly associated with activating point mutations in the tyrosine kinase JAK2.
A mutation in JAK2, a key member of the cytokine intracellular signaling pathway, can be found in 90–95% of patients with polycythemia vera.
It is characterized by :
Increased marrow production of red cells, granulocytes, and platelets (panmyelosis)
Low erythropoietin levels and elevated hematocrit
Blood viscosity and sludging lead to both thrombosis and bleeding.
Headache, dizziness, hypertension, dizziness, venous thrombosis (Budd Chiari syndrome due to hepatic vein thrombosis), bowel infarction, and stroke.
Intense pruritus especially aquagenic pruritus
Peptic ulceration, hyperuricemia

question_text:
% to 20% of patients after an average period of 10 years ->Myelofibrosis and extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis,
PCV transforms into AML in 2% of patients. Primary myelofibrosis
Marrow fibrosis associated with extramedullary hemopoiesis in the spleen.
Activating mutation in JAK2 (more commonly) or MPL.
Presence of neoplastic megakaryocytes, which are responsible for the release of fibrogenic factors like PDGF (platelet-derived growth factor) and TGF- .
Bone marrow aspiration yields dry tap due to fibrosis of the bone marrow.
So, bone marrow biopsy is the investigation of choice, which shows the presence of hypocellularity with increased deposition of reticulin inside the marrow, abnorma megakaryocytes and the characteristic finding of dilated marrow sinusoids.
Blood shows mild leukocytosis, decreased Hb and hematocrit levels, and elevated LAP scores.
Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) occurs in 5% to 20% of cases.
Essential thrombocytosis (ET) may also be associated with JAK2, MPL, or CALR mutations.
Essential thrombocytosis (ET) is often associated with activating point mutations in JAK2 (50% of cases) or MPL (5% to 10% of cases), a receptor tyrosine kinase that is normally activated by thrombopoietin.
In addition, recent DNA sequencing studies have revealed that most of the remaining cases have mutations in calreticulin (CALR), a protein with several functions in the endoplasmic reticulum and the cytoplasm. Since JAK2 and calreticulin mutations are mutually exclusive, it is hypothesized that the calreticulin mutations also increase JAK-STAT signaling through mechanisms that are currently unknown.
CML is the consequence of the balanced translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22 (t[9;22]).
PV, PMF, and ET are characterized by driver mutations that directly or indirectly constitutively activate JAK2, a tyrosine kinase essential for the function of the erythropoietin andthrombopoietin receptors and also utilized by granulocyte colony stimulating factor receptor.
Solution to Question 21:
Myocardial infarction does not cause leukemoid reaction.
Leukemoid reaction is defined as persistent leukocytosis above 50000 cells /mm3, where the cause is other than leukemia.
Causes of leukemoid reaction include:
Severe infections
Malignancy
Severe hemorrhage
Acute hemolysis
Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome)
Asplenia
Diabetic ketoacidosis
Solution to Question 22:
The given electron microscopy image shows tennis racket shaped Birbeck granules. These granules are characteristic of Langerhans cell histiocytosis.
These granules are pentalaminar tubules with dilated terminal ends. This gives a characteristic tennis racket appearance on electron microscopy. They contain the protein langerin (CD207).
The image given below shows the Birbeck granules as seen on electron microscopy.

On peripheral smear, the proliferating Langerhans cells are characterised by:
Abundant vacuolated cytoplasm
Vesicular nuclei containing linear grooves or folds - coffee bean nuclei
The image given below shows Langerhans cells with coffee bean nuclei and moderately abundant pale cytoplasm mixed with a few eosinophils.

Note: Tennis racket cells in light microscopy seen in sarcoma botryoides.

Rosai–Dorfman disease is not a histiocytic neoplasm. It is sinus histiocytosis with massive lymphadenopathy.

S-100 is a marker for Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

Solution to Question 25:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Hand–Schüller–Christian disease. Langerhans cell histiocytosis presents as multiple clinicopathological entities:
Hand–Schüller–Christian disease is a multifocal unisystem Langerhans cell histiocytosis. It usually affects young children. It is characterized by the triad of:
Diabetes insipidus (excessive thirst) - involvement of the posterior pituitary stalk of the hypothalamus
Exophthalmos
Multiple lytic bone lesions
It usually undergoes spontaneous regression. It is treated with local excision or irradiation.
Letterer–Siwe disease is a multifocal multisystem Langerhans cell histiocytosis. It occurs most frequently before 2 years of age, but occasionally affects adults.
It is characterized by the following features:
Cutaneous lesions, resembling a seborrheic eruption - caused by infiltrates of Langerhans cells over the front and back of the trunk and on the scalp
Hepatosplenomegaly
Lymphadenopathy
Pulmonary lesions
Destructive osteolytic bone lesions
Due to marrow infiltration - anemia, thrombocytopenia, predisposition to recurrent infections
(otitis media and mastoiditis)
Treatment involves intensive chemotherapy. This condition is fatal if left untreated.
Eosinophilic granuloma is a unifocal unisystem Langerhans cell histiocytosis. It is characterized by the proliferation of Langerhans cells admixed with variable numbers of eosinophils, lymphocytes, plasma cells, and neutrophils.
These lesions occur in the following sites:
Medullary cavities of bones - most commonly the calvarium, ribs, and femur
Skin
Lungs
Stomach
Bone lesions can manifest as:
Asymptomatic
Pain
Tenderness
Pathologic fractures.
Treatment is by local excision or irradiation.
Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis is most often seen in adult smokers. It regresses spontaneously upon cessation of smoking.
Solution to Question 26:
The given image showing a solitary punched-out lytic lesion without a sclerotic rim
with a beveled edge appearance, along with the age of the patient with history of normal hematological and urinary tests is suggestive of Langerhans cell histiocytosis.
Langerhans cell histiocytosis occurs due to the proliferation of a special type of immature dendritic cells, called Langerhans cells. Their normal function is to present antigens.
It is characterized by single or multiple osteolytic bone lesions. It can also infiltrate the skin (of the scalp), lungs, liver, spleen, bone marrow, or the central nervous system.
Solution to Question 27:
The image shows a bone marrow biopsy needle. Thrombocytopenia is not in itself a contraindication for bone marrow biopsy. However, a platelet count >20,000 is ensured for safety purposes.
Indications of bone marrow biopsy:
Evaluation of unexplained anemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, pancytopenia
Evaluation of polycythemia, thrombocytosis, leukocytosis
Diagnosis and staging of lymphoma or solid tumors
Diagnosis and evaluation of plasma cell disorders and leukemias
Evaluation of suspected infiltrative and storage diseases
Evaluation of fever of unknown origin, suspected mycobacterial, fungal, or parasitic infections, or granulomatous diseases
Contraindications of bone marrow biopsy:
Severe hemophilia
Severe disseminated intravascular coagulopathy
Severe bleeding disorders Procedure for bone marrow biopsy:
Prone or lateral position is chosen for the procedure. Posterior superior iliac spine is identified. After disinfection and local anaesthesia, the patient is asked to inhale slowly through the nose and exhale slowly through the mouth to relieve anxiety .The needle is inserted and rotated on its axis.
On reaching the desired depth, the stylet is removed and needle is advanced. The needle is rotated in the opposite direction to loosen the specimen. It is then withdrawn using the same rotational movement.

Solution to Question 1:
From the 3rd month of embryogenesis, the liver becomes the chief site of hematopoiesis. Development of hematopoietic tissues:
Yolk sac - blood cell progenitors first appear during the 3rd week
Liver - hematopoietic stem cells migrate to the liver during the 3rd month of embryogenesis
Bone marrow - hematopoiesis starts in bone marrow during the 4th month of intrauterine life and becomes the predominant site after birth
Solution to Question 2:
Nurse cells are specialized macrophages in the bone marrow that assist in the development of red blood cells (RBCs).
Solution to Question 3:
The structures marked A are fat cells and B are hematopoietic elements. The normal ratio of fat cells to hematopoietic elements in a normal adult is 1:1.

In hypoplastic states (like aplastic anemia), the proportion of fat cells is greatly increased
(increased fat to cell ratio).
Conversely, fat cells often disappear in conditions like hematopoietic tumors and in diseases with compensatory hyperplasias (like hemolytic anemias) and neoplastic proliferations such as leukemias (decreased fat-to-cell ratio).
Solution to Question 4:
CD34 is an antigen of pluripotent hematopoietic stem cells and progenitor cells of many lineages.

Solution to Question 5:
CD45 is called leukocyte common antigen because it is found in all leukocytes.
Solution to Question 6:
Kostmann syndrome is characterized by neutropenia.
It is a rare congenital condition in which inherited defects in specific genes impair granulocytic differentiation. This results in severe congenital neutropenia.
It presents in young children as recurrent bacterial infections (such as otitis media, cellulitis) and oral ulcers. It is associated with an increased risk of acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
Solution to Question 7:
The most common cause of agranulocytosis is drug toxicity. Causes of agranulocytosis include:
Inadequate or ineffective granulopoiesis -
Suppression of hematopoietic stem cells - aplastic anemia, infiltrative marrow disorders
Suppression of committed granulocytic precursors
Ineffective hematopoiesis - megaloblastic anemia, myelodysplastic syndromes
Congenital conditions - Kostmann syndrome
Increased destruction or sequestration of neutrophils -
Immunological injury to neutrophils - idiopathic, systemic lupus erythematosus, drug exposure
Increased peripheral utilization - bacterial, fungal, or rickettsial infections
Splenomegaly

Serious infections are most likely when the neutrophil count falls below 500/mm3.

Solution to Question 10:
The given peripheral smear, prepared from an individual with bacterial sepsis, shows reactive changes in neutrophils. The arrow-marked structure is a Döhle body.


Reactive changes in neutrophils associated with leukocytosis in severe inflammatory disorders are:
Toxic granules, which are coarser and darker than the normal neutrophilic granules, represent abnormal azurophilic (primary) granules
Döhle bodies are patches of the dilated endoplasmic reticulum that appear as sky-blue cytoplasmic puddles
Toxic cytoplasmic vacuoles
The image given below shows a neutrophil with cytoplasmic vacuoles.

Solution to Question 11:
B-cell lymphoma results in malignant proliferation within the lymph node, not follicular hyperplasia.
Follicular hyperplasia is a benign condition caused by stimuli that activate humoral immune responses. It may occur in:
Rheumatoid arthritis
Toxoplasmosis
Early stages of HIV infection
It is defined by the presence of large oblong germinal centres (secondary follicles), which are surrounded by a collar of small, resting naive B cells (mantle zone).


Solution to Question 12:
In reactive lymphoid hyperplasia, there is marked variation in the shape and size of follicles. Features favoring reactive lymphoid hyperplasia, which are absent in neoplastic follicles are:
Preservation of the lymph node architecture, including the interfollicular T-cell zones and the sinusoids
Marked variation in the shape and size of the follicles
Presence of frequent mitotic figures and phagocytic macrophages
Recognizable light and dark zones
Solution to Question 13:
Tingible-body macrophages are found in lymph nodes.
A tingible-body macrophage is a type of macrophage predominantly found in germinal
centers containing many phagocytosed apoptotic cell debris. This debris is referred to as tingible bodies (tingible meaning stainable). The presence of these macrophages suggests non-neoplastic reactive hyperplasia of the lymph node, or can be seen as the stars in the starry sky appearance of Burkitt lymphoma.


Solution to Question 14:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of infectious mononucleosis. Acute viral infections, like infectious mononucleosis, produce paracortical hyperplasia.
There are three types of lymph node hyperplasia. They are:
Follicular hyperplasia
Paracortical hyperplasia
Sinus histiocytosis (reticular hyperplasia)
Paracortical hyperplasia is seen in the T-cell-containing paracortical region of the lymph node. It is caused by stimuli that trigger T-cell–mediated immune responses. The involved regions typically contain:
Immunoblasts
Activated T-cells 3-4 times the size of resting lymphocytes t
Round nuclei
Open chromatin
Several prominent nucleoli
Moderate amounts of pale cytoplasm
Hypertrophy of sinusoidal and vascular endothelial cells, with infiltrating macrophages and eosinophils
Solution to Question 15:
In the case of lymph node metastases, there is prominent reticular hyperplasia.
Reticular hyperplasia or sinus histiocytosis refers to an increase in the number and size of the cells that line lymphatic sinusoids. Although nonspecific, this form of hyperplasia may be particularly prominent in lymph nodes draining cancers such as carcinoma of the breast.
The lining lymphatic endothelial cells are markedly hypertrophied and macrophages are greatly increased in numbers, resulting in the expansion and distension of the sinuses.
The image given below shows reticular hyperplasia in the lymph node.

Solution to Question 16:
Hemophagocytosis is usually seen on bone marrow examination, but it is neither sufficient nor required to make the diagnosis of hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH).
HLH is a reactive condition also known as macrophage-activation syndrome. The common feature of all forms of HLH is the systemic activation of macrophages and CD8+ T-cells.
The most common trigger for HLH is an infection, particularly with EBV (Epstein-Barr virus). It is characterized by acute febrile illness associated with splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and cytopenias.
Solution to Question 17:
Hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH) is associated with very high serum ferritin levels. Laboratory findings in HLH include:
Anemia
Thrombocytopenia
High serum ferritin
High plasma IL2 receptor levels
Elevated liver enzyme levels
High triglyceride levels
Features of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)

Solution to Question 1:
Vascular injury results in intimal thickening due to smooth muscle proliferation.
Vascular injury stimulates the migration of smooth muscle cells of the tunica media to the tunica intima. These smooth muscle cells proliferate and also synthesize extracellular matrix leading to intimal thickening. This is the stereotypical response of the vessel wall to an injury regardless of the cause of injury.
The image below shows intimal thickening occurring in response to vascular injury.

Solution to Question 2:
Endothelial dysfunction is not implicated in aneurysm formation. An aneurysm occurs due to the pathology of connective tissue within the vascular wall.
Endothelial dysfunction is the pathological alteration of the endothelium such that it
becomes pro-inflammatory and prothrombogenic. It is caused by various injuries to endothelial cells:
Hemodynamic stresses - responsible for vascular pathology in hypertensio
Lipid products - leading to the pathogenesis of atherosclerosis
Advanced glycation end-products (AGE) - responsible for diabetic microangiopathy
Viruses, bacterial products, cytokines, and complement components
Solution to Question 3:
The given image shows arteriosclerosis and calcification in the tunica media, that does not encroach on the vessel lumen. This is suggestive of Monckeberg's medial sclerosis.
Monckeberg's medial sclerosis affects medium-sized muscular arteries and is characterized by calcification of the medial walls of the affected arteries. Adults aged over 50 years are usually affected.

Arteriosclerosis refers to the thickening of the arterial wall and loss of elasticity. There are four patterns of arteriosclerosis:
Small vessel arteriosclerosis - involves small arteries and arterioles
It has two variants - hyaline arteriosclerosis, and hyperplastic arteriosclerosis
Monckeberg medial sclerosis - involves calcification of the walls of muscular arteries
Fibromuscular intimal hyperplasia- usually a healing response to inflammation (eg: arteritis) or mechanical injury (eg: stent insertion)
Atherosclerosis - mainly involves elastic and muscular arteries
Solution to Question 4:
The given radiograph shows extensive calcification of the femoral arteries which is suggestive of Monckeberg medial sclerosis. It is characterized by the calcification of the walls of muscular arteries, typically starting along the internal elastic lamina and involves the media of the arteries.
It occurs in people aged 50 years and above as a part of senile degeneration. It is not associated with hypertension or diabetes. It is usually an incidental finding.
Solution to Question 5:
Hypertension results in hyaline arteriosclerosis of the small vessels.
Hypertension leads to a variety of vascular pathologies. In small blood vessels, hypertension may lead to arteriosclerosis which is the thickening of the vessel wall. It has two variants which
are hyaline arteriosclerosis and hyperplastic arteriosclerosis.
In large and medium-sized arteries, hypertension leads to degenerative changes in the vessel walls, leading to:
Dissectio
Aneurysm formatio
Cerebrovascular hemorrhage
Acceleration of atherosclerosis
Solution to Question 6:
The arteriolar wall thickening in hyaline arteriosclerosis occurs as a result of plasma protein deposition.
Hyaline arteriosclerosis occurs due to injury to the endothelial cells. This allows plasma protein leakage into the arteriolar wall. The endothelial injury also stimulates increased matrix synthesis by the smooth muscle cells. These lead to the deposition of homogenous pink hyaline
material causing the thickening of arteriolar walls.
Solution to Question 7:
The given image shows hyaline arteriosclerosis. It occurs in the following conditions:
Elderly patients who are normotensive
Benign hypertension: due to chronic hemodynamic stresses
Diabetes mellitus: due to hyperglycemia-induced endothelial dysfunctio

Severe hypertension causes hyperplastic arteriosclerosis with the characteristic onion skin appearance as seen below:

Solution to Question 8:
The given image shows hyperplastic arteriosclerosis, as noted by the onion-skin appearance of the arteriole. This is seen in malignant nephrosclerosis.
Nephrosclerosis is caused by sclerosis of the small arteries and the arterioles of the kidney leading to diffuse impairment of renal blood supply. It is of 2 types:
Benignnephrosclerosis
Malignantnephrosclerosis
Seen in benign hypertension
Seen in malignant hypertensi on
Causeshyaline arteriosclerosi s
Causeshyperplastic arterioscl erosisandfibrinoid necrosisof the arterioles.


The characteristic flea-bitten appearance of the kidney is seen in malignant nephrosclerosis (shown below). This is due to small petechial hemorrhages resulting from the rupture of arterioles.

Solution to Question 9:
This clinical scenario and image showing occlusion of the left circumflex coronary artery are suggestive of atherosclerosis. It progresses in the following sequence:
Endothelial injury and dysfunctio
Accumulation of lipoproteins in the vessel wall
Monocyte adhesion to the endothelium
Platelet adhesio
Factor release from activated platelets, macrophages, and vascular wall cells
Smooth muscle cell proliferation, extracellular matrix production, and recruitment of T cells
Lipid accumulation both extracellularly and within cells
Calcification of ECM and necrotic debris late in the pathogenesis
Hence, atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory and healing response of the arterial wall to endothelial injury. The two most important causes of endothelial injury leading to atherosclerosis are hemodynamic disturbances and hypercholesterolemia.
The image below shows partial occlusion of the left circumflex coronary artery.


Solution to Question 10:
The most important independent risk factor for atherosclerosis is family history.
The familial predisposition to atherosclerosis is usually polygenic. It is related to the familial clustering of other established risk factors, such as hypertension or diabetes. It may also be due to inherited variations in pathophysiologic processes such as inflammation.
Hyperlipidemia (specifically hypercholesterolemia) is a major risk factor for atherosclerosis. Even in the absence of other risk factors, hypercholesterolemia is sufficient to initiate lesion development.
Solution to Question 11:
The most common site of atherosclerosis is the lower abdominal aorta.
In descending order, the most extensively involved vessels in atherosclerosis are:
Lower abdominal aorta
Coronary arteries
Popliteal arteries
Internal carotid arteries
Arteries of the circle of Willis
Solution to Question 12:
The above image shows yellow spots on the inner surface of the aorta, which represent fatty streaks. They indicate a collection of foamy macrophages in the intima of the vessel wall.
Fatty streaks may be present in the aorta of infants, virtually all adolescents, and even individuals without known risk factors. These lesions are not indicative of atherosclerosis, but some of
them may evolve into atheromatous plaques later in life by smooth muscle proliferation and extracellular matrix deposition.
Solution to Question 13:
The cells marked in the image above are the foam cells in atheromatous plaques. They refer to lipid-laden monocytes/ macrophages or smooth muscle cells within the plaques.
These cells ingest lipoproteins accumulated within the intima of the vessel wall. Since these lipoproteins are modified due to the action of inflammatory mediators, they cannot be degraded further within these cells. This leads to the accumulation of modified lipids within these cells converting them to foam cells.
Solution to Question 14:
T-cells and macrophages are in abundance in the shoulder of an atheromatous plaque. Structure of an atherosclerotic plaque:
Superficial fibrous cap - made up of smooth muscle cells and connective tissue, especially collagen. It also contains macrophages, foam cells, and lymphocytes. It determines the stability of plaque.
Necrotic core - contains lipid (cholesterol and cholesterol esters), debris from dead cells, calcium, and foam cells.
Shoulder - a more cellular area containing macrophages, T-cells, and smooth muscle cells.
Periphery - shows neovascularization/proliferation of small blood vessels. The image below shows the structure of an atherosclerotic plaque.

A stable atherosclerotic plaque has abundant smooth muscle cells.
These cells synthesize collagen which stabilizes the plaque. Both these features contribute to a thick fibrous cap that prevents the easy rupture of a plaque.

Solution to Question 16:
A 50-year-old patient suffering from dyslipidemia for the past 10 years is likely to have atherosclerosis. Dissection is associated with hypertension, not atherosclerosis.
An atherosclerotic plaque may undergo pathological changes such as:
Thrombus formation - due to rupture, ulceration, erosio
Increase in plaque size - due to hemorrhage into the plaque
These consequences occlude the lumen of the vessel and impair the blood supply. Impaired blood supply may lead to claudication, ischemic heart disease, myocardial infarction, cerebral infarction, or even gangrene.
The thrombus may dislodge and cause an embolism. Atherosclerotic debris released due to plaque rupture may produce microemboli, known as atheroembolism.
Atherosclerotic plaques also cause ischemic atrophy of the underlying media. This causes weakness of the vessel wall leading to aneurysm formation.
The image below depicts the late complications of atherosclerosis.

Solution to Question 17:
This symptomatic patient likely has >70% occlusion of his coronary arteries. This is known as critical stenosis.
It refers to the stage at which the occlusion is sufficiently severe to produce tissue ischemia. This leads to clinical manifestations of ischemia such as:
Stable angina
Bowel ischemia
Intermittent claudicatio
Solution to Question 18:
Elevated plasminogen levels are not associated with stroke. Elevated levels of the following are predictors for stroke:
C-reactive protein - also indicates risk for MI, PAD and used to monitor effectiveness of risk reduction measures like exercise, weight loss
Homocysteine - also correlates with MI, PAD, venous thrombosis, and premature vascular disease
Plasminogen activator inhibitor-1 - marker of hemostatic and/or fibrinolytic function and also predicts risk of MI

Late vein graft failure (after months to years) is due to:
Neointimal hyperplasia (1 month to 1 year)
Atherosclerotic plaque (> 1 year)
Aneurysm
Based on the diameter of the synthetic or autologous vascular graft, it can be:
Large diameter graft (12-18mm) -
Used in high-flow locations such as the aorta
Small diameter graft (8 mm) -
Includes saphenous vein or left internal mammary artery
Used in coronary bypass surgeries
Solution to Question 20:
Kruppel like factor-2 (KLF-2) is responsible for turning off the inflammatory gene transcription.
KLF-2 production is induced by laminar blood flow which is seen in normal endothelium. This transcription factor activates the atheroprotective genes and turns off inflammatory gene transcription. Statins up-regulate KLF-2 expression in endothelial cells, and this activity is associated with an anti-inflammatory phenotype.
Up-regulation of KLF-2 gene expression may be a novel strategy for the prevention and treatment of atherosclerosis.

Aneurysms are classified as:
Saccular aneurysms are spherical outpouchings involving only a portion of the vessel wall.
Fusiform aneurysms are diffuse, circumferential dilations involving long vascular segments.
Both saccular and fusiform aneurysms are true aneurysms because they have an intact vessel wall.

Cystic medial degeneration refers to the degenerative changes in the media of the vessel wall that lead to aneurysm formation. These include:
Loss of smooth muscle cells
Loss of elastic fibers
Inadequate extracellular matrix synthesis
Increased production of glycosaminoglycan It can be caused due to:
Medial ischemia - atherosclerosis, hypertension
Defective connective tissue - Marfan syndrome, scurvy
The image below (Movat stain) shows a cross-section of the aortic media from a patient with Marfan's syndrome showing elastin fragmentation (stained black) and loss of smooth muscle cells (cells stained red and nuclei stained violet).

Dyslipidemia is a risk factor for atherosclerosis and its complications, including abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA). AAA can also be associated with smaller aneurysms of the iliac
arteries. Patients with AAA are also likely to have atherosclerotic lesions in other vascular beds that may lead to ischemic heart disease or stroke.

Most aneurysms expand at a rate of 0.2 to 0.3 cm/year. The risk of rupture increases when there is a growth of > 0.5 cm/6 months as well as in active smokers.
Solution to Question 10:
The given clinical scenario with the CT finding of a second column of blood after an intimal tear is the classic presentation of an aortic dissection. The major risk factor for aortic dissection is hypertension.
Dissection occurs when blood enters into the media to form a blood-filled channel between the laminar planes of the media. It usually occurs due to a tear in the intima which allows blood in the lumen to flow into the media. It may also occur due to the rupture of vasa vasorum.
It occurs due to:
Hypertension
Connective tissue defects like Marfan syndrome
Iatrogenic trauma during coronary catheterization or cardiopulmonary bypass
Solution to Question 11:
The above image shows a double-barreled aorta with a superior and inferior lumen. It is a less severe type of dissection because it is less likely to cause hemorrhage.


A double-barreled aorta is seen there are two intimal tears. Hence, the hematoma enters the media through an intimal tear but re-enters back into the lumen through another intimal tear present distally. As the blood enters the lumen back, this type of dissection does not progress, thus averting hemorrhage.
This creates a false vascular channel in the blood vessel which, over time, can be endothelialized to become chronic dissections.
Solution to Question 12:
The above image shows proximal dissection of only the ascending aorta. This is classified as type II as per DeBakey's classification.
Classification of aortic dissection:
Stanford Type A - proximal lesions. These are more common and dangerous. It may involve:
Both the ascending and descending aorta - DeBakey type I
Only the ascending aorta - DeBakey type II
Stanford Type B or DeBakey type III - distal lesions not involving the ascending part and usually beginning distal to the subclavian artery

Solution to Question 1:
Giant cell arteritis is a large vessel vasculitis.
Solution to Question 2:
Giant cell arteritis does not involve the veins. Vasculitides affecting the veins are as follows:
Leukocytoclastic vasculitis
Behcet disease
Buerger disease (Thrombangiitis obliterans)
Solution to Question 3:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of giant cell arteritis.
Giant cell / temporal arteritis is a chronic inflammatory disorder of large to small-sized arteries that especially affects the temporal arteries. It is seen in people over 50 years of age. It usually presents with facial pain or headache along the course of the superficial temporal artery.
It can also affect:
Ophthalmic arteries- leading to sudden onset diplopia or blindness
Aorta- leading to giant-cell aortitis
Vertebral arteries
A biopsy is needed to confirm the diagnosis.
Giant cell arteritis needs to be promptly diagnosed and treated with steroids to prevent permanent blindness.
Solution to Question 4:
A negative biopsy cannot exclude the diagnosis of giant cell arteritis. It is because the lesions are focally distributed. A biopsy sample may be taken from the normal part of the artery leading to a false-negative report. An adequate biopsy requires at least a 1-cm segment.
Biopsy findings:
Giant cell arteritis is primarily medial granulomatous inflammation.
These lesions involve the internal elastic lamina leading to elastic lamina fragmentation.
There is intimal thickening that reduces the luminal diameter.
Granulomas with multinucleated giant cells, infiltrate of T cells (CD4+ >CD8+), and macrophages.
Note : According to the 21st edition of Harrison's Medicine, as involvement of the vessel may be segmental, getting a biopsy segment of 3–5 cm together with serial sectioning of biopsy specimens would help to increase a positive yield. And Robbin's 10th edition mentions that an adequate biopsy requires at least a 1-cm segment.
Image: Giant-cell arteritis with intimal thickening and internal elastic lamina fragmentation

Solution to Question 5:
The given clinical scenario and radiological findings are suggestive of Takayasu arteritis.
Takayasu's arteritis is a granulomatous vasculitis affecting medium and large-sized arteries, in this case, the aortic arch and its branches. Clinical manifestations include vision disturbances and profound weakening of the pulses, especially in the upper extremities.
Histopathology:
Irregular thickening of the vessel wall is seen with associated intimal hyperplasia.
Characteristic granulomatous inflammation, with the presence of giant cells and patchy media necrosis.
Disease progression is associated with collagenous scarring and chronic inflammatory infiltrates across all layers of the vessel wall.
Other options-
Option A: Giant cell arteritis (GCA), also known as temporal arteritis, is an inflammation of medium and large-sized vessels. It is more common in women and people aged >50 years.
The clinical features include headache associated with scalp pain and jaw claudication, fever, fatigue, malaise, and weight loss. Half of the patients have temporal artery abnormalities such as enlargement, tenderness, nodular swelling, and loss of pulse of the temporal artery, either unilateral or bilateral. Gentle pressure on the scalp may elicit focal or generalized tenderness.
Though the arch of the aorta may also be involved in giant cell arteritis (known as giant cell aortitis), it is seen in people more than 50 years of age. Whereas, Takayasu arteritis is seen more commonly in adolescents and young women.
Option C: Thromboangitis obliterans, also known as Buerger's disease, is an inflammatory occlusive vascular disorder involving medium- and small-sized vessels in the distal extremities. It is most frequently seen in male smokers less than 40 years of age.
Option D: Behcet's disease is a neutrophilic vasculitis affecting small- to medium-sized vessels that classically presents as a clinical triad of recurrent oral aphthous ulcers, genital ulcers, and uveitis. There can also be gastrointestinal and pulmonary manifestations, with disease mortality related to severe neurologic involvement or rupture of vascular aneurysms.
Solution to Question 6:
The most commonly involved blood vessel in Takayasu arteritis is sublclavian artery.
Takayasu arteritis is an inflammatory and stenotic disease of medium and large-sized arteries characterized by a strong predilection for the aortic arch and its branches. It is also known
as aortic arch syndrome.
The order of arteries affected in Takayasu arteritis is subclavian artery > common carotid artery > abdominal aorta > renal artery > aortic arch = vertebral > coeliac axis > iliac > pulmonary > coronary artery.
Takayasu arteritis causes irregular thickening of the vessel wall with intimal hyperplasia leading to narrowing of the lumen and organ ischemia.
It may have various clinical presentations depending on the vessel involved:
Arch of aorta and its branches:
Subclavian artery- leads to weak pulses in the upper extremities. Hence it is also known as pulseless disease
Carotid arteries- leads to weak pulses, blindness, neurological deficits
Distal aorta- leads to claudication of the legs
Pulmonary artery- leads to pulmonary hypertension
Coronary arteries- leads to myocardial infarction
Renal arteries- leads to systemic hypertension
Solution to Question 7:
The given clinical scenario and the histopathological findings are suggestive of polyarteritis nodosa (PAN).
PAN affects small or medium-sized muscular arteries. It typically affects young adults. The patient may present with rapidly accelerating hypertension due to renal artery involvement (most common) or abdominal pain and bloody stools caused by involvement of gastrointestinal vessels.
Option A: Hyperplastic arteriosclerosis is a vascular pathology seen in severe hypertension. Option B: Cystic medial degeneration leads to dissecting aortic aneurysm.
Option C: Mönckeberg’s arteriosclerosis does not cause infarction.
Solution to Question 8:
Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) characteristically spares the pulmonary circulation.
PAN is a systemic vasculitis of small or medium-sized muscular arteries. It typically involves the renal (most commonly involved) and visceral vessels. It has no association with ANCA, but about 30% of patients have chronic hepatitis-B.
Solution to Question 9:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Kawasaki disease or mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome.
Kawasaki disease is an acute febrile illness associated with arteritis of medium to large-sized vessels. It is commonly seen in infants and children <4 years of age.
Clinical features include:
Fever
Conjunctival and oral erythema
Blistering, edema of hands and feet
Erythema of palms and soles
Desquamative rash
Cervical lymphadenopathy
The disease is usually self-limiting. In some cases, the disease may involve coronary artery leading to thrombosis and acute myocardial infarction. Intravenous immunoglobulin and aspirin may be given to reduce the risk of coronary artery disease.
Solution to Question 10:
Antibodies to endothelial cells are associated with vasculitis in Kawasaki disease.
Option A: Immune complex deposition is characteristic of vasculitis due to systemic immunologic disorders such as SLE.
Option B: ANCA-associated vasculitis is seen in microscopic polyangiitis, Churg–Strauss syndrome, and granulomatosis with polyangiitis.
Option D: Autoreactive T cells are seen in giant cell arteritis.
Reports have been described in children with a multisystem inflammatory condition (MIS-C) linked to COVID-19 infection with some features similar to Kawasaki disease and toxic shock syndrome. Although shock is rarely associated with Kawasaki disease, many children with the inflammatory syndrome related to COVID show signs of shock.
Solution to Question 11:
Kawasaki disease is also known as mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome.
Kawasaki disease is an acute febrile illness occurring in children aged 4 years or younger. It is usually self- limiting. This vasculitis affects large to medium-sized vessels and even small vessels.
It is also known as mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome because it can present with
non-purulent conjunctivitis, oral erythema, edema of the hands and feet, desquamative rash, and cervical lymph node enlargement.
It has a predilection for coronary artery involvement and is the leading cause of acquired heart disease in children. Untreated patients may develop coronary artery ectasia or aneurysms, leading to rupture or thrombosis, myocardial infarction, and sudden death.
Espundia is the muco-cutaneous variant of Leishmaniasis
Solution to Question 12:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus. The vasculitis occurring in a patient with systemic lupus erythematosus is due to immune complex deposition.
Vasculitis is the inflammation of the vessel wall. The various mechanisms that cause vasculitis are:
Immune-mediated inflammation- Vasculitis caused by immune-mediated inflammation may occur due to the following factors:
Immune complex deposition: Seen in systemic immunological disorders like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA): Seen in Wegener's granulomatosis, Churg–Strauss disease, etc
Anti endothelial cell antibodies: Implicated in Kawasaki disease
Autoreactive T cells
Infectious pathogens- by direct invasion, generating immune complexes or triggering cross-reactivity.
Physical or chemical injury- from irradiation, trauma, toxins, etc.
Solution to Question 13:
Anti-proteinase-3/PR3-ANCA / c-ANCA is triggered by certain infections as proteinase 3 shares similarities with many microbial peptides. This is the major antibody responsible for Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA).
Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) are a heterogeneous group of autoantibodies directed against the constituents of neutrophils or monocytes. Many patients with vasculitis have circulating antibodies that react with neutrophil cytoplasmic antigens.
The two most important ANCAs related to vasculitis are:
Anti-proteinase-3/PR3-ANCA/c-ANCA - Directed against PR3 which is a neutrophil azurophilic granule constituent.
Anti-myeloperoxidase/MPO-ANCA/p-ANCA - Directed against MPO which is a lysosomal granule constituent involved in oxygen free-radical generation. MPO-ANCAs are induced by severa therapeutic agents, particularly propylthiouracil.
Solution to Question 14:
Type III or pauci-immune-type of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) may be a component of systemic vasculitis such as Wegener granulomatosis or microscopic polyangiitis.
Solution to Question 15:
All lesions of microscopic polyangiitis tend to be of the same age in any given patient, unlike polyarteritis nodosa where all stages of activity from early to late may coexist in different vessels or even within the same vessel.
Microscopic polyangiitis is a necrotizing vasculitis that affects capillaries, small arterioles, and venules. It is associated with MPO-ANCA. It is also called leukocytoclastic vasculitis because of apoptotic neutrophils.
It may involve the skin, mucous membranes, lungs, brain, heart, gastrointestinal tract, kidneys, and muscle. Therefore, the patient may present with hemoptysis, hematuria, proteinuria, bowel pain or bleeding, muscle pain or weakness, and palpable cutaneous purpura. Necrotizing glomerulonephritis (90% of patients) and pulmonary capillaritis are particularly common.
Solution to Question 16:
The given clinical scenario and the lab findings are suggestive of Churg–Strauss syndrome.
Churg-Strauss Syndrome / Allergic granulomatosis and angiitis is a small-vessel necrotizing vasculitis classically associated with:
asthma
allergic rhinitis
asymmetric mono neuritis multiplex
ung infiltrates
peripheral hypereosinophilia
extravascular necrotizing granulomata.
It is a multisystem disease with cutaneous involvement (palpable purpura), gastrointestinal tract bleeding, and renal disease. Eosinophilic infiltrates may also be seen in the myocardium giving rise to cardiomyopathy.
p- ANCA (MPO-ANCA) is positive in about 50% of cases. Histological features are similar to those observed in polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) or microscopic polyangiitis but characteristically accompanied by granulomas and eosinophils.
Eosinophilic vasculitis seen in Churg-Strauss syndrome:

Solution to Question 17:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of Wegener's granulomatosis. It is associated with PR3- ANCA (and not MPO- ANCA) in about 95% of cases.
Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis/Wegener granulomatosis is a necrotizing vasculitis characterized by a triad of necrotizing inflammation:
Necrotizing granulomas of the upper respiratory tract or the lung
Necrotizing or granulomatous vasculitis affecting small to medium-sized vessels, most prominently in the lungs
Focal necrotizing crescentic glomerulonephritis
Males are affected more often than females. The most common clinical features include persistent pneumonitis with bilateral nodular and cavitary infiltrates, chronic sinusitis, mucosal ulcerations of the nasopharynx, and evidence of renal disease.
Image: Chest radiograph showing pulmonary granulomatosis

Solution to Question 18:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Behçet disease. Nail fold capillary abnormalities are typically seen in systemic sclerosis.
Behcet disease is a neutrophilic vasculitis affecting small- to medium-sized vessels that classically presents as a clinical triad of recurrent oral aphthous ulcers, genital ulcers, and uveitis. Other skin findings include erythema nodosa (red tender nodules on legs) and positive pathergy test (pustular reaction 24-48 hrs after sterile needle puncture or normal saline injection).
There can also be gastrointestinal and pulmonary manifestations, with disease mortality related to severe neurologic involvement or rupture of vascular aneurysms. Dural sinus thrombosis is the most common CNS manifestation in children. Pulmonary aneurysms are the most severe feature of pediatric BD.
It is associated with HLA subtype B51. T helper 17 (Th17) cells play an important contribution in the recruitment of neutrophils, which will later infiltrate into the vessel wall.
Solution to Question 19:
The clinical features and the investigations are suggestive of Henoch-Schonlein purpura.
Henoch-Schönlein purpura is a systemic immune disorder, commonly seen in the age group of 3-8 years. The patient may present with the following clinical features:
Skin lesions- characteristically involve the extensor surfaces of arms and legs, and also the buttocks
Abdominal manifestations- include pain, vomiting, and intestinal bleeding.
Renal manifestations- include gross or microscopic hematuria, nephritic or nephrotic syndrome. Renal manifestations are more severe in the adults
It is strongly associated with atopy in a few patients, and the onset often follows an upper respiratory infection. IgA is deposited in the glomerular mesangium in a distribution similar to that of IgA nephropathy.
Solution to Question 20:
Arteries, veins and nerves can be involved in thrombangiitis obliterans (Buerger's disease). It is a vasculitis of small and medium-sized arteries and secondarily extends into contiguous veins and nerves. With time, all three structures can be encased in fibrous tissue.
Solution to Question 21:
The most likely diagnosis is thromboangiitis obliterans / Buerger disease.
It is the segmental, thrombosing, acute and chronic inflammation of medium-sized and small arteries. It principally involves the tibial and radial arteries.
It is seen in heavy cigarette smokers, usually before the age of 35 years. HLA-A-9 and HLA-B-5 associated with a high risk of TAO.
The patients present with intermittent claudication, chronic ulcerations of the extremity, and later progress to frank gangrene. The microscopy findings include luminal thrombosis (thrombangiitis), that is, thrombus containing microabscesses that occlude the lumen (obliterans). They contain small microabscesses composed of neutrophils.
Berger disease refers to IgA nephropathy. It is seen within 3-5 days of sore throat. It is associated with purpuric rash in the lower limbs.
Solution to Question 22:
Luminal thrombosis containing small microabscesses composed of neutrophils is seen in thromboangiitis obliterans or Buerger disease.
Option A: Adventitial mononuclear infiltrates with perivascular cuffing of the vasa vasorum has been described in Takayasu arteritis.
Option B: Fragmented neutrophils undergoing apoptosis infiltrating blood vessels termed leukocytoclastic vasculitis are seen in small vessel vasculitis.
Option D: Fibrinoid necrosis is seen in immune reactions involving blood vessels seen in immunologically mediated vasculitis syndromes.

Solution to Question 1:
Angiosarcoma is a malignant neoplasm. It is a vascular tumor arising from the endothelial cells.
Benign vascular tumors are characterized by well-formed vascular channels lined by normal endothelial cells. Whereas, malignant vascular tumors are characterized by poorly formed vessels with cellular atypia.
Solution to Question 2:
Hemangiopericytoma is not derived from endothelial cells. It is a malignant vascular tumor derived from supporting cells of the blood vessels.
Vascular tumors derived from endothelial cells are:
Hemangioma
Lymphangioma
Angiosarcoma
The endothelial origin of vascular neoplasms can be confirmed using endothelial cell-specific markers such as CD31 or von Willebrand factor.
Solution to Question 3:
Cystic hygroma / cavernous lymphangioma is a true neoplasm. It is a benign vascular tumor arising from endothelial cells.
Options A and B: Nevus flammeus and port wine stain are vascular ectasias which are not true neoplasms. They are congenital or acquired malformations.
Option D: Bacillary angiomatosis is non-neoplastic reactive vascular proliferation in response to opportunistic bacilli.
Solution to Question 4:
The most common form of vascular ectasia is nevus flammeus.
Vascular ectasias are the conditions involving the dilatation of blood vessels. They can be congenital or acquired malformations or hamartomas. Telangiectasia is the permanent dilation of small blood vessels. They lead to red lesions in the skin or mucous membranes.
Various types of vascular ectasias are as follows:
Nevus flammeus (birthmark): Pink/purple flat lesions on the head or neck. They regress spontaneously.
Image showing nevus flammeus in a newborn:

Port-wine stain: A special form of nevus flammeus. It thickens the skin surface. It grows during childhood and does not fade with time.
Image showing port-wine stain in a child:

Spider telangiectasias: They are pulsatile and blanch with pressure. These commonly occur on the face, neck, or upper chest. They are associated with hyperestrogenic states, such as pregnancy or liver cirrhosis.

Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (Osler–Weber–Rendu disease) is caused by mutations in genes related to the TGF- signaling pathway. It is characterized by dilated blood vessels with thin walls that bleed easily. There can be bleeding from the mucous membranes of the nose (epistaxis), tongue, mouth, eyes, and the gastrointestinal tract.
The image below shows multiple flat non pulsating telengiectasias in a patient with Osler-Weber-Rendu disease:

Solution to Question 5:
The given clinical scenario and the facial port-wine stain as seen in the image is characteristic of Sturge-Weber syndrome.
This is characterized by a triad of:
Facial port wine nevus - usually found in the distribution of the ophthalmic division (V1) of the trigeminal nerve
Glaucoma
Ipsilateral leptomeningeal angiomatosis (LAM) - can lead to seizures, mental retardation or hemiplegia and are seen as intracranial tram-track calcifications on CT as given below.

Solution to Question 6:
The most common type of hemangioma is capillary hemangioma.
Hemangiomas are benign vascular tumors of infancy and childhood. They are of the following types:
Capillary hemangiomas are the most common type. They occur in the skin, subcutaneous tissues, and mucous membranes of the oral cavities and lips.
Cavernous hemangiomas are composed of large, dilated vascular channels. They are more infiltrative and frequently involve deep structures. They do not spontaneously regress.
Juvenile hemangiomas/strawberry type hemangiomas of the newborn are extremely common. They arise in the skin and grow rapidly for a few months, and usually regress completely by the age of 7 years.
Pyogenic granulomas are capillary hemangiomas that present as rapidly growing red pedunculated lesions on the skin, gingival, or oral mucosa. They bleed easily and are often ulcerated. It is not caused by bacterial infection.
Solution to Question 7:
Capillary hemangiomas are present from birth and initially increase in size, but many eventually regress spontaneously. They are generally benign.
Images show the gross and microscopic pictures of capillary hemangioma:


Solution to Question 8:
von Hippel–Lindau disease is associated with cavernous hemangiomas. These vascular lesions are commonly found in the cerebellum, brain stem, retina, pancreas, and liver.
Cavernous hemangiomas are large, cavernous blood-filled vascular spaces separated by connective tissue stroma. They are infiltrative and involve deep structures. They do not regress spontaneously.
The given image shows the microscopic appearance of cavernous hemangioma:

Solution to Question 9:
The vascular lesions commonly seen in Turner syndrome are cavernous lymphangiomas of the neck.
Cavernous lymphangiomas (cystic hygromas) are massively dilated lymphatic spaces lined by endothelial cells and separated by connective tissue stroma. They are typically found in the neck or axilla of children and rarely in the retroperitoneum. They can be enormous causing gross deformities around the neck.
Image shows cavernous lymphangioma of the neck associated with a girl having Turner syndrome:

Solution to Question 10:
The given image shows a pyogenic granuloma. It is not caused by bacterial infection. The term pyogenic granuloma is a misnomer as it neither contains pus nor is it a granulomatous lesion.
These are capillary hemangiomas that appear as red pedunculated lesions on the skin, gingival, or oral mucosa. They are most commonly benign. They tend to grow rapidly, bleed easily and are often ulcerated.
Histologic image of pyogenic granuloma:

Solution to Question 11:
Pregnancy tumor or granuloma gravidarum is a type of pyogenic granuloma that occurs infrequently in gingiva of pregnant women.
These lesions may spontaneously regress, especially after pregnancy, or they may undergo fibrosis. Occasionally, they require surgical excision.
Solution to Question 12:
The vascular tumor arising from arteriovenous structures involved in thermoregulation is glomus tumor.
These tumors arise from modified smooth muscle cells of the glomus bodies which are specialized arteriovenous structures involved in thermoregulation. They are benign but extremely painful due to abundant nerve fibers.
Histopathology shows branching vascular channels separated by stroma containing glomus cells in nests:

Solution to Question 13:
Glomus tumors are most commonly found in the distal portion of the digits, especially under the fingernails.

Solution to Question 14:
The clinical vignette and the microscopic findings suggest the diagnosis of bacillary angiomatosis caused by Bartonella henselae.
Bacillary angiomatosis is a vascular proliferation in immunocompromised hosts caused by opportunistic gram-negative bacilli of the Bartonella family like Bartonella henselae
and Bartonella quintana.
These lesions can involve the skin, bone, brain, and other organs. They contain stromal neutrophils, nuclear dust, and causal bacteria. Histology shows capillary proliferation with endothelial cells exhibiting nuclear atypia and mitosis.
Modified silver (Warthin-Starry) stain is used for demonstrating clusters of tangled bacilli. The given image shows histologic appearance of bacillary angiomatosis:

Solution to Question 15:
The given clinical scenario and the histopathological findings are most suggestive of Kaposi sarcoma.
Kaposi sarcoma is a vascular neoplasm caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8) and is highly associated with AIDS (acquired immunodeficiency syndrome). Classic Kaposi sarcoma occurs
in older men of Eastern European and Meditteranean descent. It has the following three clinical stages:
Patches- red-purple macules on the distal lower extremities
Plaques- patches progress to large violaceous raised plaques. Lesions spread proximally.
Nodules- Lesions become nodular with more neoplastic features. This stage also progresses to involve nodes and viscera.
Diseases caused by HHV-8 infection primarily in patients with HIV infection include:
Kaposi sarcoma
Multicentric Castleman disease (MCD)
Primary effusion lymphoma (PEL)
The given image shows sheets of proliferating spindle cells:

Solution to Question 16:
AIDS-associated or epidemic Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is an AIDS-defining illness, and worldwide, it represents the most common HIV-related malignancy.
Four forms of KS are recognized, based on population demographics and risks:

Transplant-associated

Lymph node and visc eral involvement
Cutaneous, mucosal a nd visceral lesions
Lymph nodes involve d
Solution to Question 17:
Hemangioendothelioma is classified as intermediate-grade neoplasm. It encompasses a spectrum of vascular neoplasms with clinical behavior intermediate between benign well-differentiated hemangiomas and anaplastic angiosarcomas.
Solution to Question 18:
Hepatic angiosarcoma is associated with carcinogenic exposures to polyvinyl chloride.
Angiosarcoma is a malignant endothelial neoplasm that primarily affects older adults. The tumor often involves the skin, soft tissue, breast, and liver. Angiosarcomas are locally invasive and can readily metastasize.
Solution to Question 19:
Group A beta-hemolytic streptococci are the most common agents responsible for lymphangitis.
Lymphangitis represents acute inflammation elicited by the spread of bacterial infections into lymphatics. It is manifested by red, painful subcutaneous streaks (the inflamed lymphatics) and painful enlargement of the draining lymph nodes (lymphadenitis).
Filariasis causes obstructive lymphedema and chronic lymphadenitis.
Solution to Question 20:
Milroy disease refers to heredofamilial congenital lymphedema. Causes of lymphedema:
Primary lymphedema:
Simple congenital lymphedema
Heredofamilial congenital lymphedema (Milroy disease) Secondary or obstructive lymphedema:
Malignant tumors obstructing lymphatic channels
Surgical removal of regional groups of lymph nodes, e.g., radical mastectomy
Postirradiation fibrosis
Filariasis
Post-inflammatory thrombosis and scarring
