Solution to Question 1:
Adventitia is not a layer of the cardiac valves. It is the outermost layer of a blood vessel. It contains connective tissue, a few cells, macrophages, mast cells, fibroblasts, and the nerves and vessels that supply the vascular wall.
Cardiac valves are lined by endothelium and share a tri-layered architecture:
Fibrosa is a dense collagenous core at the outflow surface. It is connected to the valvular supporting structures.
Spongiosa is a central core of loose connective tissue
Ventricularis or atrialis is a layer rich in elastin on the inflow surface.
Solution to Question 2:
In the given scenario, an increase in the size of the left ventricle is not normally seen in the heart of an elderly person. The size of the left ventricular cavity is decreased in the aged heart, particularly in the base-to-apex dimension. This change is exacerbated by systemic hypertension.
Changes in the aging heart:
Chambers:
Increased left atrial cavity size
Decreased left ventricular cavity size
Valves:
Fibrous thickening of valve leaflets
Aortic and mitral valve calcific deposits
Epicardial coronary arteries:
Diminished compliance
Calcific deposits
Atherosclerotic plaques
Myocardium:
Increased subepicardial fat
Brown atrophy
Lipofuscin deposition
Basophilic degeneration
Amyloid deposits
Aorta:
Dilated with a rightward shift
Elastic fragmentation and collagen accumulation
Atherosclerotic plaque
Solution to Question 3:
Heart failure cells are hemosiderin-laden macrophages. They are telltale signs of previous episodes of pulmonary edema.
In cardiac failure, red cells and plasma proteins extravasate into the edema fluid within the alveolar spaces. These are then phagocytosed and digested by macrophages. The iron recovered from haemoglobin is stored in the form of hemosiderin.
The image given below shows heart failure cells within alveolar spaces.


Solution to Question 4:
Hypertension is the most common cause of left-sided diastolic heart failure.
Left-sided heart failure can be divided into systolic and diastolic failure. Diastolic failure predominantly occurs in patients older than age 65 years. Here, the left ventricle is abnormally stiff and cannot relax during diastole.
Causes of diastolic heart failure:
Hypertension: most common
Diabetes mellitus
Obesity
Bilateral renal artery stenosis
Systolic failure is due to insufficient ejection fraction, i.e., pump failure. It occurs when the contractile function of the left ventricle is deranged.
Solution to Question 5:
Isolated right-sided heart failure is not caused by left-sided heart failure.
Isolated right-sided heart failure is not common and usually occurs in patients with disorders affecting the lungs. Therefore, it is often referred to as cor pulmonale. It is caused by disorders of the lung parenchyma and pulmonary vasculature. It is also caused by conditions causing pulmonary vasoconstriction like obstructive sleep apnea and altitude sickness.
Pulmonary hypertension is the common feature of these disorders, which leads to hypertrophy and dilation of the right side of the heart.
Right-sided heart failure is most commonly caused by left-sided heart failure. This is because an increase in pressure in the pulmonary circulation from left-sided failure burdens the right side of the heart.
Solution to Question 6:
In the given scenario, the patient has acute cor pulmonale. This causes right ventricular dilation without hypertrophy. On cross-section, the normal crescent shape of the right ventricle is transformed to a dilated ovoid.
In chronic cor pulmonale, the right ventricular wall thickens. The hypertrophied right ventricle may compress the left ventricular chamber. It can also cause regurgitation and fibrous thickening of the tricuspid valve.
Solution to Question 7:
In the image, the liver specimen shows a nutmeg liver appearance, which occurs in congestive hepatomegaly. This is secondary to passive congestion due to right heart failure.
In right heart failure, there is congestion of hepatic and portal vessels, greatest around the central veins. This leads to increased liver size and weight. The pericentral zones become congested and red-brown. The periportal regions are normal coloured and tan. This leads to a nutmeg liver appearance. With longstanding failure, the central areas can become fibrotic, eventually culminating in cardiac cirrhosis.
Pathological changes are also seen in the spleen and the gastrointestinal tract. Portal venous hypertension also causes the enlargement of the spleen, with platelet sequestration. This is known as congestive splenomegaly. This can also contribute to chronic congestion and oedema of the bowel.
Solution to Question 8:
Estrogen reduces the risk of myocardial infarction in women in the reproductive age group.
Accelerated coronary artery disease is associated with the postmenopausal decline in estrogen production. However, postmenopausal hormonal replacement therapy (HRT) has not been shown to be beneficial.
The most common cause of death in older women is ischemic heart disease. Through middle age, males have a relatively increased risk of myocardial infarction.
Solution to Question 9:
Triphenyl tetrazolium chloride solution imparts a brick red colour to the viable non-infarcted myocardium. The infarct appears unstained and pale.
Myocardial infarcts < 12 hours old are usually not apparent on gross examination. However, if the infarct preceded death by 2 to 3 hours, it is possible to identify the area of necrosis. This is done by immersing the tissue slices in triphenyl tetrazolium chloride solution.
The histochemical stain imparts a brick-red colour to intact, noninfarcted myocardium. Here, lactate dehydrogenase, LDH, activity is preserved. LDH leaks out through the damaged membranes of dead cells, so an infarct appears as an unstained pale zone.
The image given below shows an ischemic brain after immersion in triphenyl tetrazolium chloride solution. The pale unstained region is the infarcted zone.

Solution to Question 10:
Microvascular injury begins >1 hour after the onset of ischemia.
Solution to Question 11:
Relaxation of myofibrils is the earliest detectable ultrastructural feature of myocardial infarction.
Myofibril relaxation, mitochondrial swelling and glycogen loss can be detected by electron microscopy within half an hour of myocardial infarction.
Solution to Question 12:
The earliest light microscopic change that can be observed in the heart of this patient is
the waviness of myocardial fibres. This is seen within ½-4 hours at the border of the infarct.
These changes are a result of the forceful contractions of viable fibres. The contractions cause stretching and buckling of immediately adjacent, noncontractile dead fibres.
Myocyte vacuolization or myocytolysis may also be seen in the infarct margins. It is due to the accumulation of salt and water in the sarcoplasmic reticulum. Such myocytes are viable but poorly contractile.
The image below shows microscopic features of myocardial infarction showing wavy myocardial fibres. There are wavy fibres that are elongated and narrow, as compared with normal fibres. The widened spaces between the dead fibres contain edema fluid and scattered neutrophils.

Solution to Question 13:
Early coagulative necrosis begins in myocardial infarction by 4–12 hours. However, it is prominent between 1 to 3 days after myocardial infarction.
Solution to Question 14:
The given image shows neutrophilic infiltration into the myocardium. Early neutrophil infiltration starts by 12–24 hours following the infarction. It can be visualised by examination with a light microscope.
The necrotic myocardium elicits acute inflammation most prominent between 1 and 3 days. During this time, there is a brisk interstitial infiltrate of neutrophils.
The image given below shows neutrophilic infiltration into the myocardium following MI.

Solution to Question 15:
In the given scenario, 4 days after MI, macrophages are seen in the infarcted area.
They phagocytose dead myocytes at the border of the infarct earliest by 72 hours. Removal of the necrotic myocytes is most noticeable by 3 to 7 days.
The image below shows a macrophagic infiltrate in the infarcted area.

Solution to Question 16:
The correct match is:
Well established granulation - 10 - 14 days
Complete scarring - > 2 months
Myocyte hypereosinophilia - 12 - 24 hours
Grey white scar - 2-8 weeks
Loss of nuclei and striations - 1 - 3 days
Solution to Question 17:
The given autopsy finding of hemopericardium secondary to ventricular wall rupture occurs most frequently 3-7 days after myocardial infarction (MI). During this time, the lysis of the necrotic myocardium is maximum. Thus most of the infarct has been converted to friable granulation tissue.
The risk factors for free-wall rupture are:
Age > 60 years
Female gender
First MI
Large, transmural and anterior MI
Absence of left ventricular hypertrophy
Preexisting hypertension
It is less frequent in patients with prior MI because associated fibrotic scarring inhibits myocardial tearing.
Complications of MI:
Heart failure -
This is due to ventricular dysfunction caused by the infarct and ventricular remodeling
Usually occurs within a day
Cardiogenic shock -
This is usually seen in severe multivessel coronary artery disease due to extensive involvement of myocardium
Usually occurs within a day
Arrhythmias - most common complication, occurring usually 2 days after infarction
Most common arrhythmia within one hour of MI - ventricular fibrillation
Most common arrhythmia after one hour of MI - supraventricular tachycardia
Myocardial rupture - occurs when there is transmural necrosis of a ventricle. It includes the following -
Left ventricular free wall rupture (most common) - leads to cardiac tamponade
Interventricular septal rupture - leads acute ventricular septal defect (VSD)
Papillary muscle rupture - leads to severe mitral regurgitation
Mitral regurgitation (MR) - this can occur due to -
Transient papillary muscle dysfunction - mid-systolic or late-systolic murmur
Rupture of papillary muscle - pansystolic murmur
Dressler syndrome (post-MI syndrome) -
This is an immune-mediated reaction and presents as pericarditis, pleurisy, and fever
It can occur even 48 hrs after MI but usually occurs 1–6 weeks after MI and often subside after a few days
Ventricular aneurysm
Infarct expansion associated with mural thrombus
Solution to Question 18:
Tigered myocardium appearance occurs as a result of prolonged moderate hypoxia due to fatty change. It is the gross appearance of the heart with bands of yellow myocardium alternating with normal myocardium.
Solution to Question 19:
In reperfusion injury, the maximum damage is caused by free radicals.
Reperfusion is the restoration of blood flow to the ischemic myocardium threatened by infarction. Reperfused infarcts are usually hemorrhagic because the vasculature is injured during ischemia. Once the flow is restored, there is bleeding.
On microscopic examination, the irreversibly injured myocytes exhibit contraction bands that are intensely eosinophilic intracellular stripes. These contraction bands are composed of closely packed sarcomeres.
Reperfusion injury may be mediated by:
Oxidative stress
Calcium overload
Inflammatory cells recruited after tissue reperfusion
Solution to Question 20:
Heart muscle contains MM and MB isoenzymes of creatine kinase. Creatine kinase (CK) has three isoenzymes:
CK-1 (BB) - brain, nerve tissue, prostate (small amounts), intestine, lung, bladder, kidney, uterus, thyroid
CK-2 (MB) - heart and skeletal muscle
CK-3 (MM) - skeletal and heart muscle
Elevation of the CK-MB isoforms is seen in MI. CK-MB is less
sensitive and less specific, therefore, troponins are preferred for the diagnosis of MI. CK-MB begins to rise within 3-12 hours of the onset of MI. It peaks at about 24 hours and returns to normal within approximately 48-72 hours.
Solution to Question 21:
The given scenario is suggestive of acute myocardial infarction (MI). Enzymes elevated after 4 to 8 hours of MI are CK-MB (creatine kinase MB) and troponins.
When cardiac troponin is available, CK-MB should not be used for the initial diagnosis of acute MI. If it is the only assay available, it can be used, but it is far less sensitive and less specific.
Solution to Question 22:
In the given scenario, on post-MI day 7, troponin and LDH will be raised. Troponins are highly specific for MI and remain elevated for 7 to 10 days.
Troponins are proteins that regulate calcium-mediated contraction of the cardiac and skeletal muscles. It is the single biomarker preferred for diagnosing MI, late diagnosis of MI, and diagnosis of reinfarction. Troponin I is more important than troponin T.
Cardiac troponin increases rapidly in patients with reinfarction. Sometimes, the cardiac troponin concentration is elevated, but stable or decreasing at the time of suspected reinfarction. Then
the diagnosis of reinfarction requires a 20% or greater increase in the cTn measurement.
Myoglobin is the earliest enzyme to increase after MI. It is a protein that is found in the skeletal and cardiac muscles, which binds oxygen. It is a very sensitive indicator of muscle injury. But it is not specific to cardiac muscle and can be elevated to any form of injury to skeletal muscle.
Myoglobin and SGOT levels come to baseline before day 1.
Solution to Question 23:
The yellow curve here shows the levels of CK-MB which starts rising around 4 to 8 hrs post-MI, peaks at 24 hours and becomes normal at 48 to 72 hrs.
The post-myocardial infarction blood levels of the different cardiac biomarkers are shown in the image given below.

Solution to Question 24:
Loss of function mutation in K+ channel genes KCNQ1 and KCNH2 produces the long QT syndrome. The gain-of-function mutation produces the short QT syndrome.
Long QT syndrome manifests as arrhythmias associated with excessive prolongation of cardiac repolarization. Stress-induced syncope or sudden cardiac death (SCD), are common presentations.
Short QT syndrome presents with arrhythmias associated with abbreviated repolarization intervals. They also present with palpitations, syncope, and SCD.
Brugada syndrome manifests as ECG abnormalities like ST-segment elevations and right bundle-branch block. This occurs in the absence of structural heart disease. Here, patients classically present with syncope or SCD during rest or sleep or after large meals.
Familial atrial fibrillation is caused by a gain of function mutation in genes coding potassium channels.
Solution to Question 25:
The mechanism behind sudden cardiac death (SCD) is most often a lethal arrhythmia, e.g., asystole or ventricular fibrillation.
Coronary artery disease is the leading cause of SCD, responsible for 80% to 90% of cases. But, the mechanism of SCD is most often a lethal arrhythmia. Infarction need not occur. Most of the patients who have SCD but are successfully resuscitated do not show any enzymatic or ECG evidence of myocardial necrosis.
Ischemic injury can directly affect the major components of the conduction system. But, most cases of fatal arrhythmia are triggered by electrical irritability of the myocardium.
Solution to Question 26:
Patients with hyperlipidemia have an increased susceptibility to coronary artery disease (CAD).
Hyperlipidemia is considered the second most common risk factor for CAD worldwide after hypertension. Hypercholesterolemia was implicated in 55% of cases with combined hyperlipidemia in 41% cases.
Solution to Question 27:
Lipoprotein a [Lp(a)] contains the apolipoprotein B-100 portion of LDL linked to apolipoprotein A
(apo A). It is an altered form of low-density lipoprotein (LDL).
Increased Lp(a) levels are associated with coronary and cerebrovascular disease risk. It is independent of total cholesterol or LDL levels.
Solution to Question 28:
Reperfused myocardium shows eosinophilic contraction bands on light microscopy. They occur in irreversibly injured myocytes with damaged membranes, when blood supply is restored 12-24 hours after MI.
During ischemia, the intracellular levels of calcium are increased due to impaired calcium cycling and sarcolemmal damage. This leads to augmented and uncontrolled contraction of myofibrils
after reperfusion.
On microscopic examination, the irreversibly injured myocytes exhibit contraction bands that are intensely eosinophilic intracellular stripes. These contraction bands are composed of closely packed sarcomeres.
Reperfused infarcts are usually hemorrhagic because the vasculature is injured during ischemia. This leads to bleeding after the flow is restored.
Myocardial and Pericardial Diseases and Cardiac Tumors

Solution to Question 1:
The most common type of cardiomyopathy is dilated cardiomyopathy. Restrictive cardiomyopathy is the least frequent.
Cardiomyopathies are a heterogeneous group of diseases of the myocardium associated with mechanical and/or electrical dysfunction. They usually exhibit inappropriate ventricular hypertrophy or dilatation. The causes are frequently genetic.
Cardiomyopathies maybe primary predominantly involving the heart or secondary to a systemic or multiorgan disorder. They occur in the absence of any coronary artery disease, valvular heart disease, congenital heart disease, or systemic arterial hypertension.
Types of cardiomyopathy:
Dilated cardiomyopathy
Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
Restrictive cardiomyopathy
Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy
Left ventricular non-compaction cardiomyopathy
Solution to Question 2:
Alcohol abuse is strongly associated with the development of dilated cardiomyopathy.
Alcohol and its metabolites, especially acetaldehyde have a direct toxic effect on the myocardium which leads to the development of dilated cardiomyopathy.
Causes of dilated cardiomyopathy:
Acquired causes :
Infectious and non-infectious myocarditis: most common cause globally
Alcohol is the most common cause in India
Pregnancy:
Pregnancy-associated cardiomyopathy (PACM)
Peripartum cardiomyopathy (PPCM)
Stress-induced: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy
Drug-induced:
Doxorubicin (anthracycline)
Trastuzumab
Cyclophosphamide
Nutritional deficiency:
Beriberi (thiamine),
Keshan disease (selenium),
Carnitine deficiency
Endocrine: Hypo and hyperthyroidism, acromegaly, diabetes mellitus
Others:
Cobalt toxicity,
Heavy metals (lead, mercury, arsenic, lithium)
Familial causes (50%):
Mutation in the cardiac myocyte titin gene
Haemochromatosis
Syndromes: Duchenne muscular dystrophy, Becker’s muscular dystrophy
Solution to Question 3:
Titin is the largest protein expressed in humans.
Titin is the third myofilament of cardiac muscle. It has a single giant polypeptide spanning from Z-disk to the M-band region of the sarcomere.
Mutation in TTN, the gene encoding titin, is responsible for 20% of all cases of dilated cardiomyopathy.
Solution to Question 4:
The given clinical scenario of sudden cardiac death in a previously healthy man, under a stressful situation, is suggestive of takotsubo cardiomyopathy. It is a type of dilated cardiomyopathy.
Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is also called broken heart syndrome, apical ballooning syndrome, or stress-induced cardiomyopathy. During extreme psychological stress, there is a catecholamine surge. This causes microcirculation spasms which lead to a transient myocardial stunning. It is usually seen in middle-aged women.
It leads to left ventricular contractile dysfunction. The left ventricular apex is most often affected which leads to apical ballooning. This resembles a “takotsubo,” which is Japanese for “fishing pot for trapping octopus”.
Histologically, acute cases may show microscopic areas of necrosis characterized by myocyte hyper contraction known as contraction band necrosis. Chronic cases may exhibit microscopic foci of granulation tissue.
The first image below shows a ventriculogram showing takotsubo cardiomyopathy. The second image shows a 'takotsubo,' or octopus fishing pot.


Solution to Question 5:
Selenium deficiency (Keshan's disease) is known to produce dilated cardiomyopathy and not its toxicity.
Causes of dilated cardiomyopathy:
Acquired causes:
Infectious and non-infectious myocarditis is the most common cause globally
Alcohol is the most common cause in India
Pregnancy:
Pregnancy-associated cardiomyopathy (PACM)
Peripartum cardiomyopathy (PPCM)
Stress-induced: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy
Drug-induced:
Doxorubicin: anthracyclines
Trastuzumab
Cyclophosphamide
Nutritional deficiency:
Beriberi (thiamine),
Keshan disease (selenium)
Carnitine deficiency
Endocrine: Hypo and hyperthyroidism, acromegaly, diabetes mellitus
Others:
Cobalt toxicity
Heavy metals (lead, mercury, arsenic, lithium) Familial causes (50%):
Mutation in the cardiac myocyte titin gene
Haemochromatosis
Syndromes: Duchenne muscular dystrophy, Becker’s muscular dystrophy
Solution to Question 6:
In the given scenario, liver microscopy shows hepatocellular iron, stained blue with Perl's Prussian blue stain. The patient most likely suffers from hemochromatosis. Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) is the predominant type of cardiomyopathy seen in hemochromatosis.
Hemochromatosis can also produce restrictive cardiomyopathy, but it is less common than DCM.
The image below shows hemochromatosis. There is hepatocellular iron, stained with Perl's Prussian blue.

Solution to Question 7:
In the given scenario, the histology image shows ninja-star like nuclei in myocytes. This is suggestive of dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM).
These are non-specific findings but the presence of  5% myocytes with ninja star-like nuclei are suggestive of DCM. Here, DCM is due to titin-truncating mutations. Truncating mutations are those which shorten the coding sequence of the genes.
Histologically they appear as variable myocyte hypertrophy and interstitial fibrosis. The nuclei are enlarged, bizarre and hyperchromatic exhibiting a ninja-star like appearance.
The image given below explains the ninja star-like nuclei in the myocytes.

Solution to Question 8:
In the given scenario, the patient suffered from sustained ventricular tachycardia secondary to arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC). ARVC is associated with Naxos syndrome.
ARVC is autosomal dominant cardiomyopathy characterized by fibrofatty replacement in the myocardium of the ventricles. It most commonly affects the right ventricle. It is due to mutations in the gene encoding desmosome-associated protein plakophilin 2. This leads to defective
cell-adhesion proteins in the desmosomes that link adjacent cardiac myocytes.
As shown in the image below, Naxos syndrome is characterized by woolly hair and palmoplantar hyperkeratosis.

Morphology shows severe thinning of the right ventricular wall due to loss of myocytes, accompanied by extensive fatty infiltration and fibrosis.
The image given below is a gross photograph of the heart showing dilated right ventricle and near transmural replacement of its free wall with fat and fibrosis.

Carvajal syndrome is a variant of Naxos disease but is associated with dilated cardiomyopathy.
Solution to Question 9:
The given clinical scenario and autopsy findings are suggestive of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). The image given is a histologic section of cardiac muscle showing myocyte disarray and extreme hypertrophy as seen in HCM.
HCM is the leading cause of sudden cardiac death in young adults. It is defined as left ventricular hypertrophy of >15mm on ECHO. The left ventricular myocardium is poorly compliant. This leads to abnormal diastolic filling and intermittent ventricular outflow obstruction, i.e., primarily diastolic dysfunction.
The gross features of HCM are:
Massive myocardial hypertrophy usually without ventricular dilation
Asymmetric septal hypertrophy- disproportionate thickening of the ventricular septum relative to the left ventricle free wall
Banana-shaped left ventricle- due to bulging of the ventricular septum into the lumen
The image given below shows changes in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy compared to a normal heart. HCM shows asymmetric septal hypertrophy and thickened left ventricle wall.

Histologic features of the HCM are:
Massive myocyte hypertrophy- with transverse myocyte diameters frequently greater than 40
m, normal is approximately 15 m.
Myofiber disarray- haphazard disarray of bundles of myocytes, individual myocytes, and contractile elements in sarcomeres within cells
Interstitial fibrosis and replacement fibrosis
The image given below is a histologic section of cardiac muscle showing myocyte disarray and extreme hypertrophy seen in an abnormal HCM septum.

Solution to Question 10:
Mutations causing hypertrophic cardiomyopathy are most commonly seen in the genes encoding
 -myosin heavy chain ( -MHC).
Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is an autosomal dominant disease. In the majority of cases it is due to missense mutations in the following two sarcolemmal protein genes:
Myosin binding protein C (MYBC)
Beta myosin heavy chain (MYH7)
Solution to Question 11:
Restrictive cardiomyopathy is caused by hemochromatosis, ergotamine, amyloidosis and carcinoid syndrome. Trastuzumab causes dilated cardiomyopathy.
Restrictive cardiomyopathy (RCM) is characterized by increased ventricular stiffness causing impaired diastolic filling of the ventricles. The stiffness is secondary to an underlying disease causing accumulation of intra and intercellular substances in the myocardium.
Causes of RCM:
Infiltration disorders
Amyloidosis (most common)
Sarcoidosis
Storage disorders
Fabry’s disease
Glycogen storage disease (type II>> III)
Hemochromatosis (DCM>RCM)
Fibrotic disorders
Scleroderma
Endomyocardial fibrosis
R-Radiation
E-Ergotamine
S-Serotonin
T-Tropical Endomyocardial fibrosis
C-Carcinoid syndrome
Miscellaneous: post open heart surgery, diabetes. Morphology of RCM:
Ventricles are of almost normal size or slightly enlarged
The myocardium is non-compliant
Biatrial dilation is commonly observed
Patchy or diffuse interstitial fibrosis
Solution to Question 12:
In the given scenario, the patient has progressive dyspnoea along with hypereosinophilia. This is suggestive of Loeffler's endocarditis. It leads to restrictive cardiomyopathy.
There is peripheral eosinophilia and eosinophilic infiltrates in multiple organs, including the heart. Major basic protein (MBP) is a toxic product released from eosinophils. This initiates endomyocardial necrosis followed by scarring. It leads to endomyocardial fibrosis, typically with large mural thrombi.
Many patients with Loeffler's endocarditis have a myeloproliferative disorder. This is associated with chromosomal rearrangements involving platelet-derived growth factor receptor (PDGF)- or
- genes.
Solution to Question 13:
In this scenario, the decrease in ventricular compliance indicates restrictive cardiomyopathy. Endocardial fibroelastosis is an uncommon restrictive heart
condition characterized by fibroelastic thickening that typically involves the left ventricular endocardium.
It is most common in the first 2 years of life. It results from several different insults including viral infections (e.g., intrauterine exposure to mumps) or mutations in the gene for tafazzin. These mutations affect mitochondrial inner membrane integrity.
Endomyocardial fibrosis is a disease of children and young adults in Africa and other tropical areas. It is characterized by fibrosis of the ventricular endocardium and subendocardium that extends from the apex upward. The aetiology is unknown.
Loeffler endomyocarditis results in endomyocardial fibrosis, typically with large mural thrombi. The overall morphology is similar to the tropical disease. In addition to the cardiac changes, there is often peripheral eosinophilia and eosinophilic infiltrates in multiple organs, including the heart.
Solution to Question 14:
Viral infections are the most common cause of myocarditis. Coxsackie viruses A and B and other enteroviruses account for most of the cases.
Myocarditis is a diverse group of pathologic entities in which infectious microorganisms and/or a primary inflammatory process cause myocardial injury.
Solution to Question 15:
Transthyretin is the major component of senile cardiac amyloid deposits. It is a normal serum protein synthesized in the liver that transports thyroxine and retinol-binding protein.
Amyloidosis of the heart can develop as a consequence of systemic amyloidosis or it may be localized. This is particularly seen in the elderly (senile cardiac amyloidosis). It has a far better prognosis than systemic amyloidosis.
Presentation of cardiac amyloidosis:
Restrictive cardiomyopathy- most common
Asymptomatic
Dilation
Arrhythmias
Ischemic disease
Valvular disease.
The chambers are usually of normal size, but can be dilated and have thickened walls. Small, semitranslucent nodules resembling drips of wax may be seen on the atrial endocardial surface, particularly on the left.
Histologically, hyaline eosinophilic deposits of amyloid are found in:
Interstitium
Conduction tissue
Valves, endocardium
Pericardium
Small intramural coronary arteries.
The image given shows an endomyocardial biopsy of a patient with cardiac amyloidosis stained as follows: A) Congo red only, B) Apple-green birefringence under polarized light

Solution to Question 16:
The given clinical scenario suggests post-myocardial infarction fibrinous pericarditis. It is the most common type of pericarditis.
Clinically, there is a loud pericardial friction rub. There is a rubbery fibrin mass loosely glueing the parietal and visceral pericardium together (bread and butter). It may resolve or become organized to produce adhesive pericarditis.
It is usually seen following:
Myocardial infarction
Rheumatic fever
Trauma
Uremia
Radiation
Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
Severe pneumonia
Types of acute pericarditis:
Serous pericarditis: There is a mild inflammation of epicardial and pericardial surfaces. Both acute and chronic inflammatory cells are present. There is exudative serous fluid, usually 50–200 mL. Thus, it develops slowly and rarely alters cardiac function.
It is caused by:
Rheumatic fever
SLE
Systemic scleroderma
Tumours
Uremia
Viral infection
Tuberculosis
Suppurative /purulent pericarditis: It may be due to bacterial, mycotic, or parasitic invasion. The inflammation may extend into the surrounding mediastinum. It usually, results in organization and, therefore, constrictive pericarditis with clinical sequelae. The entry of the pathogen into the pericardium may be by:
direct extension
seeding from blood
lymphatic spread
seeding by instrumentation
Hemorrhagic pericarditis: It can be due to tuberculosis or a malignant neoplasm (from lung or breast). It can also be seen following cardiac surgery. Caseous pericarditis is almost always tubercular in origin.
Solution to Question 17:
In the given scenario, fever, pericardial pain and effusion 4 weeks after MI, is suggestive of Dressler's syndrome. The aetiology of Dressler's syndrome is autoimmune.
It is also known as post-myocardial infarction (post-MI) cardiac injury syndrome. It occurs one week to as long as two to three months after MI.
A fibrinous or fibrinohemorrhagic pericarditis usually develops around the second or third day following a transmural infarct. It is a result of the underlying myocardial inflammation.
Dressler's syndrome is believed to have an autoimmune aetiology. There is an inflammatory reaction to myocardial neo-antigens formed as a result of MI.
Solution to Question 18:
Concretio cordis occurs in advanced cases of constrictive pericarditis.
In constrictive pericarditis, a thick,0.5 - 1cm, fibrous scar tissue is formed. This can obliterate the pericardial space and sometimes calcify. In extreme cases, it can resemble a plaster mold and is known as concretio cordis.
Constrictive pericarditis may be idiopathic or can occur following:
Pericarditis- serous or caseous
Cardiac surgery
Heavy irradiation
Adhesive mediastinopericarditis occurs when adhesion and fibrosis extends from the parietal pericardium into the mediastinum
Soldier’s plaque is a focal pearly thickened epicardial plaque. It indicative of healed pericarditis
Solution to Question 19:
Myxomas are the most common primary tumours of the heart in adults.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
% of myxomas are located in the atria. The left-to-right ratio of the myxoma is approximately 4:1. The region of the fossa ovalis in the atrial septum is the favoured site of origin.
Histopathological examination shows stellate or globular myxoma, “lepidic," cells. Peculiar vessel-like or gland-like structures are characteristic. Major clinical manifestations are fever and malaise (due to IL-6). Valvular “ball-valve” obstruction or embolization can occur.
Important points on cardiac tumors:
Most common cardiac tumour: metastasis
Most common benign cardiac tumour: atrial myxoma
Most common primary cardiac tumour in adults: atrial myxoma
Most common primary cardiac tumour in children: rhabdomyoma
The image given below shows an abundant amorphous extracellular matrix. It contains scattered multinucleate myxoma cells in various groupings, including abnormal vessel-like formations.

Solution to Question 20:
Null mutations in the PRKAR1A gene is seen in Carney's complex. Cardiac myxomas are present in 30–40% of Carney complex patients.
Familial syndromes associated with myxomas have activating mutations in the GNAS1 gene or null mutations in PRKAR1A. Mutations in GNAS1 is associated with McCune-Albright syndrome. PRKAR1A gene encodes a regulatory subunit of a cyclic-AMP-dependent protein kinase (Carney complex).
Skin lesions are the most common manifestation of the Carney complex. The most common type of endocrine tumour in the Carney complex is the primary pigmented nodular adrenocortical disease (PPNAD). It is a form of bilateral adrenal hyperplasia that leads to adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)-independent Cushing syndrome.
NAME syndrome and LAMB syndrome are subsets of the Carney complex. The LAMB
acronym refers to lentigines, atrial myxoma, and blue nevi. NAME refers to nevi, atrial myxoma, myxoid neurofibromas, and ephelids.
Components of Carney Complex:
Skin pigmented lesions (lentigines, blue nevi, other)
Myxomas (cutaneous, mucosal, cardiac, other)
PPNAD (Cushing Syndrome)
GH-PRL-producing adenomas (acromegaly)
Leydig or Sertoli cell tumors
Ovarian cystadenoma or carcinoma
Thyroid adenoma or cancer
Psammomatous melanotic schwannoma
Breast ductal adenoma
Osteochondromyxoma
Cancers (liver, pancreas, adrenal) Carney triad:
Extra-adrenal paraganglioma
Gastrointestinal stromal tumor
Pulmonary chondroma
Carney–Stratakis Syndrome: Familial paraganglioma and gastrointestinal stromal tumour (GIST)
Solution to Question 21:
Atrial myxomas most commonly occur in the left atrium.
Myxoma is usually single, but can rarely be multiple. The region of the fossa ovalis in the atrial septum is the favoured site of origin. Mobile tumours exert a “wrecking-ball” effect, causing damage to the valve leaflets.
They can be sporadic or familial.
The image given below shows a gross picture of an atrial cardiac myxoma arising from the region of the fossa ovalis and extending to mitral valve orifice:
Sporadic Type Myxoma
Familial Type Myx oma
Single
Multiple
Postoperative recurrance NIL
Present
Younger age
Left atria - Most common sit e

Solution to Question 22:
The given histological slide shows abundant spider cells. They are seen in rhabdomyoma.
Microscopically, they are composed of bizarre, markedly enlarged myocytes. Routine histologic processing often artifactually reduces the abundant cytoplasm to thin strands that stretch from the nucleus to the surface membrane. This appearance is referred to as “spider” cells.
Rhabdomyoma is the most frequent primary tumour of the pediatric heart. 50% of cases are associated with tuberous sclerosis, with mutations in the tumour-suppressor genes TSC1 and TSC2. They are usually multiple and occur in ventricles preferentially. They often regress spontaneously and may, therefore, be considered as hamartomas.
Image given shows spider cell in rhabdomyoma:

Solution to Question 23:
The single most important long-term limitation of cardiac transplantation is allograft arteriopathy.
Complications following cardiac transplantation:
Allograft rejection: It is the primary concern that requires close surveillance. Both classic cellular rejection and antibody-mediated rejection is recognized. Cellular rejection is characterized by interstitial lymphocytic inflammation, with associated myocyte damage.
Allograft arteriopathy: It is the single most important long-term limitation for cardiac transplantation. It is a late, progressive, diffusely stenosing intimal proliferation in the coronary arteries, leading to ischemic injury. It can lead to silent myocardial infarction since transplant patients have denervated hearts and do not experience angina. Progressive congestive heart failure and sudden cardiac death can also occur.
Other postoperative problems include infection and malignancies, especially Epstein–Barr virus-associated B-cell lymphomas.
The image given below shows allograft arteriopathy. There is severe diffuse concentric intimal thickening producing critical stenosis. The internal elastic lamina and media are intact (Movat pentachrome stain, elastin black)

Solution to Question 24:
The image shows a heart with left ventricular hypertrophy. The most common cause of left ventricular hypertrophy is chronic hypertension.
Solution to Question 25:
In the given scenario, a marathon runner will have cardiac hypertrophy with increased capillary density. Aerobic exercise, e.g., long-distance running, is associated with volume-load hypertrophy accompanied by an increase in capillary density. This is not seen in other forms of hypertrophy. This decreases resting heart rate and blood pressure.
In hypertrophy due to pressure or volume overload, there is a sustained increase in mechanical work. This cause myocytes to increase in size thus increasing the size and weight of the heart. The hypertrophied heart has an increased oxygen consumption but decreased supply. This is because hypertrophy is not accompanied by a proportional increase in capillary numbers. This leads to ischemia-related decompensation, which can evolve to cardiac failure and eventually lead to death.
The causes and consequences of hypertrophy are summarized in the below image.

Heart weight, rather than wall thickness, is the best measure of hypertrophy in dilated hearts. A patient with systemic hypertension has pressure-overload hypertrophy.
A patient with an echo finding of an aortic valvular area of 0.6cm² is suggestive of aortic stenosis. There is pressure-overload hypertrophy.
A patient with a high pitched holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex is suggestive of mitral regurgitation. There is volume-overload hypertrophy.

Solution to Question 1:
Most congenital heart diseases arise from faulty embryogenesis during gestational weeks 3 to 8 when major cardiovascular structures form and begin to function.
The most common congenital heart disease is ventricular septal defect (VSD), whereas the 2nd most common is atrial septal defect (ASD).
Solution to Question 2:
Char syndrome is associated with patent ductus arteriosus (PDA).
The clinical presentation of this syndrome includes PDA with facial dysmorphism and abnormal fifth digits.
The following images show the facial dysmorphism associated with Char syndrome.

Solution to Question 3:
Coarctation of the aorta is a feature of Turner's syndrome, not Down's syndrome.
Down's syndrome (trisomy 21) is the most common cause of congenital heart disease (CHD).
Cardiac defects in Down's syndrome are due to endocardial cushion defects. Cardiac defects in various chromosomal anomalies are as follows:
Syndrome
Cardiac defects
Down's syndrome (Trisomy 2 1)
Ventricular septal defectPate nt ductus arteriosusAtrial sep tal defect
Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13)
Ventricular septal defectPate nt ductus arteriosusAtrial sep tal defect
Edward's syndrome (Trisomy 18)
Ventricular septal defectPate nt ductus arteriosusAtrial sep tal defectDextroposition
Turner syndrome (Monosom y X)
Bicuspid aortic valveCoarctat ion of the aortaDilated ascen ding aorta
Solution to Question 4:
Secundum atrial septal defect (ASD) is the most common type of ASD.
ASDs are abnormal, fixed openings in the atrial septum caused by incomplete tissue formation that allows communication of blood between the left and right atria.
It results in a left-to-right shunt. Excess blood flow through the ASD and/or the pulmonary valve results in a murmur. They are generally well-tolerated and usually do not become symptomatic before the age of 30 years.
ASDs are classified according to their location:
Secundum ASD (90%) - usually isolated defects, can be of any size, multiple or fenestrated
Primum anomalies (5%) - occur adjacent to the AV valves, often associated with AV valve defects and/or VSD
Sinus venosus defects (5%) - located near SVC entrance and can be associated with anomalous pulmonary venous return to the right atrium

Solution to Question 5:
Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH) is a feature of the tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), not left ventricular hypertrophy.
The four cardinal features of tetralogy of Fallot are as follows:
Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
Obstruction of the right ventricular outflow tract (subpulmonary stenosis)
An aorta that overrides the VSD
Right ventricular hypertrophy
It is the most common type of cyanotic congenital heart disease (CHD). The heart is typically enlarged and is classically boot-shaped due to marked right ventricular hypertrophy.


Solution to Question 6:
The given features are suggestive of Williams (Williams–Beuren) syndrome. It is associated with supravalvular aortic stenosis.
This condition is due to deletions on chromosome 7 which includes the gene for elastin. These mutations may cause supravalvular stenosis by disrupting elastin–smooth muscle cell interactions during aortic morphogenesis. There is thickening of ascending aortic wall and consequent luminal constriction.
Other features of the syndrome include:
Elfin facies - wide mouth, chubby cheeks, long philtrum, small nose, and delicate chin (as shown n the image)
Cognitive abnormalities
Intellectual disability (usually mild)
Personality changes - over-friendliness to strangers
Hypotonia
Connective tissue abnormalities
Endocrine abnormalities (hypercalcemia, hypercalciuria, hypothyroidism, early puberty)

Solution to Question 7:
The most common cause of mitral stenosis is rheumatic heart disease. Mitral stenosis is the most common lesion in rheumatic heart disease.
In rheumatic mitral stenosis, calcification and fibrous bridging across the valvular commissures create fish mouth or buttonhole stenosis. Rheumatic mitral stenosis is associated with loud S1.
The most common causes of various valvular diseases are:
Aortic stenosis (AS) - calcification due to normal aging or congenitally bicuspid aortic valves
Aortic regurgitation (AR) - dilatation of the ascending aorta, often secondary to hypertension and/or aging
Mitral regurgitation (MR) - myxomatous degeneration (mitral valve prolapse)
Solution to Question 8:
The clinical scenario and echo findings are suggestive of calcific aortic stenosis secondary to bicuspid aortic valve (2 functional cusps). It is due to incomplete separation of valve commissures during development, not abnormal fusion.
In a congenitally bicuspid aortic valve, the 2 functional cusps are usually of unequal size. The larger cusp has a midline raphe that results from incomplete commissural separation during development. The raphe is frequently a major site of calcific deposits.
This condition is associated with mutations in the following areas:
Chromosomes 18q, 5q, and 13q
Chromosome 9q - loss-of-function mutations in NOTCH1 gene Late complications include:
Aortic stenosis or regurgitation
Infective endocarditis
Aortic dilation and/or dissection.
Predisposed to progressive calcification - Approximately 50% of cases of aortic stenosis in adults.
Note: Acquired bicuspid valves result from abnormal fusion of valve commissures because of an acquired deformity (rheumatic valve disease). It produces a conjoined cusp that is generally twice the size of the nonconjoined cusp.
Solution to Question 9:
The clinical features and echocardiography findings are suggestive of mitral valve prolapse (MVP) or Barlow syndrome. It is not associated with degenerative calcified deposits (seen in calcific valvular degeneration, not MVP).
Barlow syndrome is more common in females. It may be an isolated condition or less commonly can be associated with connective tissue disorders like Marfan's syndrome.
In this condition, there is mitral annular dilatation with floppy mitral valve leaflets. They prolapse or balloon back into the left atrium during systole. The following pathological changes are seen:
Interchordal ballooning (hooding) of the mitral leaflets
Thick, rubbery, redundant leaflets
Thickened mural endocardium
The main histologic change is marked thickening of the spongiosa layer with deposition of mucoid called myxomatous degeneration.
Most individuals diagnosed with MVP are asymptomatic. On auscultation, a mid-systolic click, sometimes followed by a mid to late systolic murmur is heard. Chest pain mimicking angina and dyspnea occur rarely.
The complications include:
Infective endocarditis
Mitral insufficiency
Stroke or other systemic infarcts
Arrhythmias
Sudden cardiac death (rarely)
Solution to Question 10:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of carcinoid syndrome. Mitral stenosis is not a feature of cardiac involvement in this condition.
Carcinoid heart disease refers to the cardiac manifestations caused by the bioactive compounds released by carcinoid tumors. Classically, the endocardium and valves of the right heart are primarily affected.
Findings in carcinoid heart syndrome:
Endocardial plaque-like thickening and fibrosis
Tricuspid insufficiency
Pulmonary stenosis
No valve destruction
Myocardium not involved
The left side of the heart is less commonly affected because the pulmonary vascular bed degrades the mediators. However, left heart carcinoid lesions can occur in the setting of ASD or VSD, or in the case of primary pulmonary carcinoid tumors.
Solution to Question 11:
Carcinoid heart disease most commonly affects the tricuspid valve.
It usually affects right heart structures. The most common features are tricuspid regurgitation and pulmonary stenosis.

Solution to Question 1:
The given clinical scenario with polyarthritis (1 major) along with fever and ESR elevated (2 minor) is suggestive of acute rheumatic fever. It is an example of type II hypersensitivity.
This condition classically occurs a few weeks after an episode of group A streptococcal pharyngitis or, less commonly, skin infections. The antibodies to streptococcal cell-wall antigen cross-react with myocardial antigen resulting in macrophage activation and inflammation.
Acute rheumatic carditis is a common manifestation of active RF and may progress over time to chronic rheumatic heart disease (RHD), mainly manifesting as valvular abnormalities. Damage to heart tissue may be caused by a combination of antibody and T-cell-mediated reactions.
Solution to Question 2:
The least commonly affected valve in acute rheumatic fever is the pulmonary valve. The most commonly affected valve is the mitral valve.
Solution to Question 3:
The clinical scenario and the gross findings seen are diagnostic of rheumatic heart disease.
Inflammation of the endocardium and the left-sided valves results in fibrinoid necrosis within the cusps or tendinous cords. Overlying these necrotic foci and along the lines of closure are small (1 to 2 mm) warty vegetations.
Subendocardial lesions, exacerbated by regurgitant jets, can induce irregular thickenings called MacCallum plaques, usually in the left atrium.


Solution to Question 4:
Monoarthralgia is a minor Jones criterion in moderate-high risk population (all-age rheumatic heart disease prevalence of >1 per 1000 population per year).

Solution to Question 8:
Acute infective endocarditis is due to infection by highly virulent organisms like Staphylococcus aureus. It results in rapidly necrotizing and destructive lesions.
Infective endocarditis is classified into acute and subacute forms.
Acute - infection of a previously normal heart valve by a highly virulent organism
Subacute - infection in previously deformed valves by organisms of lower virulence (S.viridans,
S. epidermidis, HACEK)
Solution to Question 9:
Staphylococcus aureus and coagulase-negative Staphylococci (like S. epidermidis).
The following organisms are implicated in infective endocarditis following prosthetic valve surgery:
Early (< 2 months) - Staphylococcus aureus, Staphylococcus epidermidis
Intermediate (2-12 months) and late (> 12 months):
Streptococci and Staphylococcus aureus - more common
Enterococci and Staphylococcus epidermidis
Solution to Question 10:
The given features and the image showing painful Osler nodes are suggestive of infective endocarditis. Echo showing a valve-related mass is a major criterion according to Duke’s criteria.
Infective endocarditis (IE) is a microbial infection of the heart valves or the mural endocardium. The aorta, aneurysms, other blood vessels, and prosthetic devices can also become infected. Most infections are bacterial.
Vegetations on heart valves are the classic hallmark of IE. They are friable, bulky, potentially destructive lesions. They contain fibrin, inflammatory cells, bacteria, or other organisms. The mitral valve is most commonly involved.
Complications of infective endocarditis:
Cardiac complications - valvular insufficiency or stenosis, myocardial ring abscess, suppurative pericarditis
Embolic complications - left-sided (brain, spleen, kidney) or right-sided lesion (lung infarct and abscess)
Renal complications - embolic infarcts, focal (more common) or diffuse glomerulonephritis (less common)
Solution to Question 11:
Single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetti is considered as one of the major criteria to establish the diagnosis of infective endocarditis.
Solution to Question 12:
The given clinical scenario with vegetations on both sides of valve leaflets is suggestive of Libman–Sacks endocarditis. It is a feature of systemic lupus erythematosus.
The vegetations in this condition have the following features:
Small - 1 to 4 mm in diameter
Single or multiple
Sterile, pinkish vegetations
May be located on both sides valve leaflets
Associated with intense valvulitis - characterized by fibrinoid necrosis
Mitral valve is more frequently involved and regurgitation is the usual functional abnormality.
Solution to Question 13:
Large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves are seen in infective endocarditis.
Infective endocarditis is characterized by the presence of large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves. Aortic and mitral valves are the most commonly affected, however, in some cases, the right heart valves may be involved.
Vegetations may be single or multiple and may involve one or more valves. Embolization often occurs and may lead to septic infarcts or mycotic aneurysms at the site of lodgement due to the presence of virulent organisms in the emboli.
Solution to Question 14:
The rightly matched vegetations with the conditions that they are seen are as follows: 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B
Rheumatic heart disease often presents with rheumatic fever phase where small, warty 1- 2 mm vegetations, also called veruccae, extend along the lines of closure of the valve leaflets. The cardinal anatomical changes of the mitral valve in chronic RHD are:
Leaflet thickening
Commissural fusion and shortening
Thickening and fusion of the tendinous chords
Infective endocarditis has large, irregular, friable masses on the valve cusps that can extend onto the chordae. These vegetations can be single or multiple and may involve one or more
valves. They are potentially destructive lesions and contain fibrin, inflammatory cells, bacteria or other organisms. They can erode into the underlying myocardium and produce a ring abscess.
They are prone to embolisations, resulting in abscess formation wherever they lodge due to the presence of virulent organisms. Thus, it may lead to sequelae like septic infarcts or mycotic aneurysms.
Subacute infective endocarditis contains less destructive vegetations. They contain granulation tissue at their bases indicative of healing. Fibrosis, calcification and a chronic inflammatory infiltrate can develop over the time.
Nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis is characterised by one or more small, 1-5 mm, sterile vegetations which are usually attached at the line of closure. They are seen associated with hypercoagulable states like chronic DIC or malignancy. They are loosely attached to the underlying valve and are non-destructive in nature. They do not cause any inflammatory reaction but they can be a source of systemic embolisation.
Libman-Sack's endocarditis has small- or medium-sized, 1- 4 mm, sterile vegetations associated with systemic lupus erythematosus. They may be present on one or both the sides of the leaflets, on the valve surface, chordae or anywhere on the endocardium. These vegetations develop due to immune complex deposition and complement activation. They cause intense valvulitis resulting in fibrinoid necrosis of the valve substance. Persistent injury to the valves can result in scarring and leaflet fusion.
Solution to Question 15:
Vegetations in non-bacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE) are of 1 to 5 mm size.
NBTE is seen in patients with debilitating conditions such as cancer and sepsis or systemic hypercoagulable states. Hence it is also called marantic endocarditis.
There is the deposition of small sterile thrombi loosely attached to the leaflets of cardiac valves. They form single or multiple vegetations along the lines of closure of the leaflets or cusps. They are non-invasive and do not elicit an inflammatory reaction. It can be a source of systemic emboli.

Solution to Question 1:
The minimum amount of proteinuria required to diagnose a patient with nephrotic syndrome is
subject: Pathology

question_text:
5 g/day.

Solution to Question 2:
The given clinical scenario in this child is strongly suggestive of nephrotic syndrome due to minimal change disease (MCD). It is characterized by the absence of immune deposits on biopsy and histopathological examination.
It is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children (peaks between 2–6 years). Biopsy findings of MCD are as follows:
Light microscopy - glomeruli appear normal (hence called 'minimal change')
Immunofluorescence studies - no Ig or complement deposits
Electron microscopy - diffuse effacement of foot processes of visceral epithelial cells
(podocytopathy)
Solution to Question 3:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome. It can be caused due to mutations in the following components of the glomerular filtration barrier:
Nephrin, podocin - are molecular components of the slit diaphragm complex
Alpha-actinin 4 - is a component of the foot process cytoskeleto
Megalin is not a component of the glomerular filtration barrier. It is present in proximal convoluted tubular cells. Mutations in megalin may lead to some proteinuria but not nephrotic syndrome because glomerular filtration of proteins is not affected.
Solution to Question 4:
The given clinical scenario in a patient suffering from membranous nephropathy, which is a type of nephrotic syndrome, is suggestive of renal vein thrombosis. It is due to the loss of antithrombin III (an endogenous anticoagulant) in urine.
Renal vein thrombosis is most often a consequence of a hypercoagulable state. In adults, it is most commonly seen in patients with membranous nephropathy.

Solution to Question 5:
In nephrotic syndrome, there is an increase in fibrinogen levels.
The following proteins are increased in nephrotic syndrome:
Fibrinoge
Lipoproteins - due to increased synthesis
The following proteins are decreased in nephrotic syndrome as a consequence of selective proteinuria:
Albumin - the largest proportion of protein lost in nephrotic syndrome.
Transferri
Cholecalciferol-binding protei
Thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG)
Ferriti
Coagulation factors
Antithrombin III
Solution to Question 6:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nephrotic syndrome due to a secondary cause (reflux nephropathy). Secondary nephrotic syndrome in adults is most likely due to focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS).
FSGS is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. It is a podocytopathy, with degeneration and focal disruption of visceral epithelial cells and effacement of foot processes. Glomerular hyalinosis and sclerosis are seen due to the entrapment of plasma proteins and increased extracellular matrix deposition.
FSGS is classified as follows:
Primary
Idiopathic FSGS
Secondary
HIV associated
Heroin addictio
Sickle cell disease
Obesity
Hypertensive nephropathy
Renal conditions
Focal glomerulonephritis (e.g. IgA nephropathy)
Renal ablatio
Unilateral renal agenesis or renal dysplasia
Reflux nephropathy
Inherited
Mutated proteins of the slit diaphragm - podocin, alpha-actinin 4, TRPC6


Electron microscopy of FSGS shows:
Diffuse effacement of the podocyte foot processes
Focal detachment and degeneration of the epithelial cells
Absence of electron-dense deposits
Solution to Question 7:
The collapsing variant of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is associated with the worst prognosis.
There are 5 variants of FSGS:
Collapsing variant - poor prognosis
Glomerular tip variant - good prognosis
Cellular variant
Perihilar variant
Not otherwise specified - most commo
Given below is a histological image of collapsing glomerulopathy showing the involvement of the entire glomerular tuft and proliferation of visceral epithelial cells.


Solution to Question 8:
The given electron microscopy image shows subepithelial deposits in the kidney which is suggestive of membranous nephropathy.
The following electron microscopy image shows subepithelial deposits in the kidney.

Membranous nephropathy is characterized by the diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall. It is due to the accumulation of deposits containing Ig along the subepithelial side of the basement membrane.
Solution to Question 9:
This clinical scenario and the histopathological image showing uniform, diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall are suggestive of membranous nephropathy.


Membranous nephropathy is one of the most common causes of nephrotic syndrome in the adults/elderly. It is a chronic immune-complex-mediated disease.
The following image of the glomerulus shows the characteristic spikes. The spikes are formed due to the presence of basement membrane material (have affinity to silver stain) in between the immune complex deposits (lack affinity to silver stain).


Solution to Question 10:
Mesangial deposits are seen in the following conditions:
IgA nephropathy (Berger disease)
Henoch–Schonlein purpura
Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis
Lupus nephritis classes I and II
Resolving postinfectious glomerulonephritis
Solution to Question 11:
The given clinical scenario, immunofluorescence findings, and the image showing proliferating mesangial cells and capillary endothelial cells are suggestive of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis type 2 (MPGN type 2) or dense-deposit disease.


The following image shows bright deposits scattered along capillary walls and in the mesangium by immunofluorescence microscopy with antibodies to C3.


This condition belongs to a group of disorders called C3 glomerulopathies and primarily affects children and young adults. It is associated with a dysregulation in the alternative complement pathway. It is clinically and morphologically similar to MPGN type 1 but pathogenetically distinct from it.
In this condition, a circulating autoantibody called C3 nephritic factor is present,
which stabilizes the C3 convertase enzyme. The stabilized C3 convertase enhances C3 activation and consumption causing hypocomplementemia. Patients will have consistently decreased serum C3 levels, but normal C1 and C4 levels.
The prognosis is poor, with about half of these patients progressing to end-stage renal disease
(ESRD).
Solution to Question 12:
The given electrophoresis shows hypoalbuminemia and increased alpha-2 globulin, which is classically seen in nephrotic syndrome.
Solution to Question 13:
IgA nephropathy (Berger disease) is the most common cause of primary nephritic syndrome in the world.
Nephritic syndrome is characterized by:
Acute onset of hematuria
Urinalysis - red cell casts
Diminished glomerular filtration rate (GFR) (oliguria)
Mild to moderate proteinuria
Hypertensio
Azotemia
Solution to Question 14:
The given clinical scenario, histopathology findings of mesangial widening and endocapillary proliferation, as well as immunofluorescence showing mesangial deposits are suggestive of IgA nephropathy (Berger's disease).
It is the most common type of glomerulonephritis worldwide. It is characterized by recurrent hematuria/ nephritic syndrome and the presence of prominent IgA deposits in the mesangium. Patients generally present with gross hematuria after respiratory, gastrointestinal or urinary tract infection.

The systemic variant of IgA nephropathy is called Henoch–Schönlein purpura. It is a disorder of children which presents with similar renal manifestations with characteristic IgA deposits in the mesangium in about one-third of the patients.
Solution to Question 15:
The given clinical scenario and histopathology image showing hypercellular glomeruli are suggestive of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). Rapidly progressive disease with oliguria is very rare (< 1% of patients).


Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is a type of diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis. It is usually preceded by an acute streptococcal sore throat or impetigo around 1-4 weeks prior.
It usually presents with features of nephritic syndrome including:
Hematuria
Red cell casts in the urine
Azotemia, oliguria
Hypertensio
Mild to moderate proteinuria
Edema
On microscopy, the following findings are seen:
Light microscopy - enlarged, hypercellular glomeruli with influx of leucocytes (endocapillary proliferation)
Electron microscopy - subepithelial humps
Immunofluorescence - granular IgG and C3 deposits on glomerular basement membrane and mesangium
Majority (> 95%) of affected children eventually recover renal function with conservative therapy.
Solution to Question 16:
The given image shows a crescent-shaped mass of proliferating parietal and visceral epithelial cells and leukocytes within the Bowman capsule. It is a characteristic feature of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) or crescentic glomerulonephritis.

RPGN is a type of nephritic syndrome associated with severe glomerular injury with necrosis and formation of crescents. It is usually immune-mediated and may be associated with
circulating anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCAs), anti-GBM antibodies, and antinuclear antibodies (ANA).
Injury to the glomerular capillary wall leads to the escape of procoagulant factors and cytokines in the Bowman space. This triggers:
Proliferation of glomerular epithelial cells - mostly parietal, but also some visceral cells
Recruitment of leukocytes and fibroblasts
Pathognomonic crescents - due to the circumferential accumulation of these cells and fibri The crescents progressively compress the capillary tuft. This results in a rapid decline of
glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and, consequently, acute kidney injury (AKI). Thus, the degree of crescent formation correlates with the severity and the prognosis of the disease.
Solution to Question 17:
The given clinical scenario, histopathology findings, and immunofluorescence showing linear, dense, and smooth deposits are suggestive of Goodpasture's syndrome.


Goodpasture's syndrome is an anti-GBM (glomerular basement membrane) antibody-mediated disease. The antibodies are directed against the non-collagenous portion of the 3 chain of collagen type IV. As it is present in both the alveoli and GBM, it usually presents with pulmonary hemorrhage and renal failure. It makes up about 1/5 of cases of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis.
Crescents with linear deposits of IgG and C3 in the glomerular basement membrane are seen on histopathology.
Note: Wegener's granulomatosis (granulomatosis with polyangiitis) causes the pauci-immune type of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. There is an absence of immune complex deposition on immunofluorescence.
Solution to Question 18:
The given clinical scenario with normal findings on light microscopy and diffuse thinning of the glomerular basement membrane on electron microscopy are highly suggestive of benign familial hematuria (thin basement membrane disease).
It is a type of hereditary nephritis manifested clinically by familial asymptomatic hematuria. The following are the differences between Alport's syndrome and benign familial hematuria.

Solution to Question 19:
The most common manifestation of Alport syndrome is gross or microscopic hematuria, frequently accompanied by red cell casts.
Proteinuria and oliguria may develop later in the disease, and rarely, nephrotic syndrome develops. The deafness may be subtle requiring sensitive testing.
There are no significant light microscopy changes in Alport syndrome. On electron microscopy, the glomerular basement membrane shows:
Irregular foci of thickening, alternating with attenuation (thinning)
Pronounced splitting and lamination of the lamina densa - basket-weave appearance


Solution to Question 20:
The given immunofluorescence staining of the kidney biopsy specimen shows positive staining for fibrinogen, IgG, IgA, IgM, C1q, C3,  chain, and k light chain. This is known as full-house effect. It is seen in lupus nephritis.

Solution to Question 21:
Urinary albumin excretion in the range of 30–300 mg/24 hours is called microalbuminuria. It is the hallmark of early diabetic nephropathy.
The terms microalbuminuria and macroalbuminuria are no longer used now. Proteinuria is currently classified as:

Solution to Question 22:
The given clinical scenario and histopathology image showing acellular periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive nodules are suggestive of Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease. It occurs in patients with diabetic nephropathy.


The following renal lesions are encountered in diabetic nephropathy:
Glomerular lesions -
Capillary basement membrane thickening
Diffuse mesangial sclerosis
Nodular glomerulosclerosis/ Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease
Intercapillary glomerulosclerosis
Renal vascular lesions - hyaline arteriolosclerosis
Pyelonephritis - necrotizing papillitis
Option A: In amyloidosis, glomerular deposits appear as thickenings of the mesangial matrix, forming interlacing broad ribbons of amyloid.
Option B: In focal segmental glomerulosclerosis, there is focal and segmental hyalinosis and sclerosis of the capillary wall with lipid droplets in the sclerosed area.
Option D: In lupus nephritis, immune complex deposits are seen in the mesangium or along the entire basement membrane (wire loop lesions), with mesangial cell proliferation.
Solution to Question 23:
Based on the given clinical history and microscopy showing crescents, rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) is suspected. Among the given options, anti- GBM antibody testing should be done, since it is a part of the work-up of RPGN.


Type 1 RPGN includes renal limited disease and Goodpasture's disease. In this condition, antibodies are produced against the non-collagenous domain of the 3 chain of collagen IV of the GBM.
Microscopy findings of Goodpasture's disease are:
Immunofluorescence - linear deposits of Ig and complement along the glomerular basement membrane
Electron microscopy - wrinkling of the glomerular basement membrane with focal disruptions without any immune complex deposition.
A variant of Goodpasture's disease with pulmonary involvement is known as Goodpasture's syndrome.
Option A: ANA testing is done if SLE is suspected. Electron microscopy will show immune complex deposits.
Option C: HIV RNA testing is done in immunodeficiency syndrome associated with weight loss. Electron microscopy will show diffuse podocyte injury with complete foot process effacement. Tubuloreticular inclusions will be seen in endothelial cells.
Option D: Urine electrophoresis is done if nephrotic syndrome is suspected.
Solution to Question 24:
Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) is seen in HIV, SLE, CLL, and Hepatitis B.
MPGN is caused due to immune-mediated injury. It often presents with a nephritic-nephrotic picture.
The causes of MPGN are as follows:
Primary MPGN (Idiopathic)
Secondary MPGN
System lupus erythematosus (SLE)
1-antitrypsin deficiency
Infections - hepatitis B, hepatitis C, HIV, schistosomiasis, endocarditis, infected ventriculoatrial shunts, chronic visceral abscesses
Malignancies - chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)
MPGN is characterized by the proliferation of cells predominantly in the mesangium and the capillary loops. Hence it is also called mesangiocapillary glomerulonephritis. There are 2 types of MPGN:
Type I - It is characterized by the deposition of immune complexes and mesangiocapillary proliferation.
Type II - It is now known as dense-deposit disease. It belongs to a group of disorders called C3 glomerulopathies.
Light microscopy findings of MPGN are as follows:
Lobular glomeruli with proliferating mesangial cells, capillary endothelium, and infiltrating leukocytes (endocapillary proliferation)
Duplication of the basement membrane gives a double contour or tram-track appearance. It is especially evident in silver or PAS stains.

Solution to Question 1:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of acute tubular necrosis (ATN) due to ingestion of ethylene glycol. Toxins usually result in ATN by causing damage to the proximal convoluted tubules (PCTs).
Ethylene glycol poisoning produces marked ballooning and hydropic or vacuolar degeneration of PCT. Calcium oxalate crystals are often also found in tubular lumens.
Direct toxic injury to the tubules in ATI can be caused by:
Endogenous agents: Myoglobin, hemoglobin, monoclonal light chains, bile/bilirubin
Exogenous agents: Drugs, radiocontrast dyes, heavy metals, and organic solvents
Solution to Question 2:
White blood cell casts are specific features of pyelonephritis. Neutrophil-rich casts (pus casts) indicate renal involvement because casts are formed only in tubules.
The urine contains many leukocytes (pyuria) derived from the inflammatory infiltrate. It is found in both upper and lower UTIs and cannot differentiate between them. Fever is also a non-specific finding.
Ascending infection is the most common cause of clinical pyelonephritis.
Note: Sterile pyuria is defined as white cells in the urine in the absence of significant bacterial growth. It is seen in renal TB.
Solution to Question 3:
The most common organism causing acute pyelonephritis is Escherichia coli. The organisms that cause acute pyelonephritis include:
E. coli
Proteus
Klebsiella
Enterobacter species
Mycobacteria - caseating granulomatous inflammation
Fungi - non-caseating granulomatous inflammation
Viruses (CMV and adenovirus) - immunocompromised people
Solution to Question 4:
Periglomerular fibrosis is considered typical of chronic pyelonephritis. Histopathological features of chronic pyelonephritis are:
Dilated tubules with flattened epithelium may be filled with casts resembling thyroid colloid (thyroidization)
Chronic interstitial inflammation and fibrosis in the cortex and medulla
Periglomerular fibrosis
Secondary focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), usually several years after the scarring has occurred and often in the absence of continued infection or persistent vesicoureteral reflux
Solution to Question 5:
The given image shows dilated tubules with flattened epithelium, filled with casts, resembling thyroid colloid (thyroidization). This is seen in chronic pyelonephritis.


Option A: In acute tubular necrosis, there is focal tubular epithelial necrosis, tubulorrhexis. Option C: In acute interstitial nephritis, there is patchy edema and mononuclear cell infiltrates. Option D: In systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), wire-loop lesions are seen.
Solution to Question 6:
Necrotizing papillitis or acute papillary necrosis is not associated with thalassemia. Major causes of acute papillary necrosis include
Diabetes mellitus
Sickle cell disease or trait
Analgesic abuse nephropathy
Obstruction by calculi
Focally in renal tuberculosis
Solution to Question 7:
The clinical features and histological findings are suggestive of xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis. It is associated with Proteus infection and obstructive uropathy.
Xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis is a relatively rare form of chronic pyelonephritis characterized by the accumulation of foamy macrophages intermingled with plasma cells, lymphocytes, polymorphonuclear leukocytes, and occasional giant cells.
The lesions sometimes produce large, yellowish-orange nodules that may be grossly confused with renal cell carcinoma. CECT abdomen shows dilated and enlarged renal pelvis and calyces showing a multiloculated appearance referred to as the bear paw sign.

Symmetric
Chronic glomerulonephritis
Benign nephrosclerosis
Asymmetric
Chronic pyelonephritis Causes of enlarged kidneys:

Solution to Question 9:
Image 4 shows a leather-grain appearance, which is seen in benign nephrosclerosis. Features of malignant hypertension:
Flea bitten kidney - small petechial hemorrhages on the cortical surface, leading to a mottled appearance
Fibrinoid necrosis of arterioles - cytologic detail is lost and the vessel wall takes on a smudgy eosinophilic appearance due to fibrin deposition
Onion-skinning (hyperplastic arterioles) - intimal thickening with the fine concentric layering of collagen & smooth muscles




The differential diagnosis for flea-bitten kidney includes:
Polyarteritis nodosa
Subacute bacterial endocarditis (SABE)
Malignant hypertension
Solution to Question 10:
Deficiency of ADAMTS13 leads to thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP).
Two common pathogenetic triggers of thrombotic microangiopathies are:
Endothelial injury - HUS
Excessive platelet activation and aggregation - TTP
Typical HUS
Atypical HUS

Solution to Question 11:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS). It is characterized by the presence of schistocytes in peripheral smear. It indicates microangiopathic hemolytic anemia.
Solution to Question 12:
Cholemic nephrosis is associated with casts of bile.
In patients with acute or chronic liver disease with advanced liver failure, renal function may be impaired. This is called hepatorenal syndrome. This can be associated with highly elevated bilirubin levels with bile cast formation (also known as cholemic nephrosis) in distal nephron segments.
Solution to Question 13:
The gross image suggests that the patient had autosomal-dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). This condition is not associated with hepatic fibrosis. However, patients with autosomal recessive (childhood) polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) have congenital hepatic fibrosis.
ADPKD is associated with mutations in PKD1, encoding polycystin 1, and PKD2, encoding polycystin 2. The multiple expanding cysts of both kidneys ultimately destroy the renal parenchyma and cause renal failure. Cysts arise from the tubules throughout the nephron and, therefore, have variable lining epithelia.
The common extrarenal manifestations of ADPKD include:
Hepatic cysts - most common
Seminal vesicle cysts - can result in infertility
Arachnoid membrane cysts - usually asymptomatic, may increase the risk of subdural hematoma
Pancreatic cysts
Splenic cysts
Intracranial berry aneurysms
Subarachnoid hemorrhages
Mitral valve prolapse
There are very few case reports with lung cysts in ADPKD patients, but the association between ADPKD and lung cysts has not been proved. However, there is a three-fold increase in the incidence of bronchiectasis in ADPKD patients.
Solution to Question 14:
The polycystin-2 mutation is less commonly involved and less severe.
Polycystin-1 is encoded by the PKD1 gene located on chromosome 16p13.3. It is expressed in tubular epithelial cells, particularly those of the distal nephron. It contains domains that are usually involved in cell-cell and cell-matrix interactions. Mutations in PKD1 account for about 85% of cases of ADPKD (autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease) and it causes a more severe form of the disease.
Polycystin-2 is an integral membrane protein that is expressed in all segments of the renal tubules and in many extrarenal tissues. It functions as a Ca2+ cation channel. Overall, it causes a less severe form of ADPKD disease.
Solution to Question 15:
The most common extrarenal site of cysts in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease
(ADPKD) is the liver.
subject: Pathology

question_text:
% of individuals with autosomal-dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) have one to several cysts in the liver (polycystic liver disease) that are usually asymptomatic. The cysts are derived from the biliary epithelium.
Cysts occur much less frequently in the spleen, pancreas, and lungs. There are very few case reports with lung cysts in ADPKD patients, but the association between ADPKD and lung cysts has not been proved.
Solution to Question 16:
The genes mutated in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) are located on chromosomes 16 and 4.
This condition occurs due to mutations of the PKD1 gene (chromosome 16) and PKD2 gene (on chromosome 4). These genes encode for polycystin 1 and 2 proteins respectively.
Solution to Question 17:
Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) is caused by mutations in the PKHD1 gene on chromosome 6p21-p23 which encodes fibrocystin.
The gene is highly expressed in adult and fetal kidneys and also in the liver and pancreas. Fibrocystin has been localized to the primary cilium of tubular cells.
The serious manifestations of ARPKD are usually present at birth, and may cause death by renal failure. The following gross findings are seen:
Enlarged kidneys with smooth external appearance
Spongelike appearance due to numerous small cysts in the cortex and medulla
Dilated elongated channels at right angles to the cortical surface, completely replacing the medulla and cortex
On microscopic examination, there is cylindrical or, less commonly, saccular dilation of all collecting tubules with linning of cuboidal cells. In almost all cases, the liver has cysts associated with portal fibrosis and proliferation of the portal bile ducts, termed congenital hepatic fibrosis.
Solution to Question 18:
Hepatic fibrosis is a feature of childhood (autosomal recessive) polycystic kidney disease.
Solution to Question 19:
Ammonium biurate crystals appear as spheres with radial or concentric striations and irregular projections or thorns, referred to as thorn apples. They are seen in laxative abuse.
Solution to Question 20:
Broad casts are seen in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD). They are also known as renal failure casts.
Broad casts are defined as those with a diameter 2-6 times that of normal casts. They indicate chronically damaged tubules or collecting ducts. They indicate a poor prognosis.
