Solution to Question 1:
This clinical scenario and image showing a well-circumscribed tumor with multiple necrotic, hemorrhagic, and cystic changes in the upper pole of the kidney are suggestive of
a nephroblastoma or Wilms' tumor.
It is the most common primary renal tumor of childhood (2-5 years of age). Around 10% of cases are associated with genetic syndromes and gonadal dysgenesis may be seen.
Clinical manifestations of Wilms' tumor include:
Large abdominal mass - usually unilateral and does not cross the midline
Abdominal pain
Hematuria
Hypertension
Intestinal obstruction (in some cases)
Nephrogenic rests are the precursor lesions of Wilms' tumor and suggest an increased risk of developing a contralateral Wilms' tumor.
Solution to Question 2:
Wilms' tumor is associated with the deletion of chromosome 11p13.
It is an autosomal-dominant disorder. The most common clinical presentation is an abdominal mass.
Note: MIC-2 gene expression is seen in neuroblastoma.
Solution to Question 3:
In Wilms' tumor, the presence of anaplasia is indicative of resistance to chemotherapy.
This correlates with the presence of TP53 mutations and, hence, is associated with a poor prognosis.
Solution to Question 4:
Anaplastic histology is the most important prognostic factor in Wilms' tumor.
It is seen in about 5% of cases and is characterized by the presence of cells with large, hyperchromatic, pleomorphic nuclei, and abnormal mitoses. It is associated with TP53 mutations and resistance to chemotherapy.
Anaplasia is uncommon in children < 2 years. Hence, tumors presenting at an young age have a significantly better prognosis than those presenting in older children.
Prognostic factors in Wilms' tumor include:
Favorable prognosis
Adverse prognosis
Histologic type
Classic triphasic componen t
Anaplastic histology
Tumor stage
Low
High
Molecular alteration s

Solution to Question 5:
Bilateral polycystic kidneys are not associated with Wilms tumor.
Wilms' tumor can be associated with:
Aniridia - WAGR syndrome
Gonadal dysgenesis - Denys–Drash syndrome
Hemihypertrophy and omphalocele - Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome
Solution to Question 6:
This clinical scenario and image showing periungual fibromas are strongly suggestive of tuberous sclerosis. This condition is associated with renal angiomyolipomas (present in 25–50% of cases).
Tuberous sclerosis is a multisystem disorder that has an autosomal dominant mode of inheritance. The mutations are involved in the TSC1 gene that encodes hamartin on chromosome 9 and the TSC2 gene that encodes a protein tuberin on chromosome 16.
The clinical features of tuberous sclerosis include:
Skin lesions -
Hypomelanotic ash leaf–type macules
Periungual fibromas or Koenen tumors (small fibromas or nodules of skin around fingernails or toenails)
Shagreen patch- roughened, raised lesion with an orange-peel consistency, primarily in the umbosacral region
Facial angiofibromas
Confetti skin lesions
Neurological features -
Epilepsy and intellectual disability (due to cortical tubers)
Autism spectrum disorder
Subependymal giant cell astrocytomas
Other tumors -
Cardiac rhabdomyoma
Renal angiomyolipomas, renal cysts
Pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosis
Angiomyolipoma is a benign renal neoplasm (hamartoma) originating from perivascular epithelioid cells (PEComa). It consists of vessels, smooth muscle, and fat in variable proportions. They are highly susceptibility to spontaneous hemorrhage.
The histological image of renal angiomyolipoma is given below:


Solution to Question 7:
The given clinical history is suggestive of renal oncocytoma. It arises from the intercalated cells of the collecting ducts.
It is a benign epithelial neoplasm. Grossly, these tumors appear tan or mahogany
brown and relatively homogeneous. They are usually well encapsulated with a central scar in one-third of cases.
Microscopically, they are composed of large eosinophilic cells having small, round,
benign-appearing nuclei that have large nucleoli. Ultrastructurally, these eosinophilic cells have numerous mitochondria.
The gross and histological appearances of renal oncocytoma are shown in the images given below:



Oncocytes refer to epithelial cells with abundant eosinophilic granular cytoplasm (due to the accumulation of mitochondria). They can arise in various tissues and are referred to as:
Hurthle cells/Ashkenazy cells in the thyroid gland
Oxyphilic cells in the parotid gland
Apocrine metaplasia in the breast
Solution to Question 8:
The most important determinant of malignant potential in the papillary type of renal tumor is the size of the tumor.
The papillary type of renal tumors includes:
Renal papillary adenoma ( 1.5 cm)
Papillary type of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) - > 1.5 cm
Small renal papillary growths are fairly common and incidentally found. Ruling out of malignancy is one of the processes carried out during the evaluation of donor transplant kidneys.

Papillary renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is the second most common type of renal cell carcinoma and it arises from proximal tubules. It can be multifocal or bilateral. It is typically hemorrhagic and cystic, especially when large.
It is often a circumscribed tumor composed of papillae formed by delicate fibrovascular cores that often contain foamy macrophages and Psammoma bodies.
It has two histological types:
Type 1 papillary RCC - single layer of cells on the basement membrane and low-grade nuclear features
Type 2 papillary RCC - pseudostratification of cells and usually has high-grade nuclear features
Solution to Question 9:
The given image shows a bright yellow variegated mass distorting the renal outline at the lower pole. This is suggestive of the clear cell type of renal cell carcinoma (RCC). The yellow color is due to prominent lipid accumulation.

Solution to Question 10:
The given image shows eosinophilic cells with prominent cell membranes and perinuclear halo, which is suggestive of chromophobe cell renal cell carcinoma (RCC). It is associated
with Birt–Hogg–Dubé syndrome.
Other familial cancer syndromes and the common malignancies associated with them are:
Hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer syndrome - papillary RCC
Large cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, large nuclei, and prominent inclusion-like eosinophilic nucleoli.
Tuberous sclerosis - clear-cell RCC
Von Hippel–Lindau syndrome (VHL) - clear-cell RCC
The image given below shows the histology of chromophobe cell RCC.


Solution to Question 11:
Loss of Y chromosome is a feature of sporadic papillary carcinoma, not hereditary papillary RCC.

Various types of renal carcinoma and their cytogenetic abnormalities are given below:
Papillary renal cell carcinoma -
Sporadic type - trisomies 7 and 17, loss of Y chromosome
Familial type - trisomy 7 (mapped to MET gene)
Clear-cell renal-cell carcinoma (whether familial, sporadic, or associated with VHL syndrome)
Loss of sequences on the short arm of chromosome 3, which harbors the VHL gene
Solution to Question 12:
Clear-cell renal cell carcinoma is the most common histological subtype of renal cell carcinoma, accounting for 70% to 80% of renal cell cancers.
It is most likely to arise from the proximal tubular epithelium as solitary lesions. It has a characteristic tendency to invade the renal vein. The histological features are:
Rounded or polygonal tumor cells
Abundant clear or granular cytoplasm, which contains glycogen and lipids
Arranged in a solid to trabecular (cordlike) or tubular pattern
The histological appearance of clear-cell renal cell carcinoma is shown in the image given below:


Note: The Furhman nuclear grading system was previously used for histological grading of RCC (except chromophobe RCC). It is now replaced by the WHO/International Society of Urologic Pathology (ISUP) grading system.
Solution to Question 13:
Succinate dehydrogenase (SDH)-deficient renal cell carcinoma does not show papillary architecture. It is associated with a bubbly appearance of histopathology.
It is a malignant epithelial tumor associated with germline mutations in the SDH gene. It
is composed of vacuolated, eosinophilic-clear cells arranged in a solid, nested, or tubular pattern. The presence of the vacuoles imparts the characteristic bubbly appearance, as shown below.


Renal cell carcinoma subtypes with papillary architecture in histology:
Papillary renal cell carcinoma
Hereditary leiomyomatosis renal cell carcinoma
Xp11 translocation renal cell carcinoma
Collecting duct renal cell carcinoma
Solution to Question 14:
Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma shows large cells having plant-cell-like appearance with a perinuclear halo.
They are arranged in solid sheets with a concentration of the largest cells around blood vessels.
Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma can differentiated from oncocytoma and clear cell RCC as follows:
Oncocytoma does not show perinuclear halo whereas chromophobe RCC shows perinuclear halo
CK7 is diffusely positive in chromophobe RCC but it is negative in clear-cell RCC. Chromophobe RCC cannot be histologically graded because of its innate nuclear atypia. The histological image of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma is given below:

Solution to Question 15:
The renal tumor commonly associated with Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome is chromophobe renal cell carcinoma (RCC). It has an excellent prognosis.
It constitutes 5% of all renal carcinomas. It arises from the intercalated cells of the collecting duct. Cytogenetic testing of the tumor shows multiple chromosomal losses and extreme hypodiploidy.
The histological image of chromophobe RCC is given below:

Solution to Question 16:
Collecting duct carcinoma or Bellini duct carcinoma shows a characteristic hobnail pattern and prominent desmoplastic stroma on microscopy.
The hobnail pattern refers to the bulbous nuclear projections of epithelial cells that protrude into the lumen as little bumps. It is associated with tubular, tubulopapillary, or tubulocystic pattern.
Collecting duct carcinoma arises from the principal cells of the renal collecting ducts of Bellini. The majority of these tumors are associated with poor outcome, due to their highly aggressive clinical course.
The histological section showing collecting duct carcinoma with the characteristic hobnail pattern is given below:


Note: The hobnail pattern is also seen in clear cell carcinoma of the ovary.
Solution to Question 17:
Individuals with the sickle cell trait are at a higher risk of developing medullary renal cell carcinoma.
It is a rare, highly aggressive neoplasm and is morphologically similar to collecting duct carcinoma.
The hypoxic microenvironment in the renal medulla created by hyperosmolarity, low pH, and stasis enhances red blood sickling and ischemic damage. This leads to chronic regenerative proliferation of medullary epithelium and activation of hypoxia-induced signaling
pathways, which in turn promote neoplastic change.
The histological section of renal medullary carcinoma showing prominent cytological atypia is shown below:


Solution to Question 18:
Xp11 translocation carcinoma contains neoplastic cells with clear cytoplasm with a papillary architecture on histopathology. It is also associated with Psammoma bodies.
This condition is caused by translocations of the TFE3 gene located on Xp11.2, which results in overexpression of the TFE3 transcription factor. It often occurs in young patients and is associated with a poor prognosis.
The histological section of Xp11 translocation carcinoma is given below:


Solution to Question 19:
Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is more common among males, with a male to female ratio of 2:1.
Renal cell carcinoma may arise from the proximal convoluted tubules (PCT). The classical clinical features of renal cell carcinoma are costovertebral pain, palpable mass, and painless hematuria. It characteristically invades the renal vein and has a high tendency for distant metastasis.
Paraneoplastic manifestations of renal cell carcinoma include:
Polycythemia
Hypercalcemia
Hypertension
Hepatic dysfunction
Feminization or masculinization
Cushing syndrome
Eosinophilia
Leukemoid reactions
Amyloidosis
Solution to Question 20:
The most common site of metastasis in renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is the lung (more than 50%). Common sites of metastasis of renal cell carcinoma in descending order are:
Lungs
Bones - osteolytic lesions
Regional lymph nodes
Liver
Adrenals
Brain
Solution to Question 21:
Collecting duct renal cell carcinoma has the worst prognosis of all renal cell carcinoma subtypes. The renal cell carcinoma subtypes with poor prognosis in descending order are
Collecting duct renal cell carcinoma
Medullary renal cell carcinoma
Clear cell renal cell carcinoma
Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma has the best prognosis.
Solution to Question 22:
WT gene is mutated in Wilms' tumor, not renal cell carcinoma.
The following gene mutations are associated with familial renal cell carcinoma syndromes:
C-met proto-oncogene
Fumarate hydratase gene
BHD gene
VHL gene
TSC1 gene
PTEN gene
Solution to Question 23:
Renal cell carcinoma is CK7 negative and CK20 negative.
The most common subtype of renal cell carcinoma is clear-cell renal cell carcinoma, which is CK7 negative. Therefore, in determining the origin of cancer of unknown primary, immunohistochemistry (IHC) expression of renal cell carcinoma will generally be CK7 negative and CK20 negative. Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma and papillary renal cell carcinoma are positive for CK7.

Solution to Question 1:
Hunner ulcers are chronic mucosal ulcers that are characteristic of interstitial cystitis or chronic pelvic pain syndrome.
It is a rare idiopathic condition that occurs most frequently in women. It presents with intermittent severe suprapubic pain, urinary frequency, urgency, hematuria, and dysuria.
The following cystoscopic findings are seen in the bladder mucosa:
Fissures
Punctate hemorrhages (glomerulations)
The microscopic findings include:
Mucosal ulceration covered by fibrin and necrotic materia
Increased numbers of mucosal mast cells
Submucosal edema
In later stages, transmural fibrosis may occur, leading to a contracted bladder. Biopsy must be done to rule out carcinoma in situ, which may clinically mimic interstitial cystitis.
The following image shows a Hunner's ulcer in a patient with interstitial cystitis.

Solution to Question 2:
This clinical scenario with the presence of Michaelis-Gutmann bodies is suggestive of malakoplakia.
Malakoplakia is a chronic inflammatory reaction resulting from acquired defects in phagocyte function, commonly affecting the urinary bladder. It can also be seen in other organ systems like the gastrointestinal tract, female genital tract, and central nervous system.
It is seen in chronic bacterial infection, mostly by Escherichia coli or occasionally Proteus species.
Grossly, it presents as soft, yellow-brown, slightly raised mucosal plaques. Microscopically, the following findings are seen:
Large, foamy macrophages containing -
Abundant granular cytoplasm due to undigested bacterial products
Michaelis-Gutmann bodies - PAS-positive basophilic concretions due to iron and calcium deposits in lysosomes
Occasional multinucleated giant cells and lymphocytes

Note: Xanthogranulomatous cystitis is morphologically and probably pathogenetically similar to malakoplakia, but it lacks Michaelis–Gutmann bodies.
Solution to Question 3:
The most common cause of polypoid cystitis is indwelling catheters.
Polypoid cystitis is an inflammatory lesion resulting from mucosal irritation. It may also be associated with radiation therapy and malignant tumors. It usually involves the posterior wall of the bladder.
Grossly, it may show bulbous or papillary appearance and may be confused with papillary urothelial carcinoma. Microscopically, the papillary projections are broad-based, non-branching, and without atypia. Stroma is edematous with minimal inflammation.
Options A and D: Adenovirus infection and the use of anti-cancer drugs like cyclophosphamide cause hemorrhagic cystitis.
Option B: Systemic allergic disorders cause eosinophilic cystitis.
Solution to Question 4:
Malakoplakia is not a metaplastic lesion of the bladder. It is a type of chronic granulomatous cystitis due to defective phagocytic function that may mimic malignancy.
Metaplastic lesions of the bladder include the following:
Nests of urothelium (Brunn nests) may grow downward into the lamina propria resulting in the following lesions -
Cystitis glandularis - epithelial cells in the center of the nest undergo metaplasia and take on a cuboidal or columnar appearance
Cystitis cystica - epithelial cells retract to produce cystic spaces lined by flattened urothelium
Squamous metaplasia - in response to injury, urothelium is replaced by stratified squamous epithelium.
Nephrogenic adenoma - due to implantation of shed renal tubular cells at sites of injured urothelium, resulting in replacement of urothelium by cuboidal epithelium with a papillary growth pattern
Solution to Question 5:
The most common tumor of the urinary bladder is transitional cell carcinoma or urothelial carcinoma.
Other epithelial tumors like squamous cell carcinoma, adenocarcinoma, and small cell carcinoma may also occur.
Sarcomas are distinctly uncommon in the bladder. However, the most common sarcoma in infancy or childhood is embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, and the most common sarcoma in the bladder in adults is leiomyosarcoma.
Solution to Question 6:
The image shows oval-shaped eggs with the terminal spine which is characteristic of Schistosoma haematobium. It is most commonly associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder.
The ova are deposited in the bladder wall and incite a brisk chronic inflammatory response. This induces progressive mucosal squamous metaplasia and dysplasia and, in some instances, neoplasia.
Schistosomal infection can less frequently result in adenocarcinoma or transitional cell carcinoma.
Solution to Question 7:
Isopropyl alcohol is not implicated in the causation of bladder cancer.
Benzidine, arylamines, and phenacetin are well-established risk factors for bladder cancer.
Solution to Question 8:
Activating mutation in HRAS (not NRAS) is responsible for bladder carcinoma. Genetic changes associated with carcinoma bladder:
Noninvasive low-grade papillary urothelial carcinoma is associated with:
Gain-of-function mutations of FGFR3 and HRAS genes
Chromosome 9p and 9q deletions
High-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma (either papillary or flat) is associated with:
Loss-of-function mutations of TP53 and RB genes
Note: Erdafitinib (kinase inhibitor) is the first targeted drug therapy approved by the FDA for the treatment of metastatic urothelial carcinoma especially in patients with mutations of FGFR3 or FGFR2.
Solution to Question 9:
The most consistent and persistent feature of carcinoma bladder is painless hematuria. Bladder tumors produce a wide range of clinical features including:
Painless hematuria - classical feature and may be the only clinical manifestation
Irritative urinary symptoms (frequency, urgency, dysuria) - diffuse tumors or tumors at the bladder neck
Pyelonephritis or hydronephrosis - when the ureteral orifice is involved
Obstructive symptoms, palpable suprapubic mass, or lower extremity edema - late presentation with a large tumor mass
Weight loss and/or localized bone pain - metastatic disease
Solution to Question 10:
International Society of Urological Pathology (ISUP) grading system classifies papillary urothelial carcinoma into 2 grades - low grade and high grade. The classification of papillary urothelial carcinoma into grades 1, 2, 3 was was part of the earlier WHO classification.
Grading of urothelial (transitional cell) tumors: WHO/ISUP grades:
Urothelial papilloma
Urothelial neoplasm of low malignant potentia
Papillary urothelial carcinoma, low grade
Papillary urothelial carcinoma, high grade WHO grades (old classification):
Urothelial papilloma
Urothelial neoplasm of low malignant potentia
Papillary urothelial carcinoma, grade 1
Papillary urothelial carcinoma, grade 2
Papillary urothelial carcinoma, grade 3
Solution to Question 11:
The staging (extent of spread) at the time of initial diagnosis is the most important prognostic factor in infiltrating urothelial carcinoma.
The prognosis of bladder carcinoma depends on the histologic grade and the stage at diagnosis. As most infiltrating urothelial carcinomas are high-grade, staging becomes the major factor to determine the prognosis.

Solution to Question 2:
Cystic remnants of mesonephric ducts in the cervix and vagina are termed Gartner duct cysts.
The mesonephric (Wolffian) ducts normally regress in females. Its remnants may persist into adult life as epithelial inclusions adjacent to the ovaries, tubes, and uterus. In the cervix and
vagina, these ducts may be cystic and are termed Gartner duct cysts.
The following images show the embryological development of the mesonephric duct and its persistence into adult life.

Solution to Question 3:
The given histopathological image shows benign papillary projections covered with columnar secretory epithelium and underlying myoepithelial cells. These are commonly seen in papillary hidradenoma of the vulva.

It presents as a sharply circumscribed nodule, most commonly on the labia majora or interlabial folds. Like the breast, the vulva also contains modified apocrine sweat glands. Its histologic appearance is identical to that of intraductal papilloma of the breast.
Solution to Question 4:
The most likely diagnosis is embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma (sarcoma botryoides).
It is an uncommon vaginal tumor composed of malignant embryonal rhabdomyoblasts. It is most frequently found in infants and in children < 5 years of age. They are locally invasive tumors that cause death by penetration into the peritoneal cavity or by obstruction of the urinary tract.
Grossly, polypoid, rounded, bulky masses that appear like grape clusters can be seen. On microscopy, small tumor cells with oval nuclei, and small protrusions of cytoplasm from one end resembling a tennis racket (tadpole cells) can be seen. Beneath the vaginal epithelium, the tumor cells are crowded in a cambium layer, in the dermis.
Solution to Question 5:
Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (LSIL) does not progress directly to invasive carcinoma. They initially progress to a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL), then invasive carcinoma.
The WHO currently recommends a 2-tier system of classification for cervical lesions - low and high-grade intraepithelial lesions (LSIL and HSIL). HPV-16 is the most common HPV type associated with both LSIL and HSIL
LSILs are 10 times more common than HSILs. Most of these lesions regress
spontaneously. Progression to invasive carcinoma is unpredictable and can take place over years.
Solution to Question 6:
Human papillomavirus (HPV)-16 is the most common type of HPV causing cervical carcinoma. It accounts for almost 60% of cervical cancer cases.
The ability of HPV to act as a carcinogen depends on the viral proteins E6 and E7. These proteins interfere with the activity of tumor-suppressor proteins that regulate cell growth and survival.
E6 - binds with p53 gene and promote its degradation
E7 - binds with RB gene and promotes its degradation
Solution to Question 7:
Cervical cancer screening test, commonly known as Pap smear, is stained using the Papanicolaou method.
The time for initiating Pap smear screening is 21 years, regardless of the age of first sexual intercourse.
The sample is collected using Ayre's spatula and endocervical brush. 2 samples are taken:
subject: Pathology

question_text:
nd slide - prepared from the sample taken from the endocervix (transformation zone) 95% ethanol is used as a fixative.
It is a highly specific test. Colposcopic examination and biopsy are recommended in case of abnormal Pap smear results.
Solution to Question 8:
Smoking is strongly associated with mucinous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary, but not endometrial carcinoma.
Endometrial carcinoma is the most common invasive cancer of the female genital tract. Type 1 endometrial carcinoma shows endometrioid morphology and is associated with:
Unopposed estrogen exposure (endometrial hyperplasia)
Obesity
Diabetes mellitus
Hypertension
PTEN tumor-suppressor gene is mutated in approximately 20% of endometrial hyperplasias.
Genomic sequencing of endometrial carcinoma has revealed 4 major molecular subtypes of endometrioid and serous carcinomas:
Ultramutated/ POLE tumors - mutations in DNA polymerase  (POLE)
Hypermutated/ MSI (microsatellite instability) tumors - mutations involving mismatch repair genes
Copy number low/ MSS (microsatellite stable) tumors - mutations involving the PI3K/AKT pathway
Copy number high/ serous-like tumors - TP53 mutations and numerous genomic copy number variants
Solution to Question 9:
The size of the tumor is not a criterion to distinguish between leiomyosarcoma and leiomyoma. The following features are seen in leiomyosarcomas:
Mitotic index - 10 mitoses / 10 hpf
Nuclear atypia - in the presence of nuclear atypia, 5 mitoses / 10 hpf
Tumor cell necrosis -
Characterized by an abrupt transition from viable to non-viable areas
Within the necrotic zones, atypical cells can be seen
Solution to Question 10:
The given image denotes Psammoma bodies which are a histopathological finding seen in ovarian papillary serous cystadenoma and cystadenocarcinoma. These tumors are most
commonly bilateral.

The majority of serous tumors of the ovary are benign or borderline. But the serous carcinomas of the ovary include the most common malignant tumors of the ovary.
Nulliparity, family history, and heritable mutations play a role in the development of these tumors. Mutations in the oncogenes KRAS, BRAF, or ERBB2 result in low-grade tumors, and mutation in TP53 is associated with high-grade tumors.
There is a higher frequency of carcinoma in women with low parity. Women on oral contraceptive pills or those who have undergone tubal ligation are at a lower risk. The marker for ovarian tumors is CA-125.
Solution to Question 11:
The vast majority of mucinous tumors of the ovary are benign or borderline tumors (not malignant).
It occurs principally in middle adult life and is rare before puberty and after menopause. The surface of the ovary is rarely involved, they are rarely bilateral. It is associated with the mutation of KRAS proto-oncogene.
Grossly it is multiloculated and filled with sticky, gelatinous fluid (rich in glycoproteins).
Solution to Question 12:
The given scenario and image showing unilocular cystic space containing hair and sebaceous material are suggestive of mature teratoma.


Dermoid cysts or mature teratomas are benign tumors, usually found in young women during the active reproductive years. It is bilateral in 10% to 15% of cases.
Microscopically, the cyst wall is composed of tissues from all 3 germ layers. This includes stratified squamous epithelium, with underlying sebaceous glands, hair shafts, and other skin adnexal structures. Sometimes cartilage, bone, thyroid, and neural tissue can be seen.
About 1% of the dermoids undergo malignant transformation, most commonly to squamous cell carcinoma. It can also transform into other cancers (e.g., thyroid carcinoma, melanoma).


The component tissue of immature malignant teratomas resembles embryonal and immature fetal tissue. It often consists of primitive neuroepithelial cells. The tumor is found chiefly in prepubertal adolescents and young women, the mean age being 18 years.
Monodermal or specialized teratomas:
Struma ovarii - composed entirely of mature thyroid tissue, which may be functional and cause hyperthyroidism.
Ovarian carcinoid - arises from intestinal tissue, may be functional causing carcinoid syndrome in the absence of hepatic metastasis
Solution to Question 13:
The given clinical scenario and histopathology showing Call-Exner bodies are suggestive of granulosa cell tumor.
Call-Exner bodies are small, distinctive, glandlike structures filled with an acidophilic material resembling immature follicles. Additionally, small, cuboidal to polygonal cells are seen which may grow in anastomosing cords, sheets, or strands.


Granulosa cell tumors are composed of cells that resemble granulosa cells of a developing ovarian follicle. It can be of adult and juvenile types. Elevated tissue and serum levels of inhibin, a product of granulosa cells, are associated with this tumor.
Mutations of the FOXL2 gene are seen in most adult granulosa cell tumors.
Solution to Question 14:
The given clinical features and the histopathological image showing Schiller Duval bodies are suggestive of endodermal sinus tumors. It is also known as yolk sac tumor.
The Schiller-Duval body is a glomerulus-like structure composed of a central blood vessel enveloped by tumor cells within a space that is also lined by tumor cells.
It is the second most common malignant tumor of germ cell origin. It is a unilateral tumor usually affecting children or young women.


Solution to Question 15:
Sex cord-stromal tumors include the following:
Granulosa cell tumor
Sertoli cell tumor
Fibroma
Brenner tumor is an epithelial tumor and dysgerminoma is a germ cell tumor.
Solution to Question 16:
The given clinical scenario and histopathology findings are suggestive of metastatic carcinoma of the ovary or Krukenberg tumor.
It can arise from primary carcinomas of the stomach (most common), colon, appendix, and breast
(invasive lobular carcinoma). It is often bilateral and on microscopy shows mucin-laden signet-ring cells with eccentric hyperchromatic nuclei.


Metastatic tumors of the ovary include:
Tumors of Müllerian origin (most common) - the uterus, fallopian tube, contralateral ovary, or pelvic peritoneum
Tumors of extra-Müllerian tumors - breast and gastrointestinal tract carcinomas
Pseudomyxoma peritonei - derived from appendiceal tumors
Krukenberg tumor
Solution to Question 17:
The given clinical scenario and image showing grapelike vesicles are suggestive of a complete mole. It results from the fertilization of an egg that has lost its female chromosomes, and as a result, the genetic material is completely paternally derived.


The pathogenesis of complete mole is as follows:
Androgenesis (most common) - 46XX karyotype stemming from the duplication of the genetic material of 1 sperm
Dispermy - 46XX or 46XY karyotype due to fertilization of an empty egg by 2 sperms
Microscopically, thin-walled, cystic, grapelike structures consisting of hydropic villi are seen. Trophoblastic proliferation involving the entire circumference of the villi is seen.
The embryo dies very early in development and, therefore, is usually not identified. Patients have a 2.5% risk of subsequent choriocarcinoma and a 15% risk of the persistent or invasive mole.
The following image shows the pathogenesis of molar pregnancy.

Solution to Question 18:
The given clinical scenario with grape-like vesicles in the vagina and the presence of fetal tissues on transvaginal ultrasound are suggestive of partial mole. The karyotype in a partial mole
is triploid (e.g., 69XXY) or occasionally tetraploid (92XXXY).
It results from the fertilization of an egg with 2 sperms. There is an increased risk of persistent molar disease but it is not associated with choriocarcinoma.
Given below is an image showing the karyotype of molar pregnancy.

Solution to Question 19:
Lungs are the most common site of metastasis in gestational choriocarcinoma.
It is followed by the vagina, brain, liver, bone, and kidney in descending order of frequency.
Gestational choriocarcinomas are malignant neoplasm of trophoblastic cells derived from a previously normal or abnormal pregnancy, such as an extrauterine ectopic pregnancy. The hCG levels are elevated to levels above those encountered in hydatidiform moles. It
shows hematogenous spread. It is rapidly invasive and metastasizes widely.
Gestational choriocarcinomas are chemosensitive whereas non-gestational choriocarcinomas are chemoresistant.
Solution to Question 20:
Malignant mixed Müllerian tumors (MMMTs) are carcinosarcomas whose genetic profile closely resembles endometrial carcinomas.
They involve mutations in the same genes - PTEN, TP53, and PIK3CA. The usual genetic alterations found in sarcomas are absent in MMMTs.
MMMTs are endometrial adenocarcinomas with malignant mesenchymal components. The mesenchymal component may resemble uterine mesenchymal elements (stromal sarcoma, leiomyosarcoma) or contain heterologous malignant cell types (striated muscle, cartilage, adipose tissue, and bone).
It occurs in postmenopausal women and presents with bleeding. It is associated with a poor outcome.
Solution to Question 21:
Meigs' syndrome triad includes the following:
Solid benign ovarian tumor (fibroma)
Right-sided hydrothorax
Ascites - disappears after the removal of the tumor Pseudo-Meigs' syndrome is characterized by the following:
Non-malignant ascites
Pleural effusion
Pelvic tumors - other than solid benign ovarian tumors
Note: Ovarian fibroma is also associated with nevoid basal cell carcinoma. This association is known as Gorlin syndrome.
Solution to Question 22:
The given histopathological image shows large cells with clear cytoplasm (fried egg appearance), tumor cells arranged in sheets, and cords of fibrous stroma infiltrated by lymphocytes. These findings are suggestive of dysgerminoma. It is highly responsive to radiotherapy.


Dysgerminomas are the ovarian counterparts of testicular seminoma. They may occur in childhood, but most commonly occur in the 2-3rd decades. It may occur in patients with gonadal dysgenesis, including pseudohermaphroditism. The majority of these tumors are unilateral. They express OCT-3, OCT4, and NANOG.
All dysgerminomas are malignant, but the degree of histologic atypia is variable. Only about
one-third of these lesions are aggressive. These neoplasms are responsive to chemoradiation, and overall survival exceeds 80%.

Solution to Question 1:
The given histopathological image showing papillary (villous) architecture with acanthosis, hyperkeratosis and koilocytosis of squamous epithelium, are characteristic findings of condyloma acuminatum.
Koilocytes have a prominent cell membrane, hyperchromatic resinoid nucleus, and perinuclear halo.

Grossly, they consist of single or multiple sessile or pedunculated, red papillary excrescences on the coronal sulcus, and the inner surface of the prepuce.
Option A: Condyloma lata is a maculopapular/nodular lesion seen in secondary syphilis.
Option B: Bowen's disease is carcinoma in situ of the penis characterized by the hyperproliferative epidermis and dysplastic epithelium.
Option D: Verrucous carcinoma / very well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, shows hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, and keratin pearls.
Solution to Question 2:
Bowen's disease starts as a premalignant lesion and transforms into infiltrating squamous cell carcinoma in approximately 10% of patients, usually over a span of many years.
Bowen's disease occurs in the genital region of both men and women, usually in those older than age 35 years. These lesions have a strong association with infection by high-risk human papillomavirus (HPV), most commonly type 16.
Grossly, it appears as a solitary, thickened, gray-white, and opaque plaque.
The below histological image of Bowen's disease shows dysplastic cells with large hyperchromatic nuclei, koilocytic atypia and an intact basement membrane.


Premalignant lesions of invasive penile SCC:
Erythroplasia of Queyrat
Condyloma acuminatum
Bowen's disease
Bowenoid papulosis occurs in young, sexually active adults. It presents as multiple reddish-brown papular lesions and it is histologically indistinguishable from Bowen's disease, but virtually never develops into invasive carcinoma.
Solution to Question 3:
The given histopathological features are strongly suggestive of cryptorchidism. Cryptorchidism is histopathologically characterized by the following:
Testicular atrophy: thickening of the basement membrane, arrested germ cell development, marked hyalinization
Tubules showing Sertoli cells but no spermatogenesis
Increase in the interstitial Leydig cells.
Cryptorchidism is the failure of the descent of the intra-abdominal testes into the scrotal sac. It is the most common congenital abnormality of the genitourinary tract. The testes can arrest anywhere during descent, and the most common site is the inguinal region.
Phases of testicular descent:
Transabdominal phase: Testes come to lie in the lower abdomen or pelvis. This phase of descent is regulated by Mullerian-inhibiting substances.
Inguinoscrotal phase: Testes descend along the inguinal canal and reach the scrotal sac. This phase of the descent is regulated by androgen-induced calcitonin gene-related peptide from the
genitofemoral nerve.
The exact pathogenesis remains unknown, however, deficiency in gonadotropins and Mullerian-inhibiting substance (MIS) and increased expression of estradiol in the placenta are thought to play a role. It is associated with testicular atrophy and dysfunction, which result in
sterility. Cryptorchid testes carry a 3–5-fold higher risk for testicular cancer (usually seminoma).
Solution to Question 4:
Torsion testis does not cause testicular atrophy. It may cause intense congestion to widespread hemorrhage to testicular infarction.
Causes of testicular atrophy:
Progressive atherosclerotic narrowing of the blood supply in old age
End-stage of an inflammatory orchitis
Cryptorchidism - associated with progressive tubular atrophy and sterility
Hypopituitarism
Generalized malnutrition or cachexia
Irradiation
Prolonged administration of antiandrogens (treatment for advanced carcinoma of the prostate)
Liver cirrhosis - may cause testicular atrophy as a result of increased levels of circulating endogenous estrogens not metabolized by the diseased liver
Exhaustion atrophy, which may follow persistent stimulation by high levels of the follicle-stimulating pituitary hormone
Occasionally occurs as a primary failure of genetic origins, such as in Klinefelter (XXY)
syndrome
The histological image below of testicular atrophy shows small tubules with few or no germ cells, thickening of the basement membrane of the spermatic tubules, and prominent Leydig cells. The near-normal seminiferous tubules are seen side-by-side with atrophic seminiferous tubules.


Solution to Question 5:
The above clinical scenario depicts that the patient is having Sertoli cell-only syndrome, and patients with this syndrome will have increased levels of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH).
The below image shows normal histology of testis:

In normal males, as spermatogenesis and testosterone production increase, the Sertoli cells produce inhibin, which inhibits the release of FSH. The Sertoli cells are supporting cells that are under the action of FSH. Leydig cells, which are present in the interstitial spaces, are under the action of luteinizing hormone(LH) and produce testosterone. Testosterone has a feedback inhibition on LH.
In Sertoli cell-only syndrome, within the seminiferous tubules, only Sertoli cells are seen and no germ cells. Hence, there are no spermatozoa and there is no feedback inhibition, which results in increased FSH levels. So, testosterone levels, and LH levels remain unaffected since Leydig cells are not affected. Hence, the patient will have male secondary sexual characters.
The most important indication of testicular biopsy is infertility workup.
Solution to Question 6:
The most likely diagnosis is testicular torsion. The pathological changes range from intense congestion to widespread hemorrhage to testicular infarction. In advanced stages, the testis is markedly enlarged and consists entirely of soft, necrotic, hemorrhagic tissue.


Adult torsion is typically seen in adolescence and presents with the sudden onset of testicular pain. Neonatal torsion can occur either in utero or shortly after birth and the cause is unknown.
It results from a bilateral anatomic defect that leads to increased mobility of the testes (bell- clapper□ abnormality). Twisting of the spermatic cord typically cuts off the venous drainage of the testis. But, thick-walled arteries remain patent, producing intense vascular engorgement, followed by hemorrhagic infarction. If the testis is manually untwisted within approximately 6 hours of the onset of torsion, there is a good chance that the testis will remain viable.
Solution to Question 7:
Syphilis and mumps affect the testis primarily and later spread to surrounding structures.
Syphilis can affect both the testis and epididymis, but invariably, the testis is involved first as gummas and diffuse interstitial inflammation.
Mumps most commonly affects school-aged children, but testicular involvement is uncommon in this age. Mumps infection in postpubertal males can lead to acute interstitial orchitis in 20 to 30% of cases.
Gonorrhea and tuberculosis affect the epididymis first, which can later spread to the testis.
Solution to Question 8:
Germ-cell neoplasia in situ (GCNIS) is a common precursor lesion of seminoma.
Most testicular germ-cell tumors originate from a precursor lesion called GCNIS. It is believed to arise in utero and stay dormant until puberty, after which it may progress to seminoma or
non-seminomatous tumors. The exceptions to this rule are:
Prepubertal yolk-sac tumors
Teratomas
Adult spermatocyte tumors
The lesion consists of atypical primordial germ cells, which have large nuclei and a clear cytoplasm and fail to develop into spermatogonia. This is because these cells retain the expression of the transcription factors OCT3/4 and NANOG, which maintain the pluripotency of germ cells and prevent their maturation.
Solution to Question 9:
Pure choriocarcinoma is a rare, but aggressive, tumor and has a poor prognosis.
It generally does not cause any testicular enlargement. It spreads rapidly via the bloodstream. This results in the frequent involvement of the lung and liver. However, pure germ-cell tumors (GCTs) are rare and about 60% of testicular GCTs are mixed tumors.
Teratomas in children usually follow a benign course. But, in the postpubertal male, all teratomas are regarded as malignant because they are capable of metastatic behavior.
Solution to Question 10:
Yolk sac tumor is the most common testicular tumor in infants and children up to 3 years of age. Prepubertal teratoma is the second most common testicular tumor in infants and children.
In adults, pure yolk sac tumor is rare. The yolk sac elements frequently occur in combination with embryonal carcinoma (as a mixed tumor).
Solution to Question 11:
The gross specimen showing a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface that bulges around the surrounding parenchyma is characteristic of a seminomatous germ-cell tumor or seminoma.
The histological image shows sheets of uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and central nucleus, with a prominent nucleolus (fried-egg appearance), delicate fibrous septa containing a lymphocytic infiltrate.

Seminoma is the most common type of GCT. The peak incidence is the 3rd decade and almost never occurs in infants. It is the testicular equivalent of an ovarian
dysgerminoma. Immunohistochemistry is positive for KIT, (regardless of KIT mutational status), OCT3/4, and placental alkaline phosphatase (PLAP).
Option B: Yolk sac tumor is non-encapsulated with mucinous appearance. Schiller–Duval bodies are characteristic. It is seen in children less than 3 years.
Option C: Teratoma shows derivatives of more than one germ layer like cartilage, hair, sebaceous glands.
Option D: Testicular lymphoma is a rare extranodal presentation of non-Hodgkin lymphoma
Testicular biopsy is contraindicated in case of a suspicious testicular mass because it is associated with a risk of tumor cell spillage. High inguinal orchidectomy followed by histopathological evaluation is the preferred standard management. Fixative used for testicular biopsy is Bouin's fluid.
Solution to Question 12:
The above clinical scenario of the germ-cell tumor is suggestive of embryonal carcinoma.
It is a non-seminomatous germ cell tumor (NSGCTs) that occurs mostly in the 20 to 30 year age group. These tumors are more aggressive than seminomas. Embryonal carcinomas share some markers with seminomas such as OCT 3/4 and PLAP but differ by being positive for cytokeratin and CD30 and negative for KIT.
Most patients present with a testicular mass, which can be painful due to rapid growth and may be mistaken for torsion.
Grossly, the tumor is often variegated, poorly demarcated at the margins, and punctuated by foci of hemorrhage or necrosis.
Histologically, the cells grow in alveolar or tubular patterns, sometimes with papillary convolutions; the neoplastic cells have an epithelial appearance, are large and anaplastic, and exhibit hyperchromatic nuclei with prominent nucleoli.
The below image is the histology of embryonal carcinoma showing anaplastic cells with large hyperchromatic nuclei.


Option A: Seminoma will have sheets of uniform cells with poor, demarcated lobules divided by delicate fibrous septa infiltrated by lymphocytes. Seminomas are positive PLAP and KIT, but negative for cytokeratin and CD30.
Option C: Teratoma will show derivatives of more than one germ layer like cartilage, hairs, sebaceous glands in the histology.
Option D: Yolk sac tumor affects children up to 3 yrs of age, will have elevated alpha-fetoprotein
(AFP), and exhibit Schiller–Duval bodies on histology.
Solution to Question 13:
Marked elevation of serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels is produced by the yolk sac tumor / endodermal sinus tumor.
It is the most common testicular tumor in infants and children up to 3 years of age (prepubertal yolk sac tumor). Postpubertal yolk sac tumors are associated with germ-cell neoplasia in situ and almost always occur in mixed forms.
Grossly, pure yolk sac tumors have a homogenous, mucinous appearance.
The below image is of a yolk sac tumor showing lace-like architecture and Schiller–Duval bodies (Arrow) (a hallmark of YST), and hyaline-like globules. These structures consist of a mesodermal core with central capillary as well as a visceral and parietal layer of cells (glomeruloid pattern)


Solution to Question 14:
In post-pubertal males, teratomas are considered malignant, regardless of the presence of immature elements.
Teratomas are non-seminomatous germ cell tumors (NSGCTs), which are characteristically composed of more than one germ layer derivative (ectoderm, mesoderm, endoderm).
Teratomas have complex histopathology and 2 variants may be seen:
Mature: Adult-type, well-differentiated cells or organoid structures
Immature: Embryonal-type, undifferentiated cells or primitive neural elements
In ovarian teratomas, immature elememts are needed to consider it malignant. However, the degree of immaturity is clinically insignificant in testicular teratomas. In prepubertal children, testicular teratomas have a benign course. However, in postpubertal males, teratomas are considered malignant.
The below image shows the histology of teratoma of the testis.


Solution to Question 15:
From the given clinical scenario and image showing cytotrophoblasts and multinucleated syncytiotrophoblasts in a hemorrhagic background, the most likely primary tumor appears to be choriocarcinoma.
The syncytiotrophoblasts secrete  -hCG, at levels that serve as important serological markers. Pure choriocarcinoma, although rare, is the most aggressive non-seminomatous germ cell tumor
(NSGCT). It often does not cause any testicular enlargement; instead, it spreads rapidly via the bloodstream. This results in the frequent involvement of the lung(cannon-ball metastases) and liver and a poor prognosis.

Solution to Question 16:
With a spermatocytic tumor, affected individuals are generally older than 65 years.
A spermatocyte tumor (previously called spermatocytic seminoma) is a rare, slow-growing germ cell tumor that is distinct from classical seminoma, both clinically and histologically.
GCNIS: Germ-cell neoplasia in situ PLAP: Placental alkaline phosphatase
The below image is the histology of spermatocytic tumor showing a population of small, medium-sized, and large cells and mucoid lakes

Solution to Question 17:
The given scenario is suggestive of Leydig cell tumor of the testis.
It is the most common sex-cord stromal type of testicular neoplasm. It is mostly benign and invariably unilateral. Most cases occur between 20 and 60 years of age. However, they can present at any age.
The most common presenting feature is testicular swelling or gynecomastia (~15% of cases). In children, hormonal effects manifested primarily as sexual precocity, are the dominant
features. Tumors of Leydig cells may secrete androgens and estrogens, and even corticosteroids. Grossly it shows golden brown, homogeneous circumscribed nodules <5 cm in diameter.
Histologically:
large, round, or polygonal cells
round central nucleus and prominent nucleoli
abundant granular eosinophilic cytoplasm containing lipid droplets, vacuoles, or lipofuscin pigment
crystalloids of Reinke, rod-shaped eosinophilic cytoplasmic bodies are seen in about 25% of the tumors

Option A: Spermatocytic tumor mainly occurs in older adults as a slow-growing testicular mass. They are usually hormonally silent
Option B: Sertoli cell tumor mostly presents as a painless testicular mass. They are usually hormonally silent. Hence, gynecomastia and precocious puberty are very rare.
Option C: Granulosa cell tumor usually presents as a slow-growing and non-functioning testicular mass. Gynecomastia is rare. They usualy secrete estrogen.
Solution to Question 18:
Non-Hodgkin lymphoma is the most common testicular neoplasm in men older than 60 years. The most common types of testicular lymphomas in decreasing order of frequecy:
Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma
Burkitt lymphoma
Epstein–Barr virus - positive extranodal NK/T cell lymphoma.
Testicular lymphomas are aggressive tumors with a poor prognosis. They have a higher propensity for CNS involvement.
Solution to Question 19:
Retroperitoneal para-aortic nodes are the first to be involved in the lymphatic spread of testicular tumors.
Testicular tumors have a characteristic mode of spread:
Lymphatic spread is common to all forms of testicular tumors. Initially, it spreads to retroperitoneal para-aortic nodes, then spreads to the mediastinal and supraclavicular nodes.
Hematogenous spread is primarily to the lungs, but the liver, brain, and bones may also be involved.
Solution to Question 20:
Serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) level is raised in all the above conditions except pure choriocarcinoma and pure seminoma.
Choriocarcinomas have elevated levels of HCG, which can be readily demonstrated in the cytoplasm of syncytiotrophoblastic cells.
AFP is a marker of hepatocellular cancer and non-seminomatous germ cell tumors of testes, mainly yolk sac tumors.
Solution to Question 21:
Seminomas are extremely radiosensitive tumors.
The counterpart of seminoma, which arises in the ovary, is dysgerminoma.
Solution to Question 22:
The most common malignant paratesticular tumor in children is rhabdomyosarcoma.
The paratesticular region is an extratesticular anatomical area, which includes the contents:
Spermatic cord,
Testicular tunics,
Epididymis
Vestigial remnants, such as the appendices epididymis and testis.
The most common malignant paratesticular tumor in adults is liposarcoma. The most common benign paratesticular tumor is an adenomatoid tumor. The most common paratesticular mesenchymal tumor is a lipoma.
Solution to Question 23:
Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is not used as a tumor marker for germ-cell testicular tumors. It is an oncofetal antigen used as a tumor marker in adenocarcinoma of the colon, pancreas, lung, breast, and ovary.
Markers of germ cell testicular tumors include alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), human chorionic gonadotropin, placental alkaline phosphatase, placental lactogen, and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH).
Solution to Question 24:
Benign prostatic hyperplasia originates almost exclusively in the transitional zone, hence it is surgically removed.
Nodular hyperplasia or benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) is the most common benign prostatic disease in men above 50 years. It arises from the inner aspect of the prostate gland, i.e., the transitional zone. It is characterized by benign, hyperplastic proliferation of prostatic stroma and epithelial elements, which is driven by dihydrotestosterone. This growth progressively compresses the urethra resulting in urinary obstructive symptoms.
The normal prostate contains several distinct regions, including a central zone (CZ), peripheral zone (PZ), transitional zone (TZ), and periurethral zone, as shown in the image below.

Note: Most carcinomas arise from the peripheral zone and maybe palpable during the digital examination of the rectum.
Solution to Question 25:
The Gleason score is currently reported from 6-10.
WHO/ISUP modified Gleason score is the histopathological grading system, which corresponds with the clinical behavior of prostate cancer. It is one of the key methods used in confirmation of the diagnosis, prognostication, and staging of prostate cancer (adenocarcinoma).
The Gleason grading system is primarily based on analyzing the architecture of the tumor cells in the biopsy specimens obtained. The architecture, i.e., the Gleason Patterns are classified as:
Pattern 3: Well-formed glands
Pattern 4: Poorly formed/Fused/Cribriform glands/Glomeruloid glands
Pattern 5: Sheets of the tumor, individual cells, cords, and solid nests of cells, Comedo necrosis
Pattern 1 and 2 are no longer defined
Most tumor specimens contain more than one pattern. Therefore, a numeric grade is assigned to both the primary pattern and the next most frequent secondary pattern. The sum of the
numeric grades provides the Gleason score.
Scores 2–5 are no longer assigned.
Scores of 6 - 7 are potentially treatable cancers
Scores 8 - 10 are advanced cancers that are less likely to be cured.
Based on the gleason score, they are classified into the following grade groups:
Grade group 1: score<=6
Grade group 2: 3+4=7
Grade group 3: 4+3=7
Grade group 4: score 8
Grade group 5: scores 9-10
Solution to Question 26:
The given scenario is suggestive of prostate cancer and all cribriform patterns are now defined as Gleason pattern 4 according to the 2014 WHO/ISUP grading consensus conference.
The below image of prostate cancer with Gleason pattern 4 shows cribriform pattern

Highlights of 2014 WHO/ISUP modified Gleason score:
Gleason Pattern:
Pattern 3- Well formed glands
Pattern 4- Poorly formed/Fused/Cribriform glands/Glomeruloid glands
Pattern 5- Sheets of the tumor, individual cells, cords and solid nests of cells, Comedo necrosis
Pattern 1 and 2 are no longer defined
Gleason Score:
The current Gleason score ranges from 6–10. Scores 2–5 are no longer assigned.
Grade group:
Grade group 1: score 6
Grade group 2: 3+4=7
Grade group 3: 4+3=7
Grade group 4: score 8
Grade group 5: scores 9–10
Solution to Question 27:
The upper-age-specific reference value of serum prostate-specific antigen (PSA) in men of age 70–79 is 6.5 ng/mL.
PSA is a product of prostatic epithelium secreted in the semen. Measurement of serum PSA levels is widely used to assist the diagnosis, prognosis, and management of prostate cancer. Older men have a higher serum PSA level than younger men, so the normal range varies with age.
The serum PSA levels as a screening test for prostatic cancer has poor sensitivity and specificity. This is because various other factors such as trauma, infections, BPH, instrumentation/digital exam of the prostate, and ejaculation can increase serum PSA levels. A value of 4 ng/mL usually warrants serial testing or further evaluation.
In an effort to improve the sensitivity and specificity of serum PSA levels, many novel indices are used:
Age-specific PSA reference ranges
PSA velocity: Rate of change of PSA values with time. It is considered that PSA velocity of 0.75 ng/mL per year measured at least 3 times over a period of 1.5 to 2 yrs is significant to diagnose Prostate cancer.
PSA density: Serum PSA/volume of the prostate gland
The ratio of free to bound serum PSA
Age
Upper age-specific PSA(ng/m L)

Solution to Question 1:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute hepatocellular injury due to ischemia. Zone 3 (centrilobular zone) of the liver is most susceptible for ischemia because this zone is the farthest from the blood supply.
On the basis of blood flow, liver parenchyma can be divided into three zones. Zone 1 is closest to the blood supply and zone 3 is the farthest. They are:
Zone 1 - Periportal (around portal triad)
Zone 2 - Midzonal parenchyma
Zone 3 - Centrilobular (around hepatic vein)
A schematic diagram showing the hepatic lobule indicating the direction of blood flow and the zones of decreasing oxygenation is given below.

Note: Zone most susceptible to toxin damage is zone 1.
Solution to Question 2:
Centrilobular necrosis is not seen in yellow fever. In yellow fever, swelling and necrosis of hepatocytes are seen in the midzone of the liver lobule.
Conditions causing tissue injury in the different zones of liver:
Centrilobular (Zone 3)
Chronic venous congestion (cardiac failure)
Acetaminophen toxicity
Budd Chiari syndrome
Ischemia
Alcoholic hepatitis
Midzonal (Zone 2)
Yellow fever
Periportal (Zone 1)
Viral hepatitis
A schematic diagram showing the hepatic lobule indicating the direction of blood flow and the zones of decreasing oxygenation is given below.

Solution to Question 3:
The principal cell type involved in scar deposition in cirrhosis of the liver is the hepatic stellate cell or Ito cell.
Hepatic stellate cells deposit primarily type I and type III collagen in the lobule and cause fibrosis. In their quiescent form, these cells store lipids and vitamin A.
Solution to Question 4:
Steatosis or fatty change of liver is not seen in hepatitis B infections.
Steatosis is the abnormal accumulation of triglycerides within a cell due to impaired lipid metabolism. In the liver, pathological steatosis is defined as fatty change involving >5% of hepatocytes. In the histologic sections, they appear as empty vacuoles within the hepatocyte
cytoplasm.
Hepatitis C genotype 3 is reported to cause periportal steatosis. It is due to its association with metabolic syndrome and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
In Wilson's disease, there is focal hepatocyte necrosis and steatosis due to toxic injury by the excess copper.
In protein malnutrition, fatty liver results from the reduced synthesis of the carrier protein component of lipoproteins.
Solution to Question 5:
Macrovesicular fatty liver (steatosis) is seen in obesity.
Macrovesicular steatosis is characterized by a single, large vacuole of fat that fills up the hepatocyte and displaces the nucleus to the periphery. Causes include:
Late alcoholic liver disease
Obesity
Protein-energy malnutrition
Non-alcohlic steatohepatitis (NASH)
Chronic hepatitis C
Microvesicular steatosis is characterized by small intracytoplasmic fat vacuoles, which accumulate in the cell. Causes include:
Acute fatty liver of pregnancy
Reye syndrome
Early alcoholic liver disease
Drugs and toxins
The image given below shows macrovesicular and microvesicular steatosis of liver:

Solution to Question 6:
The liver biopsy in Reye's syndrome will show marked microvesicular steatosis.
Reye's syndrome is an acute illness, encountered exclusively in children <15 years. Its onset usually follows upper respiratory tract infections. The actual cause is unknown, although viral agents and salicylates (aspirin) have been implicated.
Pathogenesis behind this condition is generalized mitochondrial dysfunction with structural and functional alterations of mitochondria in the liver, brain, and muscle. Liver is enlarged but jaundice is absent or minimum. It is characterized by clinical features such as:
Vomiting
Signs of progressive CNS damage
Signs of hepatic injury
Hypoglycemia
Extensive accumulation of fat droplets within hepatocytes (microvesicular steatosis) can be seen in histopathology. Extra-hepatic changes include fatty changes of renal tubular cells, cerebral edema, and neuronal degeneration of the brain.
The image given below shows microvesicular steatosis of liver.

Note: Aspirin is generally contraindicated in children, except in the treatment of Kawasaki disease and juvenile idiopathic arthritis.
Solution to Question 7:
The marked structure in the image is Mallory hyaline body which is not seen in primary sclerosing cholangitis. In this condition, onion skin fibrosis is seen.
Mallory hyaline bodies (Mallory–Denk bodies) are usually present as clumped, amorphous, eosinophilic material in ballooned hepatocytes. They are made up of cytokeratin 8 and cytokeratin

Solution to Question 11:
The presence of lymphoid follicles is not a feature on liver biopsy in patients with non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH). It is a feature of chronic hepatitis C infection.
The histopathological features of NASH include:
Ballooning degeneration of hepatocytes
Steatosis

Portal fibrosis
Mallory-Denk bodies
Mononuclear infiltrate

Solution to Question 12:
The most common hepatotoxin causing acute liver failure is acetaminophen.
Acetaminophen itself is not toxic. The toxic metabolite produced by the cytochrome P-450 system in zone 3 hepatocytes causes hepatocellular necrosis.
The most common hepatotoxin causing chronic liver failure is alcohol.
Solution to Question 13:
Hepatitis A does not cause chronic infection. It is usually a benign, self-limited disease.
Hepatitis B, C, and D can cause chronic infection. Hepatitis E causes chronic infection only in immunocompromised individuals, not in immunocompetent.
Solution to Question 14:
Hepatitis A virus (HAV) can cause acute hepatic failure in a few patients. However, it does not cause chronic hepatitis or a carrier state.
HAV is a usually benign, self-limited disease, with an incubation period of 15- 50 days (2 - 6 weeks).
HAV is spread by feco-oral route and is shed in the stool for 2 to 3 weeks before and 1 week after the onset of jaundice. It can also spread by sexual route. Diagnosis is by the detection of serum IgM anti HAV.
Since it does not progress to chronic infection, it does not cause hepatocellular carcinoma. The fatality rate associated with HAV is only about 0.1-0.3%.
Solution to Question 15:
Hepatitis E virus (HEV) infection accounts for most of the cases of sporadic acute hepatitis in India. It exceeds the frequency of hepatitis A virus infection.
A feature of HEV infection is the high mortality rate among pregnant women, approaching 20%.
Solution to Question 16:
HBx protein has been implicated in the pathogenesis of hepatocellular carcinoma in hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection. HBx protein is involved in the intracellular regulation of virus replication, transcription, and signal transduction.
Option A: HBsAg (surface antigen) indicates current hepatitis B infection.
Option B: HBeAg (precore antigen) is an indicator of active viral replication. It is a qualitative marker of infectivity.
Option C: HBV DNA polymerase is an indicator of active viral replication. It is a quantitative marker of infectivity.
Solution to Question 17:
During the window period of hepatitis B, the serologic diagnosis can be made by the detection of IgM anti-HBc antibody.
The window period of hepatitis B refers to the time between the disappearance of the HBsAg antigen and appearance of Anti-HBs antibody.
The window period for a test designed to detect a specific disease is the time between the first infection and when the test can reliably detect that infection.
Solution to Question 18:
In patients who are both HBsAg and HBeAg positive, declining IgM anti-HBc and rising total anti-HBc are indicative of chronic infective hepatitis.
Anti-HBc IgM antibody signifies acute infection/window period, whereas, the presence of IgG anti-HBc indicates chronic infection. However, there is no test available to directly detect the IgG
anti-HBC. Over a period of months, the IgM anti-HBc antibodies are replaced by the IgG anti-HBc antibodies. Thus a decline of IgM antibodies in the presence of rising total anti-HBC indicates that the IgM is being converted to IgG and thus the infection is chronic.
HBeAg, HBV-DNA, and DNA polymerase appear in serum soon after HBsAg, and all signify active viral replication.
Occasionally, mutated strains of HBV emerge that do not produce HBeAg but are replication-competent and express HBcAg.
Solution to Question 19:
The age at the time of infection is the best predictor of chronicity. Younger the age at the time of hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection, higher the probability of chronicity.
Other predictors in the development of chronic disease:
comorbid conditions (including exposure to other infectious agents)
host immunity
Presentations of hepatitis B infection:
Asymptomatic - 65%
Non-specific symptoms - 25%
Chronic disease - 5-10%
Acute fulminant liver disease - 0.1-0.5%
Solution to Question 20:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute hepatitis B infection. Ground-glass hepatocytes are not seen in the liver biopsy of such patients.
Histopathological findings in acute hepatits are:
Ballooning degeneration - due to inflammation
Portal or lobular inflammatory infiltration - lymphocytes, plasma cells, and eosinophils
Necrosis
Confluent necrosis - group of hepatocytes
Panlobular or panacinar necrosis - entire lobule
Bridging necrosis (in severe cases) - connecting vascular structures
Ground-glass appearance of hepatocytes is due to the endoplasmic reticulum which is swollen with HBsAg accumulation. It is a diagnostic hallmark of chronic hepatitis B infection.
The image given below shows ground glass hepatocytes in the liver biopsy.


Solution to Question 21:
Intranasal cocaine abuse is a risk factor for hepatitis C.
Contaminated implements (like straws used to inhale cocaine) inserted into the nasal cavity might come into contact with hepatitis C virus (HCV)-infected mucus or blood. This might then be transmitted to a susceptible individual while sharing the same implements.
Transmission of hepatitis C infection:
Intravenous drug abuse (54%) - Most common
Multiple sex partners
Needle-stick injury
Multiple contacts with a person with hepatitis C virus infection
Employment in medical or dental fields
Blood transfusion
Perinatal - major route of infection in children
Solution to Question 22:
The most common clinical course seen in hepatitis C infection is chronic carrier state.
Acute clinical illness is often asymptomatic/mild with a high rate of conversion to chronic hepatitis (~85%).

Solution to Question 23:
Hepatitis C virus (HCV) genotype 3 is associated with metabolic syndrome.
HCV can give rise to insulin resistance and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
Solution to Question 24:
Ballooning degeneration is not associated with chronic hepatitis. It is seen in acute hepatitis. Histopathological findings in chronic viral hepatitis are:
Portal lymphocytic/ lymphoplasmacytic inflammation
Interface activity - inflammatory cells cross the limiting plate and cause periportal hepatocyte injury
Portal, periportal, and portoportal bridging fibrosis
Specific findings in viral hepatitis:
Hepatitis B - ground glass hepatocytes
Hepatitis C - lymphoid aggregates and steatosis
Solution to Question 25:
Serum alkaline phosphatase is used to evaluate biliary excretory function. It is not used to evaluate the synthetic function of hepatocytes.
Serum ammonia, activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), and serum albumin are used to evaluate hepatic synthetic function.
Prothrombin time (PT), aPTT and serum ammonia levels are increased in liver failure, whereas serum albumin level is decreased.
Solution to Question 26:
Macronodular cirrhosis is not seen in the histopathological examination of patients with malaria. Histopathological changes in the liver in cases of malaria include the following:
Kupffer cell hyperplasia
Hemozoin pigment deposition within Kupffer cells and macrophages
Focal necrosis
Mild mononuclear portal infiltrate
Fatty change and periportal inflammation
Solution to Question 27:
Councilman bodies are apoptotic hepatocytes seen in acute hepatitis and yellow fever.
Option A: Mallory–Denk bodies are eosinophilic materials made of keratin intermediate filaments. They are seen in alcoholic liver disease, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, Wilson's disease, and chronic biliary tract diseases.
Option C: Ground-glass hepatocytes are liver cells that have eosinophilic granular, glassy cytoplasm seen on light microscopy. The appearance is due to the swelling of the endoplasmic reticulum by HBsAg and is a diagnostic hallmark of chronic hepatitis B.
Option D: Circumferential onion skin fibrosis around a degenerating bile-duct lumen is seen in primary sclerosing cholangitis.
Solution to Question 28:
Obstructive portal vein thrombosis is the prehepatic cause of portal hypertension.
Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, cirrhosis, and schistosomiasis are intrahepatic causes of portal hypertension. The most dominant cause is cirrhosis.
Solution to Question 29:
Bridging fibrosis is not seen in non-cirrhotic portal fibrosis. In this condition, there is periportal and perisinusoidal fibrosis. The fibrous septa end blindly in the lobule and do not bridge with other portal tracts, unlike those seen in cirrhosis.
Idiopathic non-cirrhotic portal hypertension (INCPH) is a rare disease characterized by intrahepatic portal hypertension in the absence of cirrhosis or other causes of liver disease and splanchnic venous thrombosis.
A liver biopsy is essential in making a diagnosis of INCPH. The features observed are as follows:
Luminal narrowing or obliteration of portal vein branches
Micronodular transformation
Sinusoidal dilatation with formation of mega sinusoids
Periportal and perisinusoidal fibrosis
Solution to Question 30:
In the given image, images marked 1 is normal liver, 2 is alcoholic steatosis, 3 is micronodular cirrhosis and 4 is alcoholic hepatitis.
Histopathological findings in the following conditions are:
Alcoholic steatosis:
A mix of small and large fat droplets
Ethanol inhibits fatty acid metabolism, leading to lipolysis and increased triglyceride. These triglycerides accumulate and cause steatosis. Liver enzymes are normal at this stage.
Micronodular cirrhosis:
The average nodule size is 3 mm in this close-up view, which is typical of the micronodular cirrhosis of alcoholic liver disease
Alcoholic hepatitis:
Mallory-Denk bodies - clumped, amorphous, eosinophilic material in ballooned hepatocytes. These inclusions are characteristic, but not a specific feature of alcoholic liver disease.

Solution to Question 1:
Wilson's disease is caused due to a loss-of-function mutation in the ATP7B gene. It an autosomal recessive condition.
The ATP7B gene is located on chromosome 13q. The gene encodes a copper transporting ATPase
(ATP7B) which has 2 functions:
Maintains copper in bound form by binding copper to apoceruloplasmin
Helps excrete free copper in bile.
The resulting ATP7B deficiency leads to reduced bound copper and impaired free copper excretion. This causes excess deposition of free copper in the tissues, particularly in the liver, brain and eye.
Menkes disease is an X-linked recessive condition leading to impaired absorption of copper and subsequent copper deficiency. Here, the mutation is in the ATP7A gene.
Solution to Question 2:
The given image shows the Kayser-Fleischer ring. This,along with the background of hepatitis and neuropsychiatric features is characteristic of Wilson's disease. The patient is thus likely to have basal ganglia atrophy.
In the majority of cases, neuropsychiatric manifestations follow hepatic manifestations. It is due to the deposition of free copper in the basal ganglia and cortex. Free copper deposition in the basal ganglia leads to bilateral degeneration and atrophy.
Solution to Question 3:
Genetic testing for the ATP7B gene is used to screen asymptomatic 1st and 2nd-degree relatives of patients with Wilson's disease. This helps to differentiate the heterozygous from the homozygous individuals. This can be useful in the early initiation of treatment before the onset of symptoms.
Low serum ceruloplasmin, raised 24 hr urinary copper and Kayser-Fleischer rings are diagnostically helpful.
Estimation of hepatic tissue copper is the gold standard for diagnosis. It is measured using neutron activation analysis / atomic absorption spectrometry.
Solution to Question 4:
The ceruloplasmin level in the blood decreases, and the copper content in urine increases in Wilson's disease.
