Solution to Question 5:
Excess copper deposition in Wilson's disease is demonstrated by rhodanine stain. Microscopic findings in Wilson's disease include:
Fatty infiltration (macrovesicular)
Glycogen deposition in periportal hepatocytes
Macronodular cirrhosis in decompensated stages.
Orcein stain is used to stain copper-associated proteins (eg: ceruloplasmin).
Solution to Question 6:
The patient most likely suffers from hemochromatosis. In the given scenario, the liver microscopy image shows hepatocellular iron, which is stained blue with Perl's Prussian blue stain.
Hemochromatosis is an inherited or acquired metabolic disorder caused by excessive iron absorption. Iron overload leads to the accumulation of iron in parenchymal organs such as the liver and pancreas followed by the heart, joints, and endocrine organs.
The image below shows the triad of haemochromatosis.

The image below is the liver microscopy image showing hepatocellular iron, stained with Perl's Prussian blue.

The total body iron pool ranges from 2 to 6 gm in normal adults. In hemochromatosis, total iron accumulation may exceed 50 gm, more than one-third of which accumulates in the liver.
Solution to Question 7:
HFE gene is located on the short arm of chromosome 6 (6p). It is the most commonly mutated gene in patients with hereditary hemochromatosis.
HFE encodes an HLA class I–like molecule that regulates the synthesis of hepcidin in hepatocytes. The most common HFE mutation is a cysteine-to-tyrosine substitution at amino acid 282 (C282Y).
Solution to Question 8:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hemochromatosis. A patient with hemochromatosis is at risk of developing hepatocellular carcinoma.
Hepatocellular carcinoma is a significant cause of death in hemochromatosis. The risk is much greater than in the general population.
The disease progression of hemochromatosis is as shown below:

Solution to Question 9:
Neonatal hemochromatosis is not an inherited disease. It is a disease of unknown origin manifested by severe liver disease and extrahepatic hemosiderin deposition. It might be related to maternal alloimmune injury to the fetal liver.
Adult hemochromatosis is generally a milder disease than the juvenile form. With treatment, life expectancy is normal.
Bantu siderosis or African iron overload is due to dietary iron overload. Consumption of beer prepared in iron pots or drums is the cause of dietary iron overload.
Skin pigmentation in hemochromatosis mostly results from increased melanin synthesis. This is due to iron deposition and not hemosiderin deposition.
In severe hemochromatosis, total iron accumulation may exceed 50 gm. More than one-third of this accumulates in the liver. In normal adults, it is in the range of 2 to 6 gms.
Solution to Question 10:
The testes do not show hemosiderin deposits in hemochromatosis.
Hypogonadism in hemochromatosis is not due to the deposition of iron in the testis. It is due to a derangement in the hypothalamic-pituitary axis. This results in decreased gonadotrophins and testosterone levels. The testis will appear small and atrophic.
Deposition of hemosiderin is seen in the following organs in the decreasing order of severity:
Liver
Pancreas
Myocardium
Pituitary gland
Adrenal gland
Thyroid
Parathyroid gland
Joints
Skin
Solution to Question 11:
In the given clinical scenario, the most likely diagnosis is alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. The liver biopsy image shows periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive and diastase-resistant round-to-oval cytoplasmic globular inclusions in hepatocytes. These are characteristic of alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.
It is an autosomal-recessive disorder of protein misfolding that results in impaired secretion of 1 antitrypsin into the serum. 1AT deficiency results in excessive degradation of alveoli by neutrophil elastase causing panacinar emphysema. It also causes liver disease as a consequence of an abnormal accumulation of the misfolded protein within hepatocytes. Cutaneous necrotizing panniculitis also occurs in a minor subset of patients. Hepatocellular carcinoma develops in 2% to 3% of cases.
The image given is a photomicrograph of a liver biopsy from a patient with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. The PAS with diastase stain shows the diastase-resistant pink globules that are characteristic of this disease.

Solution to Question 12:
The gene for alpha-1 antitrypsin is located on the long arm of chromosome 14. Alpha-1 antitrypsin is a plasma glycoprotein synthesized predominantly by hepatocytes.
For 1-antitrypsin genes, the general notation is “Pi” for “protease inhibitor." An alphabetic letter is given for the position on the isoelectric gel.
This gene has different alleles that produce different amounts of alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT).
M allele - normal levels of the AAT protein
S allele - moderately low levels
Z allele - very low levels
The alleles are expressed in a codominant manner.
Solution to Question 13:
The most common clinically significant mutation causing 1-antitrypsin deficiency is
PiZ. Homozygous individuals, with PiZZ, have only 10% of normal circulating 1-antitrypsin. So, they are at high risk of developing clinical disease.
PiMM is the most common genotype seen in normal individuals, present in about 90% of individuals.
PiS variant is clinically asymptomatic.
Pi-null is a rare variant with no detectable serum alpha-1 antitrypsin.
Solution to Question 14:
Bile duct injury and granulomas are uncommon in autoimmune hepatitis except in case of overlap with primary biliary cirrhosis.
Autoimmune hepatitis (AIH) is characterised by extensive inflammation, fibrosis and ultimately cirrhosis. The pathologic features include:
Emperipolesis - Lymphocytes and plasma cells within the cytoplasm of hepatocytes.
Interface hepatitis or piecemeal necrosis.
Rosette formation due to necrosis of groups of hepatocytes and resultant regeneration.
The image given below shows autoimmune hepatitis with lymphoplasmacytic interface hepatitis.


Solution to Question 15:
Type 2 autoimmune hepatitis shows anti-liver kidney microsomal autoantibodies (anti-LKM1) and anti–liver cytosol-1 (ACL-1) antibodies not ANA.
Type 1 autoimmune hepatitis shows anti-nuclear (ANA), anti-smooth muscle antibodies (ASMA) and anti–soluble liver antigen / liver pancreas antigen (anti-SLA/LP) antibodies. It less commonly shows anti-mitochondrial (AMA) antibodies.
Autoimmune hepatitis is a chronic disorder characterized by continuing hepatocellular necrosis and inflammation. It can progress to cirrhosis and liver failure.
Histocompatibility haplotypes such as HLA-B1, HLA-B8, HLA-DR3, and HLA-DR4 are common in patients with autoimmune hepatitis.
Histopathological features include:
Plasma cell predominance in inflammatory infiltrates
Extensive interface hepatitis (piecemeal necrosis)
Hepatocyte rosettes
The image given below shows autoimmune hepatitis showing characteristic lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate and interface hepatitis.

Solution to Question 16:
Anti-TIF1 antibodies are not associated with autoimmune hepatitis. Anti-TIF1 antibodies are found in patients with dermatomyositis.
Solution to Question 17:
Chronic hepatitis D is associated with anti-LKM 3 antibodies.
Solution to Question 18:
Onion-skin fibrosis is seen in primary sclerosing cholangitis.
The smaller ducts in primary sclerosing cholangitis show a striking circumferential “onion skin” fibrosis around an increasingly atrophic duct lumen. This eventually leads to the obliteration by a “tombstone” scar.
The image shows primary sclerosing cholangitis. There is a degenerating bile duct that is entrapped in the dense concentric onion-skin fibrosis.

Solution to Question 19:
Primary sclerosing cholangitis is characterized by inflammation and obliterative fibrosis of intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts. There is dilation of preserved segments.
On histopathologic examination, large ducts show acute neutrophilic inflammation of the epithelium. The inflamed areas develop strictures. Small ducts show onion-skin fibrosis around the atrophic duct lumen. There is an obliteration of ducts by a tombstone scar.
Solution to Question 20:
Primary biliary cholangitis is most commonly associated with Sjogren's syndrome. Other associated conditions are:
Thyroiditis
Scleroderma
Rheumatoid arthritis
Raynaud phenomenon
Celiac disease
PBC is an autoimmune disease. It is characterized by nonsuppurative, inflammatory destruction of small and medium-sized intrahepatic bile ducts. Large intrahepatic ducts and the extrahepatic biliary tree are not involved. It is a disease of middle-aged women, with a female predominance of 9:1. Antimitochondrial antibodies are the most characteristic laboratory finding in PBC.
Histopathologic examination shows diagnostic florid duct lesions. These are lymphoplasmacytic infiltrates with or without granulomas centred around the bile duct. They also show
Mallory–Denk bodies.
The image given below shows primary biliary cholangitis.

Cavernous hemangioma is the most common benign tumor of the liver.
It appears as a red-blue, soft nodule, usually < 2 cm in diameter. It may be mistaken radiographically or intraoperatively for a metastatic tumor.
Solution to Question 2:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hepatic adenoma.  -catenin-activated adenomas have a high risk of malignant transformation.
Hepatic adenomas are benign tumors of hepatocytes. Spontaneous rupture of the hepatic adenoma may cause intraabdominal bleeding, which is a surgical emergency.
Hepatic adenomas are classified into 3 subtypes:
HNF1--inactivated adenomas -
No risk of malignant transformation
Often associated with oral contraceptive pill use (OCP) and MODY-3
 -catenin-activated adenoma -
High risk of malignant transformation
Associated with oral contraceptive pills (OCP) and anabolic steroids usage
Inflammatory adenomas -
Associated with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD)
Upregulation of C-reactive protein (CRP) and serum amyloid A

Hepatoblastoma is the most common malignant liver tumor of early childhood, usually < 3 years. Serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is the most important clinical marker for hepatoblastoma. It remains the key clinical marker of malignant change, response to the treatment, and relapse.

Activation of WNT signaling plays a major role in hepatoblastomas. This occurs by a variety of mechanisms including mutations in APC gene. Hence, patients with FAP syndromes frequently develop hepatoblastomas.

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of fibrolamellar carcinoma. It is usually not associated with liver cirrhosis.
Fibrolamellar carcinoma is a distinctive and rare variant of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). It usually occurs < 35 years of age. There is no gender predilection and no identifiable predisposing conditions. It has a good prognosis compared to the classical HCC. Majority

Hepatic angiosarcoma is associated with exposure to arsenic, thorotrast and vinyl chloride.
Angiosarcoma is a malignant endothelial neoplasm. There is equal gender predilection. The tumor may occur at any site, but most often involves skin, soft tissue, breast and liver.

Solution to Question 12:
The most common tumors of the liver are metastatic tumors. The common primary sources of liver metastasis are:
Colon carcinoma
Breast carcinoma
Lung carcinoma
Pancreatic carcinoma
Solution to Question 13:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a metastatic liver tumor.
Metastases are the most common malignant neoplasms of the liver. The most common primary sources are the colon, breast, lung, and pancreas, although any cancer at any site of the body may spread to the liver.
Patients with metastases typically have multiple nodules replacing the normal liver parenchyma. There may be no clinical or laboratory evidence of hepatic insufficiency. Often, the only telltale sign of secondaries in the liver will be hepatomegaly.
Solution to Question 14:
Typhoid carriers are not at risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma.
Cholangiocarcinoma is the second most common primary malignant tumor of the liver after hepatocellular carcinoma. It is a malignancy of the biliary tree, arising from bile ducts within and outside of the liver.
The risk factors for cholangiocarcinoma include the following:
Infestation by liver flukes (particularly Opisthorchis and Clonorchis )
Primary sclerosing cholangitis, and other chronic inflammatory diseases of the large bile ducts
Chronic hepatitis B and C infections
Cirrhosis
Inflammatory bowel disease
Diabetes mellitus, obesity, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD)
Alcohol and tobacco
Precursor lesions -
Biliary intraepithelial neoplasias
Mucinous cystic neoplasms
Intraductal papillary biliary neoplasia
Solution to Question 15:
Klatskin tumors are extrahepatic cholangiocarcinomas located in the perihilar region.
These tumors are located at the junction of the right and left hepatic ducts. Distal tumors arise in the common bile duct posterior to the duodenum. Regardless of the site, the prognosis is poor.
Solution to Question 16:
Gallbladder carcinoma carries a poor prognosis because it is typically detected late due to non-specific symptoms.
Carcinoma of the gallbladder is the most common malignancy of the extrahepatic biliary tract. Most carcinomas of the gall bladder are adenocarcinomas.
Gallbladder cancer is at least twice as common in women than in men. The most important risk factor for gallbladder cancer (besides gender and ethnicity) is gallstones, which are present in 95% of cases. Her-2/neu is overexpressed in around 2/3 of the cases, and therefore, they can be targeted for therapy.

Solution to Question 1:
The most common congenital anomaly of the gallbladder is the Phrygian cap. It refers to an inward folding of the fundus of the gallbladder. It is named for its resemblance to a conical hat.


The other common congenital anomalies of the gallbladder are:
Agenesis - absence of all or any portion of the hepatic or common bile ducts
Biliary atresia - hypoplastic narrowing of biliary channels
Choledochal cysts - congenital dilations of the intra and/or extrahepatic biliary system
Solution to Question 2:
The given image shows pigmented gallstones, which are not associated with hyperlipidemia syndromes.
Pigmented gallstones are made of bilirubin and calcium salts. They can occur in:
Chronic hemolytic syndromes
Ileal resection
Biliary infection
Cystic fibrosis with pancreatic insufficiency
Cholesterol stones are made of crystalline cholesterol monohydrates. Dyslipidemia is a risk factor for the development of cholesterol gallstones.
The following image shows cholesterol gallstones:

Solution to Question 3:
This clinical scenario of chronic cholecystitis and image showing lipid-laden xanthoma cells are suggestive of xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis. This condition results due to the rupture of Rokitansky–Aschoff sinuses.

Rokitansky–Aschoff sinuses are bile-filled outpouchings of the gallbladder mucosa through the gallbladder wall. They develop in reaction to chronic inflammation of the gallbladder. Eventually, they may rupture into the wall of the gallbladder. This results in the accumulation of macrophages that have ingested biliary phospholipids, which are called xanthoma cells.

Chronic cholecystitis may have other sequelae:
Porcelain gallbladder - dystrophic calcification of the gallbladder wall
Hyalinizing cholecystitis - replacement of the gallbladder wall by dense fibrosis, with or without calcification (leads to higher incidence of gallbladder carcinoma)
Hydrops of the gallbladder - atrophic, obstructed, dilated gallbladder containing clear fluid Acute cholecystitis includes the following variants:
Emphysematous cholecystitis - acute infection of the gallbladder by gas-forming organisms
Acalculous cholecystitis - due to gallbladder stasis and ischemia
Solution to Question 4:
Pancreas divisum is the most common congenital anomaly of the pancreas.
The pancreas develops by fusion of the larger dorsal and smaller ventral pancreatic buds. The dorsal duct is the dominant duct during development and it drains into the minor papilla. The ventral duct drains into the major papilla. After fusion, the following ducts are formed:
Main pancreatic duct (of Wirsung) - formed by fusion of ducts of dorsal and ventral buds, drains into the major papilla
Accessory pancreatic duct (of Santorini) - formed by the proximal portion of the dorsal duct, drains into the minor papilla
In pancreas divisum, the ventral and dorsal ducts fail to fuse. Hence, the majority of the pancreas continues to drain through the dominant dorsal duct that enters the duodenum at the minor
papilla while the ventral duct, along with the bile duct, drains into the major papilla. These patients are more prone to pancreatitis.

The other congenital anomalies of the pancreas are:
Annular pancreas - band-like ring of normal pancreatic tissue encircling 2nd part of duodenum, may cause obstruction
Ectopic pancreas - common in stomach, duodenum, and jejunum (found in about 2% of postmortem exams)
Agenesis - rarely seen, associated with mutations of PDX1 (homeobox gene)
Solution to Question 5:
This clinical scenario in a young patient with positive family history of similar episodes is suggestive of hereditary pancreatitis. Acute episodes of pancreatitis can be precipitated by hypercalcemia, not hypocalcemia.
The following genes are implicated in hereditary pancreatitis:
Gain-of-function mutation in trypsinogen gene (PRSS1) - most common
Loss-of-function mutation in trypsin inhibitor gene (SPINK1)
Loss of CFTR - abnormal secretions that promote protein plugging, duct obstruction, leading t pancreatitis
Hereditary pancreatitis is associated with a 40% lifetime risk of developing pancreatic cancer.
Solution to Question 6:
The presence of the above clinical symptoms with migratory thrombophlebitis (Trousseau syndrome) and elevated serum levels of CEA and CA 19-9 in an elderly man point to a diagnosis of pancreatic cancer. The most frequently associated mutation with this condition is K-RAS.
It is attributed to the production of platelet-aggregating factors and procoagulants from the tumor or its necrotic products. Both venous and arterial thrombi can occur. Venous thrombi can embolize to the lungs.
Molecular alterations involved in pancreatic carcinogenesis are:
Following genes are associated with an inherited predisposition to pancreatic cancer:
BRCA2 mutation - pancreatic cancer, breast cancer, prostate cancer, and ovarian cancers
PRSS1 mutation - pancreatic carcinoma secondary to hereditary pancreatitis

Solution to Question 7:
Mucinous cystic neoplasms of the pancreas have dense stroma, similar to the ovarian stroma.
These tumors have large cystic cavities filled with thick, tenacious mucin. They are lined by columnar, mucin-producing epithelium with dense stroma. This results in similarity to ovarian stroma.
They usually arise in the tail of the pancreas and can be precursors to invasive carcinomas. They are associated with mutations in the KRAS oncogene, and the tumor-suppressor genes TP53 and RNF43.
Solution to Question 8:
Patients with carcinoma of the head of the pancreas develop jaundice due to obstruction of the biliary tract.
Cigarette smoking doubles the risk of pancreatic cancer and is the leading preventable cause. The clinical features depend on the location of the tumor.
Head - painless, palpable gallbladder with mild jaundice is suggestive of malignancy (according to Courvoisier's law)
Body and tail - may remain asymptomatic until later stages as they do not impinge on the biliary tract and do not cause jaundice
Other common pathological features of this condition are:
Desmoplastic reaction - growth of fibrous or connective tissue
Perineural invasion, as well as lymphatic and large vessel invasion

Solution to Question 1:
The esophagus is the most common site of fistulization in the gastrointestinal tract (GIT).
A tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) is an abnormal fistula communication between the esophagus and trachea. The fistula is usually present near the tracheal bifurcation, with or without esophageal atresia. A blind proximal pouch with a distal tracheooesophageal fistula is the most common type of tracheoesophageal fistula (Type C).

Solution to Question 2:
The most frequent site of the ectopic gastric mucosa is the upper third of the esophagus, where it is referred to as an inlet patch.
It is congenital and mostly asymptomatic. Occasionally, it can release acid, which can result in dysphagia, esophagitis, Barrett esophagus, or, rarely, adenocarcinoma.
Solution to Question 3:
The given clinical scenario and barium swallow image are diagnostic of Zenker’s diverticulum. It occurs due to a defect in the Killian's triangle (Killian's dehiscence).
Killian's triangle is an anatomical triangular area bordered superiorly by the firm oblique fibers of the thyropharyngeus muscle and inferiorly by the horizontal fibers of the cricopharyngeus muscle. It is located immediately above the upper esophageal sphincter.
Although the Killian-Jamieson diverticulum is an anterolateral defect, it is rarely symptomatic.
Solution to Question 4:
Paterson–Brown–Kelly or Plummer–Vinson syndrome is associated with non-progressive dysphagia, especially with incompletely chewed food.
This syndrome is common in women aged >40 years. The other components of this syndrome are:
Post-cricoid webs in the upper esophagus
Iron-deficiency anemia
Glossitis
Cheilosis
Esophageal webs are idiopathic, semi-circumferential lesions composed of fibrovascular connective tissue and overlying epithelium. They are usually limited to the proximal esophagus and may cause obstruction. They are associated with:
Plummer–Vinson syndrome
Gastroesophageal reflux disease
Chronic graft-versus-host disease
Blistering skin diseases

Esophageal rings are circumferential and thick. They include mucosa, submucosa, and occasionally, hypertrophic muscularis propria. There are 3 types:

Solution to Question 6:
The given clinical scenario and barium swallow showing the bird-beak appearance are suggestive of achalasia cardia. With respect to this patient's travel history, Chagas' disease due to infection with Trypanosoma cruzi must be suspected.
The infection destroys the myenteric plexus which results in failure of peristalsis and esophageal dilatation. Duodenal, colonic, and ureteric myenteric plexuses can also be affected by Chagas' disease.
Solution to Question 7:
Achalasia cardia is characterized by decreased release of NO(nitric oxide) and VIP(vasoactive intestinal polypeptide) in the distal part of esophagus.
Normally, NO and VIP are secreted by the inhibitory neurons of the Auerbach's plexus in the distal esophagus. This leads to relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES). In achalasia cardia, these inhibitory neurons degenerate leading to decreased release of NO and VIP. This causes increased LES tone.
The triad of achalasia cardia is as follows:
Incomplete relaxation of LES
Increased tone of LES
Absent peristalsis (aperistalisis)

Solution to Question 10:
The symptoms of the patient in the above case scenario and the image showing calcinosis are the characteristic findings of the CREST syndrome or limited scleroderma. Patients with this condition characteristically have antibodies directed against centromeric proteins
(anti-centromere antibodies).
CREST syndrome is characterized by the following:
Calcinosis
Raynaud phenomenon
Esophageal dysmotility
Sclerodactyly
Telangiectasia
In the esophagus, progressive atrophy and fibrous replacement of the muscularis propria leads to hypomotility and dysphagia. The lower 2/3 of the esophagus develops a
rubber-hose–like inflexibility. The associated dysfunction of the lower esophageal sphincter gives rise to gastroesophageal reflux, Barrett metaplasia, and stricture.
Solution to Question 11:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of a Mallory–Weiss tear. They require only conservative management and healing tends to be rapid and complete.
They are longitudinal mucosal tears that may cross the gastroesophageal junction (GEJ).
F rceful retching or vomiting along with failure of reflex relaxation of the gastroesophageal musculature results in tears involving the mucosa and submucosa. It usually occurs secondary t conditions like acute alcohol intoxication or hyperemesis gravidarum.
Boerhaave syndrome is a much more serious disorder characterized by transmural rupture of the distal esophagus. This results in acute mediastinitis with severe chest pain, tachypnea, and shock. Such patients generally require urgent surgical intervention.
Solution to Question 12:
The most frequent cause of esophagitis is reflux of gastric acid into the lower esophagus.
The most common cause of gastroesophageal reflux is transient lower esophageal sphincter relaxation. Reflux esophagitis leads to chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). This can cause Barrett's esophagus and eventually can cause adenocarcinoma.
Solution to Question 13:
Esophagitis in healthy individuals can be caused by the Herpes simplex virus. However, it is relatively uncommon.
In immunosuppressed individuals, infections can be caused by:
Herpes simplex virus
Cytomegalovirus
Candida
Solution to Question 14:
Infection with Herpes simplex virus (HSV) typically results in punched-out ulcers in the esophagus.
HSV esophagitis commonly occurs in immunocompromised patients. For diagnosis, the biopsy sample should be taken from the edge of the ulcer. The following microscopic findings are noted:
Ballooning degeneration
Ground-glass changes in nuclei
Cowdry type A intranuclear inclusion bodies

Note: CMV esophagitis causes shallow ulcerations. The biopsy is taken from the base of the ulcer and shows characteristic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions bodies.
Solution to Question 15:
This clinical scenario and image showing bleeding esophageal varices are suggestive of hepatic schistosomiasis. It is the second most common cause of varices worldwide.
Liver cirrhosis, mostly in association with alcoholic liver disease, is the most common cause of varices.
Solution to Question 16:
Barrett's esophagus increases the risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma, not squamous cell carcinoma.
Barrett's esophagus is a complication of GERD and it is estimated to occur in as many as 10% of individuals with symptomatic GERD. Microscopically, it is seen as the replacement of the squamous esophageal epithelium with goblet cells (intestinal metaplasia).

The following images show endoscopic and microscopic images of Barrett's esophagus:

Solution to Question 19:
Mediastinal fibrosis does not predispose to esophageal carcinoma. Risk factors for esophageal carcinoma include the following:
Alcohol and tobacco use
Poverty
Caustic alkali burns
Diverticula
Achalasia
Tylosis
Plummer–Vinson syndrome

Solution to Question 20:
Helicobacter pylori infection is associated with decreased risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma.
Long-standing H. pylori gastritis (chronic inflammation) causes multifocal gastric mucosal atrophy, which in turn leads to reduced parietal cell mass, acid secretion. This leads to reduced incidence of Barrett's esophagus and decreased risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma.
H. pylori infection, however, increases the risk of gastric adenocarcinoma.

malignant cells and keratin pearls, which are noted in image 4.

Carcinoid syndrome
Vit B12 Deficiency
Zollinger ellison syndrome

d
Solution to Question 1:
The given scenario is suggestive of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. It is associated with exposure to azithromycin.
Risk factors for congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis:
Turner syndrome
Trisomy 18
Erythromycin or azithromycin exposure in the first 2 weeks of life either orally or via mother's milk.
Hyperplasia of the pyloric muscularis propria obstructs the gastric outflow tract.
It is three to five times more common in males. Generally presents between 3rd and 6th weeks of life as new-onset regurgitation, projectile, non-bilious vomiting after feeding. Physical examination reveals a firm, ovoid, 1 to 2 cm abdominal mass. In some cases, abnormal left to right hyperperistalsis is seen.
Treatment is the surgical splitting of the muscularis (Ramstedt pyloromyotomy).
Solution to Question 2:
The endoscopy findings of the watermelon stomach are suggestive of gastric antral vascular ectasia (GAVE).
In GAVE, endoscopy reveals longitudinal stripes of edematous erythematous mucosa that alternate with less severely injured, paler mucosa giving the appearance of watermelon. GAVE is responsible for 4% of non-variceal upper gastrointestinal bleeding.
Dieulafoy lesion is a non-stress-related cause of GI bleeding. It is due to a submucosal artery that does not branch properly within the wall of the stomach. It is shown in the image below.

Solution to Question 3:
Patients with renal failure develop acute gastritis as a consequence of uremia.
In uremia, gastric injury is due to inhibition of gastric bicarbonate transporters by ammonium ions.
Causes of acute gastritis:
Alcohol
Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
Smoking
Ischemia/shock
Steroid use
Uremia
Chemical ingestion
Stress
Histologically, the presence of neutrophils above the basement membrane in direct contact with epithelial cells signifies acute gastritis.
Solution to Question 4:
The most common cause of chronic gastritis is infection with the bacillus Helicobacter pylori. Causes of chronic gastritis:
Helicobacter pylori - 1st most common
Autoimmune gastritis - 2nd most common
Radiation injury
Chronic bile reflux
Mechanical injury (e.g., an indwelling nasogastric tube)
Systemic diseases such as Crohn disease, amyloidosis
Graft-versus-host disease
Options B and C: Acid hypersecretion and alcohol ingestion are the causes of acute gastritis. Note: Autoimmune gastritis is the most common cause of diffuse atrophic gastritis.
Solution to Question 5:
The given slide shows the GI mucosa, which has been stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain, demonstrating the Helicobacter pylori bacilli.
On antral biopsy, H. pylori organisms are seen abundantly within the surface mucus layer, but they are difficult to visualize with routine hematoxylin (H&E) stains. Organisms are most easily demonstrated with special stains like Warthin-Starry silver stain or Giemsa stain.
The image given below is GI biopsy stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain.


The below image is a Giemsa stain showing Helicobacter pylori in a case of chronic gastritis.

Solution to Question 6:
The given scenario is suggestive of H. pylori gastritis. The preferred site for biopsy is the antrum as H. pylori are most often found in the antrum of the stomach.
H. pylori display tropism for gastric epithelia and are generally not found in the duodenal epithelium. Long-standing H. pylori gastritis may extend to involve the body and fundus, resulting in patchy mucosal atrophy.
The below image is a Warthin-Starry silver stain showing Helicobacter pylori colonized on the surface of the regenerative epithelium of the antrum.

Solution to Question 7:
Autoimmune gastritis typically spares the antrum.
Autoimmune gastritis causes diffuse mucosal damage of the acid-producing mucosa, within the body and fundus. It accounts for less than 10% of cases of chronic gastritis. CD4+T cells directed against parietal cell components, including the H+/K+ ATPase, are considered to be the principal agents of injury in autoimmune gastritis.
Characteristic features of autoimmune gastritis:
Antibodies to parietal cells and intrinsic factor
Reduced serum pepsinogen I concentration
Hypergastrinemia
Endocrine cell hyperplasia leads to carcinoid tumors
Vitamin B12 deficiency (pernicious anemia)
Defective gastric acid secretion (achlorhydria)
Solution to Question 8:
The most common site of peptic ulcer is the anterior wall of the proximal duodenum, within a few centimeters of the pyloric valve.
Gastric peptic ulcers are predominantly located along the lesser curvature near the interface of the body and antrum.
Locations of peptic ulcers (in decreasing order of frequency):
Duodenum (first part)
Stomach (lesser curvature near the junction of body and antrum)
Gastroesophageal junction in gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) or Barrett’s esophagus
Margins of jejunostomy
Stomach, duodenum, and/or jejunum in patients with Zollinger–Ellison syndrome
Ileal Meckel’s diverticulum containing ectopic gastric mucosa
The below image shows a peptic ulcer with a round to oval, sharply punched-out defect, and clean mucosal margin

Solution to Question 9:
The most common complication of peptic ulcers is bleeding.
An ulcer on the posterior wall of the duodenum causes bleeding from the gastroduodenal artery. Gastric ulcer on the lesser curvature of the stomach causes bleeding from the left gastric artery.
Other complications are perforation, obstruction, and malignant transformation.
Note: The most common cause of death in peptic ulcers is perforation followed by bleeding. Perforation accounts for two-thirds of ulcer deaths.
Solution to Question 10:
Curling's ulcers are associated with severe burns or trauma.
Curling's ulcers occur in the proximal duodenum. Systemic hypotension or reduced blood flow caused by stress-induced splanchnic vasoconstriction results in gastric mucosal injury.
Note: Cushing's ulcers arise in individuals with intracranial disease. They occur in the stomach, uodenum, and esophagus and carry a high incidence of perforation.
Solution to Question 11:
The given endoscopy image showing irregular enlargement of the gastric rugae in the body is suggestive of Ménétrier disease. It is due to excessive secretion of transforming growth factor  (TGF-).
Menetrier disease is one of the causes of hypertrophic gastropathy. It is associated with diffuse hyperplasia of the foveolar epithelium and hypoproteinemia due to protein-losing enteropathy. There is an increased risk of gastric adenocarcinoma in adults.
Below histological image shows hyperplasia of foveolar mucous cells. The glands are cystically dilated and elongated with a corkscrew-like appearance.

Solution to Question 12:
Fundic gland polyps are associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP).
Fundic gland polyps may also occur sporadically or with proton pump inhibitor use. They occur in the gastric body and fundus.
They may be asymptomatic or associated with nausea, vomiting, or epigastric pain.
Dysplasia and neoplasia may occur in FAP-associated fundic gland polyps. Another gastric polyp associated with FAP is gastric adenoma.
The below histological image of fundic gland polyp shows cystically dilated, irregular glands lined by flattened parietal and chief cells. Inflammation is typically absent or minimal.

Solution to Question 13:
The most common site of gastric adenoma is the antrum.
Gastric adenomas are premalignant neoplastic lesions. Patients are usually between 50 and 60 years of age. Males are affected three times more often than females.
The majority of adenomas are composed of intestinal-type columnar epithelium that exhibits varying degrees of dysplasia.
Solution to Question 14:
Zollinger–Ellison syndrome is not a predisposing factor for the development of gastric adenoma. It may predispose to carcinoid tumors.
Risk factors for gastric adenoma:
Chronic gastritis with atrophy
Intestinal metaplasia
Familial adenomatous polyposis
The risk of adenocarcinoma in gastric adenomas is particularly increased in lesions greater than 2 cm in diameter. Overall, carcinoma may be present in up to 30% of gastric adenomas.
Solution to Question 15:
Familial gastric cancer (diffuse type) is strongly associated with germline loss-of-function mutations in the tumor suppressor gene CDH1. It encodes the cell adhesion protein, E-cadherin.
Half of the sporadic diffuse gastric cancer cases occur due to loss-of-function mutations in CDH1. In the remaining cases, E-cadherin expression is decreased, due to hypermethylation and silencing of the CDH1promoter. Thus, the loss of E-cadherin is a key step in the development of diffuse gastric cancer.
Sporadic intestinal-type gastric cancers are strongly associated with increased signaling via the Wnt pathway (loss-of-function mutation of APC/gain-of-function mutation of  -catenin).
Mutation of TP53 is also found in the majority of sporadic gastric cancers of both types.
Solution to Question 16:
Linitis plastica or leather bottle stomach or Brintons's disease is seen in diffuse gastric cancer.
Diffuse gastric cancer is an infiltrative tumor and often evokes a desmoplastic reaction that stiffens the gastric wall. When there are large areas of infiltration, diffuse rugal flattening and a rigid, thickened wall may impart a leather bottle appearance as shown below.

Solution to Question 17:
The diffuse-type gastric adenocarcinoma does not form bulky tumors. It grows in a diffuse infiltrating pattern that stiffens the gastric wall (linitis plastica). In contrast, the intestinal type tends to form bulky masses.
Loss of E-cadherin is the key step in the development of diffuse gastric cancer, resulting in discohesive cells. These single cells have large, intracytoplasmic mucin vacuoles that push the nucleus to the periphery, creating a signet-ring cell morphology. Mutation of TP53 is found in a majority of sporadic gastric cancers of both diffuse and intestinal types.
The below H&E-stained smear shows normal gastric mucosa (red arrow) and the characteristic signet cells (green arrows) in a patient with diffuse gastric adenocarcinoma.

Note: Loss of E cadherin is also seen in lobular carcinoma of the breast.
Solution to Question 18:
Right axillary lymph nodes are least likely to be involved in gastric cancer metastasis. Sites most commonly involved in gastric cancer metastasis include the following:
Supraclavicular sentinel lymph node (Virchow node)
Periumbilical nodes (Sister Mary Joseph nodule)
Left axillary lymph node (Irish node)
Ovary (Krukenberg tumor)
Pouch of Douglas (Blumer shelf)
Solution to Question 19:
The most common translocation in gastric MALToma is t(11;18)(q21;q21). Three translocations are associated with gastric MALToma:
t(11;18)(q21;q21) - Most common
t(1;14)(p22;q32)
t(14;18)(q32;q21)
Solution to Question 20:
The given scenario is suggestive of gastric MALToma. The tumor cells express the B-cell markers CD19 and CD20. They do not express CD5 or CD10.
They are positive for CD43 in about 25% of cases, a T-cell marker that can be diagnostically helpful.
Solution to Question 21:
Gastrointestinal carcinoid tumors can secrete all of the above-mentioned secretory products except noradrenaline.
Carcinoid products at different sites:
Stomach - Histamine, somatostatin, serotonin
Duodenum - Gastrin, somatostatin, cholecystokinin
Jejunum and ileum - Serotonin, substance P, polypeptide YY
Colon - Serotonin, polypeptide YY.
Solution to Question 22:
The most aggressive carcinoid tumors of the GIT are seen in the jejunum and ileum.
Carcinoid tumors occur throughout the GI tract. The most common site is the appendix followed by the ileum and rectum.
Ileal carcinoid with metastasis to the liver cause carcinoid syndrome because the vasoactive substances escape the filtering actions of the liver. This is characterized by cutaneous flushing, sweating, bronchospasm, colicky abdominal pain, diarrhea, and right-sided cardiac valvular fibrosis.
The behavior of the carcinoid tumors differs according to their location:
Foregut carcinoid tumor
Stomach; duodenum, proximal to the ligament of Treitz; and esophagus
Gastric carcinoid tumors originate from gastric enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells
Well-differentiated neuroendocrine tumors
Variable behavior
Rarely metastasize and are generally cured by resection
Gastric carcinoid tumors without predisposing factors are often more aggressive
Midgut carcinoid tumor
Arise in the jejunum and ileum
Often multiple
Tend to be aggressive
Hindgut carcinoi
Arise in the appendix and colorectum
Appendiceal tumors are usually < 2 cm in diameter and are almost always benign
Metastasis of rectal carcinoid tumors is uncommon
Gastric carcinoid tumors may be associated with endocrine cell hyperplasia, autoimmune chronic atrophic gastritis, MEN-I, and Zollinger–Ellison syndrome.
Solution to Question 23:
The given scenario is suggestive of carcinoid tumors. The most important prognostic factors include the degree of histological differentiation, mitotic rate, and Ki-67 proliferative index.
The diagnosis of carcinoid tumor is made by increased levels of 5-hydroxy indole acetic acid
subject: Pathology

question_text:
HIAA) in a 24-hour urine sample. It is positive in larger tumors or if metastases are present.
Note: The most important prognostic factor for esophageal carcinoma and stomach carcinoma is the depth of invasion.
Solution to Question 24:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST). It arises from the interstitial cells of Cajal, or pacemaker cells, of the gastrointestinal muscularis propria.
It is the most common mesenchymal tumor of the abdomen. The peak age of incidence is 60 years.
In sporadic GIST, the most common mutations seen are gain-of-function mutation in KIT
subject: Pathology

question_text:
80%) and PDGFRA mutation (8%). Inherited/germline GIST is seen in Carney–Stratakis syndrome. It is due to loss-of-function mutation of SDH which has increased risk for GIST and paraganglioma.
GIST at a younger age is associated with the following:
Carney triad:
Gastric GIST
Paraganglioma
Pulmonary chondroma
Neurofibromatosis type 1
Grossly, it usually forms a solitary, well-circumscribed, fleshy mass covered by ulcerated or intact mucosa.
Histologically, the tumor is composed of spindle cells (most common), epithelioid cells, or mixed cell types.
The below image shows microscopy of GIST composed of bundles, or fascicles, of spindle-shaped tumor cells

Complete surgical resection is the primary treatment for localized gastric GIST.
Imatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor used to treat CML, can be used to treat GIST with mutations in KIT or PDGFRA.
Solution to Question 25:
The most specific marker for gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) is DOG-1.
KIT (CD117) is the best diagnostic marker (most sensitive marker) of GIST. However, 5–10% of GIST lack KIT expression. DOG-1 is expressed in all GIST, including CD117-negative cases. Hence, DOG-1 marker is most specific for GIST.
Solution to Question 26:
Gastric adenocarcinoma is an epithelial tumor of the stomach. Adenocarcinoma is the most common malignancy (90% cases) of the stomach. Option A: Carcinoid tumor is a neuroendocrine tumor.
Option B: Lymphoma is a lymphoid tumor.
Option C: GIST is the most common mesenchymal tumor of the abdomen.
Solution to Question 27:
The eosinophilic appearing cells marked as A are the parietal cells, the absence of which is not associated with Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome. The cells marked as B are Chief cells.
Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome is caused by gastrin-secreting neuroendocrine tumors, which leads to parital cell hyperplasia. Gastrinomas are almost always found in the small intestine or pancreas. The most remarkable feature found in the stomach is an increase in oxyntic mucosal thickness due to massive parietal cell hyperplasia.

Other options:
Option A and C: Pernicious anemia is an autoimmune disease characterized by the presence
of autoantibodies that impairs the production or activity of the intrinsic factor (IF) that is released from the parietal cells, which is required for the uptake of vitamin B12. There are three types of autoantibodies namely, type I, II, and III. The action of each of these include:
Autoantibody type I prevents the binding of vitamin B12 to the intrinsic factor (IF).
Autoantibody type II prevents the binding of vitamin B12-IF complex to the ileal receptors.
Autoantibody type III acts against the  and  subunits of the gastric proton pump, which impairs the production of intrinsic factor.
These patients also develop chronic atrophic gastritis, characterized by loss of parietal cells, infiltration of lymphocytes and plasma cells, and megaloblastic changes in mucosal cells.
Option B: Gastric carcinoid tumors originate from gastric enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells. They are referred to as well-differentiated neuroendocrine tumors. The peak incidence of carcinoid tumors is in the 6th decade. These tumors occur throughout the GI tract, most commonly in the appendix, ileum, and rectum, in decreasing order of frequency.
Gastric carcinoid tumors may be associated with endocrine cell hyperplasia, autoimmune chronic atrophic gastritis, MEN-I, and Zollinger–Ellison syndrome. Ileal carcinoid may cause carcinoid syndrome which is characterized by cutaneous flushing, sweating, bronchospasm, colicky abdominal pain, diarrhea, and right-sided cardiac valvular fibrosis.

Solution to Question 1:
The most common cause of intestinal obstruction in children < 2 years of age is intussusception.
Intussusception occurs when a segment of the intestine, constricted by a wave of peristalsis, telescopes into the immediately distal segment. It is usually idiopathic at younger ages. However, it can be associated with viral infections and rotavirus vaccines, perhaps due to reactive hyperplasia of Peyer patches.
Untreated intussusception may progress to intestinal obstruction, compression of mesenteric vessels, and infarction.
Note: The most common form of congenital intestinal atresia is imperforate anus. It occurs due to failure of the cloacal diaphragm to involute.

Solution to Question 2:
The given scenario is suggestive of celiac disease or gluten-sensitive enteropathy. It is associated with HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8 alleles.
It is an immune-mediated enteropathy triggered by the ingestion of gluten-containing foods such as barley, rye, oats, and wheat (mnemonic: BROW) in genetically predisposed individuals.
In these individuals, digestion of the gluten-containing diet leads to the formation of gliadin peptides. These peptides result in the following immune reactions:
They can activate the epithelial cells to express certain cytokines (IL-15), which result in CD8+ T cell proliferation
They undergo deamidation and interact with HLA-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8 on the antigen-presenting cells. This leads to CD4+ T cell stimulation and further cytokine production
These mechanisms result in epithelial tissue damage. Antibodies associated with celiac disease are:
Anti-gliadin antibodies
Anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies (anti-ttG)
Anti-endomysial antibodies Microscopic findings include:
Villi atrophy and flattening
Crypt hyperplasia
Increased intraepithelial T cells
Solution to Question 3:
The given scenario and histopathology findings are suggestive of celiac disease. Enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma is the most common cancer associated with celiac disease.


Small intestinal adenocarcinoma is also associated with celiac disease.
Celiac disease or celiac sprue or gluten-sensitive enteropathy is triggered by the ingestion of gluten, which is the major storage protein of wheat and similar grains. It usually affects the 2nd part of the duodenum or proximal jejunum.
Antibodies associated with celiac disease are:
Anti-gliadin antibodies
Anti tissue transglutaminase antibodies
Anti endomysial antibodies
MARSH's score is used to assess celiac disease histologically.
Dermatitis herpetiformis occurs in about 10% of patients with celiac disease.
Solution to Question 4:
In cystic fibrosis, malabsorption occurs due to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, not intestinal mucosal defects.
Cystic fibrosis is caused by pathogenic mutations in the CFTR gene on chromosome 7 that encodes the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) protein.
The absence of CFTR protein interferes with Na+, HCO3-, and water secretion resulting in defective luminal hydration. This causes the formation of pancreatic intraductal concretions and causes exocrine pancreatic insufficiency.
Solution to Question 5:
The given clinical scenario of faint salmon-colored macules is suggestive of rose spots that are seen in typhoid fever.
Rose spots are small erythematous maculopapular lesions that are seen on the chest and abdomen. In the second week of illness, abdominal pain develops and rose spots may be seen, as shown in the following image.

Note: Typhoid ulcers are oval ulcers oriented along the axis of the ileum and carry the risk of perforation. They usually develop in the 3rd week of typhoid.
Solution to Question 6:
In Whipple's disease, the cause of malabsorption is impaired lymphatic transport.
In Whipple disease, clinical symptoms occur because organism-laden macrophages accumulate within the small intestinal lamina propria and mesenteric lymph nodes, causing lymphatic obstruction. These bacteria-laden macrophages also accumulate within mesenteric lymph nodes,
synovial membranes of affected joints, cardiac valves, brain.
The clinical presentation of Whipple disease is usually a triad of diarrhea, weight loss, and arthralgia.
Solution to Question 7:
This clinical scenario and image showing distended foamy macrophages inside the lamina propria are characteristic of Whipple's disease. The diagnosis can be confirmed by acid-fast staining.

Distended foamy macrophages inside the lamina propria of the duodenum can be seen in:
Whipple's disease
Intestinal tuberculosis, particularly in immunocompromised hosts
As both organisms are PAS-positive, PAS staining cannot differentiate between the two diseases. On the other hand, acid-fast staining can be used to confirm the diagnosis, as only mycobacteria are acid fast, whereas Tropheryma whipplei is not.
Solution to Question 8:
Rotavirus damages the intestinal epithelium by a viral factor called non-structural protein 4
(NSP4), which can induce epithelial apoptosis.
Rotavirus is a common cause of severe childhood diarrhea and diarrheal mortality worldwide. Rotavirus selectively infects and destroys mature enterocytes in the small intestine. This causes repopulation of the villus surface by immature secretory cells.
Solution to Question 9:
Giardia lamblia is the most common parasitic pathogen in humans.
The following image shows teardrop (pear)-shaped Giardia with paired nuclei:

Solution to Question 10:
The given history and histological image are diagnostic of ileal carcinoid. The tumor cells are typically positive for synaptophysin on immunohistochemistry.
Histology of carcinoid typically reveals islands and nests of uniform cells with scant, pink granular cytoplasm and salt and pepper chromatin. Electron microscopy reveals cytoplasmic dense-core neurosecretory granules.


Carcinoid tumors most commonly occur in the gastrointestinal tract. The most common sites in decreasing order of frequency are the appendix, ileum, and rectum. These tumors may cause carcinoid syndrome, which is characterized by cutaneous flushing, sweating, bronchospasm, colicky abdominal pain, diarrhea, and right-sided cardiac valvular fibrosis.
Immunohistochemical (IHC) markers for carcinoid tumors are:
Neuron-specific enolase
Synaptophysin
Chromogranin A
Leu 7
Solution to Question 11:
The given scenario is suggestive of autoimmune enteropathy or IPEX syndrome. Definitive diagnosis requires gene sequencing to identify mutations in the FOXP3 gene.
FOXP3 is a transcription factor expressed in CD4+ regulatory T cells.
Autoimmune enteropathy is an X-linked disorder characterized by severe persistent diarrhea and autoimmune disease in young children. A particularly severe familial form is termed IPEX an acronym denoting immune dysregulation, polyendocrinopathy, enteropathy, and X-linked inheritance.
The classic presentation of IPEX is a triad of:
Failure to thrive with severe chronic diarrhea due to an autoimmune enteropathy
Autoimmune endocrinopathy (neonatal type 1 diabetes or thyroiditis)
Dermatitis (usually eczematous)
Solution to Question 12:
The given scenario is suggestive of microvillus inclusion disease (MVID) which is associated with MYO5B gene mutations.
Microvillus inclusion disease or Davidson disease is an autosomal recessive disorder due to mutations of MYO5B gene. This gene encodes a motor protein that is required for the transport of normal nutrients, ions, water, and plasma membrane components. Hence, it leads to defective vesicular transport that causes deficient brush-border assembly.
Clinical features of MVID are:
Profuse watery, secretory diarrhea - before 3 months of age (often in the first few days of life)
Metabolic acidosis
Hypotonic dehydration Diagnosis of MVID include:
Electron microscopy -
Inclusion containing microvilli in the apical cytoplasm of the intestinal cells.
Brush border microvilli are poorly developed with only a few/blunted microvilli
Immunostaining of villin (the brush border protein)
CD10 immunohistochemistry to detect microvillus inclusions Treatment is total parenteral nutrition and small bowel transplantation.
The following electron microscopy image shows characteristic intracytoplasmic inclusions that are lined by intact microvilli along the absorptive surfaces of the intestinal cells.

Solution to Question 1:
The most common sites of the following conditions are:
A true diverticulum is a blind outpouching of the alimentary tract that communicates with the lumen and includes all three layers of the bowel wall. The most common true diverticulum
is Meckel's diverticulum. It most commonly occurs in the ileum. It occurs as a result of the failed involution of the vitelline duct, which connects the lumen of the developing gut to the yolk sac.
The following image shows a Meckel's diverticulum.
Condition
Site
subject: Pathology

options: Colorectum  On the other hand, false or acquired diverticula either lack the muscularis entirely or have an attenuated muscularis propria. Though Crohn's disease most commonly occurs in the terminal ileum, it may occur in any area of the GI tract. Polyps are most common in the colorectal region. They can be sessile (without stalk) or pedunculated (with stalk). Intestinal polyps can be classified as non-neoplastic or neoplastic in nature. The nonneoplastic polyps can be further classified as inflammatory, hamartomatous, or hyperplastic. The most common neoplastic polyp is an adenoma. Solution to Question 2: Hirschsprung disease occurs due to the failure of migration of the neural crest cells to the bowel wall. During normal embryogenesis, the neural crest cells migrate from the caecum to the rectum. The enteric neuronal plexuses develop from these migrated neural crest cells. In Hirschsprung disease, there is an arrest in the migration of these cells, which leads to the development of a distal intestinal segment that is devoid of Meissner (submucosal) and the Auerbach (myenteric) plexus. Hence this segment is referred to as the aganglionic segment. As a result, there is a lack of coordination in the peristaltic contractions and functional obstruction, which further leads to the dilation of the intestine proximal to the affected segment, leading to congenital megacolon. Diagnosis is confirmed by demonstrating the absence of ganglion cells in biopsy sections.  Some conditions may cause acquired megacolon. These include: Chagas disease, due to the loss of ganglion cells Visceral myopathy Obstruction by neoplasm or inflammatory stricture Toxic megacolon complicating ulcerative colitis Functional psychosomatic disorders Solution to Question 3: The given scenario is suggestive of Hirschsprung disease. It is associated with Down's syndrome. Hirschsprung disease is also known as congenital aganglionic megacolon. 10% of all cases occur in children with Down's syndrome. The premature arrest of normal migration of neural crest cells from the cecum to the rectum produces aganglionosis of the distal intestinal segment. This causes functional obstruction of the affected bowel and proximal dilation. The absence of ganglion cells in the affected segment in biopsy confirms the diagnosis.  Gastrointestinal abnormalities associated with Down's syndrome include: Duodenal atresia Annular pancreas Hirschsprung disease Gastrointestinal abnormalities associated with Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18) include: Meckel's diverticulum Malrotation Gastrointestinal abnormalities associated with Patau syndrome (trisomy 13) include: Omphalocele Incomplete rotation of the colon Meckel's diverticulum Solution to Question 4: The most common site of volvulus is the sigmoid colon. The twisting of a loop of the bowel about its mesenteric point of attachment is termed volvulus. Segments involved in volvulus in the decreasing order of frequency are: Sigmoid colon Cecum Small bowe Stomach Transverse colon Solution to Question 5: The most common site of gastrointestinal ischemia is the colon. Intestinal segments at the end of their respective arterial supplies are particularly susceptible to ischemia. These are termed watershed zones. These include: Splenic flexure - where the superior and inferior mesenteric arterial circulations terminate Junction of sigmoid colon and rectum - where the inferior mesenteric, pudendal, and iliac arterial circulations end Solution to Question 6: Aplastic crisis is associated with parvovirus infection, not Campylobacter infection. Campylobacter infection can cause: Reactive arthritis, primarily in patients with HLA-B27 Erythema nodosum Guillain–Barré syndrome (GBS) Molecular mimicry has been implicated in the pathogenesis of GBS because serum antibodies to Campylobacter jejuni lipopolysaccharide crossreact with peripheral and central nervous system gangliosides. Solution to Question 7: The given histopathological image shows superficially damaged crypts with a typical pattern of mucopurulent exudates (neutrophils) emanating from a crypt that resembles a volcanic eruption. This is pathognomonic of Clostridium difficile colitis.   In this condition, disruption of the normal colonic microbiota by antibiotics allows C. difficile overgrowth. Risk factors for Clostridium difficile colitis are: Antibiotic use Advanced age Gastric suppression- PPIs, H2 receptor blockers Immunosuppression Solution to Question 8: The given scenario is suggestive of Crohn's disease. It is strongly associated with mutations in the nucleotide oligomerization binding domain 2 (NOD2) gene. Crohn's disease occurs due to the host response against microbes. NOD2 encodes an intracellular protein that binds to bacterial peptidoglycans and activates the NF-B pathway. Antibodies against the bacterial protein flagellin may be seen in NOD2-associated disease. Other Crohn's disease-related genes are autophagy-related 16-like (ATG16L1), and immunity-related GTPase M (IRGM), which are critical for cellular responses to intracellular bacteria. Crohn's disease most commonly involves the terminal ileum but can affect all parts of the GIT. The following microscopic changes may be seen: Aphthoid ulcerations Focal crypt abscesses Non-caseating granulomas can be found in all layers of the bowel, lymph nodes, mesentery, peritoneum, liver, and pancreas Note: Ulcerative colitis-associated genes are ECM1 and HNFA. Solution to Question 9: The given scenario along with cobblestone appearance on endoscopy is suggestive of Crohn's disease. This condition is associated with primary sclerosing cholangitis, not primary biliary cirrhosis. Extraintestinal manifestations of Crohn's disease include the following: Uveitis Migratory polyarthritis Sacroiliitis Ankylosing spondylitis Erythema nodosum Clubbing of the fingertips Primary sclerosing cholangitis (less frequently than ulcerative colitis) Cutaneous granulomas form nodules referred to as metastatic Crohn's disease (a misnomer since there is no cancer) Solution to Question 10: In ulcerative colitis, regenerating mucosa often bulges into the lumen to create pseudopolyps and the tips of these polyps may fuse to create mucosal bridges. Features characteristic of ulcerative colitis are: Proctocolitis/ backwash ileitis Mucosa and superficial submucosal involvement Broad-based ulcers Pseudopolyps and mucosal bridges Toxic megacolon Note: Granulomas, strictures, and mural thickening are features of Crohn's disease. Solution to Question 11: Henoch-Schönlein purpura is associated with IgA immune complex deposition in the small vessels, not p-ANCA. The following conditions are positive for perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (p-ANCA): Ulcerative colitis Crohn's disease Churg–Strauss syndrome Microscopic polyangiitis Antibodies Ulcerative colitis Crohn's disease p-ANCA Present in majority (75 %) Present in minority (11 %) Antibodies toSaccharomyces cerevisiae Absent Present Solution to Question 12: Flask-shaped ulcers are characteristic of amoebiasis, which is caused by Entamoeba histolytica. It most often affects the cecum and ascending colon. Parasites may also penetrate splanchnic vessels and embolize to the liver to produce amoebic liver abscesses. Image showing flask-shaped ulcers of amoebiasis:  Option A: In TB, ulcers are perpendicular to the axis of the intestine (transverse ulcers). Option B: In typhoid, ulcers are oriented along the axis of the intestine (longitudinal ulcers). Option C: Ulceration is not a feature of giardiasis. Solution to Question 13: Microscopic colitis encompasses two types of disorders - collagenous colitis and lymphocytic colitis. Lymphocytic colitis shows a strong association between celiac disease and autoimmune diseases, including Graves disease and rheumatoid arthritis. These idiopathic diseases both present with chronic, non-bloody, watery diarrhea without weight loss. Collagenous colitis Lymphocytic colitis Dense subepithelial collagen layer Subepithelial collagen layer i s of normal thickness Increased numbers of intraep ithelial lymphocytes Higher ratio of intraepithelial lymphocytes Solution to Question 14: The diagnosis of acute appendicitis is confirmed by the presence of neutrophilic infiltration of the muscularis propria. Surgical exploration is done when clinical suspicion for appendicitis is high but imaging studies are negative, nondiagnostic, or unavailable. In such situations, appendicitis can only be diagnosed intraoperatively or pathologically. Large Intestine - Neoplastic Conditions Question 1: What is the most common malignancy of the GI tract? Gastric adenocarcinoma Gastrointestinal stromal tumor Adenocarcinoma colon Carcinoid tumor of appendix Question 2: Which of the following patients is at an increased risk of developing malignancy? A 50-year-old man with hyperplastic polyps A 30-year-old woman with inflammatory polyps A 10-year-old girl with retention polyps A 40-year-old man with sessile serrated polyps Question 3: Which of the following sites is most commonly involved in patients with juvenile polyps? Sigmoid colon Jejunum Transverse colon Rectum Question 4: A 5-year-old child was admitted to the hospital with a history of prolapsing rectal mass and painless rectal bleeding. The histopathological image of the mass is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?  Peutz Jegher syndrome ‰illous adenoma Juvenile polyp Tubular adenoma Question 5: Patients with which of the following diseases have the highest risk of developing colorectal cancer? Juvenile polyposis syndrome Ulcerative colitis Familial adenomatous polyposis Peutz-Jeghers syndrome Question 6: What is the minimum number of polyps necessary for the diagnosis of familial adenomatous polyposis?

Question 7:
Indirect ophthalmoscopy of an infant revealed congenital hypertrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium. This is seen as an extraintestinal manifestation in association with which of the following conditions?
Classic FAP
Turcot syndrome
Peutz-Jegher syndrome
Attenuated FAP
Question 8:
Which of the following is incorrect about Peutz-Jeghers syndrome?
It has an autosomal recessive inheritance
Baseline colonoscopy must be done at 20 years of age
There is increased risk of ovarian and uterine cancer
It is associated with loss-of-function mutations in STK11
Question 9:
A 60-year-old man presented with complaints of chronic diarrhea, loss of weight, and hair loss. On examination, pallor, nail atrophy, and abnormal skin pigmentation were noted. On endoscopic evaluation, multiple sessile polyps were visualized in the small bowel and colon. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Bannayan-Ruvalcaba-Riley syndrome
Cronkhite-Canada syndrome
Gardner syndrome
Peutz-Jeghers syndrome
Question 10:
Which of the following acts as the initiating mutation in the majority of sporadic colon cancers?
Gain-of-function mutation of APC
Loss-of-function mutation of APC
Gain-of-function mutation of TP53
Loss-of-function mutation of TP53
Question 11:
A 70-year-old man with hematochezia and weight loss is diagnosed with colorectal cancer. Which of the following is the most important prognostic factor for this condition?
Site of lesion
Tumor histology
Age of patient
Lymph node status
Question 12:
A 52-year-old lady has just been diagnosed with endometrial carcinoma. On taking history, she revealed that both her mother and her elder sister had been diagnosed with synchronous colorectal and endometrial cancer in their forties. She should be tested for mutations in which of the following genes?
APC
MSH
MYH
BRAF
Question 13:
Which of the following is incorrect about tumors of the appendix?
The most common tumor is carcinoid
Primary adenocarcinoma is usually serous
Goblet cell variant of carcinoid is more aggressive
Peritoneal dissemination can result in pseudomyxoma peritonei
Answer Key
Question No.
Correct Option

question_text:
b
Solution to Question 1:
Adenocarcinoma of the colon is the most common malignancy of the GI tract.
Tumors in the proximal colon often grow as polypoid, exophytic masses. These tumors rarely cause obstruction.
Carcinomas of the distal colon tend to be annular lesions that produce napkin-ring constrictions and luminal narrowing.
Solution to Question 2:
Patients with sessile serrated polyps are at an increased risk of developing malignancy.
Histologically, sessile serrated polyps appear like hyperplastic polyps, but a serrated architecture throughout the full length of the glands and lateral growth is the differentiating feature. They lack cytological features of dysplasia.
Solution to Question 3:
The most common site of juvenile polyps is in the rectum.
Juvenile polyps are focal malformations of the epithelium and lamina propria. They may be sporadic or syndromic. They typically present with rectal bleeding in children < 5 years.
Sporadic juvenile polyps - solitary lesions, also called retention polyps
Juvenile polyposis - autosomal dominant syndrome with multiple hamartomatous polyps that have malignant potential
Solution to Question 4:
The clinical features and the histopathological image showing characteristic cystically dilated crypts and glands are suggestive of a juvenile polyp.


Juvenile polyps are malformations of epithelium and lamina propria commonly located in the rectum. It is seen in children <5 years of age. The typical presentation is painless rectal bleeding. Sometimes there may be a proliferating rectal mass.
The disease may be sporadic or syndromic.
Sporadic juvenile polyp occurs as a single mass and is called retention polyp.
Juvenile polyposis syndrome is characterized by multiple hamartomatous polyps, which may be premalignant.
Morphologically, both of these types are indistinguishable.
Gross appearance: They appear as pedunculated, smooth reddish lesions, and with cystic spaces.
Microscopic appearance: The cysts appear as dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory debris.
Note: Complex glandular architecture and the presence of smooth muscle cutting through the lamina propria are seen in Peutz-Jeghers polyps.
Solution to Question 5:
Patients with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) have the highest risk of developing colorectal cancer. 100% of untreated patients with FAP develop colorectal carcinoma, often before the age of 30 years.
Solution to Question 6:
The diagnosis of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) requires 100 polyps.
The current definition of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) requires evidence of any one of the below:
Germline mutation in APC gene
100 colorectal adenomatous polyps (classical definition)
Any colorectal adenomas < 30 years in a patient with a family history of FAP
Intra-abdominal desmoid fibromatosis, osteoma of the mandible, or multiple epidermoid cysts in a patient with a family history of FAP
Colorectal adenocarcinoma develops in 100% of untreated FAP patients, often before age of 30 years and nearly always by age of 50 years.
Attenuated FAP is a less severe form of FAP with the following features:
Usually <100 adenomas
First appear usually in late childhood
Adenomas usually 1 cm until adulthood
Adenomas fewer and later
Adenomas and carcinomas 60–75% right-sided
The mean age of carcinoma is 55 years
The following image shows a gross specimen of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP):

Solution to Question 7:
Classic FAP and Gardner's syndrome are associated with congenital retinal pigment epithelium
(RPE) hypertrophy.
Congenital hypertrophy of the RPE can be generally detected at birth and is, therefore, an adjunct to the early screening of FAP.
Solution to Question 8:
Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant syndrome.
It is commonly associated with germline heterozygous loss-of-function mutations in the gene STK11.
It is characterized by:
Multiple gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps
Mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation
Increased risk of gastrointestinal and extraintestinal malignancies (including ovarian and uterine cancer)
Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy for screening are done at 20 years of age, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.
Solution to Question 9:
The given scenario of intestinal polyps, cutaneous pigmentation, and diarrhea points toward a diagnosis of Cronkhite–Canada syndrome.
It is a non-hereditary polyposis syndrome that occurs at a mean age of 50 years. Clinical features include:
Diarrhea and abdominal pain
Nail atrophy, hair loss, and cutaneous hyperpigmentation
Cachexia and anemia
Characterized by hamartomatous polyps of the stomach, small intestine, and colon due t abnormalities in the nonpolypoid mucosa
Solution to Question 10:
The majority of sporadic colon tumors typically include loss of function mutation of APC gene, early in the neoplastic process (the classic adenoma-carcinoma sequence).
About 10-15% of sporadic colon cancers involve the microsatellite instability pathway, which is associated with DNA mismatch repair defects (Lynch syndrome).
Solution to Question 11:
The two most important prognostic factors of colorectal cancer are the depth of invasion and the presence of lymph node metastases.
The liver is the most common site of metastasis from the colon due to its portal drainage.
Solution to Question 12:
The given scenario is suggestive of hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC) or Lynch syndrome. She should be tested for mutations in MSH genes.
It occurs due to defective DNA mismatch repair. It is caused by inherited mutations in genes that encode proteins responsible for the detection, excision, and repair of errors that occur during DNA replication. They include MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, and PMS2 or EPCAM genes.
It is the most common syndromic cause of colon cancer. It tends to occur at younger ages than sporadic colon cancers and often involves the right colon. Familial clustering of cancers occurs at several sites including:
Colorectum, small bowel, and stomach
Endometrium and ovary
Ureters
Brain
Hepatobiliary tract and pancreas
Skin
Solution to Question 13:
Primary adenocarcinoma of the appendix is usually of mucinous type.
Peritoneal dissemination of mucinous tumors can cause pseudomyxoma peritonei.
The most common tumor of the appendix is carcinoid tumor. This neoplasm, which is almost always benign, most frequently forms a solid bulbous swelling at the distal tip of the appendix. Goblet cell variant of carcinoid tumor is more aggressive.
Congenital anomalies, ARDS, Infections

It is associated with respiratory failure and poor prognosis despite treatment

Question 8:
A newborn baby born at term was noted to have respiratory distress. Radiography revealed diffuse ground-glass opacities in all lung fields. Exogenous surfactant administration resulted in a brief improvement, but his condition continued to worsen once surfactant therapy was

Question 9:
A 76-year-old woman is brought to the casualty with high-grade fever, dysuria, and flank pain. On examination, she is disoriented with suprapubic and costovertebral angle tenderness. Her BP is 70/40 mm Hg, pulse rate is 130/min, and her temperature is 103 ºF. She becomes increasingly hypoxic after admission and requires ventilation. What is the likely reason for respiratory failure?
Alveolar proteinosis

Question 10:
A 68-year-old man presented with episodes of shortness of breath and coughing at night that awaken him from sleep. He was diagnosed with COPD 7 years ago. Question 15:
A 28-year-old woman underwent an emergency LSCS under general anesthesia to deliver a term, healthy infant. Two hours later, she developed sudden tachypnea, cyanosis, and massive pulmonary edema and died despite resuscitative measures. The histopathological picture of her lung is shown below. What is the likely cause of death?

Question 16:

A 38-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to several weeks of occasional hemoptysis, weight loss, and fever. He has lost 7 kg over the past 3 months. Sputum culture grows acid-fast bacilli and his chest X-ray is shown below. What is this lesion called?

The admission chest X-ray and a repeat X-ray taken 3 days later are shown below. The patient died a few hours after the 2nd X-ray was taken. Which of the following statements regarding his diagnosis is true?

The cause of death likely a malignant pleural effusion
The spread is mostly due to lymphatic dissemination
Pancytopenia may be seen due to infiltration of the bone marrow

Question 21:
A 52-year-old woman diagnosed with COVID-19 developed severe shortness of breath and died 5 days after admission. What lung pathology can be expected in this patient on autopsy?
