question_text:
b
Solution to Question 1:
Neuroendocrine cells in the bronchial mucosa of the lungs are called Kulchitsky cells.
Bronchial mucosa contains a population of neuroendocrine cells that have neurosecretory-type granules and can release a variety of factors including serotonin, calcitonin, and gastrin-releasing peptide (bombesin).
The main cell types of the bronchial mucosa are:
Clara cells - non-ciliated cuboidal epithelial cells that secrete important defence markers and serve as progenitor cells after injury
Type I pneumocytes - seen in the alveolar epithelium and are responsible for gas exchange
Type II pneumocytes - seen in the alveolar epithelium and produce surfactants
Basal cells
Neuroendocrine (Kulchitsky-type) cells
Ciliated cells
Serous cells
Goblet cells
Solution to Question 2:
Pores of Kohn (alveolar pores) are seen in the alveolar wall.
They are the interalveolar connections that permit the passage of bacteria and exudate between adjacent alveoli. This plays an important role in the pathogenesis of lobar pneumonia. During the gray hepatization phase, fibrin also spreads through these pores.
When the lung is partially deflated, collateral ventilation can also occur to some extent through these pores.

Solution to Question 3:
Type II pneumocytes are not involved in gaseous exchange. They are only involved in repair and surfactant production.
Alveolar epithelium is a continuous layer of two cell types: The following image shows types of cells in the alveoli.
Type I pneumocytes
Type II pneumocytes
Flattened, plate-like
Rounded
The lining epithelium of alve oli (covers 95% of the alveola r surface)Gaseous exchange
Synthesize surfactantRepair of the alveolar epitheliumReg eneration of type I cells

Solution to Question 4:
Ciliocytophthoria refers to the degeneration of ciliated cells. It occurs in viral infections, such as acute respiratory infections.
Options B and C: Kartagener syndrome is also known as primary ciliary dyskinesia/ immotile cilia syndrome. It occurs due to a defect in the dynein arm of cilia. It is characterized by the triad of:
Sinusitis
Situs inversus
Bronchiectasis
Option D: In cystic fibrosis ciliary ultrastructure remains normal.
Solution to Question 5:
Foregut cysts are most often located in the hilum or middle mediastinum.
They are the congenital cysts that arise from abnormal detachments of primitive foregut. Foregut cysts are classified as bronchogenic, esophageal, or enteric. The most common type of foregut cyst is bronchogenic cyst.
Microscopically, the cyst is lined by ciliated pseudostratified columnar epithelium.
Solution to Question 6:
Contraction atelectasis is an irreversible disorder. It occurs when focal or generalized pulmonary or pleural fibrosis prevents full lung expansion.
Atelectasis refers either to an incomplete expansion of the lungs (neonatal atelectasis) or to the collapse of the previously inflated lung.
The main types of atelectasis in adults are:
Resorption atelectasis stems from complete obstruction of an airway. Over time, the air is resorbed from the dependent alveoli, which collapse. E.g. mucous plugs, foreign body aspiration
Compression atelectasis occurs whenever significant volumes of fluid, tumor, or air accumulate within the pleural cavity. E.g. pneumothorax, pleural effusion.
Contraction atelectasis occurs when focal or generalized pulmonary or pleural fibrosis prevents full lung expansion.

Solution to Question 7:
This clinical scenario is characteristic of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) or hyaline membrane disease. With treatment, it rarely leads to respiratory failure and has a good prognosis.
The fundamental defect is a deficiency of pulmonary surfactant, produced by type II pneumocytes.
Microscopically, the hyaline membranes are largely made up of fibrin admixed with necrotic cell debris. Grossly, the lungs are of normal size, solid, airless, reddish-purple, and they usually sink in water.
Corticosteroids help in surfactant production and are given prophylactically to at-risk pregnant women.

Solution to Question 8:
The above scenario is suggestive of surfactant dysfunction disorder. It is most commonly caused by mutations of ABCA3 gene.
In this disorder, lack of production of surfactant leads to severe respiratory failure in neonates. There is transient improvement with administration of exogenous surfactant, but it worsens once surfactant therapy is stopped. This condition occurs due to mutations in genes encoding proteins involved in surfactant trafficking or secretion such as:
ATP binding cassette protein member 3 (ABCA3)
Surfactant protein C
Surfactant protein B
Solution to Question 9:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of urosepsis. This presentation is likely the result of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) or shock lung. It is characterized histologically by diffuse alveolar damage.
It is also known as acute lung injury and is clinically characterized by the abrupt onset of significant hypoxemia and bilateral pulmonary infiltrates in the absence of cardiac failure. Chest x-ray shows diffuse bilateral infiltrates, known as white-out appearance. The prognosis is poor with mortality up to 40%.


Solution to Question 10:
The given scenario is suggestive of heart failure. The image shows heart failure cells, which are siderophages or hemosiderin-containing macrophages.


They are seen in the alveoli of patients with chronic pulmonary edema. The alveolar walls become thickened and fibrosed. These pigmented macrophages result in a brown induration of the lung.
The following image shows siderophages.


Solution to Question 11:
The given image shows diffuse alveolar damage which is the characteristic histologic finding of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). Heart failure is not associated with ARDS.


ARDS is characterized by bilateral pulmonary infiltrates and hypoxemia in the absence of heart failure. The causes of ARDS are:
Sepsis
Diffuse pulmonary infections
Infectious - viral, Mycoplasma, and Pneumocystis, miliary tuberculosis
Gastric aspiration
Mechanical trauma, including head injuries, burns
Near-drowning
Solution to Question 12:
In the stage of gray hepatization in pneumonia, there is an accumulation of fibrin along with disintegration of RBCs within the alveoli.
Bacterial pneumonias can be classified morphologically as:
Lobular pneumonia (bronchopneumonia) - patchy consolidation of the lung
Lobar pneumonia - consolidation of an entire lobe Stages of lobar pneumonia are as follows:
Stages
Durati on
Description
Congestion

Solution to Question 13:
The predominance of alveolar exudates is a feature of bacterial pneumonia, not viral pneumonia.
Solution to Question 14:
The given image shows a cytomegalic pneumocyte containing characteristic intranuclear basophilic inclusion surrounded by a clear halo known as owl’s eye appearance. Along with the given clinical scenario, it is suggestive of cytomegalovirus (CMV) pneumonia.


CMV is a  -group herpesvirus. It causes the following conditions:
Immunocompetent individuals - asymptomatic or mononucleosis-like infection
Neonates - devastating systemic infections
Immunosuppressed individuals - serious, life-threatening, disseminated CMV infections of the lungs (pneumonitis) and gastrointestinal tract (colitis)
Option A: Small-cell carcinoma has small cells with scant cytoplasm, salt-and-pepper chromatin with inconspicuous nucleoli.
Option C: In cryptococcal infection, encapsulated yeasts are seen on direct microscopy. Option D: Tuberculosis is associated with well-defined epithelioid granuloma.
Solution to Question 15:
The given scenario and image showing massive neutrophilic infiltration are suggestive of Mendelson’s syndrome or aspiration pneumonitis.
Mendelson's syndrome is a chemical pneumonitis caused by the aspiration of sterile gastric contents during general anesthesia, especially during pregnancy. The most common cause of maternal mortality associated with general anesthesia is either due to a pulmonary aspiration or a failed endotracheal intubation.
The risk factors for Mendelson's syndrome include:
Gastric volume > 25 mL (0.4 mL/kg)
Gastric pH < 2.5
Incidence of aspiration can be reduced by administration of:
Non-particulate antacids like sodium citrate 30-45 minutes prior to intubation
H2 receptor antagonists like intravenous ranitidine
Metoclopramide 1-2 hours prior to induction
Option B: Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia is a type of ILD associated with Masson bodies and plugs of loose connective tissue on histology.
Option C: CMV pneumonia is associated with the owl's eye appearance on histology. Option D: PCP pneumonia is associated with black-walled cysts on silver staining.
Solution to Question 16:
The given histopathological image clearly shows a granuloma with refractile granules indicative of a foreign body. It is seen in aspiration pneumonia due to vegetative matter (such as food).
In this condition, the chest x-ray shows bilateral diffuse infiltrates especially in the right middle and lower lobes. Patients with altered sensorium are at high risk (stroke, medications).

Solution to Question 17:
The given image shows the presence of granulomas of epithelioid cells with central caseous necrosis and Langhan's giant cells. These findings point towards the diagnosis of tuberculosis.
Langhan's giant cells show horseshoe or slipper-shaped arrangements of nuclei.

Solution to Question 18:
The given x-ray of this patient with tuberculosis shows an infraclavicular lesion. It is known as Assmann's focus.
Primary tuberculosis occurs on first exposure and involves lower part of upper lobe and upper part of lower lobe. The following findings may be seen:
Ghon's focus - focus of infection located subpleurally
Ghon's complex - Ghon's focus with lymph node involvement
Ranke complex - a calcified Ghon's complex
Secondary tuberculosis occurs due to the reactivation of TB. It affects the apex. The following findings may be seen:
Puhl's complex - supraclavicular lesion
Assmann's complex - infraclavicular lesion
Disseminated or miliary tuberculosis is characterised by 1-2 mm disseminated lesions all over the lung. The following findings may be associated:
Simon's focus - early hematogenous seeding in the apex of lungs
Rich focus - tuberculous caseous foci in brain, meninges and spinal cord
Solution to Question 19:
The given clinical scenario and the gross image showing individual lesions which are small
(2-mm) foci of yellow-white consolidation scattered through the lung parenchyma is suggestive of miliary tuberculosis.
Miliary tuberculosis (TB) refers to the widespread dissemination of
Mycobacterium tuberculosis via hematogenous spread. It occurs when organisms draining through the lymphatics enter the venous blood and circulate back to the lung. Miliary TB may infect any number of organs, including the lungs, liver, and spleen.
The adjective 'miliary' is derived from the resemblance of these foci to millet seeds. Mantoux test is negative in miliary TB.
Solution to Question 20:
The given history, clinical features, and chest X-Ray point towards a diagnosis of miliary tuberculosis. Pancytopenia may be seen due to infiltration of the bone marrow in such cases.
The second X-ray shows acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). Chest x-ray appearance of ARDS varies depending on the severity and typically appears as bilateral diffuse alveolar opacities with dependent atelectasis in some cases. The opacities may have a patchy ground-glass appearance. The cause of death here is likely ARDS. (option A)
In immunodeficient individuals (eg.- patient having HIV), there may occur widespread dissemination of M. tuberculosis, via the hematogenous route (option B) that leads to the seeding of bacteria in various organs (hepatosplenomegaly). This is known as miliary TB.
It is a form of disseminated pulmonary tuberculosis, and not extrapulmonary (option D)
The risk factors of miliary TB include-
Extremes of age
Alcohol use
Malignancy
HIV
Corticosteroids
Connective tissue disease
Renal failure
Diabetes, and pregnancy
Solution to Question 21:
Diffuse alveolar damage may be seen in patients suffering from COVID-19, on histological analysis. It is the most common lung finding in COVID-19 pneumonia.
Other COVID-19 related histopathological changes in the lungs include:
Hyaline membrane formation
Desquamation of pneumocytes
Fibrin deposits in lungs
Inflammation with mononuclear cells
However, diffuse alveolar damage is not specific to COVID-19. It may be seen in all cases of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) including pneumonia, burns, near drowning, etc.

Bronchial asthma - characterized by reversible bronchoconstriction caused by airway hyperresponsiveness to a variety of stimuli
Bronchiectasis - destruction of smooth muscle and elastic tissue by chronic necrotizing infections eading to permanent dilation of bronchi and bronchioles

Solution to Question 2:
The given gross image is characteristic of centriacinar emphysema.


In paraseptal emphysema subpleural spaces are mainly affected (shown below).

In panacinar emphysema all air spaces within acini are evenly enlarged (shown below).

Solution to Question 3:
Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) usually have centriacinar emphysema which involves respiratory bronchioles.
Emphysema is classified into four major types:
Centriacinar
Panacinar
Parasepta

Solution to Question 4:
The above gross specimen shows emphysematous damage involving enlargement of the entire acinus suggestive of panacinar emphysema. It is caused due to alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency.
In panacinar (panlobular) emphysema, the acini are uniformly enlarged from the level of the respiratory bronchiole to the terminal blind alveoli. It occurs commonly in the lower zones and in the anterior margins of the lung and is most severe at the bases.
The image below shows panacinar emphysema.

Solution to Question 5:
The above scenario is suggestive of 1-antitrypsin deficiency. The 1-antitrypsin is encoded by the proteinase inhibitor (Pi) locus on chromosome 14.
1-AT is a polymorphic gene located on chromosome 14. It is part of a larger family of structurally unique serine protease inhibitors, referred to as serpins. The most common clinically significant mutation in 1-antitrypsin deficiency is PiZZ.
1-antitrypsin, normally present in serum, tissue fluids, and macrophages is a major inhibitor of proteases (particularly elastase) secreted by neutrophils during inflammation. The absence of 1- antitrypsin activity results in excessive digestion of elastic tissue by elastase.
Patients with 1-antitrypsin deficiency have a markedly increased tendency to develop panacinar emphysema.
Solution to Question 6:
In the above image, y/x denotes the ratio of the thickness of the submucosal gland layer to that of the bronchial wall. This is called as Reid index and it is normally 0.4.
It is increased in chronic bronchitis.

Chronic bronchitis is defined by the presence of a persistent productive cough for at least 3 consecutive months in at least 2 consecutive years. The single most important cause is cigarette smoking. The distinctive features of chronic bronchitis are as follows:
Hypersecretion of mucus
Hypertrophy of submucosal glands
Goblet-cell hyperplasia
Inflammation
Difference between clinical presentation of emphysema and chronic bronchitis:
Predominant Bronchitis
Predominant Emphysema

Solution to Question 7:
The above clinical scenario gives a picture of acute exacerbation of COPD. The most common bacterial cause of acute COPD exacerbation is Haemophilus influenzae.
Moraxella is the second most common bacterial cause of acute exacerbation of COPD.
Solution to Question 8:
The given clinical scenario and the sputum microscopy showing Charcot–Leyden crystals (arrows in below image), lakes of mucus, and numerous eosinophils, are diagnostic of bronchial asthma.

Asthma is characterized by reversible bronchoconstriction caused by airway hyperresponsiveness to a variety of stimuli. Atopic asthma is caused by a TH2 and IgE-mediated immunologic reaction to environmental allergens (type-1 hypersensitivity reaction). Triggers for non-atopic asthma are less clear but include viral infections and inhaled air pollutants.
Genetic susceptibility for developing asthma:
Chromosome 5q - site of the susceptibility locus for asthma
IL-13 gene polymorphisms (on 5q chromosome) - most consistent associations with asthma or allergic disease
IL-4 receptor gene variants - associated with atopy, elevated total serum IgE, and asthma The sputum of patients with bronchial asthma shows:
Charcot–Leyden crystals - made of an eosinophilic membrane protein called galectin 10
Curschmann spirals - spirals of mucus plugs from subepithelial mucous gland ducts or bronchioles
Creola bodies - desquamated epithelial cells
Numerous eosinophils
Note: The hygiene hypothesis was previously used to explain the development of asthma and other hypersensitivity disorders.
Solution to Question 9:
The image above shows markedly distended bronchi involving the middle and lower lobe of the lung which is seen in bronchiectasis.
Bronchiectasis is a suppurative lung disease with abnormal and irreversible dilatation of the bronchi. It is an end-stage condition of various diseases that result in destruction of the bronchial wall and its surrounding supporting tissues.
The normal clearing mechanisms are impaired, either due to congenital causes or due to bronchial obstruction. This results in pooling of secretions, secondary infection, and inflammation, often with necrosis, fibrosis, and eventually cystic dilation of airways up to four times the normal size.
Note: Kartagener syndrome is a primary ciliary dyskinesia characterized by the classical triad of situs inversus, chronic sinusitis, and bronchiectasis.
Solution to Question 10:
The image above shows alveolar spaces filled with balls of fibroblasts (Masson bodies). This is characteristically seen in cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP).
Masson bodies are polypoid plugs of loose organizing connective tissue within alveolar ducts, alveoli, and bronchioles along with foci of fibrosis.

The clinical presentation of COP is the development of nonspecific systemic and respiratory symptoms. It is associated with filling of the lung alveoli that is visible on a chest X-ray as patchy unilateral or bilateral consolidation.
COP was previously known as bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP).
Solution to Question 11:
Silicosis is the most common pneumoconiosis in the world.
Silicosis is caused by the inhalation of crystalline silica (e.g., quartz). Individuals involved with the concrete work, sandblasting, stone carvers, and jewelers using chalk molds are at high risk.
Pneumoconioses encompass a group of chronic fibrosing diseases of the lung resulting from exposure to organic and inorganic particulates, most commonly mineral dust.
Solution to Question 12:
Pleural plaques are the most common manifestation of asbestos exposure.
They are well-circumscribed plaques of dense collagen, often containing calcium. They develop most frequently on the parietal pleura and over the domes of the diaphragm. They do not contain asbestos bodies, and only rarely occur in persons without prior asbestos exposure.
Asbestos occurs in two distinct forms - serpentine chrysotile (more common)
and amphibole (more pathogenic). Exposure may result in the following conditions:
Localized fibrous plaques or, rarely, diffuse pleural fibrosis
Pleural effusions
Parenchymal interstitial fibrosis (asbestosis)
Lung carcinoma
Mesotheliomas
Extrapulmonary neoplasms including laryngeal, ovarian, and colon carcinomas
The image below shows fibrous pleural plaques seen on the diaphragmatic pleural surface in asbestosis.

Solution to Question 13:
This clinical scenario and image showing typical asbestos bodies are suggestive of asbestosis.
Asbestosis is a type of pneumoconiosis associated with asbestos exposure. The disease-causing capabilities of the different forms of asbestos depend on concentration, size, shape, and solubility. This condition is marked by diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis.
Asbestos bodies are a typical finding. They are golden brown, fusiform, or beaded rods with a translucent center. They consist of asbestos fibers coated with an iron-containing proteinaceous material and arise when these fibers are phagocytosed by macrophages.


Other inorganic particulates may become coated with similar iron-protein complexes and are called ferruginous bodies.
Solution to Question 14:
Patient B is a worker in the sandblasting industry with eggshell calcification on x-ray. This is suggestive of silicosis. Patients with silicosis have a higher risk of tuberculosis as the crystalline silica impairs the ability of pulmonary macrophages to kill phagocytosed mycobacteria.
The given clinical picture of patient A is classical of asbestosis and that of patient C is suggestive of anthracosis.

The image shows golden-brown, beaded rods with a translucent center called asbestos bodies which are seen in asbestosis. These patients are at risk of developing both lung
carcinoma and mesothelioma.

Asbestosis is marked by diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis and the presence of multiple asbestos bodies.

Option C: Occupational asthma may be triggered by fumes (epoxy resins, plastics), organic and chemical dust (wood, cotton, platinum), gases (toluene), or other chemicals (formaldehyde, penicillin products).
Solution to Question 16:
The given clinical scenario and image showing the lesion of lupus pernio point towards sarcoidosis. It is a multisystemic disease characterized by polyclonal hypergammaglobulinemia.
Lupus pernio is seen in cutaneous sarcoidosis and presents as infiltrated erythematoviolaceous plaques involving the nose, cheeks, ears, lips, forehead, and fingers. On the cheeks,
telangiectasia is characteristic. It is usually painless. As it does not ulcerate, it is not as mutilating as lupus vulgaris.
Immunological abnormalities include:
Polyclonal hyperglobulinemia
A CD4/CD8 ratio > 3.5
T- cell expansion and macrophage activation
Impaired dendritic cell function
Anergy to common skin tests.
The hallmarks of sarcoidosis include:
B/L hilar lymphadenopathy
Non-caseating granulomas
Lupus pernio
Erythema nodosum (acute sarcoidosis) Syndromes associated with sarcoidosis are:
Mikulicz syndrome - sarcoidosis combined with uveoparotid involvement
Lofgren's syndrome - acute presentation of sarcoidosis, consisting of arthritis, erythema nodosum, and bilateral hilar adenopathy
The image below shows the characteristic non-caseating sarcoid granuloma.

The image below shows stellate inclusions known as asteroid bodies that are found within giant cells in approximately 60% of the granulomas.


The image below shows laminated concretions composed of calcium and proteins known as Schaumann bodies that are found within giant cells in approximately 60% of the granulomas.


Solution to Question 17:
Bone morphogenetic protein receptor 2 (BMPR2) is the most common gene mutation
in pulmonary hypertension. Inactivating mutations in this gene are found in 75% of the familial cases of pulmonary hypertension, and 25% of sporadic cases.
The BMPR2 receptor is a cell surface protein belonging to the TGF- receptor superfamily. It is involved in the regulation of growth, differentiation, and apoptosis of pulmonary artery endothelial and smooth muscle cells.
Due to the mutation, there is enhanced proliferation and reduced apoptosis of vascular endothelial and smooth muscle cells leading to pulmonary hypertension.
Solution to Question 18:
The given scenario and microscopy showing alveoli filled with a dense, amorphous, protein-lipid granular precipitate are suggestive of autoimmune pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP). It is caused by circulating neutralizing antibodies specific for granulocyte-macrophage
colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF).


PAP is a condition characterized by the accumulation of surfactants in alveoli and terminal airways. It can be due to impaired clearance or abnormal production of surfactants.
PAP can be of three forms:
Primary (most common): There is impaired GM-CSF-dependent surfactant clearance by the alveolar macrophages. It can be due to:
Autoantibodies against GM-CSF (acquired/idiopathic/autoimmune PAP)
Mutation in GM-CSF receptors (hereditary PAP)
Secondary: There is a reduction in the number or ability of alveolar macrophages that causes impaired surfactant clearance. It can be due to:
Silicosis
Immunodeficiency disorders
Hematopoietic disorders and malignancies
Congenital: It affects neonates and children. There is abnormal surfactant production due to mutation in the genes coding for:
Surfactant protein B
Surfactant protein C
ATP binding cassette protein member 3

Silicosis: Crazy paving pattern
Mesothelioma: Malignant pleural effusion without mediastinal shift
Caplan syndrome: Initially demonstrated in coal workers
Asbestosis: Basal lobes are involved
Caplan's syndrome also called rheumatoid pneumoconiosis, is a combination
of rheumatoid arthritis and pneumoconiosis. It manifests as pneumoconiotic nodules along with features of seropositive rheumatoid arthritis. Caplan syndrome was first described in coal miners and later in patients with silicosis too.

Solution to Question 20:
The black-colored pigment in the hilar lymph node of the resected bronchoscopic specimen is likely to be an anthracotic pigment.
The black color is due to the deposition of carbon particles. The inhaled carbon particles are engulfed by the lung macrophages and then transported to the hilar lymph nodes.
This accumulates and causes the blackening of the lung tissues or anthracosis.
It is commonly seen in people who work in environments where there is high air pollution with carbon particles, such as coal mines. It is also the most common exogenous pigment found in the human body as a result of air pollution in urban areas. The aggregates of the carbon dust may induce fibroblastic reaction or emphysema that may lead to a condition called coal worker's pneumoconiosis.
The following image shows anthracosis with deposition of black carbon particles, within the cytoplasm of macrophages.

Option B: Melanin is brown-black in color which occurs as a result of oxidation of tyrosine in melanocytes, as shown in the following histopathology of a lymph node.

Option C: Lipochrome or lipofuscin (brown lipid) is seen as a yellow-brown pigment in histopathological sections of the liver and heart of normal aging patients, patients with severe malnutrition, and cancer cachexia. It is derived through lipid peroxidation and indicates free radical injury and lipid peroxidation. The following image shows a cardiac myocyte with fine yellow-brown lipofuscin granules in the perinuclear region.


Option D: Hemosiderin is a hemoglobin-derived golden-yellow colored pigment seen in conditions associated with iron overload such as hemochromatosis. The following image shows extensive intra-alveolar hemosiderin deposition following pulmonary hemorrhage.

The most common histology is adenocarcinoma (43.8%), followed by squamous cell (26.2%).

Solution to Question 3:
The given image shows keratin pearls and islands of large polygonal malignant cells. These as seen in squamous cell carcinoma of the lungs. P40 is the most sensitive and specific marker for squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the lungs.
Other markers include cytokeratin 5/6 and P63.
TTF-1 and napsin-A are the markers for adenocarcinoma.
Chromogranin, synaptophysin, and CD56 are the markers for small cell lung carcinoma.
Note: The 2015 World Health Organization Classification of Lung Tumors has made
a recommendation that at least one antibody each for squamous (P40 or P63) and glandular (e.g. TTF-1) differentiation should be used for an initial workup. Thus a simple panel of TTF-1 and p40 may be able to classify most non-small cell carcinoma-not otherwise specified cases.
Solution to Question 4:
Small-cell carcinoma of the lung is the most aggressive type of lung cancer.
This tumor originates from neuroendocrine progenitor cells (Kulchitsky cells), which are present in the lining bronchial epithelium.
Histopathological examination of small cell lung carcinoma shows:
Clusters of small cells with scant cytoplasm
Ill-defined cell borders
Finely granular nuclear chromatin (salt and pepper pattern)
Absent or inconspicuous nucleoli
The cells are round, oval, or spindle-shaped, and nuclear molding is prominent. The image below shows the histopathological findings of small cell lung carcinoma.

Solution to Question 5:
The given clinical features and the histopathology showing the Azzopardi effect are suggestive of a small cell carcinoma of the lung.
Azzopardi effect is described as basophilic staining of vascular walls due to encrustation by DNA from necrotic tumor cells.

Solution to Question 7:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of adenocarcinoma lung.
It is the most common form of lung cancer. It is an invasive malignant epithelial tumor with glandular differentiation. The tumor cells produce mucin. It is usually located peripherally (it arises from the terminal bronchiole).
Molecular genetics show frequent mutations in EGFR, ALK, ROS, MET, and RET (Receptor tyrosine kinase genes) or KRAS mutations.
Histologically, lepidic growth patterns are seen. It refers to the pattern of spread of the tumor in which the tumor cells “crawl” along normal-appearing alveolar septae and resembles butterflies resting on a fence.
Adenocarcinomas grow in various patterns, including acinar, lepidic, papillary, micropapillary, and solid with mucin formation. Tumor cells are positive for mucin and thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1)
Tumors 3 cm or less in diameter characterized by lepidic growth pattern without stromal invasion are now called adenocarcinoma in situ (formerly called bronchoalveolar carcinoma).
The image below shows histopathological findings of adenocarcinoma of the lung.

Solution to Question 8:
Thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1), mucin, and napsin-A are positive in adenocarcinoma lung.
TTF-1 is required for normal lung development. It can be used to distinguish primary adenocarcinoma of the lungs (TTF-1 positive) from other histological types of lung cancers, metastatic adenocarcinoma, and mesothelioma (TTF-1 negative).
P40 and P63 are the markers for squamous cell carcinoma.
Chromogranin, synaptophysin, and CD56 are the markers for small cell lung carcinoma.
Solution to Question 9:
Calretinin is most likely to be positive in this tumour as the given clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of malignant mesothelioma.
Malignant mesothelioma is a rare malignant tumour of the pleura, associated with heavy asbestos exposure (shipping factory). The lifetime risk of developing mesothelioma in heavily exposed individuals is as high as 7% to 10%.
It has strong male predilection (3:1). There is a long latent period of 25 to 45 years for the development of asbestos-related mesothelioma.
The image below shows a lung autopsy sample with mesothelioma.

Grossly, it appears as a diffuse lesion arising either from the visceral or parietal pleura. The affected lung becomes ensheathed by a thick layer of soft, gelatinous, grayish pink tumor tissue.
Microscopically, they are of three types: epithelioid (60%), sarcomatoid (20%), and mixed (20%).
Electron microscopy in mesothelioma will show numerous long, slender microvilli and abundant monofilaments but absent microvillous rootlets and lamellar bodies.
The image below shows the epithelioid type of mesothelioma showing cuboidal, columnar, or flattened cells forming tubular or papillary structures resembling adenocarcinoma. Inset shows strong positivity for Calretinin immunostain.

Solution to Question 10:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of bronchial carcinoid. Bronchial neuroendocrine tumors
(NETs) arise from Kulchitsky cells.
WHO divides neuroendocrine neoplasms into four categories:
Typical carcinoid
Atypical carcinoid
Large-cell neuroendocrine carcinoma
Small-cell carcinoma
Carcinoid tumors are low-grade malignant epithelial neoplasms that represent 1% to 5% of all lung tumors. It is not related to smoking. Carcinoids may occur in patients with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1.
On gross examination, these tumors grow as fingerlike or spherical polypoid masses that project into the lumen of the bronchus or as collar button lesions, penetrating the bronchial wall to fan out in the peribronchial tissue.
Histologically, the tumor is composed of organoid, trabecular, palisading, ribbon, or rosette-like arrangements of cells separated by a delicate fibrovascular stroma. On electron microscopy, the cells exhibit the dense-core neurosecretory granules.
Immunohistochemistry shows positivity for serotonin, neuron-specific enolase, bombesin, calcitonin, or other peptides.

question_text:
% of the cases may produce carcinoid syndrome.
Most carcinoids follow a relatively benign course and have good prognosis.
Solution to Question 11:
Approximately, 10% of bronchial carcinoids give rise to the carcinoid syndrome.
Most bronchial carcinoids follow a relatively benign course, do not have secretory activity and do not metastasize to distant sites.
Classic carcinoid syndrome is characterized by intermittent attacks of diarrhea, flushing, bronchospasm and cyanosis.
Carcinoid syndrome is due to excessive production of serotonin, a specialised product of tryptophan metabolism by argentaffin cells (cells in the carcinoid tumor). It is then metabolised and excreted in urine.
If urinary levels of 5- HIAA exceed 25 mg/day, a diagnosis of carcinoid syndrome can be made.
Solution to Question 12:
Cartilage is the most common connective tissue in lung hamartoma.
Pulmonary hamartoma consists of nodules of connective tissue intersected by epithelial clefts. There are islands of cartilage, fat, smooth muscle, and entrapped respiratory epithelium in
pulmonary hamartoma.
It is a benign clonal neoplasm associated with chromosomal aberrations involving either 6p21 or 12q14-q15.
Lung hamartoma is usually discovered as an incidental coin lesion on a routine chest radiograph. The given below is an image of lung hamartoma.

Pituitary ,Parathyroids and Pancreas

Solution to Question 1:
This clinical scenario and brain MRI showing a pituitary adenoma are suggestive of a lactotroph adenoma (prolactinoma).

Pituitary adenomas are usually found in adults. The most common genetic alterations in this condition are mutations in G proteins (particularly GNAS).
Depending on their size, they are classified as:
Microadenomas - diameter < 1 cm
Macroadenomas - diameter > 1 cm
They may be functioning or non-functioning. The most common type of functioning pituitary adenomas are prolactinomas.
The clinical features of prolactinoma include:
Due to mass effect -
Features of raised intracranial tension
Visual field disturbances (bitemporal hemianopia) - due to compression of optic chiasm
Hypopituitarism - due to compressed hypophyseal stalk
Due to hyperprolactinemia -
Galactorrhoea
Amenorrhoea or oligomenorrhoea
Infertility
Loss of libido
Gynecomastia
Serum prolactin concentrations tend to correlate with the size of the adenoma. The normal range of serum prolactin is 5-20 g/L. The diagnosis of prolactinoma is most likely to be associated with a prolactin level >200 g/L.
Solution to Question 2:
The following features are required for the diagnosis of pituitary carcinoma:
A pituitary tumor that has metastasized to distant sites, either craniospinal or systemic sites
(and/or)
Presence of a pituitary tumor that is not contiguous with the primary sellar tumour
Pituitary carcinoma is extremely rare (< 1% of total tumors). They are associated with activating mutations of the HRAS oncogene.
The diagnosis of pituitary carcinoma cannot be made based on histologic appearance alone. Though pituitary adenomas normally show cellular monomorphism and the absence of a reticulin network, they can have some overlapping features with malignant tumors such as:
Atypical adenomas - show pleomorphism and atypical mitosis
Invasive adenomas -
Non-encapsulated
Show local invasion into cavernous and sphenoid sinuses, dura, brain
However, they remain confined to the primary tumor site
Solution to Question 3:
Parathyroid hormone (PTH) is secreted by the chief cells of the parathyroid glands.
The function of the parathyroids is to regulate calcium homeostasis. This gland is composed of two cell types:
Chief cells -
Polygonal cells with uniform nuclei and pink cytoplasm
Water-clear appearance - due to presence of large amounts of cytoplasmic glycogen
Secretory granules containing PTH
Oxyphil cells - Slightly larger cells with acidophilic cytoplasm with no known function. The following image shows the normal histology of the parathyroid gland:


C-cells or parafollicular cells are present in the thyroid. They secrete calcitonin.
Solution to Question 4:
The most common cause of asymptomatic hypercalcemia (isolated hypercalcemia without signs or symptoms) is primary hyperparathyroidism. It is also the most common cause of hypercalcemia overall.
Primary hyperparathyroidism results in autonomous overproduction of parathyroid hormone (PTH), resulting in elevated levels. It usually results from an adenoma or hyperplasia of parathyroid tissue.
The most common cause of symptomatic hypercalcemia is malignancy. The most common mechanism through which osteolytic tumors induce hypercalcemia is the secretion of the PTH-related peptide (PTHrP).
Solution to Question 5:
The given clinical picture is highly suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism. The most common cause is a sporadic, solitary parathyroid adenoma.
Parathyroid tumors may be associated with cyclin D1 gene inversions and MEN1
mutations. Hyperparathyroidism refers to elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH). It is classified into:
Primary - autonomous overproduction of PTH
Secondary - compensatory hypersecretion of PTH in response to prolonged hypocalcemia
Tertiary - persistent hypersecretion of PTH even after correction of prolonged hypocalcemia. (e.g. after renal transplant)
The classical symptoms and signs of primary hyperparathyroidism are due to hypercalcemia as well as increased parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels. The features of hypercalcemia are as follows:
The features of elevated PTH levels are as follows:
Osteitis fibrosa cystica
Osteopenia/osteoporosis
Hyperuricemia and gout
Pseudogout
Increased production of calcitrio
Nephrolithiasis
Hypophosphatemia
Anemia
The clinical signs associated with primary hyperparathyroidism can be remembered with the mnemonic - “bones, stones, groans, moans with fatigue overtones”

Solution to Question 6:
The clinical scenario and lab findings point towards a diagnosis of hyperparathyroidism. The bone finding associated with this condition is osteitis fibrosa cystica.
This condition is also called brown tumor or von Recklinghausen disease of bone.
In hyperparathyroidism, high levels of PTH result in increased osteoclast activity. This results in bone loss which predisposes to microfractures and secondary hemorrhages. This results in the following changes:
An influx of macrophages that form giant cells
Mass of reparative fibrous tissue
Increased vascularity, hemorrhage, and hemosiderin deposition - results in brown color
The image given below is showing a brown tumor with numerous giant cells with interstitial hemorrhage, hemosiderin.

Option A: Osteoporosis circumscripta is a large, well-defined lytic lesion seen in the skull of patients with Paget's disease.
Option B: Fraying and cupping of the metaphysis of the bones are classically seen in patients suffering from rickets.
Option D: Punched out lytic lesions of the bone are seen in patients with multiple myeloma.
Solution to Question 7:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of hypoglycemia due to hyperinsulinemia. As C-peptide is a marker of endogenous insulin secretion, its levels would help in identifying the source of insulin:
High C-peptide - excess insulin production (insulinoma)
Normal/ low C-peptide - exogenous insulin administration (factitious disorder)
The precursor molecule of insulin is pre-proinsulin, which gets cleaved to form proinsulin. This proinsulin gets cleaved to form insulin and C-peptide (by-product). Hence, both are secreted in equimolar quantities during insulin secretion. Hence, the level of C-peptide corresponds to the level of endogenous insulin.
The levels of C-peptide decrease with the loss of  -cell mass in type 1 diabetes.
Solution to Question 8:
Edward's syndrome or trisomy 18 is not associated with diabetes mellitus. Genetic syndromes associated with diabetes mellitus include:
Down's syndrome (trisomy 21)
Klinefelter's syndrome (XXY karyotype)
Turner's syndrome (XO karyotype)
Prader–Willi syndrome (deletion of paternal chromosome 15) Other causes of diabetes mellitus include:
Genetic defects in insulin action -
Type A insulin resistance
Lipoatrophic diabetes
Exocrine pancreatic defects -
Chronic pancreatitis
Pancreatectomy/trauma
Neoplasia
Cystic fibrosis
Hemochromatosis
Fibrocalculous pancreatopathy
Endocrinopathies -
Acromegaly
Cushing syndrome
Hyperthyroidism
Pheochromocytoma
Glucagonoma
Infections -
Cytomegalovirus
Coxsackie B virus
Congenital rubella
Solution to Question 9:
The image shows a Congo red-stained biopsy specimen with apple-green birefringence under polarized microscopy. It is indicative of amyloid accumulation within the pancreatic islets. This is commonly associated with type 2 diabetes mellitus.
Amyloid deposition begins in and around capillaries and between cells. In advanced stages, the islets may be virtually obliterated and fibrosis may also be observed.
Solution to Question 10:
Advanced glycation end products (AGEs) result in increased procoagulant effects on endothelial cells and macrophages, not anticoagulant effects.
AGEs are formed by nonenzymatic reactions between intracellular glucose-derived dicarbonyl precursors with the amino groups of proteins. They bind to a specific receptor (RAGE) that is expressed on inflammatory cells (macrophages and T cells), endothelium, and vascular smooth muscle.
The detrimental effects of the AGE-RAGE signalling axis within the vascular compartment include:
Release of cytokines and growth factors, including TGF- - leads to deposition of excess basement membrane materia
Generation of reactive oxygen species in endothelial cells.
Increased procoagulant activity on endothelial cells and macrophages.
Enhanced proliferation of vascular smooth muscle cells and synthesis of extracellular matrix
These effects are responsible for the microvascular and macrovascular complications in diabetes mellitus.
Solution to Question 11:
Insulinoma ( -cell tumors) is the most common pancreatic endocrine neoplasm. It produces sufficient insulin to induce clinically significant hypoglycemia.
The three most common and distinctive clinical syndromes associated with functional pancreatic endocrine neoplasms are as follows:
Hyperinsulinism
Zollinger–Ellison syndrome (hypergastrinemia)
Multiple endocrine neoplasias (MEN)
Solution to Question 12:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a gastrin-producing tumor or gastrinoma
(Zollinger-Ellison syndrome). The family history of pituitary and parathyroid tumors is suggestive
of MEN1 syndrome. This syndrome is associated with multifocal gastrinomas. On the other hand, sporadic gastrinomas are usually single.
Gastrinomas usually arise in the duodenum, peripancreatic soft tissues, pancreas. The site of origin is the duodenum when ZES is associated with MEN1. Most tumors are locally invasive and metastasize early.
Hypergastrinemia gives rise to extreme gastric acid secretion and peptic ulceration, that is refractory to proton pump inhibitors. It results in multiple ulcers in duodenum, stomach, and uncommon areas like jejunum.
Solution to Question 13:
The given scenario is suggestive of a -cell tumor or somatostatinoma. It results in hypersecretion of somatostatin.
Somatostatin inhibits pancreatic and biliary secretions. Patients with somatostatinoma usually present with vague abdominal pain along with the triad of:
Gallstones - due to bile stasis
Diabetes mellitus - due to inhibition of insulin secretion
Steatorrhea - due to inhibition of pancreatic exocrine secretion and bile secretion
Solution to Question 14:
The given scenario is suggestive of WDHA syndrome. It is due to hypersecretion of VIP
(vasoactive-intestinal peptide).
WDHA syndrome includes the following features:
Watery diarrhea
Hypokalemia (Serum K+< 3.5 mmol/L)
Achlorhydria (bloating, indigestion, iron deficiency)
Neural crest tumors, such as neuroblastomas, ganglioneuroblastoma, ganglioneuromas, and pheochromocytomas can also be associated with VIPoma syndrome.

question_text:
b
Solution to Question 1:
Graves' disease is the most common cause of endogenous hyperthyroidism.
It is an autoimmune disorder due to the production of TSH-receptor stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI) which cause hyperthyroidism.
It is characterized by the triad of:
Thyrotoxicosis
Infiltrative ophthalmopathy (exophthalmos)
Dermopathy (pretibial myxedema)
Glycosaminoglycan deposition, lymphoid infiltrates, and fatty infiltrates are responsible for ophthalmopathy and dermopathy.
Grossly, there is a diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland and a beefy deep red parenchyma. Histology shows tall crowded follicular cells with scalloped margins and lymphoid infiltrates. Laboratory features include elevations in free T3 and T4 and decreased TSH.
Solution to Question 2:
The given clinical scenario along with the given image showing exophthalmos is suggestive of Graves' ophthalmopathy. Sympathetic overactivity of Muller's muscle results in a wide, staring gaze and lid lag, but not exophthalmos.
Exophthalmos is characterized by abnormal protrusion of the eyeball. It is due to increased volume of the retroorbital connective tissues and extraocular muscles because of:
Marked lymphocytic infiltration of the retro-orbital space
Inflammation with edema and swelling of extraocular muscles
Accumulation of hydrophilic glycosaminoglycans such as hyaluronic acid and chondroitin sulfate
Increased numbers of adipocytes (fatty infiltration)
Solution to Question 3:
Hashimoto thyroiditis is not associated with hyperthyroidism. It is associated with transient thyrotoxicosis, followed by chronic hypothyroidism.
Thyrotoxicosis is a hypermetabolic state caused by elevated circulating levels of free T3 and T4. On the other hand, hyperfunctioning of the thyroid gland itself is referred to as hyperthyroidism.

Solution to Question 4:
The given image shows follicular hyperplasia with a scalloping colloid. The clinical scenario along with the image is suggestive of Graves' disease.
In Graves' disease, the thyroid is diffusely hyperplastic. The follicles are lined by tall columnar epithelial cells that project into lumina. The cells actively resorb the colloid in the center of the follicle which results in a scalloped appearance of the edges of the colloid.


Solution to Question 5:
The given clinical picture and image showing Hurthle cells are suggestive of Hashimoto's thyroiditis.
In this condition, the following microscopic features are seen:
Intense lymphocytic infiltrate containing small lymphocytes, plasma cells, and well developed germinal centers
Atrophied thyroid follicles
The epithelial cells lining the follicles contain eosinophilic granular cytoplasm (oncocytes)
This is called oncocytic metaplasia
These cells are called Hurthle cells
Ultrastructurally, these cells have numerous mitochondria

Hashimoto's thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease, characterized by the gradual destruction of the thyroid gland leading to thyroid failure. It is commonly seen in women between 45 to 65 years of age. It is caused by the presence of circulating autoantibodies against thyroglobulin and thyroid peroxidase.
Morphologically, there is a diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland, with an intact capsule. It is well demarcated from the adjacent structures.
Note: Oncocytes can arise in various tissues and are referred to as follows:
Hurthle cells/ Ashkenazy cells - thyroid gland
Oxyphilic cells - parotid gland
Apocrine metaplasia - breast
Solution to Question 6:
Orphan-Annie eye nuclei are a feature of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, not Hashimoto's thyroiditis.
Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease that results in the destruction of the thyroid gland and gradual and progressive thyroid failure.
It is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in areas of the world where iodine levels are sufficient.
The thyroid gland is often diffusely enlarged, painless, with some degree of hypothyroidism. This may be preceded by transient thyrotoxicosis (Hashitoxicosis). It is associated with an increased risk of:
Other autoimmune conditions
Extranodal marginal zone B-cell lymphomas
Papillary carcinoma
Histologically, the following findings are seen:
Intense lymphocytic infiltrate containing small lymphocytes, plasma cells, and well developed germinal centers
Atrophied thyroid follicles
The epithelial cells lining the follicles contain eosinophilic granular cytoplasm
This is called oncocytic metaplasia
These cells are called Hurthle cells


Solution to Question 7:
Autoimmune hypothyroidism is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas of the world.
The thyroid gland is typically enlarged. The circulating autoantibodies found in this disorder are:
Antimicrosomal antibodies
Antithyroid peroxidase antibodies
Antithyroglobulin antibodies
Note: Wolff-Chaikoff effect refers to iodine-induced hypothyroidism.
Solution to Question 8:
The given clinical condition is suggestive of subacute granulomatous thyroiditis.
It is the most common cause of a painful thyroid. It is also known as painful subacute thyroiditis, de Quervain thyroiditis, or migratory thyroiditis (this is because the pain can shift to different locations in the thyroid).
Option A: Subacute lymphocytic thyroiditis (postpartum thyroiditis) is typically painless. It often occurs after pregnancy and is characterized by lymphocytic inflammation in the thyroid.
Option B: Riedel's thyroiditis is a rare disorder characterized by a painless, rapidly growing thyroid mass with extensive fibrosis involving the thyroid and contiguous neck structures.
Option C: Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease that presents as painless enlargement of the thyroid associated with some degree of hypothyroidism in middle-aged women.
Solution to Question 9:
Nodules in younger patients are more likely to be malignant than those in older patients.
The solitary thyroid nodule is a palpably discrete swelling within an otherwise apparently normal thyroid gland. A higher incidence is seen in areas with endemic iodine deficiency. They are more common in women than in men.
Malignant transformation is more common in:
Solitary nodules > Multinodular goiter
Solitary nodules in males > females
Cold nodules > Hot nodules
However, benign neoplasms are more common than thyroid carcinomas by a ratio of nearly 10:1.
Solution to Question 10:
The most common thyroid cancer is papillary carcinoma.
Major subtypes of thyroid carcinoma and their relative frequencies are as follows:
Papillary carcinoma - most common
Follicular carcinoma
Medullary carcinoma
Anaplastic carcinoma - least common
Thyroid carcinomas are derived from the thyroid follicular epithelium, except medullary carcinoma which is derived from parafollicular C cells.
Solution to Question 11:
The given image shows psammoma bodies, which are seen in papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. This type of carcinoma is associated with a history of long-standing unresected thyroglossal cyst.

Psammoma bodies are concentrically calcified structures often present within the cores of papillae in papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. These structures are almost never found in follicular and medullary carcinomas. They arise from:
Infarction and dystrophic calcification of papillae tips
Calcification of intra-lymphatic tumor thrombi. Psammoma bodies are seen in:
Papillary carcinoma (thyroid, kidney, endometrium, lungs)
Prolactinoma
Meningioma
Papillary serous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary
Solution to Question 12:
The presence of empty appearing nuclei, also called Orphan Annie eye nuclei as seen in the above image is diagnostic of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.
Microscopic features of papillary thyroid carcinoma include:
Branching papillae with fibrovascular stalk
Covering epithelium is simple or stratified cuboidal
Orphan Annie eye nuclei -
Empty-appearing nuclei due to dispersed chromatin
They are diagnostic, regardless of papillary architecture
Psammoma bodies - concentric calcified structures
Foci of lymphatic invasion


Note: Orphan Annie refers to a comic book character with empty appearing eyes, as shown below.

Solution to Question 13:
Hematogenous spread is rare in papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. Metastases to lymph nodes are more commonly associated with this condition.
It is associated with previous exposure to ionizing radiation. The presence of nuclear features such as Orphan Annie eye nuclei (empty-appearing nuclei) are diagnostic, regardless of papillary architecture.


Solution to Question 14:
The FNAC image is suggestive of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. Among the given options, the most common site of metastasis is the lungs.

The histological features of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid are:
Papillary architecture
Nuclear findings (enough to diagnose the condition even in the absence of papillary architecture)
Nuclear overlapping, grooving, crowding
Ground-glass appearance (Orphan Annie eye nuclei)
Dusty and pale chromatin
Intranuclear inclusion bodies
The most common mode of spread overall is through the lymphatic route, with lymph node metastases being common at initial presentation.
Solution to Question 15:
Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid is associated with gain-of-function mutations in the following genes:
NTRK1 (receptor tyrosine kinase)
RET (receptor tyrosine kinase)
BRAF (serine/threonine kinase)

The most common variant of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid is the follicular variant. It has the following features:
Characteristic nuclear features of papillary carcinoma
Almost entirely follicular architecture
Can be either -
Encapsulated - favorable prognosis (or)
Poorly circumscribed and infiltrative - requires aggressive treatment The variants of papillary carcinoma include:

Solution to Question 17:
Papillary thyroid cancers have the best prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate seen in more than 95% of the patients.
The prognosis of papillary thyroid cancers is dependent on several factors, including age (being less favorable among patients older than 40 years), the presence of extrathyroidal extension, and presence of distant metastases.
The thyroid cancer with the worst prognosis is anaplastic carcinoma.

Option C: Anaplastic carcinoma is associated with rapidly progressive swelling with obstructive features and undifferentiated cells on histopathology.
Option D: In medullary carcinoma, amyloid stroma is seen on histopathology.
Solution to Question 19:
RAS mutations are associated with follicular carcinoma.
It is also associated with acquired mutations in the PIK3CA gene (PI3K/AKT arm of the receptor tyrosine kinase signaling pathway) and the PAX8-PPARG fusion gene.

p53 is is a tumor-suppressor gene and not an oncogene.

Solution to Question 21:
The given clinical scenario and histological appearance showing amyloid stroma are suggestive of medullary carcinoma of the thyroid. This condition can occur in the setting of MEN2A (Sipple syndrome) or MEN2B.


Medullary carcinomas of the thyroid are neuroendocrine neoplasms derived from the parafollicular cells or C cells of the thyroid. They may be:
Sporadic (70%)
Familial or associated with MEN2 syndromes (30%) -
More aggressive and metastasize more frequently than sporadic
Usually bilateral and multicentric
Both forms can be associated with RET mutations. These tumors may present with:
Mass in the neck
Dysphagia
Hoarseness
Diarrhea due to the secretion of VIP
Cushing's syndrome due to ACTH secretion
Histopathology shows polygonal to spindle-shaped cells, which may form nests, trabeculae, and even follicles. Acellular amyloid deposits derived from calcitonin polypeptides are present in the stroma. These lesions secrete calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen.

Solution to Question 1:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of iatrogenic Cushing's syndrome. In this condition, the normal basophilic cytoplasm of the corticotrophs of anterior pituitary becomes homogeneous and pale. This is termed the Crooke hyaline change and is due to the accumulation of intermediate keratin filaments in the cytoplasm.
This change occurs due to high levels of circulating glucocorticoids in Cushing's syndrome.

Based on the cause of Cushing's syndrome, the following pathological changes are seen in the adrenals:
Iatrogenic - atrophy of zona fasciculata and zona reticularis (as zona glomerulosa functions independently of ACTH)
ACTH-dependent - diffuse hyperplasia (due to high ACTH levels)
ACTH-independent - nodular hyperplasia, adenoma, or carcinoma
Note: Eosinophilic inclusion bodies in adrenal cells are called spironolactone bodies. They are seen in Conn's syndrome.
Solution to Question 2:
Obesity is the most common clinical feature of Cushing's syndrome.
Clinical features of Cushing’s syndrome are attributed to the glucocorticoid, mineralocorticoid, and sex steroid actions of cortisol. They include:
System

Body fat
Centralortruncal obesity(mos t common)Buffalo hump (fat deposition behind the neck) Moon facies

Solution to Question 3:
The clinical scenario and the image showing hyperpigmentation of palmar creases and oral mucosa are suggestive of primary adrenal insufficiency. It presents with low aldosterone, high renin, and high ACTH levels.
In primary adrenal insufficiency, lack of aldosterone production results in compensatory rise in ACTH and renin levels. The high ACTH results in hyperpigmentation. The most common causes are autoimmune in developed countries and tuberculosis in developing countries.
In secondary adrenal insufficiency, there is pituitary dysfunction leading to low ACTH levels. Renin and aldosterone levels are normal, as they function independently of ACTH.
Solution to Question 4:
This clinical scenario and image showing bilateral adrenal hemorrhage are suggestive
of Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome. Neisseria gonorrhoeae is not a cause of this condition. It is caused by highly virulent organisms such as:
Neisseria meningitidis or meningococci (classically)
Streptococcus pneumoniae or pneumococci
Pseudomonas aeruginosa
Haemophilus influenzae
Staphylococcus species
This condition is more common in children. Overwhelming bacterial infection leads to bilateral adrenal hemorrhage, thereby causing acute adrenal insufficiency. This is likely a result of direct bacterial seeding of small vessels and endothelial dysfunction caused by microbial products and inflammatory mediators.
It usually presents with rapidly progressive hypotension and shock and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) with widespread purpura. Without prompt recognition and treatment, death occurs within hours to a few days.
Solution to Question 5:
Bilateral nodular hyperplasia of the adrenal glands is the most common cause of primary hyperaldosteronism.
Adrenal adenoma is the second most common cause. It is usually solitary, but multiple adenomas may occur occasionally. Other rare causes include:
Ectopic aldosterone-producing tumors
Familial idiopathic hyperaldosteronism - due to germline mutations of KCNJ5 (encodes a potassium channel)
Solution to Question 6:
The underlying pathology in patients with Conn's syndrome is adrenal adenoma. Hyperaldosteronism may be primary or secondary.
Primary hyperaldosteronism is due to autonomous overproduction of aldosterone with resultant suppression of RAAS. It can occur due to adrenal hyperplasia, adenoma, or carcinoma. It presents with the following features:
Hypertension (most common)
Hypokalemia
Metabolic alkalosis
Polyuria (due to ANP)
Polydipsia (due to polyuria)
Muscle weakness
It is confirmed by elevated ratios of plasma aldosterone concentration to plasma renin activity
(PAC / PRA).
When primary hyperaldosteronism is due to an aldosterone-secreting adenoma, it is called Conn syndrome. Patients are usually treated with spironolactone followed by surgical removal of adenoma. In patients treated with spironolactone, the adenomas contain eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions called spironolactone bodies.


In secondary hyperaldosteronism, aldosterone release occurs in response to the activation of the renin-angiotensin system (RAAS).
Solution to Question 7:
MEN2B syndrome is associated with pheochromocytoma and medullary carcinoma of thyroid, not adrenocortical carcinoma.
Adrenocortical carcinoma is associated with the following hereditary cancer syndromes:
Li–Fraumeni syndrome - due to germline TP53 mutations
Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome - a disorder of epigenetic imprinting
MEN1 syndrome - due to mutations of MEN1 gene
Solution to Question 8:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of autoimmune polyendocrinopathy (APS) type 1. It is also called APECED (autoimmune polyendocrinopathy, candidiasis, and ectodermal dystrophy).
It is caused by mutations in the autoimmune regulator (AIRE) gene. This gene usually increases tolerance of central T-cells to peripheral tissue antigens. When this function is lost, the T-cells become more prone to mount immune reactions against tissue antigens, promoting autoimmunity. These patients develop autoantibodies against IL-17 and IL-22, which are crucial for defense against fungal infections.
It presents in childhood with the following features:
Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
Ectodermal dystrophy (abnormalities of the skin, dental enamel, and nails)
Organ-specific autoimmune disorders such as -
Autoimmune adrenalitis
Autoimmune hypoparathyroidism
Idiopathic hypogonadism
Pernicious anemia
Autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome (APS) type 2 usually presents in early adulthood as a combination of the following:
Adrenal insufficiency
Autoimmune thyroiditis or type 1 diabetes
Solution to Question 9:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of pheochromocytoma. This patient does not need to be examined for a shagreen patch. It is a feature of tuberous sclerosis syndrome, which is not associated with pheochromocytoma.
Familial syndromes associated with pheochromocytoma are:
Even patients with no family history must be evaluated for findings of these genetic syndromes, as they may occur sporadically in some cases.

Solution to Question 10:
Primary hyperparathyroidism is the most common manifestation of Wermer’s syndrome or MEN-1 syndrome.
MEN1 syndrome is due to germline mutations in the MEN1 tumor-suppressor gene, which encodes a protein called menin. The most commonly secreted products are pancreatic polypeptides.
Solution to Question 11:
The definitive diagnosis of malignancy in pheochromocytomas is based exclusively on the presence of metastases to regional lymph nodes as well as distant sites like liver, lung, and bone.
Capsular and vascular invasion may be encountered even in benign lesions. Malignant pheochromocytomas are histologically and biochemically the same as benign ones. Hence, typical histological criteria like cellular atypia, mitotic spindles, and vascular invasion are insufficient to confirm malignancy in pheochromocytomas.
Solution to Question 12:
The given histopathology slide shows nests of cells arranged in an organoid pattern, with fibrovascular septae, and finely granular cytoplasm. This is called the zellballen pattern. It is typically seen in paragangliomas and pheochromocytomas.
Paragangliomas are benign neuroendocrine tumors arising from paraganglia in the neck or abdomen. They are composed of chief and sustentacular cells arranged in an organoid pattern.


Solution to Question 13:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of a paraganglioma (ectopic pheochromocytoma) located in the abdomen. They commonly arise from the organ of Zuckerkandl, located at the bifurcation of the aorta. It is part of the vertebral paraganglia (clusters of chromaffin cells along the autonomic nerve chains).
Other sites of origin of paragangliomas include:
Urinary bladder - rarely
Carotid and aortic bodies
Ganglion nodosum of the vagus nerve
Jugulotympanic ganglia
Solution to Question 14:
Familial paraganglioma is most likely associated with mutations in the SDH (succinate dehydrogenase) gene.
The SDH complex is involved in mitochondrial electron transport and oxygen sensing. It is believed that SDH mutations also lead to the upregulation of HIF-1, which is a key oncogenic driver in this type of tumor.
Solution to Question 15:
This clinical scenario and image showing mucosal neuromas are suggestive of MEN2B syndrome. This condition is associated with medullary carcinoma of the thyroid.
The MEN syndromes are a group of inherited diseases of multiple endocrine
organs. Tumors occur at a younger age than sporadic tumors, either synchronously (at the same time) or metachronously (at different times).
MEN2 syndrome occurs due to abnormal activation of the RET gene. Medullary carcinoma is seen in both MEN 2A and 2B syndromes. However, it tends to be more aggressive and metastasizes more frequently in MEN2B syndrome.
Note: RET gene is deactivated in Hirschsprung disease.
Solution to Question 16:
Polycythemia paraganglioma syndrome occurs due to germline mutations in the EPAS1 gene. This syndrome presents with neuroendocrine tumors and early-onset polycythemia.
RET gene mutation is seen in MEN2A and MEN2B syndromes.
SDHD and SDHB mutations are seen in hereditary paraganglioma 1 and hereditary paraganglioma 4 syndromes respectively.
