Solution to Question 1:
Periductal mastitis arises from the large lactiferous ducts.
It is also known as squamous metaplasia of lactiferous ducts, recurrent subareolar abscess, or Zuska disease.
The terminal duct lobular unit (TDLU) is the basic functional and histopathological unit of the breast. Successive branching of large ducts eventually leads to the TDLU. Sclerosing adenosis, blue dome cyst, and carcinoma breast arise from the TDLU.
Solution to Question 2:
Duct ectasia and Paget's disease arise from the large ducts of the breast.
Normal anatomy of the breast includes ducts, lobules, and stroma. Successive branching of the large ducts eventually leads to the terminal duct lobular unit.
Atypical hyperplasia arises from the terminal ducts and lobules, whereas, fibroadenoma and phyllodes tumors arise from the intralobular stroma.
Solution to Question 3:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute mastitis. The most common cause of acute mastitis is Staphylococcus aureus.
Acute bacterial mastitis typically occurs during the 1st month of breastfeeding (lactational breast abscess). It is caused by a local bacterial infection when the breast is most vulnerable due to cracks and fissures in the nipples.
Staphylococcal acute mastitis typically results in localized abscesses.
Option A: Breast abscess caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa is uncommon, only a few cases have been documented in immunocompromised patients.
Options B and C: Streptococcal infections tend to spread throughout the breast in the form of cellulitis.
Solution to Question 4:
Periductal mastitis is strongly associated with a history of smoking. More than 90% of the affected individuals are smokers.
Periductal mastitis is also called recurrent subareolar abscess or squamous metaplasia of lactiferous ducts or Zuska disease. In this condition, a relative deficiency of vitamin A associated with smoking or toxic substances in tobacco smoke alters the differentiation of the ductal epithelium.
Histologically, there is keratinizing squamous metaplasia of the nipple ducts. Keratin shed from these cells is trapped and plugs (keratin plug) the ductal system, causing dilation and eventually rupture of the duct. This results in keratin spillage into the surrounding periductal tissue forming a chronic granulomatous inflammatory response.
It presents with a painful erythematous subareolar mass that clinically mimics bacterial abscess. It has a high recurrence rate.

Solution to Question 5:
The typical history of a breast lump following trauma and mammography findings of a radiolucent cystic lesion with rimmed calcification suggests a diagnosis of fat necrosis.
About half the affected women with fat necrosis of the breast have a history of breast trauma or previous surgery. It can present as a painless palpable mass, skin thickening or retraction, or
mammographic densities or calcifications.
Histologically, necrotic adipose tissue with foamy macrophages, multinucleated giant cells, and chronic inflammatory cells are seen often with hemosiderin deposits, fibrosis, and calcification.
The following image shows an area of fat necrosis within breast tissue.

Note: Calcifications are seen on mammography in the following conditions -
Apocrine cysts
Hyalinized fibroadenomas
Sclerosing adenosis
Duct ectasia
Breast carcinoma- shows irregular densities and small, numerous, clustered calcification
(microcalcifications).
Solution to Question 6:
Papillomas are classified under proliferative breast diseases without atypia.
Proliferative breast lesions without atypia are not clonal and usually have no genetic changes. Thus they are predictors of risk but are not true precursors of carcinoma.
Benign epithelial lesions are classified into three groups, according to the subsequent risk of developing breast cancer. These are:
Non-proliferative breast changes
Proliferative breast disease without atypia
Atypical hyperplasia
Note: Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) has recently been classified as a benign lesion with associated risk for developing carcinoma in the future but not as a malignancy capable of
metastases.
Solution to Question 7:
Duct ectasia is a non-proliferative breast change.
Radial scar, sclerosing adenosis, and florid hyperplasia belong to proliferative breast lesions without atypia.
Proliferative breast lesions without atypia are not clonal and are not commonly found to have genetic changes. Thus they are predictors of risk but unlikely to be true precursors of carcinoma.
Solution to Question 8:
The most common clinical presentation seen in patients with duct papilloma is nipple discharge. More than 80% of large duct papillomas produce a nipple discharge.
Papillomas grow within a dilated duct and are composed of multiple branching fibrovascular cores. It can be serous or bloody.
Serous discharge - due to intermittent blockage and release of normal breast secretions or irritation of the duct by the papilloma
Bloody discharge - due to torsion of the stalk, causing infarction
Solution to Question 9:
The image given depicts gynecomastia. Seminoma is not a cause of this condition.
Gynecomastia occurs due to increased estrogenic action. The most common causes of gynecomastia include:
Cirrhosis of the liver
Alcoho
Mari˜uana, heroin
Antiretroviral therapy
Anabolic steroids
Klinefelter syndrome (››Y karyotype)
Functioning testicular neoplasms such as Leydig cell or Sertoli cell tumors
Microscopically, there is an increase in the dense collagenous connective tissue. It is associated with epithelial hyperplasia of the duct lining with characteristic tapering micro-papillae. Lobule formation is almost never observed.
Solution to Question 10:
Apocrine change does not increase the risk of cancer as it is a non-proliferative change.
Moderate or florid hyperplasia, fibroadenoma with complex features, and sclerosing adenosis are classified under proliferative disease without atypia with a 1.5- to 2-fold increased risk of carcinoma.
Both breasts are at increased risk, although the risk to the ipsilateral breast may be slightly higher.
Solution to Question 11:
The given image is suggestive of the comedo type of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS).
Myoepithelial cell markers like p63 can differentiate DCIS from invasive carcinoma.


DCIS is a malignant clonal proliferation of epithelial cells limited to ducts and lobules by the intact basement membrane. It is rarely palpable and is almost always detected by mammography.
Myoepithelial cells (basal cell layer) are preserved in involved ducts or lobules in DCIS. Hence the myoepithelial cell markers like p63, basal cytokeratin (CK 5/6), calponin will be positive in DCIS whereas it will be absent in infiltrating ductal carcinoma. However, myoepithelial markers may be diminished in high-grade DCIS compared to surrounding normal ducts or lobules.
Once the tumor cells penetrate through the basement membrane and grow within the stroma, they are considered to be invasive carcinoma.

Note: Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) has recently been classified as a benign lesion with associated risk for developing carcinoma in the future but not as a malignancy capable of metastases.
Solution to Question 12:
The given scenario showing a red eczematous rash over the areola of the breast is suggestive of Paget's disease of the nipple. The next best step in management is biopsy of the nipple.
Paget's disease can be mistaken for eczema, and hence, biopsy of the nipple should be the initial management of choice. Paget cells are readily detected by nipple biopsy.
Solution to Question 13:
The given clinical scenario and image showing Paget's cells (malignant cells with abundant pale cytoplasm and pleomorphic nuclei) are suggestive of Paget's disease of the nipple. These cells are ER-negative.
Paget's disease of the nipple is a rare form of ductal carcinoma in-situ (DCIS). The characteristic Paget's cells are scattered individually throughout the squamous epithelium. They do not breach
the basement membrane but extend via the lactiferous sinuses into the nipple skin. The following images show Paget's cells that do not breach the basement membrane.


It presents as a unilateral erythematous eruption with a scale crust. A palpable mass is seen in about half the patients with this disease.
The underlying carcinomas are usually poorly differentiated, ER-negative, and overexpress HER2. The prognosis of Paget's disease depends on the features of the underlying carcinoma.
Paget's disease may mimic the following conditions:
Eczema (clinical appearance) - can be differentiated by the presence of malignant cells on biopsy
Superficial spreading melanoma (histological appearance) - Paget's cells are PAS-positive and diastase resistant unlike melanoma cells
Note: Paget's disease of the bone is a distinct condition that results in abnormal bone metabolism due to osteoclastic overactivity.
Solution to Question 14:
Early full-term pregnancy (younger than 20 years) is protective against breast cancer. It halves the risk of developing breast cancer compared to that of nulliparous women.
Women with very dense breasts on mammography have a four- to six-fold higher risk of both ER-positive and ER-negative breast cancer compared to women with low density.
Obese women under the age of 40 years have a decreased risk as a result of anovulatory cycles and lower progesterone levels. In contrast, postmenopausal obese women are at an increased risk, which is attributed to the synthesis of estrogens in fat depots.
Early menarche, late menopause, and nulliparity are risk factors of breast cancer due to hyperestrogenemia. Exercise and breastfeeding are protective against breast cancer.
Solution to Question 15:
The upper outer quadrant is the most common site of carcinoma in the breast.
Approximately 50% of carcinomas are located in the upper outer quadrant, 10% in each of the remaining quadrants, and about 20% in the central or subareolar region.
A palpable mass is the most common clinical sign of invasive breast carcinoma.
Triple assessment is recommended for the diagnosis of any palpable breast lump. It includes:
Clinical examination
Radiological assessment (mammography/USG)
Pathological assessment (FNAC/biopsy)
Techniques of palpation for breast examination are:
Vertical strip/lines pattern
Circular pattern
Wedges or radial spokes pattern

Solution to Question 16:
BRCA2 gene is located on the long arm of chromosome 13 (13q12.3).
Mutations in BRCA1 and BRCA2 are responsible for 80 to 90% of single gene familial breast cancers and about 3% of all breast cancers.
ER-positive, HER2-negative cancers (luminal type) is the most common subtype of breast cancer in individuals who inherit germline mutations in BRCA2. This gene is associated more frequently with male breast cancer.
Single gene mutations associated with familial breast cancer can be categorized into:
High penetrance germline mutations (>4 fold increased risk) - BRCA1, BRCA2, TP53, PTEN, STK11, CDH I, PALPB2
Moderate penetrance germline mutations (2-4 fold increased risk) - ATM, CHEK2
Solution to Question 17:
The given scenario is suggestive of triple-negative breast cancer (ER-negative, PR-negative, and HER2-negative). TP53 is the most commonly mutated gene in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC).
Common gene mutations in the 3 ma˜or molecular types of invasive breast carcinoma are:
Molecular Subtype
Common gene mutations
Luminal (ER+/HER2
-)
Luminal A: PIK3CA (more co mmon), TP53Luminal B: PIK 3CA (more common), TP53
Molecular Subtype
Common gene mutations
HER2 Positive (HER 2+)
TP53 (more common), PIK3C A
TNBC (ER-/ HER2-)
TP53 (more common), PIK3C A
Solution to Question 18:
The given immunohistochemistry (IHC) staining shows positive ER, PR (brown nucleus), and negative Her-2 (no membrane-bound brown stain) expression, which is suggestive of luminal A molecular subtype. It shows a poor response to paclitaxel.
Hormone receptors (ER, PR) are present in the nucleus. Therefore ER, PR–positive breast cancer cells will stain dark in the nucleus on IHC. Her-2 receptors are membrane-bound receptors, and hence, cells having these receptors are darkly stained on the membranes.
Luminal A type is more commonly associated with BRCA2 mutations.
Hormone receptor-positive tumors are responsive to hormonal chemotherapeutic agents like tamoxifen and aromatase inhibitors. In Her-2 negative cases, trastuzumab is not effective as it is a recombinant humanized monoclonal antibody directed against HER-2.
The following image shows ER/ PR/ Her-2 positivity:

Note: At least 10% of luminal type A breast cancers express tp53 mutations. tP53 mutations are associated with triple-negative tumors as well.
Solution to Question 19:
Carcinomas with immunohistochemistry ER and HER2/ negative are all of the above except mucinous carcinomas. Mucinous carcinomas are usually ER-positive and HER2/neu negative (luminal A type)
ER-negative, HER2-negative (triple-negative) molecular subtype commonly includes the following histological subtypes:
Medullary
Adenoid cystic
Secretory
Metaplastic
Spindle ce
Squamous
Matrix-producing
Solution to Question 20:
ER-positive, HER2-negative status on immunohistochemistry is suggestive of the luminal type of breast carcinoma, which does not include secretory carcinoma.
The ER-positive, HER2-negative molecular subtype (luminal type) commonly includes the following histological subtypes:
Well and poorly differentiated lobular carcinoma
Tubular carcinoma
Mucinous carcinoma
Papillary carcinoma
Secretory carcinomas are usually ER-negative and Her2/neu negative (basal type).
Solution to Question 21:
Lobular carcinoma is the most common type of breast carcinoma to present as an occult primary carcinoma.
Lobular carcinoma of the breast is seen bilaterally and with multicentricity. Loss of E-cadherin is the hallmark of lobular carcinoma. They also have characteristic patterns of metastatic spread, often involving the peritoneum and retroperitoneum, leptomeninges (carcinomatous meningitis), gastrointestinal tract, ovaries, and uterus.
The histological hallmark of lobular carcinoma is the presence of discohesive infiltrating tumor cells, often arranged in a single Indian file pattern or in loose clusters or sheets.

Solution to Question 22:
There is no or very slight desmoplastic response seen in lobular carcinomas.
Desmoplasia refers to collagenous stromal proliferation induced by tumor cells which is essential for tumor growth and spread. It results in hard and stony tumors. However, this is not seen in lobular carcinoma. This is likely due to the loss of expression of CDH1, the gene that
encodes e-cadherin (normally maintains intercellular adhesiveness). This also results in disaggregation of cells.
Lobular carcinomas are often bilateral and multicentric. It shows characteristic metastatic spread, often involving:
Peritoneum and retro peritoneum
Leptomeninges (carcinomatous meningitis)
Gastrointestinal tract
Ovaries
Uterus
Histopathological image of invasive lobular carcinoma of breast showing discohesive cells with few signet ring cells.


Note: Individuals with heterozygous germline mutations in CDH1 (loss of E-cadherin) also have a greatly increased risk of gastric signet-ring cell carcinoma.
Solution to Question 23:
T4d in the TNM staging of carcinoma breast points toward a diagnosis of inflammatory breast carcinoma. It shows extensive invasion and proliferation of tumor cells within the dermal lymphatics leading to obstruction.
Inflammatory breast cancer is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The hallmark of this condition is the overexpression of e-cadherin. This results in increased tumor cohesion and the formation of tumoral clumps which can result in emboli. It has a particularly poor prognosis.
These tumors are usually of high grade but do not belong to any particular molecular
subtype. More than half (60%) are ER-negative and 40% to 50% overexpress HER2. There is no association with trauma.
Due to lymphatic obstruction, it results in brawny induration, erythema with a raised edge, and edema called peau d’orange appearance. This may mimic non-neoplastic inflammatory lesions like mastitis. A breast lump may or may not be present.
The following image shows a peau d’orange appearance of the right breast.

Solution to Question 24:
The immunohistochemistry (IHC) pattern of patient C reveals moderately strong circumferential staining (faint brown color) in >10 % of cells, which is classified as 2+ or equivocal staining. Hence, she should be sub˜ected to fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) to confirm
HER2-positive gene amplification status.



The following are classified as HER2-positive tumors:
Tumors that show 3+ staining on IHC (here FISH is not needed).
Tumors with 2+ staining on IHC, followed by HER2-gene amplification confirmed by FISH
Once HER2-positive status is confirmed, targeted therapy against HER2 can be initiated with trastuzumab or lapatinib.
Solution to Question 25:
HER2 overexpression in a patient with carcinoma breast is associated with poor survival.
The main importance of HER2 status is as a predictor of response to agents that target this receptor.

Solution to Question 26:
This clinical scenario and image showing duct proliferation are suggestive of fibroadenomas. The use of cyclosporin-A after transplantation is associated with fibroadenomas that regress after cessation of the treatment.

Fibroadenomas are the most common benign tumor of the female breast. Nearly 2/3 cases are associated with mutations in the MED12 gene.
They are frequently multiple and bilateral and usually occur in women <30 years of age. They are solid, well-defined, highly mobile masses (also known as breast mice).
Fibroadenomas can be classified into 2 types:
Without complex features - classified as a non-proliferative condition
With complex features -
Associated with cysts > 0.3 cm, sclerosing adenosis, epithelial calcifications, or papillary apocrine change
Classified as proliferative changes without atypia
Solution to Question 27:
The given clinical scenario and image are suggestive of phyllodes tumor. Here, only the stromal component is involved in metastasis.


Phyllodes tumor is a fibroepithelial tumor arising from the intralobular stroma. It presents as a smooth, rapidly growing, multinodular, painless breast lump that is usually palpable. It most commonly presents in the 6th decade of life and is associated with:
Gain in chromosome 1q
HO›B13 overexpression
Phyllodes tumors show stromal cellularity next to the epithelium (subepithelial or
periepithelial regions). This feature helps to differentiate it from intracanalicular fibroadenoma.
The prognosis of phyllodes tumors depends on their histological grade. Most phyllodes tumors are low grade, with limited stromal cellularity. They recur only occasionally and do not metastasize.
The features of malignant (intermediate and high grade) phyllodes tumors are:
Markedly increased stromal cellularity
Stromal overgrowth - absence of epithelial elements
Nuclear atypia
Increased mitosis (>10/ 10 hpf)
Highly recurrent
Regardless of the grade, lymphatic spread is rare in phyllodes tumors. Hence, axillary lymph node dissection is contraindicated.
Solution to Question 28:
Angiosarcoma is the most common stromal malignancy in the breast.
It arises in the interlobular stroma and accounts for < 0.05% of breast malignancies. It is a high-grade tumor with a poor prognosis. It can either be sporadic or occur in association with radiation therapy. The mean age of affected individuals is 35 years.
Solution to Question 29:
BRCA-2 mutation does not predispose to the development of renal cell carcinoma.
BRCA-2 mutation predisposes to the development of prostate and pancreatic cancer. It is also associated with an increased risk of male breast cancer.
Solution to Question 30:
The given scenario is suggestive of colloid or mucinous carcinoma of the breast.
Colloid carcinoma is an invasive breast carcinoma, which shows intracellular and extracellular mucin deposition.
On histopathological examination, extracellular type shows tumor cells with faint nuclei, arranged in clusters, floating in lakes or pools of mucin. In intracellular type, nuclei are pushed to the periphery to form a signet ring appearance.

Solution to Question 1:
Osteoclasts are specialized multinucleated macrophages derived from circulating monocytes that are responsible for bone resorption.
Osteocytes are formed when osteoblasts are embedded in the matrix within lacunae and canaliculi. They control calcium and phosphate levels in the microenvironment.
Osteoblasts are mesenchymal cells that rim the bony spicule, responsible for bone synthesis and mineralization.
Chondrocytes are specialized cells that produce and maintain the extracellular matrix of cartilage. The image given below shows different cells present in a bone.

Solution to Question 2:
Osteocalcin is not a bone resorption marker.
It is a protein secreted only by osteoblasts. Thus, it is a bone formation marker (osteoblastic marker).
Solution to Question 3:
Osteochondroma, also known as exostosis, is the most common benign bone tumor.
It is a benign cartilage-capped tumor. 85% of osteochondromas are solitary. The remainder is seen as part of the multiple hereditary exostosis syndromes, an autosomal-dominant hereditary disease.
Lesions arise from the metaphysis near the growth plate of long tubular bones, especially near the knee. They are either sessile or pedunculated and range in size from 1 to 20 cm. Histologically, the cap is composed of benign hyaline cartilage varying in thickness and is covered peripherally by perichondrium.
Osteochondromas can progress to chondrosarcoma.
The image below shows the histopathological specimen of osteochondroma, displaying a cartilage cap lined by perichondrium contiguous with mature bone.

Solution to Question 4:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of osteogenesis imperfecta type II.
The type II variant of osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) is uniformly fatal in utero or during the perinatal period. Type II OI is characterized by extraordinary bone fragility with multiple intrauterine fractures.
Osteogenesis imperfecta (brittle bone disease) is caused by deficiencies in the synthesis of type I collagen. It can be separated into four major clinical subtypes that vary widely in severity. The severity of the disease is based on the location of the mutation within the protein.
Individuals with type I OI have a normal life span, but experience childhood fractures that decrease in frequency following puberty.
Solution to Question 5:
This given clinical scenario is suggestive of achondroplasia.
A hondroplasia is the most common skeletal dysplasia and a major cause of dwarfism. It has autosomal dominant inheritance.
It occurs due to the gain of mutation in fibroblast growth factor receptor (FGFR3). This leads to abnormal cartilage proliferation at growth plates and affects endochondral bone growth. Infants present with:
Short stature
Rhizomelic shortening of limbs
Frontal bossing
Midface deficiency
The condition is not associated with changes in longevity, intelligence, or reproductive status.
The image below shows a baby affected with achondroplasia. Note the prominent forehead, triangular face, and body asymmetry in the image (a); a low nasal bridge in the image (b); trident hands in the image (c); and scoliosis in the image (d).

Solution to Question 6:
Albers-Schönberg disease or osteopetrosis is also known as marble bone disease.
The term osteopetrosis reflects the stone-like quality of the bones. The bones are abnormally brittle and fracture easily, like a piece of chalk. It occurs due to reduced bone resorption and diffuse symmetric skeletal sclerosis because of impaired formation or function of osteoclasts.
Note: Osteogenesis imperfecta is also called brittle bone disease. Paget's disease is also called osteitis deformans; it presents with mosaic pattern of lamellar bone.
Solution to Question 7:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of osteopetrosis. It occurs due to autosomal recessive defects in the gene for the enzyme carbonic anhydrase II.
Carbonic anhydrase II is required by osteoclasts and renal tubular cells to generate protons from carbon dioxide and water (acidification). The absence of carbonic anhydrase II prevents osteoclasts from acidifying the resorption pit and dissolution of calcium hydroxyapatite within the bone matrix. It also blocks the acidification of urine by the renal tubular cells. This leads to reduced bone resorption and diffuse symmetric skeletal sclerosis.
Due to deficient osteoclast activity, bones involved by osteopetrosis lack a medullary canal giving it a bone-in-bone appearance. The ends of long bones are bulbous (Erlenmeyer flask deformity) and misshapen. The neural foramina are small and compress the exiting nerves, leading to cranial nerve palsies.
Extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis leads to leukopenia and prominent hepatosplenomegaly. As carbonic anhydrase II is widely expressed, mutations of this gene result in a condition called marble brain disease or Guibaud-Vainsel syndrome.
Solution to Question 8:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of osteoporosis. Cytokines stimulate osteoclast recruitment and activity in osteoporosis by increasing the levels of RANKL.
RANKL helps in diminishing the expression of osteoprotegerin (OPG), increasing osteoclast proliferation, and preventing osteoclast apoptosis.
Decreased estrogen levels after menopause actually increase both bone resorption and formation. However, the latter does not keep up with the former, leading to a high turnover. Decreased estrogen appears to increase the secretion of inflammatory cytokines such as IL-6, TNF-, and
IL-1.
Solution to Question 9:
Histologically normal bone with decreased density is the hallmark feature of osteoporosis.
In advanced osteoporosis, both the trabecular bone of the medulla and the cortical bone are markedly thinned leading to progressive microfractures.

Option A: Inadequate mineralization in osteomalacia leads to a thickened osteoid matrix. Option C: Paget's disease presents with a mosaic pattern of lamellar bone.
Option D: Dissecting osteitis cystica is seen in severe hyperparathyroidism.
Solution to Question 10:
Paget disease is monostotic in about 15% of cases and polyostotic in the rest of them.
Paget disease (osteitis deformans) is a disorder of increased, but disordered and structurally unsound, bone mass. The onset is in late adulthood (average age at diagnosis, 70 years).
It occurs due to mutations in the SQSTM1 gene. This increases the activity of NF-B, which then increases osteoclast activity.
Three sequential phases exist:
Initial osteolytic stage
Mixed osteoclastic-osteoblastic stage
Final burned-out quiescent osteosclerotic stage
The axial skeleton or proximal femur is involved in up to 80% of the cases. The typical x-ray findings are as follows:
Enlargement of the craniofacial skeleton: leontiasis ossea or lion face
Invagination of the skull base (platybasia)
Chalk stick-type fractures in the long bones of the lower extremities
The pathological hallmark is a mosaic pattern of lamellar bone, seen in the sclerotic phase as shown below. It shows a jigsaw-like pattern produced by unusually prominent cement lines, which join haphazardly oriented units of lamellar bone.

Laboratory findings show elevated serum alkaline phosphatase and urinary hydroxyproline
(normal serum calcium and phosphorus).
Following tumors can develop in the affected bones in Paget's disease:
Benign tumors -
Giant cell tumors
Giant cell reparative granuloma
Extra-osseous masses of hematopoietic tissue
Sarcoma (osteosarcoma or fibrosarcoma) - most dreaded complication. Occurs in < 1 % of
all individuals with Paget disease, and in 5% to 10% of those with the severe polyostotic disease.
Solution to Question 11:
Osteopetrosis does not belong to the clinical spectrum of hyperparathyroidism. The features of hyperparathyroidism are as follows:
Osteitis fibrosa cystica
Osteopenia/osteoporosis
Hyperuricemia and gout
Pseudogout
Increased production of calcitriol
Dissecting osteitis and brown tumors
Nephrolithiasis
Hypophosphatemia
Anemia
Hyperparathyroidism leads to significant skeletal changes related to unabated osteoclast activity. Increased osteoclast activity is most prominent in cortical bone, but the medullary bone
is not spared. Osteoclasts may tunnel into and dissect centrally along the length of the trabeculae, creating the appearance of railroad tracks, diagnostic of dissecting osteitis. Generalised osteoporosis may be seen in the phalanges, vertebrae, and proximal femur.
Brown tumor presents with bone loss leading to microfractures and secondary hemorrhages which causes influx of macrophages and ingrowth of reparative fibrous tissue. Generalized osteitis presents with increased bone cell activity, peri-trabecular fibrosis, and cystic brown tumors.
Solution to Question 12:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of acute pyogenic osteomyelitis. Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of culture-positive pyogenic osteomyelitis.
Osteomyelitis denotes inflammation of bone and marrow, almost always secondary to infection. Organisms may reach the bone by
Hematogenous spread
Extension from a contiguous site
Direct implantation
The common causative organisms include:
Staphylococcus aureus - the most common cause overall
Pseudomonas aeruginosa - most common cause in IV drug abusers
Salmonella - common in patients of sickle cell anemia
Haemophilus influenzae - was a common causative organism in children, less common now due to vaccination
Streptococcus pyogenes - most common in neonates
Escherichia coli, Klebsiella- most common cause in patients with genitourinary tract infections
Solution to Question 13:
Salmonella enteritidis is commonly implicated in osteomyelitis in patients with sickle cell anemia. The common causative organisms include:
Staphylococcus aureus - the most common cause overall
Pseudomonas aeruginosa - most common cause in IV drug abusers
Salmonella - most common in patients of sickle cell anemia
Haemophilus influenzae - was a common causative organism in children, less common now due to vaccination
Streptococcus pyogenes - neonates
Escherichia coli, Klebsiella- most common cause in patients with genitourinary tract infections
Solution to Question 14:
The patient is most likely suffering from TB osteomyelitis. Brodie's abscess is not a complication of this condition.
In tuberculous osteomyelitis, weight-bearing joints - spine (Pott's disease), hips, and knees, are most commonly affected.
Complications of tuberculous osteomyelitis include:
Scoliosis or kyphosis (gibbus)
Neurologic deficits secondary to spinal cord and nerve compression leading to paraplegia -
Tuberculous arthritis
Sinus tract formation
Psoas abscess - may be due to paravertebral “cold” abscess
AA amyloidosis
Solution to Question 15:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of osteoblastoma.
Histopathology shows well-circumscribed lesions composed of randomly interconnecting trabeculae of woven bone that are prominently rimmed by a single layer of osteoblasts. Stroma surrounding the neoplastic bone consists of loose connective tissue that contains many dilated and congested capillaries.
The image below shows the histopathological findings in osteoblastoma.


Osteoid osteoma and osteoblastoma are benign bone-producing tumors that have identical histologic features. The differentiating features between them are given below:
Osteoid osteoma
Osteoblastoma
Less than 2 cm in diameter
Larger than 2 cm in diameter
Predilection for the appendic ular skeleton
involves the posterior spine (l aminae and pedicles)
Thick rind of reactive cortical bone is seen on radiography
Usually, no marked bony rea ction is seen on radiography

Pain which is unresponsive t o aspirin
Solution to Question 16:
The given history and classic sunburst appearance on the X-ray are highly suggestive of osteosarcoma. Mutation of p53 (Li-Fraumeni syndrome) is associated with a greater risk of sarcomas, particularly osteosarcoma.
The image given below shows sunburst pattern seen in osteosarcoma.

Option A: Translocation (X;18) is characteristic of synovial sarcoma. Option B: Translocation (12;16) is characteristic of myxoid liposarcoma.
Option D: 1p rearrangements are characteristic of conventional chondrosarcoma.
Solution to Question 17:
Osteosarcomas usually arise in the metaphyseal region of the long bones of the extremities. It commonly occurs in the knee (i.e., distal femur or proximal tibia).
The most common subtype is primary, intramedullary, osteoblastic, and high grade. It is a malignant tumor in which the cancerous cells produce an osteoid matrix or mineralized bone. It occurs in all age groups but has a bimodal age distribution.
The formation of fine lace-like neoplastic bone by the tumor cells is diagnostic histopathologically of osteosarcoma as shown below.


Radiography shows a large destructive, mixed lytic and blastic mass with infiltrative margins, which breaks through the cortex and lifts the periosteum, resulting in reactive periosteal bone formation. The triangular shadow between the cortex and raised ends of the periosteum, known radiographically as the Codman triangle, is characteristic of osteosarcoma. This is shown in the radiograph below.

Solution to Question 18:
Ollier disease and Maffucci syndrome are nonhereditary disorders characterized by multiple enchondromas. Maffucci syndrome is, in addition, distinguished by the presence of spindle-cell hemangiomas.
Enchondromas are benign tumors of hyaline cartilage that usually occur in bones of enchondral origin. They are usually diagnosed in individuals 20 to 50 years of age. They present as solitary metaphyseal lesions of tubular bones of the hands and feet.
The radiographic features consist of circumscribed lucencies with central irregular calcifications, a sclerotic rim, and an intact cortex. They are usually smaller than 3 cm. They are gray-blue and translucent, composed of well-circumscribed nodules of hyaline cartilage containing cytomorphologically benign chondrocytes.
The enchondromas in Ollier disease and Maffucci syndrome are sometimes more cellular than sporadic enchondromas and exhibit cytologic atypia, making them more difficult to distinguish from chondrosarcomas.
The image below displays the histopathological picture of an enchondroma showing lobules of hyaline cartilage encased by bone and covered by perichondrium (fibrous tissue).


Solution to Question 19:
The clear cell and the mesenchymal variants of chondrosarcoma occur in younger patients (teens or 20s).
Chondrosarcomas are malignant tumors that produce cartilage. They commonly arise in the axial skeleton, especially the pelvis, shoulder, and ribs.
They are subclassified histologically as following variants:
Conventional (hyaline cartilage producing) - 90% cases
Clear cell
Dedifferentiated
Mesenchymal
In multiple hereditary exostosis, osteochondromas can progress to chondrosarcoma. Increased thickness of the cartilage cap has been reported as an indicator of potential malignancy. The average age of secondary chondrosarcoma is younger than patients with primary tumors.
Solution to Question 20:
Osteochondromas, multiple enchondromas, and synovial chondromatosis can progress to become chondrosarcoma.
The average age of patients with secondary chondrosarcoma is 35 years (less than that of those with primary tumors). These tumors most commonly affect the pelvic bones. The increased thickness of the cartilage cap (normally 1–3 mm) is considered an indicator of potential malignancy.
Multiple enchondromas in the setting of Ollier’s disease or Maffucci's syndrome carry a significantly higher risk of transformation to secondary chondrosarcoma than solitary enchondromas. Histological findings of abundant myxoid change, cyst formation, and permeation of existing trabeculae suggest malignancy.
Secondary malignancy in synovial chondromatosis has been reported, but it is rare.
Solution to Question 21:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Ewing sarcoma. It arises in the diaphysis of long bones, especially the femur and the flat bones of the pelvis.
Ewing sarcoma follows osteosarcoma as the second most common group of bone sarcomas in children. It generally affects patients < 20 years. Boys are affected slightly more frequently than girls. Usually, the tumor arises in the diaphysis of long tubular bones, especially the femur and the flat bones of the pelvis.
Fever, elevated sedimentation rate, anemia, and leukocytosis may be seen. Plain radiographs show a destructive lytic tumor with permeative margins that extend into the surrounding soft tissues. The characteristic periosteal reaction produces layers of reactive bone deposited in an onion-skin fashion. It arises in the medullary cavity and usually invades the cortex, periosteum, and soft tissue.
On microscopy, sheets of uniform, small, round cells with scant cytoplasm are seen, which may appear clear because they are rich in glycogen. The presence of Homer–Wright rosettes indicates a greater degree of neuroectodermal differentiation.
The image given below shows the histopathological findings in Ewing sarcoma.


Most Ewing sarcoma family tumors contain an (11;22) (q24;q12) translocation. Variant translocations fuse the EWS to other members of the ETS transcription factor family. CD99(MIC2), FLI1, and NSE would be positive in ES/PNET.
Solution to Question 22:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of osteoclastoma/ giant-cell tumor (GCT) of bone.
GCT is a relatively uncommon benign, but locally aggressive, neoplasm that usually arises in individuals in their 20s to 40s. The neoplastic cells express high levels of RANKL. It promotes the proliferation of osteoclast precursors and their differentiation into mature osteoclasts via RANK expressed by these cells.
GCTs arise in the epiphysis but may extend into the metaphysis. The majority arise around the knee (distal femur and proximal tibia). Most are solitary, multicentric tumors in the distal extremities. The tumors destroy the overlying cortex, producing a bulging soft tissue mass delineated by a thin shell of reactive tissue.
Histopathologically, sheets of uniform oval mononuclear cells and numerous osteoclast-type giant cells are seen with 100 or more nuclei. Necrosis and mitotic activity may be prominent.
The image given below shows the histopathological findings seen in osteoclastoma.


Typically, they are treated with curettage, but 40% to 60% recur locally.
Up to 4% of tumors metastasize to the lungs, but these sometimes spontaneously regress and they are rarely fatal. The RANKL inhibitor, denosumab, has shown promise as adjuvant therapy in GCT.
Note: The E mnemonic for GCT:
Epiphyseal
Eccentri
Egg-shell crackling
Expansile
Solution to Question 23:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of an aneurysmal bone cyst.
It affects all age groups, but generally occurs during the first 2 decades of life and has no sex predilection. It usually occurs in the metaphysis of long bones and the posterior elements of vertebral bodies.
This is a tumor characterized by multiloculated blood-filled cystic spaces separated by septae, composed of multinucleated osteoclast-like giant cells and reactive woven bone. Radiographically, an aneurysmal bone cyst is seen as an eccentric, expansile, lesion with well-defined margins. Most lesions are completely lytic and often contain a thin shell of reactive bone at the periphery.
The spindle cells of aneurysmal bone cyst frequently demonstrate rearrangements of chromosome 17p13, leading to USP6 overexpression.
The majority of secondary aneurysmal bone cysts arise in association with:
Benign neoplasms
Giant-cell tumor of the bone (most common)
Chondroblastoma
Osteoblastoma
Fibrous dysplasia
Osteosarcoma

Prostatic adenocarcinoma is associated with predominantly osteoblastic secondaries to the bones
(vertebral column).
The radiographic appearance of bone metastases may be purely lytic (bone destroying), purely blastic (bone-forming), or mixed lytic and blastic. Most cancers are associated with predominantly one pattern or the other.
Parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP) and transforming growth factor- (TGF- ) are implicated in osteolytic secondaries, while proteins such as endothelin-1 and morphogenetic proteins are implicated in osteoblastic lesions.

Solution to Question 1:
The x-ray image of the hip shows narrowing of the joint space and subchondral sclerosis which is diagnostic of osteoarthritis (OA), also called degenerative joint disease.
OA is the most common type of joint disease, which is characterized by the degeneration of joint cartilage. This results in structural and functional failure of synovial joints. Osteoarthritis can be classified into 2 types:
Primary OA: Insidious onset, without apparent initiating cause, as an aging phenomenon
Secondary OA: Predisposing conditions such as joint deformity, a previous joint injury, or an underlying systemic disease such as diabetes, ochronosis, hemochromatosis, or marked obesity.
The knees and hands are more commonly affected in women and the hips in men. OA lesions occur due to the degeneration of the articular cartilage and its disordered repair. Inflammatory cells are sparse, but cytokines and diffusible factors, particularly TGF- (which induces matrix metalloproteinases), TNF, prostaglandins, and nitric oxide, have been implicated in OA.
Solution to Question 2:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of rheumatoid arthritis. The patient's serum will test positive for rheumatoid factor.
Microscopy of the excised nodule shows a necrotizing granuloma with a central zone of fibrinoid necrosis surrounded by a prominent rim of activated macrophages and numerous lymphocytes and plasma cells.
Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory disorder of autoimmune origin that principally attacks the joints, producing nonsuppurative, proliferative, and inflammatory synovitis. The inflammation progresses to the destruction of the articular cartilage and ankylosis of the joints.
In RA, the synovium contains germinal centers with secondary follicles and abundant plasma cells, which produce antibodies, some are autoantibodies. Many of the autoantibodies produced in the lymphoid organs are specific for citrullinated peptides (CCPs). 80% of patients have serum IgM or IgA autoantibodies that bind to the Fc portions of their own IgG. These autoantibodies are called rheumatoid factor and may also deposit in joints as immune complexes
The characteristic histologic features of RA include:
Synovial cell hyperplasia and proliferation
Dense inflammatory infiltrates
Increased vascularity due to angiogenesis
Fibrinopurulent exudate on the synovial and joint surfaces
Osteoclastic activity in underlying bone
Subcutaneous nodule: necrotizing granulomas with a central zone of fibrinoid necrosis surrounded activated macrophages, lymphocytes, and plasma cells
This altogether leads to a mass of edematous synovium called pannus, which grows over the articular cartilage and causes its erosion.
Solution to Question 3:
The most likely diagnosis is gout. Aspirate from the joint shows dense neutrophilic infiltrate and crystals that are long, slender, needle-shaped, and negatively birefringent.
Gout is marked by transient attacks of acute arthritis initiated by crystallization of monosodium urate (MSU) within and around joints. This results in the production of cytokines that recruit leukocytes. Macrophages phagocytose the MSU and the inflammasome activates caspase-1, which is involved in the production of some biologically active cytokines.
The distinctive morphologic changes in gout are acute arthritis, chronic tophaceous arthritis, tophi in various sites, and gouty nephropathy. Tophi are the pathognomonic hallmark of gout. These are large aggregations of urate crystals surrounded by an intense inflammatory reaction of foreign body giant cells which may appear in the articular cartilage, ligaments, tendons, bursae, earlobes, fingertips, or kidneys.
Gouty nephropathy refers to the renal complications caused by MSU crystals or tophi in the renal medullary interstitium or tubules. Complications include uric acid nephrolithiasis and pyelonephritis.
Solution to Question 4:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. In this condition, there is a deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT).
Lesch–Nyhan syndrome is charecterised by neurological and behavioral abnormalities such as lip and finger biting and head banging.
It also causes the overproduction of uric acid, leading to gouty arthritis and impaired kidney function. It is classified as secondary gout.
Solution to Question 5:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition disease
(CPPD), also known as pseudo-gout and chondrocalcinosis.
The image shows aspirated crystals which are rhomboid, 0.5 to 5 m in the greatest dimension, and positively birefringent (yellow).
It usually occurs in individuals older than 50 years of age and becomes more common with old age.
CPPD is classified into sporadic (idiopathic), hereditary, and secondary types. It is caused by germline mutations in the pyrophosphate transport channel. The secondary form is associated
with
Previous joint damage
Hyperparathyroidism
Hemochromatosis
Hypomagnesemia
Hypothyroidism
Ochronosis
Diabetes
Inflammation is usually milder than in gout. CPPD may produce acute, subacute, or chronic arthritis that can be confused with osteoarthritis or rheumatoid arthritis. The joint involvement may be monoarticular or polyarticular; the knees, followed by the wrists, elbows, shoulders, and ankles, are most commonly affected.
Solution to Question 6:
The pleomorphic variant of liposarcoma is usually aggressive and frequently metastasizes.
Liposarcoma is one of the most common sarcomas of adulthood seen mainly in people in their 50s to 60s in the deep soft tissues of the proximal extremities and in the retroperitoneum.
Amplification of 12q13-q15 and t(12;16) are characteristic of well-differentiated and myxoid liposarcomas, respectively. One of the key genes in the amplified region of chromosome 12q is MDM2, which is a potent inhibitor of p53.
Well-differentiated liposarcoma contains adipocytes with scattered atypical spindle cells. Myxoid liposarcoma contains an abundant basophilic extracellular matrix, arborizing capillaries (“chicken-wire” or “crow’s feet” vasculature), and primitive cells reminiscent of fetal fat.
The well-differentiated variant is relatively indolent, while the myxoid/round cell type is intermediate in its malignant behavior.
Solution to Question 7:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of myxoid liposarcoma.
The image shows abundant ground substance, with branching capillaries and a few immature adipocytes.
Liposarcoma is the most common sarcoma in adults and is usually seen in the 5th to 6th decade of life. They commonly occur in the deep soft tissues of the proximal extremities and in the retroperitoneum.
Histologically the liposarcomas are divided into three subtypes:
Well-differentiated liposarcoma: It consists of mature adipocytes and scattered spindle cells with hyperchromatic nuclei. It is associated with amplification of 12q13-q15.
Myxoid liposarcoma: It contains abundant basophilic extracellular matrix with branching capillaries. Few immature adipocytes are found scattered within the matrix. It is associated with t(12;16).
Pleomorphic liposarcoma: It consists of sheets of anaplastic cells with bizarre nuclei and few immature adipocytes.
Among the three subtypes, the pleomorphic liposarcoma is the most malignant and often metastasizes, while the well-differentiated is least malignant. Myxoid liposarcoma has intermediate malignancy behaviour.
Solution to Question 8:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nodular fasciitis.
Nodular fasciitis is a self-limited fibroblastic and myofibroblastic proliferation that typically occurs in young adults in the upper extremity. Etiology is unclear but a history of trauma is present in approximately 25% of cases. The tumors grow rapidly over a period of several weeks, typically no larger than 3 cm. It typically regresses spontaneously and if excised, rarely recurs.
Microscopically, it is richly cellular and contains plump, immature-appearing fibroblasts and myofibroblasts, arranged randomly or in short fascicles reminiscent of tissue culture fibroblasts. A gradient of maturation from cellular, loose, and myxoid to organized and fibrous is typical. The cells vary in size and shape (spindle to stellate) and have conspicuous nucleoli; mitotic figures are abundant.
Immunohistochemistry shows positivity for vimentin, smooth muscle actin, and muscle-specific actin.
Desmoid tumours are firm and poorly demarcated masses which infiltrate the surrounding muscle, nerve and fat. Histologically, fibroblasts are arranged in long parallel fascicles amid dense collagen. (Option 2)
The image below shows the histopathological findings of nodular fasciitis.

Solution to Question 9:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of rhabdomyomas.
Rhabdomyoma is a benign neoplasm of skeletal muscle that mainly occurs in the head and neck region. Although the mass is usually asymptomatic, it may compress or displace the tongue or may cause partial obstruction of the pharynx.
Rhabdomyomas can be classified into cardiac (most common) or extracardiac.
Spider cells are seen in this condition. These are large, rounded, polygonal cells with glycogen vacuoles separated by strands of cytoplasm extending between the cell membrane and nucleus.
The image given below shows spider cells.

Solution to Question 10:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of sarcoma botryoids, which is a variant of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma. It is a malignant mesenchymal tumor with skeletal muscle differentiation.
Rhabdomyosarcomas are the common soft tissue sarcomas of childhood and adolescence, classified into four subtypes: alveolar, embryonal, pleomorphic, and spindle-shaped/ sclerosing.
Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma: It contains sheets of both primitive round and spindled cells in a myxoid stroma. Sarcoma botryoids is a variant that occurs in the walls of hollow, mucosal-line structures, such as the nasopharynx, common bile duct, bladder, and vagina.
Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma: consists of the network of fibrous septae that divide the cells into clusters or aggregates, creating a crude resemblance to pulmonary alveoli.
Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma - consists of large, sometimes multinucleated, bizarre eosinophilic tumor cells.
Spindle cell/sclerosing rhabdomyosarcoma - Consists of fusiform cells with vesicular chromatin arranged in long fascicles or in a storiform pattern.
On immunohistochemistry, they are positive for desmin, myoglobin, myogenin, MyoD1, and vimentin. Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma is seen predominantly in adults.
The botryoid variant of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma has the best prognosis, while the pleomorphic subtype is often fatal.
Solution to Question 11:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of synovial sarcoma.
It can be present in locations (chest wall, head, and neck) that lack synovium. Most lesions occur in people in their 20s to 40s. Patients usually present with a deep-seated mass that has been present for several years.
Most synovial sarcomas show a characteristic chromosomal translocation t(x;18)(p11;q11) producing SS18-SSX1, SS18-SSX2, or SS18-SSX4 fusion genes.
They are morphologically classified into monophasic or biphasic:
Monophasic synovial sarcoma consists of uniform spindle cells with scant cytoplasm and dense chromatin growing, in short, tightly packed fascicles.
Biphasic type consists of a spindle cell component with gland-like structures composed of cuboidal to columnar epithelioid cells. Tumor cells, especially in the biphasic type, are positive for epithelial markers (e.g., keratins), differentiating them from most of the other sarcomas.
Solution to Question 12:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Ewing's sarcoma.
It is a malignant bone tumor that occurs primarily in children and young adults, in the age group of 10-20 years. It usually affects the long bones, such as the femur, tibia, or humerus.
Occasionally, the tumor may begin in the muscles or soft tissues (extraosseous Ewing's sarcoma).
Microscopically, solid sheets of small uniform round cells with PAS-positive magenta pink colored cytoplasm are characteristic of Ewing’s Sarcoma/PNET. The cells show PAS positivity due to the presence of large amounts of cytoplasmic glycogen. This is an important feature for the differential diagnosis of Ewing's with other small round cell tumors.
Solution to Question 13:
Acid mucin is stained by Alcian blue.
Solution to Question 14:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of myositis ossificans (MO).
It is a pseudo-inflammatory tumor that originates from skeletal muscle and corresponds to a heterotopic, metaplastic, nonmalignant bone tumor.
It is a highly inflammatory, rapidly growing, and painful muscular mass, which is seen following muscular trauma. The late stage is characterized by a typical zonal pattern (zonal phenomenon). It consists of three zones:
Innermost zone: made of proliferating fibroblasts and myofibroblasts with areas of hemorrhage and necrosis
Intermediate zone: contains osteoblasts with the immature osteoid formation
Peripheral zone: the mature bone
Solution to Question 15:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of septic arthritis. The most common organism implicated in this condition in children < 2 years is Staphylococcus aureus.
Since the advent of the Haemophilus influenzae vaccine, the predominant causes of septic arthritis among children <5 years of age have been S. aureus, Streptococcus pyogenes (group A Streptococcus), and (in some centers) Kingella kingae.

Antibodies against desmoglein 1
Suprabasal acantholytic blister is a characteristic feature

Question 16:
A 70-year-old woman presents with multiple tense itchy blisters on the trunk and thigh region. Histopathology demonstrates subepidermal, non-acantholytic blisters. Direct immunofluorescence for IgG and C3 shows the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Question 17:
A 28-year-old man with gluten sensitivity presents with severely itchy papulovesicular lesions on extremities, knees, elbows, and buttocks for one year. Direct immunofluorescence staining of the lesions showed IgA deposition as follows. What is the most probable diagnosis?

Solution to Question 1:
The above scenario is suggestive of Langerhans cell histiocytosis. The image shows Langerhans cells with abundant, often vacuolated cytoplasm and vesicular nuclei containing linear grooves or folds and surrounding eosinophils. They stain positive for CD1a and S-100. They
are intraepidermal dendritic cells.
The image below shows Langerhans cells.


Clonal proliferation of Langerhans cells leads to Langerhans cell histiocytosis, a histiocytic and dendritic cell neoplasm.
These cells secrete factors that augment innate immune responses, and also the antigen-presenting cell of the skin, thereby stimulating the adaptive immune system.
Solution to Question 2:
The above scenario is suggestive of Merkel cell carcinoma. It arises from Merkel cells.
These cells are located in epithelial basal cell layer and have neuroendocrine and mechanoreceptor functions.
Merkel cell carcinoma is a rare and aggressive neuroendocrine tumor of the skin, most commonly found in white men and diagnosed at a mean age of 70 years. A rapidly growing, flesh-colored
papule or plaque characterizes the disease. About 80% of the cases are seen associated with Merkel cell polyomavirus.
Regional lymph nodes are involved in 30% of the patients and 50% will develop systemic disease. CK-20 is a specific marker for Merkel cell carcinoma. Wide local excision is usually necessary.
The image below shows Merkel cell carcinoma composed of uniform small round cells having granular chromatin and scant cytoplasm.

Solution to Question 3:
Nevus cells often become non-pigmented and resemble neural tissue as they grow deep into the dermis. This change is called neurotization and suggests the benign nature of the nevus.
This morphological change in nevus cells occurs due to progressive loss of tyrosinase activity and acquisition of cholinesterase activity in deeper “nervelike” nevus cells.
Melanocytic nevi (moles) are common benign neoplasms caused by acquired activating mutations in components of the RAS signaling pathway.
Based on the location, it may be junctional nevi, intradermal nevi, or compound nevi.
Melanocytic nevi are thought to progress through a series of morphologic changes over time. Superficial nevus cells are larger, tend to produce melanin, and grow in nests. Deeper nevus cells are smaller, produce little or no pigment, and appear as cords and single cells. At the deepest extent of the lesions, these cells often acquire fusiform contours and grow in fascicles resembling neural tissue (neurotization).
Melanocytic nevi with neurotization indicate normal maturation change and help in differentiating benign nevi from melanomas (which lacks such features).

Solution to Question 4:
The above image is suggestive of melanoma. Mutations in the hedgehog signaling pathway are associated with basal cell carcinoma.
All other mutations are associated with melanoma.
Melanoma is a highly aggressive malignancy linked to UV exposure.
Most sporadic melanomas are associated with mutations in cell cycle regulators (p16/INK4a, CDK4), proteins in receptor tyrosine kinase signaling pathway (KIT, RAS, BRAF), and telomerase (TERT mutation).
Dysplastic nevus syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition with inherited CDKN2A mutation that can lead to familial melanoma.
Solution to Question 5:
The superficial spreading type of melanoma is the most common type of melanoma. The progression of melanoma may be described as:
Radial growth phase: the horizontal spread of melanoma within the epidermis and superficial dermi
Acral lentiginous - unrelated to sun exposure
Lentigo maligna (Hutchinson freckle) - sun-exposed region
Superficial spreading (most common)
Vertical growth phase: the tumor cells invade downward into the deeper dermal layers as an expansile mass (nodular)
The image below shows melanoma in the radial growth phase. It shows the irregular nested and single-cell growth of melanoma cells within the epidermis and an underlying inflammatory response within the dermis.

The image below shows melanoma cells that have large nuclei with irregular contours. The chromatin is characteristically clumped at the periphery of the nuclear membrane with prominent red (eosinophilic) nucleoli.


Solution to Question 6:
The above image is suggestive of melanoma. The absence of regression is a favorable prognostic factor in melanomas.
Immunohistochemistry markers for melanoma are:
S-100
HMB (Human Melanoma Black)-45
LDH
MELAN-A
Regression is defined as partial or complete disappearance of a previously documented tumor in the absence of therapeutic interventions or physical trauma. Microscopically, it is characterized by the replacement of melanoma cells by dense inflammtory cell infiltrate or dermal fibrosis.
This phenomenon explains some apparent discrepancies between expected and observed prognosis based on tumor thickness and also the cases of metastatic melanoma with occult primary.
Determinants of a more favorable prognosis in melanoma include:
Thinner tumor depth
No or very few mitoses (< 1 per mm2)
A brisk tumor infiltrating lymphocyte response
The absence of regression
Lack of ulceration
Absence of metastases in the sentinel lymph node
Solution to Question 7:
Mutations in the FGFR3 gene are not described in melanomas. Fibroblast growth factor receptor-3 (FGFR3) is a receptor tyrosine kinase. Defects in the FGFR3 gene have been associated with several conditions:
Hypochondroplasia
Thanatophoric dwarfism
Seborrheic keratosi
Acanthosis nigrican
Bladder cancer
Craniosynostosi
Severe achondroplasia with developmental delay and acanthosis nigricans (SADDAN)
Solution to Question 8:
The above image shows a jigsaw puzzle appearance which is seen in cylindroma (turban tumor/Spiegler’s tumor).
Cylindroma is a familial autosomal dominant disorder. It is due to the loss of the cylindromatosis gene, CYLD on chromosome 16q12-13. It has also been reported to follow radiotherapy
epilation of the scalp.
The lesions are frequently multiple, smooth, firm, pink to red, and somewhat pedunculated. They are mostly seen on the scalp. Histologically, it contains mosaic■like masses - a jigsaw appearance. Malignant transformation is very rare.
Surgery is the treatment of choice.

Note: Genetic syndromes associated with adnexal tumors:
Germline mutations in CYLD - familial cylindromatosis, familial trichoepithelioma
Brooke–Spiegler syndrome - associated with trichoepithelioma, cylindroma, spiradenoma
Muir–Torre syndrome - sebaceous adenoma
Cowden syndrome - multiple trichilemmoma
Solution to Question 9:
Neoplastic dyskeratosis is seen in actinic keratosis.
Dyskeratosis is premature keratinization of individual keratinocytes. These cells usually have pink or reddish cytoplasm. It can be benign or malignant:
Benign dyskeratosis - seen in Darier’s disease, warty dyskeratoma, and familial benign pemphigu
Neoplastic dyskeratosis - seen in Bowen’s disease, squamous cell carcinoma, and actinic keratosi
Actinic keratoses usually occur in sun-damaged skin and are considered precursor lesions of quamous cell carcinoma. Some lesions produce so much keratin that a cutaneous horn develops.
The image below shows the histology of actinic keratosis. It shows atypical basal cells, dyskeratotic cells, and parakeratosis in the stratum corneum (cells with a retained nucleus).


Solution to Question 10:
The above image shows keratinous pearls and atypical tumor cells suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma. Human papillomavirus (HPV) subtypes 5 and 8 may predispose to squamous cell carcinoma, but not Epstein–Barr virus (EBV).
Risk factors for squamous cell carcinoma:
Exposure to UV light
HPV subtypes 5 and 8
Epidermodysplasia verruciformi
Industrial carcinogens (tars and oils)
Chronic ulcers and draining osteomyeliti
Old burn scars (Marjolin ulcers)
Ingestion of arsenical
Ionizing radiation
Tobacco and betel nut chewing (in the oral cavity)
Precursor lesions:
Actinic keratosi
Xeroderma pigmentosum


The image below shows an SCC lesion in the oral cavity.

Solution to Question 11:
The clinical presentation and histology are suggestive of basal cell carcinoma (BCC). It is a locally aggressive cutaneous tumor, and metastasis is very rare.
It occurs in sun-exposed areas with increased incidence in the setting of immunosuppression and in disorders of DNA repair, such as xeroderma pigmentosum.
BCCs usually present as pearly papules and locally invasive ulcers (rodent ulcers).
Histologically, the tumor cells resemble those in the normal basal cell layer of the epidermis with peripheral palisading and retraction cleft.
It is associated with mutations that activate the hedgehog pathway signaling.
Gorlin syndrome is an autosomal-dominant disorder with multiple basal cell carcinomas, medulloblastomas, ovarian fibromas, and odontogenic keratocysts, pits of the palms, and soles.
The image below shows the histopathology of BCC.


Solution to Question 12:
The clinical image shows diffuse erythema and scaling of the entire body surface (erythroderma) and histopathology shows the presence of lymphocytes in the epidermal cell layer (epidermotropism). This is suggestive of Sézary syndrome which is a disseminated and severe form of mycosis fungoides (cutaneous T-cell lymphoma).
Mycosis fungoides is a cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (CD4+ T-cells) that presents in the skin. It remains localized to the skin for many years, but it may eventually evolve into a systemic lymphoma.
The image of mycosis fungoides showing hallmark features - Sezary Lutzner cells showing epidermal infiltration (epidermotropism),

Solution to Question 13:
The above scenario is suggestive of urticaria pigmentosa caused by cutaneous mastocytosis. The Masson-Fontana stain is used to demonstrate melanin in nevus and malignant melanoma.
Darier's sign is seen in urticaria pigmentosa. It refers to the development
of urticaria and erythema around the lesions after mild trauma, including scratching or rubbing of the lesion.
Mast cells may be difficult to differentiate from lymphocytes in routine, hematoxylin, and eosin (H&E)–stained sections. Special metachromatic stains (toluidine blue or Giemsa) are used to visualize their granules.
Stains for mast cells:
Toluidine blue
Giemsa
Tryptase
Leder stain (Chloracetate esterase)
CD 117
The image below shows mast cells stained with toluidine blue.


Solution to Question 14:
The above image shows the suprabasal splitting of the epidermis (acantholysis) giving rise to the row of tombstones appearance. This is suggestive of pemphigus vulgaris.
Pemphigus vulgaris is the most common type of pemphigus. It involves the mucosa and skin. Autoantibodies against desmoglein 1 and 3 are present.
Pemphigus is a blistering disorder caused by autoantibodies that result in the dissolution of intercellular attachments within the epidermis and mucosal epithelium.
Variants of pemphigus:
Pemphigus vulgari
Pemphigus vegetan
Pemphigus foliaceus - autoantibodies are against Dsg1 alone, leading to superficial, subcorneal blisters.
Pemphigus erythematosu
Paraneoplastic pemphigus - in association with various malignancies, most commonly non-Hodgkin lymphoma

Solution to Question 15:
Antibodies against hemidesmosomes is the false statement as the given image shows a characteristic fish-net appearance on direct immunofluorescence, which is diagnostic of pemphigus vulgaris. The antibodies are against the desmosomal adhesion proteins such as desmogleins 1 and 3.
This pattern is due to intraepidermal intercellular deposition of IgG and C3.
The first-line investigation in pemphigus vulgaris is the Tzanck smear. It allows us to visualize the histology by collecting material from the floor of a fresh blister that is stained with Giemsa or any Romanowsky stain. Tzanck cells are seen on microscopy.

Direct immunofluorescence microscopy (DIF) is the most accurate test.
Antibodies against hemidesmosomes that link basal keratinocytes to the underlying basement membrane are seen in bullous pemphigoid.
Solution to Question 16:
The above image showing linear IgG and C3 deposits on direct immunofluorescence (DIF)
microscopy is characteristic of bullous pemphigoid.
Bullous pemphigoid is characterized by tense itchy bulla in the flexor areas and trunk which do not rupture easily. In bullous pemphigoid, the antibodies are formed against bullous pemphigoid antigens (BPAGs)- BP 180 and BP 230, which are components of hemidesmosomes.
The separation of bullous pemphigoid from pemphigus is based on the identification of subepidermal, nonacantholytic blisters that are Nikolsky negative.
Nikolsky's sign is elicited by applying firm tangential sliding pressure with a finger on lesional or perilesional skin. If the lesion is opened (i.e., skin sloughed off), then the Nikolsky's sign is present/positive.

Solution to Question 17:
The above image showing granular deposits of IgA on direct immunofluorescence is suggestive of dermatitis herpetiformis or Duhring's disease. These deposits localize in the tips of dermal papillae.
Dermatitis herpetiformis presents as grouped vesicles and papules. These lesions are commonly located over the extensor aspects of knees, elbows, buttocks, back, scalp which are associated with intense pruritus.
It is associated with gluten-sensitive enteropathy or celiac disease. It is also associated with HLA DQ2/DQ8/B8. Deposition of IgA antitransglutaminase antibodies in the dermal papillae results in true subepidermal blisters and vesicles.
The characteristic microscopic feature is subepidermal blisters with papillary tip microabscesses containing neutrophils.
The initial treatment of choice for dermatitis herpetiformis is a gluten-free diet.
The image below shows subepidermal vesicles, with papillary neutrophil microabscesses, with neutrophil, eosinophil and lymphocytes infiltrates in the superficial dermis in case of dermatitis herpetiformis.


The image below shows vesicular lesions of dermatitis herpetiformis.

Solution to Question 18:
The given microscopic image shows large, ellipsoid, homogeneous, cytoplasmic inclusion in cells of the stratum granulosum and the stratum corneum classically seen in molluscum contagiosum.
Molluscum contagiosum is a common, self-limited viral disease of the skin caused by a
poxvirus. Poxvirus is brick-shaped and is about 300 nm in size, the largest pathogenic poxvirus in humans
Tzanck smear shows intracytoplasmic molluscum bodies (Henderson–Patterson bodies), the largest known inclusion bodies (30–35 m).
Individual lesions are firm, pruritic, pink to skin-colored umbilicated papules (shown below). A curd-like material can be expressed from the central umbilication


Solution to Question 19:
The image above shows Touton giant cells having a central ring of nuclei while the peripheral cytoplasm is clear due to accumulated lipid. These cells are formed by the fusion of
lipid-containing macrophages. They are not seen in sarcoidosis. These cells are seen in:
Fat necrosi
Xanthoma
Xanthogranuloma
Dermatofibroma
The cardinal histopathologic feature of sarcoidosis is the non-caseating epithelioid granuloma with occasional other microscopic features:
Schaumann bodies - laminated concretions composed of calcium and protein
Asteroid bodies - stellate inclusions enclosed within giant cell
Solution to Question 20:
The most likely diagnosis is tuberculoid leprosy.
On microscopic examination, tuberculoid leprosy has granulomatous lesions closely resembling those found in tuberculosis. Because of the strong host defense, bacilli are almost never found, hence the name paucibacillary leprosy.
Leprosy or Hansen disease is a slowly progressive infection caused by Mycobacterium leprae, mainly affecting the skin and peripheral nerves.
Solution to Question 21:
The image shows many histiocytes containing Leishman–Donovan bodies and surrounding chronic inflammatory cells classically seen in cutaneous leishmaniasis.
Cutaneous leishmaniasis presents with a shallow and slowly expanding ulcer, often with heaped-up borders.
On microscopic examination, the lesion shows granulomatous inflammation, usually with many giant cells and few parasites.
Diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis is characterized by a single skin nodule, which continues spreading until the entire body is covered by nodular lesions. Microscopically, they contain aggregates of foamy macrophages stuffed with leishmania.
Solution to Question 22:
Max Joseph’s space is a histopathological feature of lichen planus. Histological features of lichen planus:
Orthokeratosis, parakeratosis, thickening of the stratum granulosum.
Acanthosis with the formation of colloid bodies (also known as Civatte bodies/Sabouraud bodies)
Liquefactive degeneration of the stratum basale, with separation from the underlying lamina propria, as a result of desmosome loss, creating small spaces (Max Joseph spaces)
Infiltration of T cells in a band-like pattern into the dermis “hugging” the basal layer (interface dermatitis)

Solution to Question 23:
The image shows silvery-white scaly lesions on the extensor aspect of the knees suggestive of psoriasis. Munro microabscesses are seen in psoriasis.
Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory dermatosis that appears to have an autoimmune basis. The lesions are pink to salmon-colored plaque covered by loosely adherent silver-white scales. Auspitz sign and Koebner phenomenon can be demonstrated. Nail changes include pitting, dimpling, separation of the nail plate, onycholysis, thickening, and crumbling.
Microscopy shows thinning of stratum granulosum, supra papillary plates, and neutrophils forming small aggregates within the superficial epidermis (spongiform pustules) and within the stratum corneum (Munro microabscesses).

Some types of microabscesses and their examples are given below:
Predominant cell
Name of microabscess
Disease
Neutrophilic microabscess
Papillary tip microabscessMu nro microabscess (superficial) Spongiform pustules of Kogoj (deep)
Dermatitis herpetiformisPsor iasisPsoriasis
Lymphocytic microabsces
Pautrier's microabscess
Mycosis fungoides
Eosinophillic microabsces
Pemphigus vegetans

Question 11:
A 34-year-old man is admitted with a history of altered sensorium and abnormal behavior. The patient subsequently died and on autopsy, the following findings are seen in the Purkinje cells of the cerebellum. What are these called?

A 35-year-old immunocompromised patient presented with fever, headache, and neurological deficits. MRI showed multiple enhancing lesions and a stereotactic biopsy of the lesion was done. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Solution to Question 1:
Microglia are mesoderm-derived phagocytic cells that serve as the resident monocyte-lineage population of the CNS and accumulate in response to injury.
They respond to injury by:
Activation and proliferating
Developing elongated nuclei (rod cells), as in neurosyphilis
Forming aggregates around small foci of tissue necrosis (microglial nodules)
Congregating around cell bodies of dying neurons (neuronophagia)
Solution to Question 2:
Red neurons are the earliest morphologic markers of neuronal cell death.
Acute neuronal injury refers to a spectrum of changes that accompany acute CNS hypoxia / ischemia or other acute insults and reflect the earliest morphologic markers of neuronal cell death. They are evident by about 12 to 24 hours after an irreversible insult.
Morphologic features consist of:
Shrinkage of the cell body
Pyknosis of the nucleus
Disappearance of the nucleolus
Loss of Nissl substance
Intense eosinophilia of the cytoplasm.
Stages of neuronal injury and their pathological features are given below:
Stages
Time
Features
Early change
