Solution to Question 3:
Astrocytes are more resistant to focal cerebral ischemia than neurons, and die by delayed necrosis.
The cells most susceptible to ischemia are:
Pyramidal cell layer cells of the hippocampus (especially area CA1, also referred to as Sommer sector)
Purkinje cells of the cerebellum
Pyramidal neurons of the cerebral cortex(the watershed zones)
Solution to Question 4:
The image shows the presence of rosenthal fibres. Rosenthal fibres are not seen in Pick's disease.
Rosenthal fibers are thick, elongated, brightly eosinophilic, irregular structures that occur within astrocytic processes. They contain two heatshock proteins (B crystallin and HSP27) as well as ubiquitin.They are typically found in regions of longstanding gliosis and are characteristic of a
type of glial tumor—pilocytic astrocytoma.
Alexander disease is a leukodystrophy associated with mutations in the gene encoding GFAP. In this condition, abundant rosenthal fibers are found in periventricular, perivascular, and subpial locations.
Solution to Question 5:
Hemorrhages in the basal ganglia and thalamus are commonly designated ganglionic hemorrhages. Those that occur in the lobes of the cerebral hemispheres are called lobar hemorrhages.
Solution to Question 6:
Charcot–Bouchard microaneurysms are caused by chronic hypertension. They are most commonly seen within the basal ganglia.
Solution to Question 7:
The given clinical condition is suggestive of hypertensive intraparenchymal hemorrhage. The most common site (50-60%) of hypertensive hemorrhage in the brain is the putamen.
Hypertension is the most common cause of intracerebral hemorrhage.
Solution to Question 8:
In a patient with a known history of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, the most common type of intracranial aneurysm is saccular aneurysm.
Although the majority occur sporadically, genetic factors may be important in their pathogenesis of saccular aneurysms. There is an increased incidence of saccular aneurysm in individuals with certain Mendelian disorders like autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, Ehlers–Danlos syndrome type IV, neurofibromatosis type 1 [NF1], and Marfan syndrome, fibromuscular dysplasia of extracranial arteries, and coarctation of the aorta. Other predisposing factors include cigarette smoking and hypertension.
The most frequent cause of clinically significant subarachnoid hemorrhage is rupture of a saccular
(berry) aneurysm in a cerebral artery.
Solution to Question 9:
Cerebral autosomal dominant arteriopathy with subcortical infarcts and leukoencephalopathy
(CADASIL) is an autosomal-dominant disorder caused by mutations in the NOTCH3 gene.
This leads to the misfolding of the extracellular domain of the NOTCH3 receptor that is preferentially expressed in vascular smooth muscle. It is clinically characterized by recurrent strokes (usually ischemic, less often hemorrhages) and dementia.
Arteries in the CNS and in other tissues such as skin show concentric thickening of the media and adventitia, loss of smooth muscle cells, and the presence of basophilic, periodic acid Schiff
(PAS)-positive deposits. Deposits contain the misfolded NOTCH3 protein. These appear as osmiophilic compact granular material on electron microscopy and are consistently detected in the walls of affected vessels.
Solution to Question 10:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of aseptic meningitis. Enterovirus is the most common cause, accounting for around 90% of the cases.
Solution to Question 11:
The image shows characteristic Negri bodies found in the Purkinje cell of the cerebellum. These are the pathognomonic microscopic finding in rabies. This patient's clinical features of altered sensorium and abnormal behavior are suggestive of rabies.
Negri bodies are cytoplasmic, round to oval, eosinophilic inclusions that can be found in the pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum. The rabies virus can be detected within Negri bodies by ultrastructural and immunohistochemical methods.

Solution to Question 12:
Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) is an encephalitis caused by the JC polyomavirus.
The disease occurs almost exclusively in immunosuppressed individuals, most commonly among patients with acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). The most prominent symptoms are clumsiness, progressive weakness, and visual, speech, and personality changes.
Since the virus preferentially infects oligodendrocytes, demyelination is its principal pathologic effect. It affects the subcortical white matter, particularly that of the parietal and occipital lobes. On microscopic examination, enlarged oligodendrocyte nuclei containing glassy amphophilic viral inclusions are seen.
The image below shows a brain biopsy of a progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy patient, showing oligodendrocytes with nuclear enlargement and glassy chromatin.

Solution to Question 13:
The above image shows lymphocytes, macrophages and eosinophils surrounding the
toxoplasma bradyzoites encased in cysts. Along with the case scenario, the most likely diagnosis is cerebral toxoplasmosis.
Cerebral toxoplasmosis is an opportunistic infection commonly found in the setting of
HIV-associated immunosuppression. Toxoplasmosis of the CNS produces brain abscesses, which are found most often in the cerebral cortex (near the grey-white junction) and deep gray nuclei.
Lesions of acute cerebral toxoplasmosis exhibit central necrosis, petechial haemorrhages surrounded by acute and chronic inflammation, macrophage infiltration, and vascular proliferation. Both free tachyzoites and encysted bradyzoites may be found at the periphery of the necrotic foci. Chronic lesions consist of small cystic spaces containing scattered lipid and hemosiderin-laden macrophages that are surrounded by gliotic brain.
Option A: In cerebral malaria caused by P. falciparum, brain vessels are plugged with parasitized red cells. Around the vessels, ring hemorrhages and small focal inflammatory reactions (called malarial or Dürck granulomata) are seen.
Option C: Herpes simplex encephalitis is necrotizing and often hemorrhagic. Cowdry type A intranuclear viral inclusion bodies may be found in both neurons and glia.
Option D: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) is an encephalitis caused by the JC polyomavirus. The disease occurs almost exclusively in immunosuppressed individuals. The virus preferentially infects oligodendrocytes and hence demyelination is its principal pathologic effect. The enlarged oligodendrocyte nuclei contain glassy amphophilic viral inclusions.
Solution to Question 14:
Brain abscess is the most likely diagnosis in the above patient with progressive focal neurologic deficits and increased intracranial pressure.

Acute bacterial endocarditis, which may give rise to multiple brain abscesses.
Congenital heart diseases with right to left shunt.
Chronic pulmonary disease, as in bronchiectasis.
Systemic disease with immunosuppression. Organisms involved are:
Streptococcus spp. and Staphylococcus spp. (most common aerobic organisms)
Bacteroides fragilis and Peptostreptococcus spp.(most common anaerobic organisms). Foci of organisms in brain abscess:
Direct implantation of organisms
Local extension from adjacent foci (mastoiditis, paranasal sinusitis)
Hematogenous spread (from primary foci of heart, lungs, bones of extremities, dental extraction) CSF analysis in brain abscess:

HIV encephalopathy is seen in subcortical regions of the brain and not in frontal and parietal lobes. It is characterized by defects in short-term memory and executive function. It is also known as subcortical dementia.

Solution to Question 16:
The disease causing isoform of prion protein is PrPSc.
Prions are the proteinaceous infectious particle that lacks nucleic acid, composed entirely of alternatively folded proteins that undergo self-propagation. They bind to the normal, cellular isoform of the prion protein (PrPC) which is rich in -helix, and stimulate conversion of PrPC into the disease-causing isoform PrPSc which contain less -helix and a high amount of  -structure.  structured proteins are resistant to digestion by human cellular enzymes. Transmission of prion disease may be sporadic, familial or iatrogenic.
This group of diseases include:
Creutzfeldt Jakob disease
Gerstmann Sträussler Scheinke syndrome
Fatal Familial Insomnia
Kuru disease
Scrapie in sheep and goats
Bovine spongiform encephalopathy in cows
Most common prion disease in humans is CJD, which is most commonly sporadic. CJD is characterized by a constellation of dementia, myoclonus, and periodic electrical bursts in EEG.
Autoclaving at 134 degree Celsius for 5 hours or treatment with 2 N NaOH for several hours is recommended for sterilization against prions (tip: 1234-5 for prions).
Solution to Question 17:
The patient is most likely suffering from subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE), a delayed late complication of measles.
Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is a rare, progressive clinical syndrome characterized by cognitive decline, spasticity of limbs, seizures and psychosis. It occurs in children or young adults, months or years after an initial, early-age acute infection with measles.
The pathogenesis of SSPE is not well understood but may involve persistent infection with a genetic variant of measles virus within the central nervous system.
Solution to Question 18:
Berry aneurysm occurs due an arterial internal elastic lamina defect.
As an aneurysm develops, it typically forms a neck with a dome and the arterial internal elastic lamina disappears at the base of the neck. The media thins and connective tissue replaces the smooth-muscle cells. The site of rupture is most often the dome. Here the wall thins, and the tear that allows bleeding is usually 0.5 mm long.
Risk of aneurysm rupture is higher if:
Aneurysm is >7 mm in diameter
Aneurysm at the top of the basilar artery
Aneurysm at the origin of the posterior communicating artery

Solution to Question 1:

Solution to Question 2:
The clinical scenario and the images showing amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles are diagnostic of Alzheimer's disease (AD), complicated by cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA). The formation and aggregation of A peptides are responsible for AD.

Amyloid precursor protein (APP) is neurotrophic and neuroprotective. It is present in astrocytes and neuroglia. This protein is cleaved at 3 sites by secretase enzymes (,  , and ), and the products are known as A peptides.
In Alzheimer's disease, A peptides get aggregated in the form of amyloid plaques, which stain positive for Congo red. These get deposited within the neural tissue (A 42) and the cerebral arterioles (A 40 protein, causing CAA), which causes neuronal dysfunction, and is the first sign of AD.
Normally, tau proteins within the neurons stabilize microtubules, however, in AD, these get hyperphosphorylated and lose their function. Hyperphosphorylated tau proteins combine with cytoplasmic fibrils, to form neurofibrillary tangles (NFTs) and get abnormally accumulated around the neuronal nucleus.

Neurofibrillary tangles (NFTs) are found in:
Normal aging
Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis

NFTs are aggregates of hyperphosphorylated tau proteins (microtubule-associated proteins) found in numerous diseases known as tauopathies. NFTs can also be seen in relatively lower numbers in elderly people without dementia.
Solution to Question 6:
Punch drunk syndrome is due to accumulation of tau proteins in the brain.
This condition is also called dementia pugilistica or chronic traumatic encephalopathy. It is a dementing illness that develops following repeated head trauma in boxers and other athletes. Affected brains are typically atrophic, with enlarged ventricles. They show accumulation of tau-- containing□ neurofibrillary tangles in a characteristic pattern involving the superficial frontal and temporal lobe cortex.
Solution to Question 7:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of Parkinson's disease. This condition is not associated with Pick cells and Pick bodies. They are seen in Pick’s disease or frontotemporal dementia.
In Parkinson's disease, there is loss of the substantia nigra neurons projecting to the striatum. This leads to pallor of the substantia nigra as well as a decrease or absence of dopamine in the striatum. This leads to slowing of movements and tremors.
Lewy Bodies are seen within the neurons of affected patients. They are filamentous projections of the protein ■synuclein or ubiquitin. They are present in surviving neurons and can be found in the cortex.
Solution to Question 8:
Mutations in the gene encoding LRRK2 (leucine rich repeat kinase 2) are a common cause of autosomal dominant Parkinson's disease. They are also found in some sporadic cases of the disease.
Solution to Question 9:
The MRI shows bilateral atrophy of caudate nuclei with compensatory dilatation of lateral ventricles, also known as boxcar ventricles. Along with the clinical features, it is suggestive of Huntington's disease (HD). It has an autosomal dominant mode of inheritance.
It is commonly seen in the 4th and 5th decades of life. It is a degenerative disease of the caudate and putamen (striate neurons) caused by trinucleotide (CAG) repeats in the huntingtin gene
on chromosome 4. The severity of the disease depends on the number of repeats. With more repeats, the disease becomes more severe. The disease also manifests at an earlier age, a phenomenon called anticipation.
The caudate nucleus is dramatically atrophied, with accompanying atrophy of the putamen, cortex, and hydrocephalus ex vacuo of the 3rd ventricle. The medium-sized GABAergic neurons are especially affected.
It causes chorea and dementia. Motor problems like chorea typically precede dementia.
Solution to Question 10:
In Huntington's disease, the affected HTT gene is located on chromosome 4.
The coding region has a trinucleotide repeat (CAG/ glutamine). The severity and age of onset of the disease depend on the number of repeats increases. This phenomenon is called anticipation.
Solution to Question 11:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Friedrich's ataxia. It is associated with mutations of genes on chromosome 9q13.
It is an autosomal recessive disease caused by the expansion of a GAA trinucleotide repeat in the gene encoding frataxin. The clinical features are given by the mnemonic FRIEDRICHS:
F - Frequent falls (ataxia), foot deformity (pes cavus or overarched foot)
R - Recessive
I - Iron accumulation in mitochondria
E - Eye movements (nystagmus)
D - Dorsal column (loss of fine touch, vibration, position)
R - Reflexes (deep tendon) lost, with extensor plantar reflex
I - Incoordination
C - Cerebellar involvement
H - Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM)
S - Scoliosis (with kyphosis), staggering gait

It occurs in advanced cases of chronic alcoholism. There is a loss of Purkinje cells

Solution to Question 15:
The clinical scenario showing motor symptoms and rapid progression to death, an autopsy of the brain showing globoid cells is highly suggestive of Krabbe's disease. The globoid cells are macrophages.

Krabbe's disease or globoid cell leukodystrophy is a neurodegenerative disorder with severe myelin destruction due to a deficiency of galactocerebroside  -galactosidase.
The onset of symptoms is between 3 to 6 months of age, dominated by motor signs such as stiffness and weakness. Survival beyond the age of 2 years is uncommon. The brain shows loss of myelin and oligodendrocytes with a similar process affecting the peripheral nerves.
Solution to Question 16:
The given clinical scenario with involvement of the dorsal column and investigations
showing macrocytic anemia is suggestive of subacute combined degeneration (SACD) of the spinal cord. It is due to a deficiency of vitamin B12 which is involved in myelin synthesis.
The most severely affected regions are the posterior columns at the cervical and upper thoracic levels.
The clinical features include:
Peripheral nerve and spinal cord involvement
Paresthesias in the hands or feet
Weakness and unsteadiness of gait
Loss of vibration or joint position sense in the legs
Mental slowing, depression, confusion, delusions, and hallucinations
MRI spine shows diffuse myelopathy and areas of demyelination. Treatment involves a replacement regimen of vitamin B12 intramuscular daily injections of 1000 g for the first week followed by weekly 1000 g injections for 1 month. Monthly injections are given thereafter.
While vitamin E deficiency can also cause SACD, it is rare and is associated with hemolytic anemia.
Solution to Question 17:
Korsakoff syndrome is caused by the deficiency of thiamine.
This syndrome is characterized by pronounced anterograde and retrograde amnesia along with impairment in visuospatial, abstract, and other types of learning. It is usually completely or partially permanent in about half the patients.
Wernicke's encephalopathy refers to the acute form of thiamine deficiency. It is characterized by nystagmus and ophthalmoplegia, mental status changes, and unsteadiness of stance and gait. It is a medical emergency and IV or IM thiamine should be initiated immediately.

Solution to Question 1:
Most common primary malignant brain tumor in children is medulloblastoma.
Solution to Question 2:
The given clinical history and the image showing Rosenthal fibers is diagnostic of pilocytic astrocytoma. It belongs to WHO grade I tumors.
Pilocytic astrocytoma typically occurs in children and young adults and is usually located in the cerebellum. It is usually a slow-growing tumor and if it occurs in the cerebellum, it can be resected. If it extends into the hypothalamic region from the optic tract, it can have a more ominous clinical course because of its location.
It is often cystic, if solid, it may be well circumscribed. It is often biphasic with both loose microcystic and fibrillary areas.
The tumor is composed of bipolar cells with long, thin hair-like processes that are GFAP-positive and form dense fibrillary meshworks. Rosenthal fibers and eosinophilic granular bodies are characteristic findings under microscopy. BRAF mutation is seen in this tumor.
Solution to Question 3:
The clinical history and histological image are suggestive of primary glioblastoma, IDH - wild type.
The given histological image shows foci of necrosis with pseudo-palisading of malignant nuclei and endothelial cell proliferation, which are characteristic of glioblastoma (previously called glioblastoma multiforme).
According to the WHO classification of CNS diseases 2016, glioblastomas are classified as follows:
Glioblastoma, IDH - wild type:
About 90% of the cases
Primary or de novo glioblastoma
Over 55 years of age
Glioblastoma, IDH - mutant type:
About 10% of the cases
Secondary glioblastoma, with a history of prior lower-grade diffuse glioma
Arises in younger patients
Glioblastoma, NOS, where full IDH evaluation cannot be performed.
Solution to Question 4:
The clinical picture is suggestive of oligodendroglioma and the most common genetic alterations in oligodendroglioma are mutations of the isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH1 and IDH2) genes.
IDH1 and IDH2 gene mutations are seen in upto 90% of oligodendroglioma and they are associated with a better prognosis. Deletions of portions of chromosomes 1p and 19q are seen in up to 80% of the cases.
Solution to Question 5:
The histological image shows fried egg appearance of cells and is seen in oligodendroglioma.
Oligodendroglioma is an infiltrating glioma comprised of cells that resemble oligodendrocytes. It commonly occurs in the fourth and fifth decades. The lesion is found mostly in the cerebral hemispheres, with a predilection for white matter.
The tumor is composed of sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm giving a fried egg appearance. Tumor cells infiltrating the cerebral cortex often collect around the neurons (perineuronal satellitosis).
Fried eggs in pathology:
Oligodendroglioma on histopathology
Hairy cell leukemia on bone marrow biopsy
Seminoma / Dysgerminoma on light microscopy
Mycoplasma pneumonia fried egg colonies on Eaton agar

Myxopapillary ependymoma is a slow-growing tumor and do not follow an aggressive clinical course.
Myxopapillary ependymoma belongs to WHO grade 2 tumors histologically as of the 2021 WHO clasiffication of central nervous system tumors. It occurs commonly in the filum terminale of the spinal cord and contains papillary elements in a myxoid (acidic and neutral mucopolysaccharides) background, admixed with ependymoma-like cells microscopically.
Solution to Question 10:
The given clinical features and the family history of colon cancer point to the diagnosis of Turcot syndrome.
Turcot syndrome is a rare hereditary disorder clinically characterized by the occurrence of primary tumors of the colon and the central nervous system.
Two types of tumors are seen in Turcot syndrome. The first is characterized by childhood cerebellar medulloblastoma caused by mutations in the APC gene. The second type is characterized by gliomas, particularly glioblastoma multiforme, arising in both children and adults and is related to mismatch repair gene mutations.
Familial carcinoma syndromes and the common malignancies associated with them:
Gorlin syndrome: Medulloblastoma and multiple early-onset basal cell carcinomas
Lynch syndrome: Gastrointestinal and genito-urinary tumors and rarely gliomas in the brain
Neurofibromatosis: Schwannoma

Medulloblastoma belongs to WHO grade IV tumors.
Medulloblastoma accounts for 20% of brain tumors in children. It occurs predominantly in children and exclusively in the cerebellum. Drop metastasis through CSF dissemination is a common complication. It is an extremely radiosensitive tumor.

The given clinical history is suggestive of limbic encephalitis.
Limbic encephalitis is characterized by subacute dementia. Histologically, it is characterised by perivascular inflammatory cuffs, microglial nodules, neuronal loss, and gliosis evident in the anterior and medial portions of the temporal lobe.
Some of these patients have a circulating ANNA1 antibody (antiHu) that is most commonly associ- ated□ with small cell carcinoma of the lung. Another group of these patients have a circulating antibody that recognizes the NMDA receptor and cross-reacts with hippocampal neurons.

Solution to Question 14:
The given MRI showing homogeneously enhancing extra - axial, dural based tumor and the microscopic findings are highly suggestive of meningioma. The most common cytogenetic abnormality in meningioma is 22q deletion.
Meningioma is predominantly a benign tumors of adults, usually attached to the dura. It arises from the meningothelial cells of the arachnoid. 50% - 60% of the sporadic meningioma harbors
mutations in the NF2 gene (in chromosome 22q12) resulting in the absence of functional merlin protein. In meningioma without NF2 mutations, the most common mutations occur in TNF receptor - associated factor 7 (TRAF7).
Solution to Question 15:
Breast carcinoma is commonly associated with meningeal carcinomatosis.
Meningeal carcinomatosis presents as tumor nodules studding the surface of the brain, spinal cord, and intradural nerve roots.
Solution to Question 16:
Duret hemorrhages are characteristic of transtentorial herniation.
Transtentorial (uncinate, mesial temporal) herniation occurs when the medial aspect of the temporal lobe is compressed against the free margin of the tentorium. Progression of transtentorial herniation is often accompanied by secondary hemorrhagic lesions in the midbrain and pons, termed Duret hemorrhages. These linear or flame - shaped lesions usually occur in the midline and paramedian regions and are believed to be due to the distortion or tearing of penetrating veins and arteries supplying the upper brainstem.
With increasing displacement of the temporal lobe, the third cranial nerve is compromised, resulting in pupillary dilation and impairment of ocular movements on the side of the lesion. The posterior cerebral artery may also be compressed, resulting in ischemic injury to the territory supplied by that vessel, including the primary visual cortex.
When the extent of herniation is large enough, the contralateral cerebral peduncle may be compressed, resulting in hemiparesis ipsilateral to the side of the herniation. The compression in the peduncle in this setting is known as the Kernohan notch.
Solution to Question 17:
Cerebellum is involved in tonsillar herniation.
Tonsillar herniation refers to the displacement of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum. This pattern of herniation is life-threatening because it causes brainstem compression and compromises vital respiratory and cardiac centers in the medulla.
Solution to Question 18:
Primary central nervous system lymphoma is the most common CNS neoplasm in immunosuppressed individuals, including those with AIDS and immunosuppression after transplantation.
The vast majority of primary central nervous system lymphomas are of B-cell origin. Overall, primary central nervous system lymphomas are aggressive and have worst outcome. The Epstein-Barr virus plays an important role in the pathogenesis of HIV-related primary central nervous system lymphoma.
Solution to Question 19:
The given clinical history and biopsy picture is characteristic of schwannoma.
The biopsy specimen in schwannoma shows hypocellular (Antoni B) and hypercellular areas (Antoni A). Antoni A area has the nuclei of tumor cells aligned in palisading rows. The nuclear-free zones that lie between nuclear palisading are known as Verocay bodies.

Solution to Question 20:
Most of the meningiomas are benign tumors and very rarely metastasize to CSF.
The primary intracerebral malignancies that may cause metastases to the subarachnoid space are:
Glioblastoma (GBM)
Anaplastic astrocytoma
Medulloblastoma
Ependymoma
Pineoblastomas
Oligodendroglioma
Leptomeningeal metastases, also known as carcinomatous meningitis, refer to the spread of malignant cells through the CSF space. These cells can originate both in primary CNS tumors (e.g. drop-metastases), as well as from distant tumors that have metastasized (hematogenous spread).
The most common secondary tumors that spread to CSF are breast cancer > lung cancer >
melanoma > GI malignancies.
Contrast MRI is the investigation of choice and shows leptomeningeal enhancement and tumor scattered over the brain in a ‘sugar-coated’ manner.

Solution to Question 1:
The most common cause of peripheral neuropathy is diabetes mellitus.
The most common pattern of diabetic neuropathy is an ascending, distal symmetric, sensorimotor polyneuropathy (glove and stocking type).
The most common type of hereditary neuropathy is Charcot-Marie-Tooth (CMT) disease.
Solution to Question 2:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Charcot–Marie–Tooth (CMT) disease. It is most commonly associated with chromosome 17.
It is the most common type of hereditary neuropathy. The most common variant of this condition is CMT1A. It is caused by a duplication of a region on chromosome 17 that includes the peripheral myelin protein 22 (PMP22) gene.
It usually presents in the first to third decade of life with distal leg weakness, e.g., foot drop with no numbness or tingling. There is reduced sensation to all modalities with reduced muscle stretch reflexes. Atrophy of the muscles below the knee leads to inverted champagne bottle legs.

Solution to Question 3:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of myasthenia gravis. It is most commonly associated with thymic hyperplasia (65% of cases).
Thymoma is seen in around 10% of patients with myasthenia gravis.
Myasthenia gravis is a neuromuscular disorder that is characterized by weakness and the fatigability of skeletal muscles. It is due to the autoantibody-mediated destruction of
the acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at the neuromuscular junction. This consequentially leads to a decreased transmission at the neuromuscular (myoneural) junction.
There is a characteristic pattern of muscle involvement. Lid and extraocular muscles (diplopia and ptosis) are involved early in the disease course. The facial muscles weakness can produce a snarling expression, weakness in chewing, and nasal timbre to the voice. Weakness increases with repeated use of the muscles and improves with rest. The reflexes are normal in this condition.
Solution to Question 4:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS). It is associated with small-cell lung carcinoma.
It is an autoimmune disorder caused by antibodies that block acetylcholine release by inhibiting a presynaptic calcium channel. In contrast to myasthenia gravis, rapid, repetitive
stimulation (muscle activity) results in an increase in muscle response and strength.
Patients typically present with weakness of their extremities. In about half the cases, there is an underlying malignancy; most often, neuroendocrine carcinoma of the lung (Small cell lung carcinoma). The stimulus for autoantibody formation in paraneoplastic cases may be the expression of the same calcium channel in the neoplastic cells.
Patients without cancer often have other autoimmune diseases, such as vitiligo or thyroid disease. Treatment consists of drugs that increase acetylcholine release by depolarizing synaptic membranes (pyridostigmine), plasmapheresis, and immunosuppressive agents, similar to myasthenia gravis.
Solution to Question 5:
Dermatomyositis is the most common inflammatory myopathy in children. Two types of dermatomyositis are known—juvenile and adult.
Juvenile dermatomyosit is
Adult dermatomyositis

Solution to Question 6:
The muscle biopsy shows myofiber atrophy accentuated at the edges of the fascicles (perifascicular atrophy). The biopsy along with the history is suggestive of dermatomyositis. It is associated
with perimysial CD4+ cellular infiltrates.
Dermatomyositis is an immunologic disease in which damage to small blood vessels contributes to muscle injury.


Note: Viral myositis occurs 1-7 days after a viral infection (HIV-1, coxsackievirus). Muscle weakness and tenderness are seen. There are raised CK levels, muscle necrosis without inflammation, and positive urine myoglobin.
Solution to Question 7:
This patient has developed paraneoplastic dermatomyositis. Anti-P155/P140 antibodies (directed against several transcriptional regulators) are associated with paraneoplastic dermatomyositis and juvenile dermatomyositis.
It presents as gradual, symmetric muscle weakness and myalgias, typically affecting the proximal muscles first. Fine movements controlled by distal muscles are affected late in the disease.
Myopathic changes and elevation in serum creatine kinase levels suggest muscle damage.

Solution to Question 8:
Antibodies to cN1A are seen in inclusion-body myositis.
It is the most common inflammatory myopathy in patients >65 years.
Patients present with slowly progressive muscle weakness that tends to be most severe in the quadriceps and the distal upper extremity muscles. Dysphagia from esophageal and pharyngeal muscle involvement can also occur.
Laboratory studies usually show modestly elevated creatine kinase levels. Most myositis-associated autoantibodies are absent but are positive for antibodies to cN1A.
Solution to Question 9:
The given clinical history and the image showing pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles are highly suggestive of Duchenne's muscular dystrophy. It is an X-linked recessive condition.
Duchenne's and Becker's muscular dystrophy are caused by loss-of-function mutations in the dystrophin gene on the X chromosome. It is one of the largest human genes. Dystrophin provides mechanical stability to the myofiber during muscle contraction. Defects in the complex may lead to small membrane tears that permit the influx of calcium, triggering events that result in myofiber degeneration.
Duchenne's muscular dystrophy is associated with deletions or frame-shift mutations that result in the total absence of dystrophin. Immunohistochemical studies for dystrophin show the absence of the normal sarcolemmal staining pattern.
In contrast, the mutations in Becker's muscular dystrophy typically permit the synthesis of a truncated version of dystrophin, which retains some function. Immunohistochemical studies for dystrophin show reduced staining.
Solution to Question 10:
NARP syndrome - Neuropathy Ataxia Retinitis Pigmentosa syndrome is described as a mitochondrial function disorder.
NARP syndrome is due to a point mutation of the mitochondrial ATPase-6 gene. It has 2 phenotypes:
NARP
Maternally inherited Leigh syndrome (MILS)
It is characterized by moderate, diffuse cerebral and cerebellar atrophy and symmetric lesions of the basal ganglia on MRI. The severity of the syndrome corresponds to the mutant mitochondrial DNA load in the tissues.
Solution to Question 11:
The following conditions are mitochondrial disorders:
Myoclonic epilepsy with ragged red fibers
Leber hereditary optic neuropathy
Kearns-Sayre syndrome
The proteins and tRNAs in the mitochondria may be encoded by 2 sets of genes:
Nuclear genome - Mendelian inheritance patterns
Mitochondrial genome (mtDNA) - maternally inherited, as the oocyte contributes all the mitochondria in the embry
Mitochondrial disorders are caused by mutations in the mitochondrial genome.
The most consistent pathologic change in skeletal muscle is abnormal aggregates of mitochondria.
These are seen preferentially in the subsarcolemmal area of affected myofibers, producing a ragged red fibers appearance, as shown below.

Solution to Question 12:
Hypokalemic periodic paralysis is most commonly caused by the mutation of the genes encoding calcium channels (CALCL1A3).
It is an autosomal dominant ion channel myopathy with an onset in adolescence. Males are usually affected more than females. It presents as proximal muscle weakness. Ocular and bulbar muscles are less likely to be involved.
The diagnosis is established by a low serum potassium level during an attack, after excluding secondary causes.

Solution to Question 13:
Mutations affecting the chloride channel CLC1 cause myotonia congenita. The resulting deficiency of CLC1 is responsible for the characteristic myotonia in myotonic dystrophy.

Solution to Question 14:
Glial hamartia are seen in neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF 2). These are microscopic nodular collections of glial cells at abnormal locations, often in the superficial and deep layers of the cerebral cortex.
NF2 is associated with the following:
Bilateral eighth-nerve schwannomas
Multiple meningiomas
Gliomas - typically ependymomas of the spinal cord
Nonneoplastic lesions - schwannosis, meningioangiomatosis, and glial hamartia
Option A: NF 1 is associated with neurofibromas of all types, malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors, gliomas of the optic nerve, other glial tumors, hamartomatous lesions, and pheochromocytomas.
Option C: Tuberous sclerosis is associated with hamartomas within the CNS in the form of cortical tubers and subependymal nodules. Other lesions include subependymal giant-cell astrocytoma, renal angiomyolipomas, retinal glial hamartomas, pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosis, cardiac rhabdomyomas, and cysts in the liver, kidneys, and pancreas.
Option D: Von Hippel–Lindau disease is associated with hemangioblastomas of the CNS and cysts involving the pancreas, liver, and kidneys, and have a propensity to develop renal cell carcinoma and pheochromocytoma.
NOTE: A hamartia is not considered to be a tumor and is distinct from a hamartoma. A hamartoma is a benign neoplasm characterized by tissue misarrangement similar to a hamartia.
Solution to Question 15:
Focal collections of pseudo-Meissner corpuscles or tactile-like bodies (cells mimicking the appearance of Meissner corpuscles) is a feature of diffuse neurofibroma.
Note: Meissner corpuscles consist of a cutaneous nerve ending responsible for transmitting the sensations of fine, discriminative touch and vibration.
Solution to Question 16:
The most common variant of Guillain-Barré syndrome is acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP). The area affected in this condition is the myelin sheath (marked as 2 in the image).

Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is an acute autoimmune disease that causes fulminant polyradiculoneuropathy. It is a T-cell mediated immune response.
GBS is usually associated with a history of upper respiratory infection (URI) or acute gastroenteritis (AGE) 1-3 weeks prior. The causative organisms may be Campylobacter jejuni, cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr virus, and Mycoplasma pneumoniae.
It presents with the following features:
Ascending motor paralysis (lower limbs > upper limbs)
Sensory deficits may or may not be seen
Deep tendon reflexes - absent
Transient bladder dysfunction - severe cases
Autonomic manifestations - loss of vasomotor control, postural hypotension, cardiac dysrhythmias
Histological examination shows inflammation of peripheral nerves, manifested as perivenular and endoneurial infiltration by lymphocytes, macrophages, and a few plasma cells. On electron microscopy, an early effect on myelin sheaths is seen. There is segmental demyelination induced by the actions of activated macrophages.
There are several types of Guillain–Barre syndrome:
Demyelinating
Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP) - most common
Axonal
Acute motor axonal neuropathy (AMAN)
Acute motor-sensory axonal neuropathy (AMSAN)
Regional GBS syndromes: Miller–Fisher syndrome (MFS)
